text: <Gene>A specific human lysophospholipase: cDNA cloning, tissue distribution and kinetic characterization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Lysophospholipases are critical enzymes that act on biological membranes to regulate the multifunctional lysophospholipids; increased levels of lysophospholipids are associated with a host of diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Herein we report the cDNA cloning of a human brain 25 kDa lysophospholipid-specific lysophospholipase (hLysoPLA).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The enzyme (at both mRNA and protein levels) is widely distributed in tissues, but with quite different abundances.</Gene>
<Gene>The hLysoPLA hydrolyzes lysophosphatidylcholine in both monomeric and micellar forms, and exhibits apparent cooperativity and surface dilution kinetics, but not interfacial activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Detailed kinetic analysis indicates that the hLysoPLA binds first to the micellar surface and then to the substrate presented on the surface.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The kinetic parameters associated with this surface dilution kinetic model are reported, and it is concluded that hLysoPLA has a single substrate binding site and a surface recognition site.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The apparent cooperativity observed is likely due to the change of substrate presentation.</Gene>
<Gene>In contrast to many non-specific lipolytic enzymes that exhibit lysophospholipase activity, hLysoPLA hydrolyzes only lysophospholipids and has no other significant enzymatic activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of special interest, hLysoPLA does not act on plasmenylcholine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Of the several inhibitors tested, only methyl arachidonyl fluorophosphonate (MAFP) potently and irreversibly inhibits the enzymatic activity.</Gene>
<Gene>The inhibition by MAFP is consistent with the catalytic mechanism proposed for the enzyme - a serine hydrolase with a catalytic triad composed of Ser-119, Asp-174 and His-208.</Gene>
<Gene>Functional domains of the SYT and SYT-SSX synovial sarcoma translocation proteins and co-localization with the SNF protein BRM in the nucleus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The t(X;18)(p11.2;q11.2) chromosomal translocation commonly found in synovial sarcomas fuses the SYT gene on chromosome 18 to either of two similar genes, SSX1 or SSX2, on the X chromosome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The SYT protein appears to act as a transcriptional co-activator and the SSX proteins as co-repressors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we have investigated the functional domains of the proteins.</Gene>

<Gene>The SYT protein has a novel conserved 54 amino acid domain at the N-terminus of the protein (the SNH domain) which is found in proteins from a wide variety of species, and a C-terminal domain, rich in glutamine, proline, glycine and tyrosine (the QPGY domain), which contains the transcriptional activator sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of the SNH domain results in a more active transcriptional activator, suggesting that this domain acts as an inhibitor of the activation domain.</Gene>
<Gene>The C-terminal SSX domain present in SYT-SSX translocation protein contributes a transcriptional repressor domain to the protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, the fusion protein has transcriptional activating and repressing domains.</Gene>
<Gene>We demonstrate that the human homologue of the SNF2/Brahama protein BRM co-localizes with SYT and SYT-SSX in nuclear speckles, and also interacts with SYT and SYT-SSX proteins in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This interaction may provide an explanation of how the SYT protein activates gene transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification and expression of delta-isoforms of the multifunctional Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase in failing and nonfailing human myocardium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Despite its importance for the regulation of heart function, little is known about the isoform expression of the multifunctional Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase (CaMKII) in human myocardium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we investigated the spectrum of CaMKII isoforms delta2, delta3, delta4, delta8, and delta9 in human striated muscle tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Isoform delta3 is characteristically expressed in cardiac muscle.</Gene>
<Gene>In skeletal muscle, specific expression of a new isoform termed delta11 is demonstrated.</Gene>
<Gene>Complete sequencing of human delta2 cDNA, representing all common features of the investigated CaMKII subclass, revealed its high homology to the corresponding rat cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Comparative semiquantitative reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction analyses from left ventricular tissues of normal hearts and from patients suffering from dilated cardiomyopathy showed a significant increase in transcript levels of isoform delta3</Gene>
<Gene>relative to the expression of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase in diseased hearts (101.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>6+/-11.0% versus 64.9+/-9.9% in the nonfailing group; P < 0.05, n=6).</Gene>
<Gene>Transcript levels of the other investigated cardiac CaMKII isoforms remained unchanged.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>At the protein level, by using a subclass-specific antibody, we observed a similar increase of a delta-CaMKII-specific signal (7.2+/-1.0 versus 3.8+/-0.7 optical density units in the nonfailing group; P < 0.05, n=4 through 6).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The diseased state of the failing hearts was confirmed by a significant increase in transcript levels for atrial natriuretic peptide (292.</Gene>
<Gene>9+/-76.4% versus 40.1+/-3.2% in the nonfailing group; P < 0.05, n=3 through 6).</Gene>
<Gene>Our data characterize for the first time the delta-CaMKII isoform expression pattern in human hearts and demonstrate changes in this expression pattern in heart failure.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and sequencing of the complete cDNA encoding the human insulin receptor related receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The insulin receptor related receptor (IRR) is a heterotetrameric transmembrane receptor with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The IRR shares large homology with the insulin and the insulin-like growth factor-1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(IGF-I) receptor with regard to amino acid sequence and protein structure.</Gene>

<Gene>So far, only a partial human sequence containing the complete 3' end has been reported, although the full-length human IRR cDNA had been used for transfection studies and functional analysis of the receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a full-length human IRR cDNA and report on the 5' translated and untranslated region of the human IRR gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The full length IRR sequence contains 4150 bases and shares a high degree of homology with the guinea pig IRR cDNA sequence and rat IRR sequences that had been reported earlier on by others.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sequencing of the IRR cDNA revealed that the human IRR cDNA contains 341 bases corresponding to the IRR 5' end in addition to the bases that had been reported on before.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Also, this sequence contains the start codon of translation.</Gene>
<Gene>The full length cDNA for the human IRR can now be used for functional expression studies and to elucidate the nature of the ligand for this receptor type.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation and chromosomal mapping of a novel human gene showing homology to Na+/PO4 cotransporter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We isolated a cDNA clone which shows a significant similarity with the renal Na+/phosphate cotransporter (NPT) from a human intestine mucosa cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA is 2626 bases long, with one open reading frame encoding a protein of 497 amino acids.</Gene>
<Gene>The deduced amino acids sequence shows an overall homology of 48% with the human renal NPT1 protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This gene is expressed in intestine, colon, liver, and pancreas.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus, this gene may code for intestinal type NPT or closely related proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The chromosomal location of the gene was determined on the chromosome 6p21.3-p22 region by polymerase chain reaction-based analysis with both a human/rodent mono-chromosomal hybrid cell panel and a radiation hybrid mapping panel.</Gene>
<Gene>Cutting edge: immature dendritic cells generated from monocytes in the presence of TGF-beta 1 express functional C-C chemokine receptor 6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although CD34+ progenitor-derived immature dendritic cells (DCs) express CCR6, several recent studies reported that monocyte-derived immature DCs do not do so.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed that DCs generated from monocytes in the presence of GM-CSF, IL-4, and TGF-beta 1 consistently responded to liver and activation-regulated chemokine (LARC, also known as macrophage inflammatory protein-3 alpha).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These immature DCs expressed one class of high-affinity binding sites for LARC, and expressed both CCR6 mRNA and protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, LARC-CCR6 interaction presumably also contributes to the regulation of trafficking of monocyte-derived DCs, and utilization of TGF-beta can potentially provide a ready source of CCR6+ monocyte-derived DCs for therapeutic purposes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification and characterization of PKNbeta, a novel isoform of protein kinase PKN: expression and arachidonic acid dependency are different from those of PKNalpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA clone encoding a novel isoform of protein kinase PKN, termed PKNbeta, was isolated from a HeLa cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PKNbeta had high sequence homology with PKNalpha, originally isolated PKN, especially in the repeats of charged amino acid-rich region with leucine-zipper like sequences (CZ region/HR1), in the carboxyl-terminal catalytic domain, and in approximately 130 amino acid stretch (D region/HR2), located between CZ region/HR1 and the catalytic domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the amino acid sequence of PKNbeta differed from that of PKNalpha in the region immediately amino-terminal to the catalytic domain, which contained two distinct proline-rich sequences consistent with the class II consensus sequence, PXXPXR, for binding to SH3 domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Distribution of PKNbeta differed from that of PKNalpha in the following two respects: (1) Northern blotting indicated that PKNbeta mRNA could not be detected in human adult tissues, but was expressed abundantly in human cancer cell lines; (2) immunochemical analysis indicated that PKNbeta localized in nucleus and perinuclear Golgi apparatus, and was almost absent in cytoplasmic region in NIH3T3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recombinant PKNbeta expressed in COS7 cells displayed autophosphorylation and peptide kinase activity, but was found to be significantly less responsive to arachidonic acid than PKNalpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The identification of this novel isoform underscores the diversity of PKN signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Coats' disease of the retina (unilateral retinal telangiectasis) caused by somatic mutation in the NDP gene: a role for norrin in retinal angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Coats' disease is characterized by abnormal retinal vascular development (so-called 'retinal telangiectasis') which results in massive intraretinal and subretinal lipid accumulation (exudative retinal detachment).</Gene>
<Gene>The classical form of Coats' disease is almost invariably isolated, unilateral and seen in males.</Gene>
<Gene>A female with a unilateral variant of Coats' disease gave birth to a son affected by Norrie disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Both carried a missense mutation within the NDP gene on chromosome Xp11.2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Subsequently analysis of the retinas of nine enucleated eyes from males with Coats' disease demonstrated in one a somatic mutation in the NDP gene which was not present within non-retinal tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We suggest that Coats' telangiectasis is secondary to somatic mutation in the NDP gene which results in a deficiency of norrin (the protein product of the NDP gene) within the developing retina.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This supports recent observations that the protein is critical for normal retinal vasculogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>A common polymorphic allele of the human luteinizing hormone beta-subunit gene: additional mutations and differential function of the promoter sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A common genetic variant (V) of the human luteinizing hormone (LH) beta-subunit gene was recently discovered.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The V-LH molecules have higher bioactivity in vitro, but shorter half-life in circulation, which apparently is related to the alterations of LH function observed in individuals homo- and heterozygous for the V-LHbeta allele.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have now studied whether additional mutations in the V-LHbeta promoter sequence could contribute to the altered physiology of the LH variant molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The 661 bp 5'-flanking region of the V-LHbeta gene, retrieved from human genomic DNA by PCR, contained eight single-nucleotide changes, as compared with the wild-type (wt) LHbeta promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The finding was consistent in DNA samples of different ethnic groups.</Gene>

<Gene>Reporter constructs with various lengths of the wt- and V-LH promoter sequences, driving the firefly luciferase reporter gene, were transfected into an immortalized mouse pituitary cell line, LbetaT(2), known to express the endogenous LHbeta gene, and into a non-endocrine human embryonic kidney cell line, HEK 293.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Basal expression levels of the V-LHbeta promoter constructs were on average 36% higher in LbetaT(2)cells ( P < 0.001; n = 29), and 40% higher in HEK 293 cells ( P < 0.001; n = 16), as compared with the respective wt sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Numerous qualitative and quantitative differences were found between the two cell lines in responses of the two promoter sequences to stimulation with 12- O -tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate, forskolin, 8-bromo-cAMP, progesterone and gonado- tropin-releasing hormone.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, the V-LHbeta promoter has higher basal activity, and differs in response to hormonal stimulation, as compared with the wt-LHbeta promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The altered promoter function of the V-LHbeta gene provides evidence for differences in regulation of the wt- and V-LHbeta genes, which may contribute to the differences observed in pituitary-gonadal function between carriers of the two LHbeta alleles.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The findings also suggest a novel evolutionary mechanism whereby polymorphic changes resulting in altered bioactivity of a gene product may be compensated for by additional mutations in the cognate promoter sequence, changing transcription of the same gene.</Gene>
<Gene>The gene encoding hydroxypyruvate reductase (GRHPR) is mutated in patients with primary hyperoxaluria type II.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Primary hyperoxaluria type II (PH2) is a rare monogenic disorder that is characterized by a lack of the enzyme that catalyzes the reduction of hydroxypyruvate to D-glycerate, the reduction of glyoxylate to glycolate and the oxidation of D-glycerate to hydroxypyruvate.</Gene>
<Gene>The disease is characterized by an elevated urinary excretion of oxalate and L-glycerate.</Gene>
<Gene>The increased oxalate excretion can cause nephrolithiasis and nephrocalci-nosis and can, in some cases, result in renal failure and systemic oxalate deposition.</Gene>
<Gene>We identified a glyoxylate reductase/hydroxypyruvate reductase (GRHPR) cDNA clone from a human liver expressed sequence tag (EST) library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nucleotide sequence analysis identified a 1198 nucleotide clone that encoded a 984 nucleotide open reading frame.</Gene>
<Gene>The open reading frame encodes a predicted 328 amino acid protein with a mass of 35 563 Da.</Gene>

<Gene>Transient transfection of the cDNA clone into COS cells verified that it encoded an enzyme with hydroxy-pyruvate reductase, glyoxylate reductase and D-glycerate dehydrogenase enzymatic activities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Database analysis of human ESTs reveals widespread tissue expression, indicating that the enzyme may have a previously unrecognized role in metabolism.</Gene>
<Gene>The genomic structure of the human GRHPR gene was determined and contains nine exons and eight introns and spans approximately 9 kb pericentromeric on chromosome 9.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Four PH2 patients representing two pairs of siblings from two unrelated families were analyzed for mutations in GRHPR by single strand conformation polymorphism analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All four patients were homozygous for a single nucleotide deletion at codon 35 in exon 2, resulting in a premature stop codon at codon 45.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNA that we have identified represents the first characterization of an animal GRHPR sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The data we present will facilitate future genetic testing to confirm the clinical diagnosis of PH2.</Gene>
<Gene>These data will also facilitate heterozygote testing and prenatal testing in families affected with PH2 to aid in genetic counseling.</Gene>

<Gene>Ectodysplasin is a collagenous trimeric type II membrane protein with a tumor necrosis factor-like domain and co-localizes with cytoskeletal structures at lateral and apical surfaces of cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Anhidrotic ectodermal dysplasia (EDA) is a human genetic disorder of impaired ectodermal appendage development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The EDA gene encodes isoforms of a novel transmembrane protein, ectodysplasin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The sequence of the longest isoform includes an interrupted collagenous domain of 19 Gly-X-Y repeats and a motif conserved in the tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-related ligand family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In order to understand better the function of the ectodysplasin protein molecule and its domains, we have studied the processing and localization of wild-type and mutated isoforms in transfected human fetal kidney 293 and monkey kidney COS-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Similar to other members of collagenous membrane proteins and members of TNF-related ligands, ectodysplasin is a type II membrane protein and it forms trimers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The membrane localization of ectodysplasin is asymmetrical: it is found on the apical and lateral surfaces of the cells where it co-localizes with cytoskeletal structures.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The TNF-like motif and cysteines found near the C-terminus are necessary for correct transport to the cell membrane, but the intracellular and collagenous domains are not required for the localization pattern.</Gene>

<Gene>Our results suggest that ectodysplasin is a new member in the TNF-related ligand family involved in the early epithelial-mesenchymal interaction that regulates ectodermal appendage formation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bis, a Bcl-2-binding protein that synergizes with Bcl-2 in preventing cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bcl-2 is the best characterized inhibitor of apoptosis, although the molecular basis of this action is not fully understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using a protein interaction cloning procedure, we identified a human gene designated as bis (mapped to chromosome 10q25) that encoded a novel Bcl-2-interacting protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bis protein showed no significant homology with Bcl-2 family proteins and had no prominent functional motif.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Co-immunoprecipitation analysis confirmed that Bis interacted with Bcl-2 in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNA transfection experiments indicated that Bis itself exerted only weak anti-apoptotic activity, but was synergistic with Bcl-2 in preventing Bax-induced and Fas-mediated apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that Bis is a novel modulator of cellular anti-apoptotic activity that functions through its interaction with Bcl-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BCAR1, a human homologue of the adapter protein p130Cas, and antiestrogen resistance in breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Treatment of breast cancer with the antiestrogen tamoxifen is effective in approximately one half of the patients with estrogen receptor-positive disease, but tumors recur frequently because of the development of metastases that are resistant to tamoxifen.</Gene>

<Gene>We have previously shown that mutagenesis of human estrogen-dependent ZR-75-1 breast cancer cells by insertion of a defective retrovirus genome caused the cells to become antiestrogen resistant.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we isolated and characterized the crucial gene at the breast cancer antiestrogen resistance 1 (BCAR1) locus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS/RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>Transfer of the BCAR1 locus from retrovirus-mutated, antiestrogen-resistant cells to estrogen-dependent ZR-75-1 cells by cell fusion conferred an antiestrogen-resistant phenotype on the recipient cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The complete coding sequence of BCAR1 was isolated by use of exon-trapping and complementary DNA (cDNA) library screening.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis of human BCAR1 cDNA predicted a protein of 870 amino acids that was strongly homologous to rat p130Cas-adapter protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genomic analysis revealed that BCAR1 consists of seven exons and is located at chromosome 16q23.1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BCAR1 transcripts were detected in multiple human tissues and were similar in size to transcripts produced by retrovirus-mutated ZR-75-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transfection of BCAR1 cDNA into ZR-75-1 cells again resulted in sustained cell proliferation in the presence of antiestrogens, confirming that BCAR1 was the responsible gene in the locus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Overexpression of the BCAR1 gene confers antiestrogen resistance on human ZR-75-1 breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of BCAR1 in retrovirus-mutated cells appears to result from activation of the gene's promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The isolation and characterization of this gene open new avenues to elucidating mechanisms by which the growth of human breast cancer becomes independent of estrogen.</Gene>
<Gene>Langerin, a novel C-type lectin specific to Langerhans cells, is an endocytic receptor that induces the formation of Birbeck granules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have identified a type II Ca2+-dependent lectin displaying mannose-binding specificity, exclusively expressed by Langerhans cells (LC), and named Langerin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LC are uniquely characterized by Birbeck granules (BG), which are organelles consisting of superimposed and zippered membranes.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we have shown that Langerin is constitutively associated with BG and that antibody to Langerin is internalized into these structures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Remarkably, transfection of Langerin cDNA into fibroblasts created a compact network of membrane structures with typical features of BG.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Langerin is thus a potent inducer of membrane superimposition and zippering leading to BG formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that induction of BG is a consequence of the antigen-capture function of Langerin, allowing routing into these organelles and providing access to a nonclassical antigen-processing pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterisation of the Sry-related transcription factor gene Sox8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOX proteins form a large family of transcription factors related by a DNA-binding domain known as the HMG box.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Some 30 Sox genes have been identified in mammals and orthologues have been found in a wide range of other metazoans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sox genes are highly conserved and are known to play important roles in embryonic development, including roles in gonadal, central nervous system, neural crest and skeletal development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Several SOX genes have been implicated in human congenital diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report here the isolation of Sox8 and its characterisation in mice and humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This gene has a remarkably similar primary structure and genomic organisation to the campomelic dysplasia gene SOX9 and the Waardenburg-Shah syndrome gene SOX10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOX8 protein is able to bind to canonical SOX target DNA sequences and activate transcription in vitro through two separate trans -activation regions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further, Sox8 is expressed in the central nervous system, limbs, kidneys, gonads and craniofacial structures during mouse embryo development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sox8 maps to the t complex on mouse chromosome 17 and to human chromosome 16p13.3, a region associated with the microphthalmia-cataract syndrome CATM and the alpha-thalassemia/mental retardation syndrome ATR-16.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Syntaphilin: a syntaxin-1 clamp that controls SNARE assembly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Syntaxin-1 is a key component of the synaptic vesicle docking/fusion machinery that forms the SNARE complex with VAMP/synaptobrevin and SNAP-25.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identifying proteins that modulate SNARE complex formation is critical for understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying neurotransmitter release and its modulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have cloned and characterized a protein called syntaphilin that is selectively expressed in brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Syntaphilin competes with SNAP-25 for binding to syntaxin-1 and inhibits SNARE complex formation by absorbing free syntaxin-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transient overexpression of syntaphilin in cultured hippocampal neurons significantly reduces neurotransmitter release.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, introduction of syntaphilin into presynaptic superior cervical ganglion neurons in culture inhibits synaptic transmission.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that syntaphilin may function as a molecular clamp that controls free syntaxin-1 availability for the assembly of the SNARE complex, and thereby regulates synaptic vesicle exocytosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human follicle stimulating hormone receptor variants lacking transmembrane domains display altered post-translational conformations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Variant splicing of gonadotropin receptor mRNA commonly occurs, however expression of receptor protein variants and their trafficking has yet to be studied in detail.</Gene>

<Gene>To determine receptor variant trafficking and intracellular processing in mammalian cells, the intracellular fate of intentionally truncated variants of human follicle stimulating hormone receptor (hFSH-R) expressed in CHO cells was examined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) were made against the hFSH-R's extracellular domain (ECD) expressed in insect cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Four mAbs 106.156, 106.290, 106.318, and 106.263 were chosen as probes.</Gene>

<Gene>Epitope mapping using synthetic peptides, and truncated hFSH-R variants revealed that mAb 106.156 bound to ECD residues 183-220, while mAbs 106.318, 106.290, 106.263 bound ECD residues 300-331.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunofluorescence microscopy showed that mAbs 106.318 and 106.156 stained the surface of fixed, intact CHO cells expressing wild type hFSH-R. However, following cell permeabilization all four antibodies stained hFSH-R in Golgi and endoplasmic reticulum.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Permeabilized cells expressing truncated variants ECD213 and ECD254 showed staining accumulated in the endoplasmic reticulum/nuclear envelope continuum.</Gene>
<Gene>ECD335/</Gene>
<Gene>His was found to accumulate in extended endoplasmic reticulum (ER).</Gene>
<Gene>The ER location of ECD335/</Gene>
<Gene>His was confirmed by double labeling experiments with concanavalin A and ECD mAb.</Gene>
<Gene>Glycosidase digestion followed by Western blot analysis show ECD213 and ECD335/His to be glycosylated, but not ECD254.</Gene>

<Gene>Both glycosylated truncated hFSH-R variants were sensitive to peptide-N-glycanase F and endoglycosidase H but insensitive to neuraminidase indicating that these variants possess high mannose type oligosaccharides.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus truncated hFSH-R variants do not reach the medial or trans Golgi where high mannose oligosaccharides are trimmed and sialic acid is added.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that the conformation the ECD of the wild type receptor is different from the ECD alone expressed in the endoplasmic reticulum.</Gene>

<Gene>This information suggests that the ECD serves two distinct roles; the first is to bind FSH and the other is likely to contact the endodomain of the receptor, which presumably leads to activation of the endodomain for signal transduction.</Gene>

<Gene>The pro-alpha3(V) collagen chain. Complete primary structure, expression domains in adult and developing tissues, and comparison to the structures and expression domains of the other types V and XI procollagen chains.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The low abundance fibrillar collagen type V is widely distributed in tissues as an alpha1(V)(2)alpha2(V) heterotrimer that helps regulate the diameters of fibrils of the abundant collagen type I. Mutations in the alpha1(V) and alpha2(V) chain genes have been identified in some cases of classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), in which aberrant collagen fibrils are associated with connective tissue fragility, particularly in skin and joints.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Type V collagen also exists as an alpha1(V)alpha2(V)alpha3(V) heterotrimer that has remained poorly characterized chiefly due to inability to obtain the complete primary structure or nucleic acid probes for the alpha3(V) chain or its biosynthetic precursor, pro-alpha3(V).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we provide human and mouse full-length pro-alpha3(V) sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pro-alpha3(V) is shown to be closely related to the alpha1(V) precursor, pro-alpha1(V), but with marked differences in N-propeptide sequences, and collagenous domain features that provide insights into the low melting temperature of alpha1(V)alpha2(V)alpha3(V) heterotrimers, lack of heparin binding by alpha3(V) chains and the possibility that alpha1(V)alpha2(V)alpha3(V) heterotrimers are incorporated into heterotypic fibrils.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In situ hybridization of mouse embryos detects alpha3(V) expression primarily in the epimysial sheaths of developing muscles and within nascent ligaments adjacent to forming bones and in joints.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This distribution, and the association of alpha1(V), alpha2(V), and alpha3(V) chains in heterotrimers, suggests the human alpha3(V) gene COL5A3 as a candidate locus for at least some cases of classical EDS in which the alpha1(V) and alpha2(V) genes have been excluded, and for at least some cases of the hypermobility type of EDS, a condition marked by gross joint laxity and chronic musculoskeletal pain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>COL5A3 is mapped to 19p13.2 near a polymorphic marker that should be useful in analyzing linkage with EDS and other disease phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mdm2 is a RING finger-dependent ubiquitin protein ligase for itself and p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mdm2 has been shown to regulate p53 stability by targeting the p53 protein for proteasomal degradation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We now report that Mdm2 is a ubiquitin protein ligase (E3) for p53 and that its activity is dependent on its RING finger.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we show that Mdm2 mediates its own ubiquitination in a RING finger-dependent manner, which requires no eukaryotic proteins other than ubiquitin-activating enzyme (E1) and an ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is apparent, therefore, that Mdm2 manifests an intrinsic capacity to mediate ubiquitination.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutation of putative zinc coordination residues abrogated this activity, as did chelation of divalent cations.</Gene>
<Gene>After cation chelation, the full activity could be restored by addition of zinc.</Gene>

<Gene>We further demonstrate that the degradation of p53 and Mdm2 in cells requires additional potential zinc-coordinating residues beyond those required for the intrinsic activity of Mdm2 in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Replacement of the Mdm2 RING with that of another protein (Praja1) reconstituted ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of Mdm2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, this RING was ineffective in ubiquitination and proteasomal targeting of p53, suggesting that there may be specificity at the level of the RING in the recognition of heterologous substrates.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of endoglycan, a member of the CD34/podocalyxin family of sialomucins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD34 and podocalyxin are structurally related sialomucins, which are expressed in multiple tissues including vascular endothelium and hematopoietic progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These glycoproteins have been proposed to be involved in processes as diverse as glomerular filtration, inhibition of stem cell differentiation, and leukocyte-endothelial adhesion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using homologies present in the cytoplasmic tails of these proteins, we have identified a novel member of this family, which we designate endoglycan.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This protein shares a similar overall domain structure with the other family members including a sialomucin domain, but also possesses an extremely acidic amino-terminal region.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, endoglycan contains several potential glycosaminoglycan attachment sites and is modified with chondroitin sulfate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Endoglycan mRNA and protein were detected in both endothelial cells and CD34(+) bone marrow cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, CD34, podocalyxin, and endoglycan comprise a family of sialomucins sharing both structural similarity and sequence homology, which are expressed by both endothelium and multipotent hematopoietic progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While the members of this family may perform overlapping functions at these sites, the unique structural features of endoglycan suggest distinct functions for this molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a human follicular dendritic cell molecule that stimulates germinal center B cell growth.</Gene>
<Gene>The initial interaction between B cells and follicular dendritic cells (FDCs) appears to be essential for germinal center (GC) formation.</Gene>

<Gene>To identify molecules regulating this interaction, we generated FDC-staining monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and screened them for their ability to block FDC-mediated costimulation of growth and differentiation of CD40-stimulated B cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Using one of the inhibitory mAbs, 8D6, we expression cloned the cDNA encoding the 8D6 antigen (Ag) from a human FDC line, HK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 8D6 Ag is a novel protein of 282 amino acids that is expressed abundantly on FDCs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Monolayers of COS cells transiently transfected with the 8D6 Ag cDNA stimulate B cell growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mAb 8D6 blocks the costimulatory function completely.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The inhibitory activity of the mAb 8D6 was demonstrated to be due to an inhibition of cell cycle progression of CD40 ligand-stimulated GC B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the mAb 8D6 inhibits the growth of a lymphoma of GC origin, L3055, which depends on FDCs or HK cells for its growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that the primary function of FDCs in the GC is to stimulate B cell growth.</Gene>
<Gene>An FDC signal molecule, 8D6 Ag, may be an important molecule to mediate this function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Neutrophil polarity and locomotion are associated with surface redistribution of leukosialin (CD43), an antiadhesive membrane molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study analyzed the behavior of an antiadhesive membrane molecule, CD43, in neutrophil polarization and locomotion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CD43 cross-linking by antibodies induced neutrophil locomotion, with CD43 molecules clustered at the uropod of polarized neutrophils.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, CD11b/CD18 cross-linking by antibodies did not affect either cell polarization or locomotion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Stimulation of suspended or adherent neutrophils with chemotactic peptide results in cell polarization and locomotion and a concomitant redistribution of CD43 to the uropod.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This process is entirely reversible.</Gene>
<Gene>The study also investigated which actin-binding protein could be involved in CD43 lateral redistribution.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>alpha-Actinin and moesin are preferentially adsorbed on Sepharose beads bearing a recombinant CD43 intracellular domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis by immunofluorescence confocal microscopy shows a codistribution of moesin during CD43 lateral redistribution.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By contrast, alpha-actinin is located at the leading edge, an area devoid of CD43.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results shed new light on the role of CD43 membrane redistribution, which appears to be directly related to neutrophil polarity and locomotion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>(Blood.</Gene>
<Gene>A G protein-coupled receptor for UDP-glucose.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Uridine 5'-diphosphoglucose (UDP-glucose) has a well established biochemical role as a glycosyl donor in the enzymatic biosynthesis of carbohydrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is less well known that UDP-glucose may possess pharmacological activity, suggesting that a receptor for this molecule may exist.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we show that UDP-glucose, and some closely related molecules, potently activate the orphan G protein-coupled receptor KIAA0001 heterologously expressed in yeast or mammalian cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nucleotides known to activate P2Y receptors were inactive, indicating the distinctly novel pharmacology of this receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The receptor is expressed in a wide variety of human tissues, including many regions of the brain.</Gene>
<Gene>These data suggest that some sugar-nucleotides may serve important physiological roles as extracellular signaling molecules in addition to their familiar role in intermediary metabolism.</Gene>
<Gene>Spinocerebellar ataxia type 6 mutation alters P-type calcium channel function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Abnormal CAG repeat expansion in the alpha1A voltage-dependent calcium channel gene is associated with spinocerebellar ataxia type 6, an autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia with a predominant loss of the Purkinje cell.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction analysis of mRNA from mouse Purkinje cells revealed a predominant expression of the alpha1A channel lacking an asparagine-proline (NP) stretch in the domain IV (alpha1A(-NP)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human alpha1A channels carrying various polyglutamine length with or without NP were expressed in HEK293 cells, and channel properties were compared using a whole-cell voltage clamp technique. alpha1A(-NP), corresponding to P-type channel, with 24 and 28 polyglutamines found in patients showed the voltage dependence of inactivation shifting negatively by 6 and 11 mV, respectively, from the 13 polyglutamine control.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Contrarily, the alpha1A channel with NP (alpha1A(+NP)), corresponding to Q-type channel, with 28 polyglutamines exhibited a positive shift of 5 mV. These results suggest that altered function of alpha1A(-NP) may contribute to degeneration of Purkinje cells, which express predominantly alpha1A(-NP), due to the reduced Ca(2+) influx resulting from the negative shift of voltage-dependent inactivation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the other hand, other types of neurons, expressing both alpha1A(-NP) and alpha1A(+NP), may survive because the positive shift of voltage-dependent inactivation of alpha1A(+NP) compensates Ca(2+) influx.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Structure, mapping and expression of the human gene encoding the homeodomain protein, SIX2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vertebrate genes with sequence similarity to the Drosophila homeobox gene, sine oculis (so), constitute the SIX family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There is notable expression of members of this family in anterior neural structures, and several SIX genes have been shown to play roles in vertebrate and insect development, or have been implicated in maintenance of the differentiated state of tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in three of these genes in man (SIX5, SIX6 and SIX3) are associated with severe phenotypes, and therefore, the cloning of other human genes from this family is of interest.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have cloned and characterised the gene that encodes human SIX2, elucidated its gene structure and conducted expression studies in a range of tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>SIX2 is widely expressed in the late first-trimester fetus, but has a limited range of expression sites in the adult.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression pattern of SIX2 and its localisation to chromosome 2p15-p16 will be of use in assessing its candidacy in human developmental disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Enhanced growth of MCF-7 breast cancer cells overexpressing parathyroid hormone-related peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PTH-related peptide (PTHrP) is a secreted protein produced by breast cancer cells both in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because of its structural similarity to PTH at the amino terminus, the two proteins interact with a common cell surface receptor, the PTH/PTHrP receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When overproduced by tumor cells, PTHrP enters the circulation, giving rise to the common paraneoplastic syndrome of humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although initially discovered in malignancies, PTHrP is now known to be produced by most cells and tissues in the body.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It acts as an autocrine and paracrine mediator of cell proliferation and differentiation, effects which are mediated via the PTH/PTHrP receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent evidence also has shown that, directly after translation, PTHrP is able to enter the nucleus and/or nucleolus and influence cell cycle progression and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we have either overproduced PTHrP or inhibited endogenous PTHrP production in the breast cancer cell line, MCF-7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of PTHrP was associated with an increase in mitogenesis, whereas inhibiting endogenous PTHrP production resulted in decreased cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The overexpressed peptide targeted to the perinuclear space.</Gene>
<Gene>In contrast, PTHrP interaction with the cell surface PTH/PTHrP receptor resulted in decreased cell proliferation in the same cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This latter effect is dependent on interaction with the receptor, in that exogenously added PTHrP moieties known not to interact with the receptor had no effect on cell growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, neutralization of added peptide with an anti-PTHrP antiserum completely abolished the growth inhibitory effects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, this antibody has no effect on the increased proliferation rate of the MCF-7 transfectants that overexpress PTHrP, compared with control cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The net effect of autocrine/paracrine and intracrine effects of PTHrP in MCF-7 cells overproducing the peptide is accelerated cell growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings have critical implications regarding the role of PTHrP in breast cancer, and they suggest that controlling PTHrP production in breast cancer may be useful therapeutically.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intracellular parasitism by the human granulocytic ehrlichiosis bacterium through the P-selectin ligand, PSGL-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human granulocytic ehrlichiosis (HGE) is a febrile tick-borne illness caused by a recently discovered intracellular bacterium remarkable for its tropism for professionally phagocytic neutrophils.</Gene>

<Gene>Monoclonal antibodies against the P-selectin binding domain of the leukocyte P-selectin glycoprotein ligand, PSGL-1, prevented HGE cell binding and infection, as did enzymatic digestion of PSGL-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, simultaneous neoexpression in nonsusceptible cells of complementary DNAs for both PSGL-1 and its modifying alpha-(1,3) fucosyltransferase, Fuc-TVII, allowed binding and infection by HGE.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, the HGE bacterium specifically bound to fucosylated leukocyte PSGL-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Selectin mimicry is likely central to the organism's unique ability to target and infect neutrophils.</Gene>
<Gene>3-Methyladenine-DNA glycosylase (MPG protein) interacts with human RAD23 proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human 3-methyladenine-DNA glycosylase (MPG protein) initiates base excision repair by severing the glycosylic bond of numerous damaged bases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In comparison, homologues of the Rad23 proteins (hHR23) and the hXPC protein are involved in the recognition of damaged bases in global genome repair, a subset of nucleotide excision repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this report, we show that the hHR23A and -B also interact with the MPG protein and can serve as accessory proteins for DNA damage recognition in base excision repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the MPG.hHR23 protein complex elevates the rate of MPG protein-catalyzed excision from hypoxanthine-containing substrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This increased excision rate is correlated with a greater binding affinity of the MPG protein-hHR23 protein complex for damaged DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that the hHR23 proteins function as universal DNA damage recognition accessory proteins in both of these major excision repair pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression, purification, and functional analysis of the human serine protease HtrA2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HumHtrA2 or Omi is a recently described member of a novel family of mammalian serine proteases homologous to the Escherichia coli htrA gene product.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although the physiological function of members of this new family is unclear, the current understanding is that as well as being involved with the degradation aberrantly folded proteins during conditions of cellular stress, they may possess a chaperone-like role under normal conditions.</Gene>
<Gene>In this report we describe the overexpression of humHtrA2 in two heterologous systems comparing the merits of each.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found that molecular analysis of processing events in Sf9 cells allowed us to revisit E. coli expression systems which were initially unsuccessful.</Gene>
<Gene>Using E. coli we were able to produce milligram amounts of >90% pure recombinant enzyme as determined by SDS-PAGE gels.</Gene>
<Gene>By means of fluorescently labeled substrates alpha- and beta-casein and zymography, the proteolytic activity of recombinant HumHtrA2 was also demonstrated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Repression of IL-2 promoter activity by the novel basic leucine zipper p21SNFT protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-2 is the major autocrine and paracrine growth factor produced by T cells upon T cell stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The inducible expression of IL-2 is highly regulated by multiple transcription factors, particularly AP-1, which coordinately activate the promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Described here is the ability of the novel basic leucine zipper protein p21SNFT to repress AP-1 activity and IL-2 transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A detailed analysis of the repression by p21SNFT repression on the IL-2 promoter distal NF-AT/AP-1 site demonstrates that it can bind DNA with NF-AT and Jun, strongly suggesting that it represses NF-AT/AP-1 activity by competing with Fos proteins for Jun dimerization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The importance of this repression is that p21SNFT inhibits the trans-activation potential of protein complexes that contain Jun, thereby demonstrating an additional level of control for the highly regulated, ubiquitous AP-1 transcription factor and the IL-2 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of distinct surface-expressed and intracellular CXC-chemokine receptor 2 glycoforms in neutrophils: N-glycosylation is essential for maintenance of receptor surface expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The G protein-coupled CXC-chemokine receptor CXCR-2 mediates activation of neutrophil effector functions in response to multiple ligands, including IL-8 and neutrophil-activating peptide 2 (NAP-2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although CXCR-2 has been successfully cloned and expressed in several cell lines, the molecular properties of the native neutrophil-expressed receptor have remained largely undefined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report on the identification and characterization of distinct CXCR-2 glycoforms and their subcellular distribution in neutrophils.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunoprecipitation and Western blot analyses of surface-expressed receptors covalently linked to IL-8 or NAP-2 as well as in their unloaded state revealed the occurrence of a single CXCR-2 variant with an apparent size of 56 kDa.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>According to deglycosylation experiments surface-expressed CXCR-2 carries two N-linked 9-kDa carbohydrate moieties that are both of complex structure.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, two other CXCR-2 variants of 38 and 40 kDa were found to occur exclusively intracellular and to carry N-glycosylations of high mannose or hybrid type.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These receptors did not participate in ligand-induced receptor trafficking, while surface-expressed CXCR-2 was internalized and re-expressed following stimulation with NAP-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By enzymatic removal of one 9-kDa carbohydrate moiety in surface-expressed CXCR-2 we can show that neither NAP-2-induced trafficking nor signaling of the receptor is dependent on its full glycosylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, glycosylation was found to protect CXCR-2 from proteolytic attack, as even partial deglycosylation is associated with serine protease-mediated disappearance of the receptor from the neutrophil surface.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, although not directly involved in signaling, glycosylation appears to be required to maintain neutrophil responsiveness to CXC-chemokines during inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human TREK2, a 2P domain mechano-sensitive K+ channel with multiple regulations by polyunsaturated fatty acids, lysophospholipids, and Gs, Gi, and Gq protein-coupled receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechano-sensitive and fatty acid-activated K(+) belong to the structural class of K(+) channel with two pore domains.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we report the isolation and the characterization of a novel member of this family.</Gene>
<Gene>This channel, called TREK2, is closely related to TREK1 (78% of homology).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Its gene is located on chromosome 14q31.</Gene>
<Gene>TREK2 is abundantly expressed in pancreas and kidney and to a lower level in brain, testis, colon, and small intestine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the central nervous system, TREK2 has a widespread distribution with the highest levels of expression in cerebellum, occipital lobe, putamen, and thalamus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In transfected cells, TREK2 produces rapidly activating and non-inactivating outward rectifier K(+) currents.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The single-channel conductance is 100 picosiemens at +40 mV in 150 mm K(+).</Gene>
<Gene>The currents can be strongly stimulated by polyunsaturated fatty acid such as arachidonic, docosahexaenoic, and linoleic acids and by lysophosphatidylcholine.</Gene>
<Gene>The channel is also activated by acidification of the intracellular medium.</Gene>
<Gene>TREK2 is blocked by application of intracellular cAMP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>As with TREK1, TREK2 is activated by the volatile general anesthetics chloroform, halothane, and isoflurane and by the neuroprotective agent riluzole.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TREK2 can be positively or negatively regulated by a variety of neurotransmitter receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Stimulation of the G(s)-coupled receptor 5HT4sR or the G(q)-coupled receptor mGluR1 inhibits channel activity, whereas activation of the G(i)-coupled receptor mGluR2 increases TREK2 currents.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These multiple types of regulations suggest that TREK2 plays an important role as a target of neurotransmitter action.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>SHP2 mediates the protective effect of interleukin-6 against dexamethasone-induced apoptosis in multiple myeloma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our previous studies have shown that activation of a related adhesion focal tyrosine kinase (RAFTK) (also known as Pyk2) is required for dexamethasone (Dex)-induced apoptosis in multiple myeloma (MM) cells and that human interleukin-6 (IL-6), a known growth and survival factor for MM cells, blocks both RAFTK activation and apoptosis induced by Dex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the mechanism whereby IL-6 inhibits Dex-induced apoptosis is undefined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we demonstrate that protein-tyrosine phosphatase SHP2 mediates this protective effect.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that IL-6 triggers selective activation of SHP2 and its association with RAFTK in Dex-treated MM cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SHP2 interacts with RAFTK through a region other than its Src homology 2 domains.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrate that RAFTK is a direct substrate of SHP2 both in vitro and in vivo, and that Tyr(906) in the C-terminal domain of RAFTK mediates its interaction with SHP2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, overexpression of dominant negative SHP2 blocked the protective effect of IL-6 against Dex-induced apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings demonstrate that SHP2 mediates the anti-apoptotic effect of IL-6 and suggest SHP2 as a novel therapeutic target in MM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Alpha(2) adrenoceptors regulate proliferation of human intestinal epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND AND AIMS:</Gene>
<Gene>Previous studies on rodents have suggested that catecholamines stimulate proliferation of the intestinal epithelium through activation of alpha(2) adrenoceptors located on crypt cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The occurrence of this effect awaits demonstration in humans and the molecular mechanisms involved have not yet been elucidated.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we examined the effect of alpha(2) agonists on a clone of Caco2 cells expressing the human alpha(2A) adrenoceptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Cells were transfected with a bicistronic plasmid containing the alpha2C10 and neomycin phosphotransferase genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>G418 resistant clones were assayed for receptor expression using radioligand binding.</Gene>
<Gene>Receptor functionality was assessed by testing its ability to couple Gi proteins and to inhibit cAMP production.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) phosphorylation was followed by western blot, and cell proliferation was estimated by measuring protein and DNA content.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Permanent transfection of Caco2 cells allowed us to obtain a clone (Caco2-3B) expressing alpha(2A) adrenoceptors at a density similar to that found in normal human intestinal epithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Caco2-3B retained morphological features and brush border enzyme expression characteristic of enterocytic differentiation.</Gene>
<Gene>The receptor was coupled to Gi2/Gi3 proteins and its stimulation caused marked diminution of forskolin induced cAMP production.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of Caco2-3B with UK14304 (alpha(2) agonist) induced a rapid increase in the phosphorylation state of MAPK, extracellular regulated protein kinase 1 (Erk1), and 2 (Erk2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This event was totally abolished in pertussis toxin treated cells and in the presence of kinase inhibitors (genistein or PD98059).</Gene>
<Gene>It was unaffected by protein kinase C downregulation but correlated with a transient increase in Shc tyrosine phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, sustained exposure of Caco2-3B to UK14304 resulted in modest but significant acceleration of cell proliferation.</Gene>
<Gene>None of these effects was observed in the parental cell line Caco2.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The results obtained in the present study support a regulatory role for alpha(2) adrenoceptors in intestinal cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IL-4 enhances keratinocyte expression of CXCR3 agonistic chemokines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IFN-induced protein of 10 kDa (IP-10), monokine induced by IFN-gamma (Mig), and IFN-inducible T-cell alpha-chemoattractant (I-TAC) belong to the non-glutamate-leucine-arginine motif CXC chemokine family and act solely through the CXCR3 receptor for potent attraction of T lymphocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we evaluated the capacity of the T cell-derived cytokines IL-4, IL-10, and IL-17 to modulate IP-10, Mig, and I-TAC in cultured human keratinocytes and CXCR3 expression in T cells from allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-4, but not IL-10 or IL-17, significantly up-regulated IFN-gamma- or TNF-alpha-induced IP-10, Mig, and I-TAC mRNA accumulation in keratinocytes and increased the levels of IP-10 and Mig in keratinocyte supernatants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemistry of skin affected by ACD revealed that >70% of infiltrating cells were reactive for CXCR3 and that CXCR3 staining colocalized in CD4+ and CD8+ T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nickel-specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cell lines established from ACD skin produced IFN-gamma and IL-4 and expressed moderate to high levels of CXCR3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, CXCR3 agonistic chemokines released by stimulated keratinocytes triggered calcium mobilization in skin-derived nickel-specific CD4+ T cells and promoted their migration, with supernatant from keratinocyte cultures stimulated with IFN-gamma and IL-4 attracting more efficaciously than supernatant from keratinocytes activated with IFN-gamma alone.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, IL-4 exerts a proinflammatory function on keratinocytes by potentiating IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha induction of IP-10, Mig, and I-TAC, which in turn may determine a prominent recruitment of CXCR3+ T lymphocytes at inflammatory reaction sites.</Gene>

text: <Gene>The human GRAF gene is fused to MLL in a unique t(5;11)(q31;q23) and both alleles are disrupted in three cases of myelodysplastic syndrome/acute myeloid leukemia with a deletion 5q.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated the human GRAF gene (for GTPase regulator associated with the focal adhesion kinase pp125(FAK)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This gene was fused with MLL in a unique t(5;11)(q31;q23) that occurred in an infant with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>GRAF encodes a member of the Rho family of the GTPase-activating protein (GAP) family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the protein level, it is 90% homologous to the recently described chicken GRAF gene that functions as a GAP of RhoA in vivo and is thus a critical component of the integrin signaling transduction pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The particular position of the human GRAF gene at 5q31 and the proposed antiproliferative and tumor suppressor properties of its avian homologue suggest that it also might be pathogenetically relevant for hematologic malignancies with deletions of 5q.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate this possibility, we sequenced 4-5 individual cDNA clones from 13 cases in which one allele of GRAF was deleted.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found point mutations within the GAP domain of the second GRAF allele in one patient.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In two additional patients we found an insertion of 52 or 74 bp within the GRAF cDNA that generates a reading frame shift followed by a premature stop codon.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>GRAF maps outside the previously defined commonly deleted 5q31 region.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nevertheless, inactivation of both alleles in at least some cases suggests that deletions and mutations of the GRAF gene may be instrumental in the development and progression of hematopoeitic disorders with a del(5q).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>LEC induces chemotaxis and adhesion by interacting with CCR1 and CCR8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Liver-expressed chemokine (LEC) is an unusually large CC chemokine, which is also known as LMC, HCC-4, NCC-4, and CCL16.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously, LEC was shown to induce leukocyte migration but the responsible signaling receptors were not characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report chemotaxis and competitive binding studies that show LEC binds to and activates CCR1 and CCR8 transfected HEK-293 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LEC induced maximal migration of CCR1 and CCR8 transfected cells at 89.3 nmol/L and cell adhesion at 5.6 nmol/L. The molar concentration of LEC required to induce maximum cell migration is 20- to 200-fold greater than that required for RANTES or I309, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>All 3 chemokines induced maximal static adhesion at 5 to 7 nmol/L. A neutralizing polyclonal antibody to LEC was developed to demonstrate that the unusually high concentration of LEC required to induce chemotaxis was a property of LEC and not as a result of an irrelevant protein contamination.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study suggests that LEC may be a more effective inducer of cell adhesion than cell migration.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ataxin-3, the MJD1 gene product, interacts with the two human homologs of yeast DNA repair protein RAD23, HHR23A and HHR23B.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Machado-Joseph disease (MJD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by an expansion of the polyglutamine tract near the C-terminus of the MJD1 gene product, ataxin-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The mutant ataxin-3 forms intranuclear inclusions in cultured cells as well as in diseased human brain and also causes cell death in transfected cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the normal function of ataxin-3 remains unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To explore the function of ataxin-3, we used the two-hybrid system to screen for the protein(s) that interacts with ataxin-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that ataxin-3 interacts with two human homologs of the yeast DNA repair protein RAD23, HHR23A and HHR23B.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we confirmed that ataxin-3 interacts with the -ubiquitin-like domain at the N-terminus of the HHR23 proteins, which is important for nucleotide excision repair; however, ataxin-3 does not interact with -ubiquitin, implying that ataxin-3 might be functionally associated with the HHR23 proteins through this specific interaction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The normal and mutant ataxin-3 proteins show no difference in their ability to bind to the HHR23 proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, in 293 cells HHR23A is recruited to intranuclear inclusions formed by the mutant ataxin-3 through its interaction with ataxin-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that this interaction is associated with the normal function of ataxin-3 and that some functional abnormality of the HHR23 proteins might exist in MJD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Retinoschisin, the X-linked retinoschisis protein, is a secreted photoreceptor protein, and is expressed and released by Weri-Rb1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>X-linked retinoschisis is characterized by microcystic-like changes of the macular region and schisis within the inner retinal layers, leading to visual deterioration in males.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Many missense and protein-truncating mutations of the causative gene RS1 have now been identified and are thought to be inactivating.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RS1 encodes a 224 amino acid protein, retinoschisin, which contains a discoidin domain but is of unknown function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have generated a polyclonal antibody against a peptide from a unique region within retinoschisin, which detects a protein of approximately 28 kDa in retinal samples reduced with dithiothreitol, but multimers sized >40 kDa under non-reducing conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A screen of human tissues with this antibody reveals retinoschisin to be retina specific and the antibody detects a protein of similar size in bovine and murine retinae.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the expression pattern in the retina of both RS1 mRNA (using in situ hybridization with riboprobes) and retinoschisin (using immunohistochemistry).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The antisense riboprobe detected RS1 mRNA only in the photoreceptor layer but the protein product of the gene was present both in the photoreceptors and within the inner portions of the retina.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, differentiated retinoblastoma cells (Weri-Rb1 cells) were found to express RS1 mRNA and to release retinoschisin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that retinoschisin is released by photo-receptors and has functions within the inner retinal layers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, X-linked retinoschisis is caused by abnormalities in a putative secreted photoreceptor protein and is the first example of a secreted photo-receptor protein associated with a retinal dystrophy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a common protein association region in the neuronal Cdk5 activator.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cyclin-dependent protein kinase 5 (Cdk5) depends on the association with neuronal Cdk5 activator (Nck5a) for kinase activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A variety of cellular proteins have been shown to undergo high affinity association with Nck5a, including three novel proteins, C42, C48, and C53 found by a yeast two-hybrid screen (Ching, Y. P., Qi, Z., and Wang, J. H. (2000) Gene 242, 285-294).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The three proteins show competitive binding to Nck5a suggesting that they bind at a common site.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The binding site has been mapped to a region of 26 amino acid residues (residues 145 to 170) at the N-terminal boundary of the kinase activation domain of Nck5a.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This region of Nck5a contains an amphipathic alpha-helix whose hydrophobic face is involved in Cdk5 activation (Chin, K. T., Ohki, S, Tang, D., Cheng, H. C., Wang, J. H. , and Zhang, M. (1999) J. Biol.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chem.</Gene>
<Gene>Several lines of evidence suggest that Nck5a interacts with the binding proteins at the hydrophilic face of the amphipathic alpha-helix.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>First, the Nck5a-(145-170) peptide can bind Cdk5 and Nck5a-binding proteins simultaneously.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Second, the association of Nck5a-(145-170) to C48 can be markedly reduced by high ionic strength whereas the interaction between Nck5a and Cdk5 is not affected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Third, substitution of Glu(157) by glutamine in Nck5a-(145-170) abolishes the peptide's ability to bind to the three Nck5a-binding proteins without diminishing its Cdk5 binding activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
