text: <Gene>CXC chemokine receptor 3 expression on CD34(+) hematopoietic progenitors from human cord blood induced by granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor: chemotaxis and adhesion induced by its ligands, interferon gamma-inducible protein 10 and monokine induced by interferon gamma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CXC chemokine receptor 3 (CXCR3), which is known to be expressed predominately on memory and activated T lymphocytes, is a receptor for both interferon gamma (IFN-gamma)-inducible protein 10 (gamma IP-10) and monokine induced by IFN-gamma (Mig).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report the novel finding that CXCR3 is also expressed on CD34(+) hematopoietic progenitors from human cord blood stimulated with granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) but not on freshly isolated CD34(+) progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Freshly isolated CD34(+) progenitors expressed low levels of CXCR3 messenger RNA, but this expression was highly up-regulated by GM-CSF, as indicated by a real-time quantitative reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction technique.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>gamma IP-10 and Mig induced chemotaxis of GM-CSF-stimulated CD34(+) progenitors by means of CXCR3, since an anti-CXCR3 monoclonal antibody (mAb) was found to block gamma IP-10-induced and Mig-induced CD34(+) progenitor chemotaxis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These chemotactic attracted CD34(+) progenitors are colony-forming units-granulocyte-macrophage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>gamma IP-10 and Mig also induced GM-CSF-stimulated CD34(+) progenitor adhesion and aggregation by means of CXCR3, a finding confirmed by the observation that anti-CXCR3 mAb blocked these functions of gammaIP-10 and Mig but not of chemokine stromal cell-derived factor 1 alpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>gamma IP-10-induced and Mig-induced up-regulation of integrins (CD49a and CD49b) was found to play a crucial role in adhesion of GM-CSF-stimulated CD34(+) progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, gamma IP-10 and Mig stimulated CXCR3 redistribution and cellular polarization in GM-CSF-stimulated CD34(+) progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that CXCR3-gamma IP-10 and CXCR3-Mig receptor-ligand pairs, as well as the effects of GM-CSF on them, may be especially important in the cytokine/chemokine environment for the physiologic and pathophysiologic events of differentiation of CD34(+) hematopoietic progenitors into lymphoid and myeloid stem cells, subsequently immune and inflammatory cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These processes include transmigration, relocation, differentiation, and maturation of CD34(+) hematopoietic progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>(Blood.</Gene>
<Gene>HIV-1 gp120- and gp160-induced apoptosis in cultured endothelial cells is mediated by caspases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The immune dysfunction and cell destruction that occur in the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected host appear to result from the direct cytopathic effects of viral infection and the effects of viral proteins on uninfected bystander cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Recently, the alpha-chemokine receptor CXCR4 has been reported to mediate apoptosis in neuronal cells and in CD4(+) and CD8(+) T cells after its binding to HIV-1 envelope proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the current study, it was observed that human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) undergo apoptosis after their treatment with the HIV-1 envelope proteins gp120/160.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Anti-CXCR4 monoclonal antibody decreased HIV-1 gp120/160-induced apoptosis, suggesting that the CXCR4 chemokine receptor mediates the apoptotic effects of these HIV envelope glycoproteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies revealed that caspases play an important role in this process because the pretreatment of cells with a general caspase enzyme inhibitor decreased the extent of HUVEC apoptosis induced by gp120/160.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, it was found that caspase-3 was activated on HIV-1 gp120/160 treatment of these cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It was also observed that gp120/160 treatment slightly increased the expression of the pro-apoptotic molecule Bax.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins can disrupt endothelial integrity through the interaction with CXCR4, thereby facilitating virus transit out of the bloodstream and contributing to the vascular injury syndromes seen in acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(Blood.</Gene>

<Gene>Collagen XVIII, containing an endogenous inhibitor of angiogenesis and tumor growth, plays a critical role in the maintenance of retinal structure and in neural tube closure (Knobloch syndrome).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Knobloch syndrome (KS) is an autosomal recessive disorder defined by the occurrence of high myopia, vitreoretinal degeneration with retinal detachment, macular abnormalities and occipital encephalocele.</Gene>
<Gene>The KS causative gene had been assigned to a 4.3 cM interval at 21q22.3 by linkage analysis of a large consanguineous Brazilian family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We reconstructed the haplotypes of this family with ten additional markers (five were novel) and narrowed the candidate interval to a region of < 245 kb, which contains 24 expressed sequence tags, the KIAA0958 gene and the 5' end of the COL18A1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified a homozygous mutation at the AG consensus acceptor splice site of COL18A1 intron 1 exclusively among the 12 KS patients, which was not found among 140 control chromosomes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This mutation predicts the creation of a stop codon in exon 4 and therefore the truncation of the alpha1(XVIII) collagen short form, which was expressed in human adult retina.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide evidence that KS is caused by mutations in COL18A1 which, therefore, has a major role in determining the retinal structure as well as in the closure of the neural tube.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we show for the first time that the absence of a collagen isoform impairs embryonic cell proliferation and/or migration as a primary or secondary effect.</Gene>
<Gene>CIKS, a connection to Ikappa B kinase and stress-activated protein kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pathogens, inflammatory signals, and stress cause acute transcriptional responses in cells.</Gene>
<Gene>The induced expression of genes in response to these signals invariably involves transcription factors of the NF-kappaB and AP-1/ATF families.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of NF-kappaB factors is thought to be mediated primarily via IkappaB kinases (IKK), whereas that of AP-1/ATF can be mediated by stress-activated protein kinases (SAPKs; also named Jun kinases or JNKs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IKKalpha and IKKbeta are two catalytic subunits of a core IKK complex that also contains the regulatory subunit NEMO (NF-kappaB essential modulator)/IKKgamma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The latter protein is essential for activation of the IKKs, but its mechanism of action is not known.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we describe the molecular cloning of CIKS (connection to IKK and SAPK/JNK), a previously unknown protein that directly interacts with NEMO/IKKgamma in cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When ectopically expressed, CIKS stimulates IKK and SAPK/JNK kinases and it transactivates an NF-kappaB-dependent reporter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of NF-kappaB is prevented in the presence of kinase-deficient, interfering mutants of the IKKs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CIKS may help to connect upstream signaling events to IKK and SAPK/JNK modules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CIKS could coordinate the activation of two stress-induced signaling pathways, functions reminiscent of those noted for tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor adaptor proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Functional consequences of tumorigenic missense mutations in the amino-terminal domain of Smad4.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Smads, the intracellular effectors of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) family members, are somatically mutated at high frequency in particular types of human cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Certain of these mutations affect the Smad amino-terminal domain, which, in the case of Smad3 and Smad4, binds DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the functional consequences of four missense mutations in the Smad4 amino-terminal domain found in human tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mutant proteins were found to have impaired abilities to bind DNA although they were fully capable of forming complexes with Smad3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All four Smad4 mutants showed decreased protein stability compared to wild-type Smad4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two of the Smad4 mutants (G65V and P130S) were translocated to the nucleus and were capable of transactivating a Smad-dependent promoter in a ligand-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the L43S and R100T mutants were not translocated efficiently to the nucleus and consequently resulted in severely defective transcriptional responses to TGF-beta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, we demonstrate here the critical importance of two basic residues in the beta-hairpin loop of Smad3 or Smad4 for DNA binding, consistent with predictions from the Smad3 crystal structure.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, our results reveal that in the TGF-beta-induced heteromeric signaling complex, loss of DNA binding of Smad4 can be compensated by Smad3, however, both Smad3 and Smad4 are needed for efficient DNA binding and signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, mutations in the amino-terminal domain of Smad4, that are found in cancer, show loss of multiple functional properties which may contribute to tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interaction between LIS1 and doublecortin, two lissencephaly gene products.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in either LIS1 or DCX are the most common cause for type I lissencephaly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report that LIS1 and DCX interact physically both in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Epitope-tagged DCX transiently expressed in COS cells can be co-immunoprecipitated with endogenous LIS1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, endogenous DCX could be co-immunoprecipitated with endogenous LIS1 in embryonic brain extracts, demonstrating an in vivo association.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The two protein products also co-localize in transfected cells and in primary neuronal cells.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, we demonstrate homodimerization of DCX in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using fragments of both LIS1 and DCX, the domains of interaction were mapped.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LIS1 and DCX interact with tubulin and microtubules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results suggest that addition of DCX and LIS1 to tubulin enhances polymerization in an additive fashion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In in vitro competition assays, when LIS1 is added first, DCX competes with LIS1 in its binding to microtubules, but when DCX is added prior to the addition of LIS1 it enhances the binding of LIS1 to microtubules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that LIS1 and DCX cross-talk is important to microtubule function in the developing cerebral cortex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Localization and enhanced current density of the Kv4.2 potassium channel by interaction with the actin-binding protein filamin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Kv4.2 potassium channels play a critical role in postsynaptic excitability.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunocytochemical studies reveal a somatodendritic Kv4.2 expression pattern, with the channels concentrated mainly at dendritic spines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The molecular mechanism that underlies the localization of Kv4.2 to this subcellular region is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We used the yeast two-hybrid system to identify the Kv4.2-associated proteins that are involved in channel localization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we demonstrate a direct interaction between Kv4.2 and the actin-binding protein, filamin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that Kv4.2 and filamin can be coimmunoprecipitated both in vitro and in brain and that Kv4.2 and filamin share an overlapping expression pattern in the cerebellum and cultured hippocampal neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To examine the functional consequences of this interaction, we expressed Kv4.2 in filamin(+) and filamin(-) cells and performed immunocytochemical and electrophysiological analyses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results indicate that Kv4.2 colocalizes with filamin at filopodial roots in filamin(+) cells but shows a nonspecific expression pattern in filamin(-) cells, with no localization to filopodial roots.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the magnitude of whole-cell Kv4.2 current density is approximately 2.7-fold larger in filamin(+) cells as compared with these currents in filamin(-) cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We propose that filamin may function as a scaffold protein in the postsynaptic density, mediating a direct link between Kv4.2 and the actin cytoskeleton, and that this interaction is essential for the generation of appropriate Kv4.2 current densities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
