text: <Gene>Insertion of beta-satellite repeats identifies a transmembrane protease causing both congenital and childhood onset autosomal recessive deafness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Approximately 50% of childhood deafness is caused by mutations in specific genes.</Gene>
<Gene>Autosomal recessive loci account for approximately 80% of nonsyndromic genetic deafness.</Gene>

<Gene>Here we report the identification of a new transmembrane serine protease (TMPRSS3; also known as ECHOS1) expressed in many tissues, including fetal cochlea, which is mutated in the families used to describe both the DFNB10 and DFNB8 loci.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An 8-bp deletion and insertion of 18 monomeric (approximately 68-bp) beta-satellite repeat units, normally present in tandem arrays of up to several hundred kilobases on the short arms of acrocentric chromosomes, causes congenital deafness (DFNB10).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A mutation in a splice-acceptor site, resulting in a 4-bp insertion in the mRNA and a frameshift, was detected in childhood onset deafness (DFNB8).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first description of beta-satellite insertion into an active gene resulting in a pathogenic state, and the first description of a protease involved in hearing loss.</Gene>
<Gene>A human BRCA2 complex containing a structural DNA binding component influences cell cycle progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Germline mutations of the human BRCA2 gene confer susceptibility to breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although the function of the BRCA2 protein remains to be determined, murine cells homozygous for BRCA2 inactivation display chromosomal aberrations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a 2 MDa BRCA2-containing complex and identified a structural DNA binding component, designated as BRCA2-Associated Factor 35 (BRAF35).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BRAF35 contains a nonspecific DNA binding HMG domain and a kinesin-like coiled coil domain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Similar to BRCA2, BRAF35 mRNA expression levels in mouse embryos are highest in proliferating tissues with high mitotic index.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Strikingly, nuclear staining revealed a close association of BRAF35/BRCA2 complex with condensed chromatin coincident with histone H3 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, antibody microinjection experiments suggest a role for BRCA2/BRAF35 complex in modulation of cell cycle progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning, expression and chromosomal location of NKX6B TO 10Q26, a region frequently deleted in brain tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nkx6-2 (former Gtx) is a murine-homeobox-containing gene localized distally on Chromosome (Chr) 7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of the expression pattern, together with DNA binding assays, suggests that this gene product might be important for differentiated oligodendrocyte function and in the regulation of myelin gene expression.</Gene>
<Gene>We now report on the cloning and characterization of the human homolog (NKX6B).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DNA sequence analysis of an 11-kb genomic fragment revealed that the complete human gene spans 1.2 kb and is composed of three exons.</Gene>
<Gene>NKX6B is predicted to encode a polypeptide of 277 amino acids with 97% identity to mouse Nkx6-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot experiments showed that NKX6B expression is tightly controlled in a tissue-specific fashion with the highest site of expression being the brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, using STS content mapping and RH analyis, we demonstrated that NKX6B maps to the 10q26, a region where frequent loss of heterozygosity has been observed in various malignant brain tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results may implicate NKX6B as a candidate tumor suppressor gene for brain tumors, particularly for oligodendrogliomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) upregulates BCL-2 and inhibits apoptosis in human and murine mammary adenocarcinoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tumour progression is regulated by the balance of proliferation and apoptosis in the tumour cell population.</Gene>
<Gene>To date, the role of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) in tumour growth has been attributed to the induction of angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF has been shown to be a survival factor for endothelial cells, preventing apoptosis by inducing Bcl-2 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In both murine (4T1) and human (MDA-MB-231) metastatic mammary carcinoma cell lines, we found that VEGF upregulated Bcl-2 expression and anti-VEGF antibodies reduced Bcl-2 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These alterations in Bcl-2 expression were reflected by the levels of tumour cell apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF resulted in reduced tumour cell apoptosis, whereas its inhibition with anti-VEGF neutralizing antibodies induced apoptosis directly in tumour cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, in addition to its role in angiogenesis and vessel permeability, VEGF acts as a survival factor for tumour cells, inducing Bcl-2 expression and inhibiting tumour cell apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Endothelial cell costimulation of T cell activation through CD58-CD2 interactions involves lipid raft aggregation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human endothelial cells (EC) costimulate CD4(+) memory T cell activation through CD58-CD2 interactions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study we tested the hypothesis that EC activate distinct costimulatory pathways in T cells that target specific transcription factors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AP-1, composed of fos and jun proteins, is a critical effector of TCR signaling and binds several sites in the IL-2 promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EC augment c-fos promoter activity in T cells; however, deletion analysis reveals no transcription factor binding sites in the promoter uniquely responsive to EC costimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of AP-1 proteins in T cells augments the activity of an AP-1-luciferase reporter gene equally in the absence or the presence of EC costimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, EC stimulate a similar 2- to 3-fold up-regulation of AP-1, NF-AT, NF-kappaB, and NF-IL-2-luciferase reporters.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD2 mAbs completely block EC effects on all of these pathways, as well as costimulation of IL-2 secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that EC costimulation through CD2 does not trigger a single distinct costimulatory pathway in T cells, but rather, it amplifies several pathways downstream of the TCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Indeed, we find that early EC costimulation acts " upstream " of the TCR by promoting lipid raft aggregation, thus amplifying TCR signaling.</Gene>
<Gene>Soluble CD2 mAbs block EC-induced raft aggregation, whereas cross-linking CD2 promotes aggregation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data are consistent with the critical role of CD2 in organizing the T cell-APC contact zone.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AMP-activated protein kinase suppresses protein synthesis in rat skeletal muscle through down-regulated mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is viewed as an energy sensor that acts to modulate glucose uptake and fatty acid oxidation in skeletal muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Given that protein synthesis is a high energy-consuming process, it may be transiently depressed during cellular energy stress.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus, the intent of this investigation was to examine whether AMPK activation modulates the translational control of protein synthesis in skeletal muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Injections of 5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide 1-beta-d-ribonucleoside (AICAR) were used to activate AMPK in male rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The activity of alpha1 AMPK remained unchanged in gastrocnemius muscle from AICAR-treated animals compared with controls, whereas alpha2 AMPK activity was significantly increased (51%).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AICAR treatment resulted in a reduction in protein synthesis to 45% of the control value.</Gene>

<Gene>This depression was associated with decreased activation of protein kinases in the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) signal transduction pathway as evidenced by reduced phosphorylation of protein kinase B on Ser(473), mTOR on Ser(2448), ribosomal protein S6 kinase on Thr(389), and eukaryotic initiation factor eIF4E-binding protein on Thr(37).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A reduction in eIF4E associated with eIF4G to 10% of the control value was also noted.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, eIF2B activity remained unchanged in response to AICAR treatment and therefore would not appear to contribute to the depression in protein synthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first investigation to demonstrate changes in translation initiation and skeletal muscle protein synthesis in response to AMPK activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Protocadherin LKC, a new candidate for a tumor suppressor of colon and liver cancers, its association with contact inhibition of cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Protocadherins are a major subfamily of the cadherin superfamily, but little is known about their functions and intracellular signal transduction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We cloned a novel human protocadherin gene, containing seven EC domains, and identified functional aspects of this gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The gene was predominantly expressed in liver, kidney and colon tissues, and was thus designated Protocadherin LKC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of Protocadherin LKC is markedly reduced in cancers arising from these tissues at both transcriptional and protein levels.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate the effects of Protocadherin LKC expression in colon cancer, we introduced the gene into colon cancer cell line HCT116, which does not express this gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Significantly, Protocadherin LKC expression induced contact inhibition of cell proliferation although it did not affect growth rate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>When grown to post-confluence in monolayer cells cultures, Protocadherin LKC-expressing HCT116 no longer formed multiple cell layers and showed the typical paving stone morphology of normal epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, expression of Protocadherin LKC suppressed tumor formation of HCT116 cells in a nude mouse model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we identified a protein, hMAST205 (microtubule-associated serine/threonine kinase-205 kDa), which interacted with Protocadherin LKC; the interaction occurring between the PDZ domain of hMAST205 and C-terminal tail of Protocadherin LKC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results suggest that Protocadherin LKC, which directly binds PDZ protein, is a molecular switch for contact inhibition of epithelial cells in the liver, kidney and colon tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Daxx and histone deacetylase II associate with chromatin through an interaction with core histones and the chromatin-associated protein Dek.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human Daxx is a protein that functions, in part, as a transcriptional co-repressor through its interaction with a growing number of nuclear, DNA-associated proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To determine the mechanism by which hDaxx represses transcription, we used conventional chromatography to isolate endogenous hDaxx.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We determined that hDaxx has an apparent molecular weight of 360 kDa, which is consistent with the fact that multiple domains of hDaxx are required for transcriptional repression and suggests that hDaxx associates with multiple proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using co-fractionation and co-immunoprecipitation we demonstrate that hDaxx associates with proteins that are critical for transcriptional repression, such as histone deacetylase II, constituents of chromatin such as core histones H2A, H2B, H3 and H4, and Dek, a chromatin-associated protein reported to change the topology of DNA in chromatin in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also demonstrate a requirement for the SPT domain and the first paired amphipathic helix of hDaxx for its association with histone deacetylase II and acetylated histone H4, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we provide evidence suggesting that the association of hDaxx with chromatin-related proteins is dependent on the post-translational phosphorylation status of hDaxx.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A working model for the repressive action of hDaxx through its association with chromatin related proteins is presented.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Regulation of human separase by securin binding and autocleavage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Sister chromatid separation is initiated by separase, a protease that cleaves cohesin and thereby dissolves sister chromatid cohesion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Separase is activated by the degradation of its inhibitor securin and by the removal of inhibitory phosphates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In human cells, separase activation also coincides with the cleavage of separase, but it is not known if this reaction activates separase, which protease cleaves separase, and how separase cleavage is regulated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Inhibition of separase expression in human cells by RNA interference causes the formation of polyploid cells with large lobed nuclei.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In mitosis, many of these cells contain abnormal chromosome plates with unseparated sister chromatids.</Gene>
<Gene>Inhibitor binding experiments in vitro reveal that securin prevents the access of substrate analogs to the active site of separase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upon securin degradation, the active site of full-length separase becomes accessible, allowing rapid autocatalytic cleavage of separase at one of three sites.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The resulting N- and C-terminal fragments remain associated and can be reinhibited by securin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A noncleavable separase mutant retains its ability to cleave cohesin in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Our results suggest that separase is required for sister chromatid separation during mitosis in human cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data further indicate that securin inhibits separase by blocking the access of substrates to the active site of separase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Securin proteolysis allows autocatalytic processing of separase into a cleaved form, but separase cleavage is not essential for separase activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Contribution of CD3 gamma to TCR regulation and signaling in human mature T lymphocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD3 proteins may have redundant as well as specific contributions to the intracellular propagation and final effector responses of TCR-mediated signals at different checkpoints during T cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report here on the participation of CD3 gamma in the activation and effector function of human mature T lymphocytes at the antigen recognition checkpoint.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Following TCR-CD3 engagement of human CD3 gamma-deficient T cell lines, and despite their lower TCR-CD3 surface levels compared to normal controls, mature T cell responses such as protein tyrosine phosphorylation and the regulation of expression of several cell surface molecules, including the TCR-CD3 itself, were either normal or only slightly affected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, other physiological responses like the specific adhesion and concomitant cell polarization on ICAM-1-coated dishes were selectively defective, and activation-induced cell death was increased.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data indicate that CD3 gamma contributes essential specialized signaling functions to certain mature T cell responses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Failure to generate appropriate interactions may abort cytoskeleton reorganization and initiate an apoptotic response.</Gene>
<Gene>ADAM10-mediated cleavage of L1 adhesion molecule at the cell surface and in released membrane vesicles.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cells can release membrane components in a soluble form and as membrane vesicles.</Gene>
<Gene>L1, an important molecule for cell migration of neural and tumor cells, is released by membrane-proximal cleavage, and soluble L1 promotes cell migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Release of L1 is enhanced by shedding inducers such as phorbol ester and pervanadate, but it is also enhanced by depletion of cellular cholesterol with methyl-beta-cyclodextrin (MCD).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>How such different compounds can induce shedding is presently unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>We show here that ADAM10 is involved in L1 cleavage, which occurs at the cell surface and in the Golgi apparatus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MCD and pervanadate treatment induced the release of microvesicles containing full-length L1 and the active form of ADAM10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>L1 cleavage occurred in isolated vesicles.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>L1-containing microvesicles could trigger haptotactic cell migration.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Only the neural L1 form carrying the RSLE signal for clathrin-dependent endocytosis was recruited and cleaved in vesicles.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Phorbol ester treatment activated L1 cleavage predominantly at the cell surface.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results provide evidence for two pathways of L1 cleavage, based on ADAM10 localization, that can be activated differentially: 1) direct cleavage at the cell surface, and 2) release and cleavage in secretory vesicles most likely derived from the Golgi apparatus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The findings establish a novel role for ADAM10 as a vesicle-based protease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Yaf2 inhibits Myc biological function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The proto-oncogenes of the myelocytomatosis viral oncogene homolog (MYC) family, including MYC, MYCN and MYCL, encode nuclear proteins that act as transcription factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Myc protein is the best studied member of this family and is involved in cell cycle regulation, differentiation and cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously demonstrated that the zinc-finger protein Yaf2 interacts with the central region of MycN and enhances MycN dependent transcriptional activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that Yaf2 also binds to the Myc protein in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast to the activating effect on MycN function, Yaf2 inhibits Myc mediated transactivation and transformation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This differential influence on two members of the Myc family gives insight into a new mechanism to modulate the biological activities of Myc transcription factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression cloning of a human dual-specificity phosphatase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using an expression cloning strategy, we isolated a cDNA encoding a human protein-tyrosine-phosphatase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Bacteria expressing the kinase domain of the keratinocyte growth factor receptor (bek/fibroblast growth factor receptor 2) were infected with a fibroblast cDNA library in a phagemid prokaryotic expression vector and screened with a monoclonal anti-phosphotyrosine antibody.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among several clones showing decreased anti-phosphotyrosine recognition, one displayed phosphatase activity toward the kinase in vitro.</Gene>
<Gene>The 4.1-kilobase cDNA encoded a deduced protein of 185 amino acids with limited sequence similarity to the vaccinia virus phosphatase VH1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The purified recombinant protein dephosphorylated several activated growth factor receptors, as well as serine-phosphorylated casein, in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both serine and tyrosine phosphatase activities were completely abolished by mutagenesis of a single cysteine residue conserved in VH1 and the VH1-related (VHR) human protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These properties suggest that VHR is capable of regulating intracellular events mediated by both tyrosine and serine phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of the Ah receptor nuclear translocator protein (Arnt) as a component of the DNA binding form of the Ah receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Ah (dioxin) receptor binds a number of widely disseminated environmental pollutants, including 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and mediates their carcinogenic effects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ligand-bound receptor activates Cyp 1a1 gene transcription through interaction with specific DNA sequences, termed xenobiotic responsive elements (XREs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Ah receptor nuclear translocator protein (Arnt) is required for Ah receptor function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Arnt is now shown to be a structural component of the XRE binding form of the Ah receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Arnt and the ligand-binding subunit of the receptor were extracted as a complex from the nuclei of cells treated with ligand.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Arnt contains a basic helix-loop-helix motif, which may be responsible for interacting with both the XRE and the ligand-binding subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Characterization of SAF-A, a novel nuclear DNA binding protein from HeLa cells with high affinity for nuclear matrix/scaffold attachment DNA elements.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified four proteins in nuclear extracts from HeLa cells which specifically bind to a scaffold attachment region (SAR) element from the human genome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of these four proteins, SAF-A (scaffold attachment factor A), shows the highest affinity for several homologous and heterologous SAR elements from vertebrate cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SAF-A is an abundant nuclear protein and a constituent of the nuclear matrix and scaffold.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The homogeneously purified protein is a novel double stranded DNA binding protein with an apparent molecular weight of 120 kDa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>SAF-A binds at multiple sites to the human SAR element; competition studies with synthetic polynucleotides indicate that these sites most probably reside in the multitude of A/T-stretches which are distributed throughout this element.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition we show by electron microscopy that the protein forms large aggregates and mediates the formation of looped DNA structures.</Gene>

<Gene>Expression cloning of a cDNA encoding UDP-GlcNAc:Gal beta 1-3-GalNAc-R (GlcNAc to GalNAc) beta 1-6GlcNAc transferase by gene transfer into CHO cells expressing polyoma large tumor antigen.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA encoding UDP-GlcNAc:Gal beta 1-3GalNAc-R (GlcNAc to GalNAc) beta 1-6GlcNAc transferase (EC 2.4.1.102), which forms critical branches in O-glycans, has been isolated by an expression cloning approach using Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Increased activity of this enzyme and the concomitant occurrence of the O-glycan core 2 structure [Gal beta 1-3(GlcNAc beta 1-6)GalNAc] has been observed in a variety of biological processes, such as T-cell activation and immunodeficiency due to the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and AIDS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since CHO cells do not express this enzyme, CHO cell lines were established to stably express polyoma large tumor (T) antigen, which enables transient expression cloning.</Gene>
<Gene>Because the antibody used was found to detect most efficiently the oligosaccharide products attached to leukosialin, the CHO cells were also stably transfected with leukosialin cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By using this particular CHO cell line, a cDNA that encodes a protein determining the formation of the core 2 structure was isolated from an HL-60 cDNA library.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNA sequence predicts a protein with type II membrane topology, as has been found for all other mammalian glycosyltransferases cloned to date.</Gene>

<Gene>The expression of the presumed catalytic domain as a fusion protein with the IgG binding domain of protein A enabled us to demonstrate unequivocally that the cDNA encodes the core 2 beta-1,6-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase, the enzyme responsible for the formation of Gal beta 1-3(GlcNAc beta 1-6)GalNAc structures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>No activity with this enzyme was detected toward the acceptors for other beta 1-6GlcNAc transferases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning of a novel tumor necrosis factor-alpha-inducible primary response gene that is differentially expressed in development and capillary tube-like formation in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TNF is a proinflammatory cytokine that has pleiotropic effects on cells and tissues, mediated in large part by alterations in target tissue gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have used the technique of differential hybridization to identify several primary response genes induced by TNF in human umbilical vein endothelial (HUVE) cells, a cell type that is profoundly activated by cytokine treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One of these cDNA, designated B94, detects a rapidly and transiently induced 4-kb transcript in TNF-treated HUVE cells, and this transcript is superinduced in the concomitant presence of cycloheximide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Other proinflammatory stimuli including IL-1 beta and LPS are also able to induce B94 mRNA expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nuclear run-on experiments demonstrate that TNF induction of B94 transcript occurs primarily at the level of transcriptional activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further, B94 is shown to be a single copy gene that is evolutionarily conserved.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The gene is localized to the q32 region of chromosome 14, a region that is often rearranged in lymphoid neoplasms.</Gene>
<Gene>B94 transcript expression is also found to be regulated during mouse development and in an in vitro model of endothelial capillary tube formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Developmental regulation occurs most prominently in mouse embryonic liver and kidney, and a second smaller form of B94 transcript is detected in the placenta and testes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>B94 and other TNF-responsive transcripts are also induced during capillary tube formation suggesting overlap between genes induced by TNF and those induced during angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis of the B94 cDNA reveals an open reading frame encoding a 73-kDa polypeptide that has no homology to any known protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Polyclonal antisera directed against the carboxyl-terminal portion of the B94 protein immunoprecipitates a protein of the predicted molecular mass both from COS cells transfected with a B94 expression vector and from TNF-treated HUVE cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and expression of a cell surface receptor for advanced glycosylation end products of proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Advanced glycosylation end products of proteins (AGEs) are nonenzymatically glycosylated proteins which accumulate in vascular tissue in aging and at an accelerated rate in diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A approximately 35-kDa polypeptide with a unique NH2-terminal sequence has been isolated from bovine lung and found to be present on the surface of endothelial cells where it mediates the binding of AGEs (receptor for advanced glycosylation end product or RAGE).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using an oligonucleotide probe based on the amino-terminal sequence of RAGE, an apparently full-length cDNA of 1.5 kilobases was isolated from a bovine lung cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This cDNA encoded a 394 amino acid mature protein comprised of the following putative domains: an extracellular domain of 332 amino acids, a single hydrophobic membrane spanning domain of 19 amino acids, and a carboxyl-terminal domain of 43 amino acids.</Gene>
<Gene>A partial clone encoding the human counterpart of RAGE, isolated from a human lung library, was found to be approximately 90% homologous to the bovine molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Based on computer analysis of the amino acid sequence of RAGE and comparison with databases, RAGE is a new member of the immunoglobulin superfamily of cell surface molecules and shares significant homology with MUC 18, NCAM, and the cytoplasmic domain of CD20.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of the RAGE cDNA in 293 cells allowed them to bind 125I-AGE-albumin in a saturable and dose-dependent manner (Kd approximately 100 nM), blocked by antibody to RAGE.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Western blots of 293 cells transfected with RAGE cDNA probed with anti-RAGE IgG demonstrated expression of immunoreactive protein compared to its absence in mock-transfected cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that RAGE functions as a cell surface receptor for AGEs, which could potentially mediate cellular effects of this class of glycosylated proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Structure of the CD59-encoding gene: further evidence of a relationship to murine lymphocyte antigen Ly-6 protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene for CD59 [membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL), protectin], a phosphatidylinositol-linked surface glycoprotein that regulates the formation of the polymeric C9 complex of complement and that is deficient on the abnormal hematopoietic cells of patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, consists of four exons spanning 20 kilobases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The untranslated first exon is preceded by a G+C-rich promoter region that lacks a consensus TATA or CAAT motif.</Gene>
<Gene>The second exon encodes the hydrophobic leader sequence of the protein, and the third exon encodes the amino-terminal portion of the mature protein.</Gene>
<Gene>The fourth exon encodes the remainder of the mature protein, including the hydrophobic sequence necessary for glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol anchor attachment.</Gene>
<Gene>The structure of the CD59 gene is very similar to that encoding Ly-6, a murine glycoprotein with which CD59 has some structural similarity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The striking similarity in gene structure is further evidence that the two proteins belong to a superfamily of proteins that may also include the urokinase plasminogen-activator receptor and a squid glycoprotein of unknown function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and chromosome mapping of the human interleukin-1 receptor antagonist gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>By screening a human genomic library with an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1ra) cDNA probe, we have isolated a 15 kb clone which contains the entire coding region of the gene as expressed in monocytes, and includes 6 kb of 5'-upstream sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene contains four exons which code for the secreted form of the IL-1ra, however, our clone does not contain the alternative first exon used to generate an intracellular form of the protein as the protein as found in epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of the sequence reveals a consensus TATA box, and three Alu repeats, two of which are in the upstream region and one in intron 3.</Gene>
<Gene>The sequence also reveals an 86 bp motif tandomly repeated four times within intron 2, and may reflect the polymorphism known to exist in this region of the gene.</Gene>
<Gene>By in-situ fluorescence hybridization we have shown that the IL-1ra gene is found on the long arm of chromosome 2 and maps to 2q13-14.1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Previous studies have revealed that IL-1 alpha, and IL-1 beta and both type I and type II forms of the IL-1 receptor all map close to this region of chromosome 2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Aprataxin, the causative protein for EAOH is a nuclear protein with a potential role as a DNA repair protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Early-onset ataxia with ocular motor apraxia and hypoalbuminemia (EAOH) is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by early-onset ataxia, ocular motor apraxia, and hypoalbuminemia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, the causative gene for EAOH, APTX, has been identified.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of the two splicing variants of APTX mRNA, the short and the long forms, long-form APTX mRNA was found to be the major isoform.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Aprataxin is mainly located in the nucleus, and, furthermore, the first nuclear localization signal located near the amino terminus of the long-form aprataxin is essential for its nuclear localization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found, based on the yeast two-hybrid and coimmunoprecipitation experiments, that the long-form but not the short-form aprataxin interacts with XRCC1 (x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly the amino terminus of the long-form aprataxin is homologous with polynucleotidekinase-3'-phosphatase, which has been demonstrated to be involved in base excision repair, a subtype of single-strand DNA break repair, through interaction with XRCC1, DNA polymerase beta, and DNA ligase III.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results strongly support the possibility that aprataxin and XRCC1 constitute a multiprotein complex and are involved in single-strand DNA break repair, and furthermore, that accumulation of unrepaired damaged DNA underlies the pathophysiological mechanisms of EAOH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of APAF-1 expression in human cutaneous melanoma progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>APAF-1 plays a pivotal role in mitochondria-dependent apoptosis, binding to cytochrome c and favoring activation of caspase-9.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It has been shown that epigenetic silencing of the APAF-1 gene is a common event in several metastatic melanoma cells in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We determined, by Western blot, variation in the level of expression of APAF-1 in several human melanoma cell lines and, by immunohistochemistry, in a group of 106 histological samples including benign and malignant melanocytic lesions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed APAF-1 down-regulation or loss of expression in two metastatic melanoma cell lines, compared to primary melanoma cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The immunohistochemical analysis revealed a significant difference in APAF-1 staining between nevi and melanomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we found a significant negative correlation between APAF-1 expression level and tumor thickness and between primary melanomas and metastases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that loss of APAF-1 expression can be considered as an indicator of malignant transformation in melanoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A tissue-specific MAR/SAR DNA-binding protein with unusual binding site recognition.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A human cDNA was cloned that encodes a DNA-binding protein (SATB1) that is expressed predominantly in thymus and binds selectively to the nuclear matrix/scaffold-associating DNAs (MARs/SARs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Missing nucleoside experiments showed that SATB1 selectively binds in a special AT-rich sequence context where one strand consists of mixed A's, T's, and C's, excluding G's (ATC sequences).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>When this feature is destroyed by mutation, SATB1 binding is greatly reduced even if the direct contact sequence remains intact.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Conjunctional SATB1-binding sequences become stably unpaired in supercoiled DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Specific mutations that diminish the unwinding potential greatly reduce SATB1 binding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, SATB1 does not bind single-stranded DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Chemical interference assays show that SATB1 binds along the minor groove with very little contact with the bases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This suggests that SATB1 recognizes the ATC sequence indirectly through the altered sugar-phosphate backbone structure present in the double-stranded DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of a human angiotensin II type 1 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A human liver cDNA library was screened using a rat type 1 angiotensin II receptor cDNA coding sequence as a probe.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cDNA clones were isolated which encoded a protein of 359 amino acids that shared 94.4% and 95.3% identify to rat and bovine type 1 angiotensin II receptors, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ligand binding studies of the cloned receptor expressed in COS cells suggested that it is pharmacologically a type 1 angiotensin II receptor subtype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Electrophysiological studies of the receptor expressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes revealed that it could functionally couple to a second messenger system leading to the mobilization of intracellular stores of calcium.</Gene>

<Gene>Southern and Northern blot analyses indicated that the cloned receptor is represented as a single copy in the human genome and is expressed in many tissues of different histogenic origin with the exception of brain, where mRNA transcripts were barely detectable.</Gene>
<Gene>Cloning, expression and localization of an RNA helicase gene from a human lymphoid cell line with chromosomal breakpoint 11q23.3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A gene encoding a putative human RNA helicase, p54, has been cloned and mapped to the band q23.3 of chromosome 11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted amino acid sequence shares a striking homology (75% identical) with the female germline-specific RNA helicase ME31B gene of Drosophila.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike ME31B, however, the new gene expresses an abundant transcript in a large number of adult tissues and its 5' non-coding region was found split in a t(11;14)(q23.3;q32.3) cell line from a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutually exclusive expression of a helix-loop-helix gene and N-myc in human neuroblastomas and in normal development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a novel human gene encoding a helix-loop-helix (HLH) protein by molecularly cloning chromosome 1p36-specific CpG islands.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene termed heir-1 was localized to the neuroblastoma consensus deletion at 1p36.2-p36.12.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Its predicted protein is 95.8% identical to the mouse HLH462 protein and has clear homology to the mouse Id and Drosophila emc proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Heir-1 does not encode a basic DNA binding domain as found in basic HLH proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene is expressed specifically at high abundance in adult lung, kidney and adrenal medulla, but not in adult brain.</Gene>
<Gene>Despite prominent heir-1 expression in adrenal medulla, which is a prime target for neuroblastomas, 10 out of 12 neuroblastoma-derived cell lines revealed very low levels of heir-1 mRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Low heir-1 expression was generally found in tumor cell lines with N-myc overexpression, whereas the two cell lines displaying high heir-1 levels did not overexpress N-myc.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutually exclusive expression of both genes was also found by in situ hybridization in developing mouse tissues, particularly in the forebrain neuroectoderm.</Gene>

<Gene>We conclude that heir-1 expression is reduced specifically in the majority of neuroblastomas and suggest an inverse correlation between heir-1 and N-myc expression in neuroblastoma tumors and in embryonic development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Primary structure and binding activity of the hnRNP U protein: binding RNA through RGG box.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoproteins (hnRNPs) are thought to influence the structure of hnRNA and participate in the processing of hnRNA to mRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The hnRNP U protein is an abundant nucleoplasmic phosphoprotein that is the largest of the major hnRNP proteins (120 kDa by SDS-PAGE).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HnRNP U binds pre-mRNA in vivo and binds both RNA and ssDNA in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we describe the cloning and sequencing of a cDNA encoding the hnRNP U protein, the determination of its amino acid sequence and the delineation of a region in this protein that confers RNA binding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted amino acid sequence of hnRNP U contains 806 amino acids (88,939 Daltons), and shows no extensive homology to any known proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The N-terminus is rich in acidic residues and the C-terminus is glycine-rich.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, a glutamine-rich stretch, a putative NTP binding site and a putative nuclear localization signal are present.</Gene>
<Gene>It could not be defined from the sequence what segment of the protein confers its RNA binding activity.</Gene>
<Gene>We identified an RNA binding activity within the C-terminal glycine-rich 112 amino acids.</Gene>
<Gene>This region, designated U protein glycine-rich RNA binding region (U-gly), can by itself bind RNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, fusion of U-gly to a heterologous bacterial protein (maltose binding protein) converts this fusion protein into an RNA binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A 26 amino acid peptide within U-gly is necessary for the RNA binding activity of the U protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, this peptide contains a cluster of RGG repeats with characteristic spacing and this motif is found also in several other RNA binding proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have termed this region the RGG box and propose that it is an RNA binding motif and a predictor of RNA binding activity.</Gene>
<Gene>Identification, cloning, and expression of a cytosolic megakaryocyte protein-tyrosine-phosphatase with sequence homology to cytoskeletal protein 4.1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a cDNA encoding a third type of protein-tyrosine-phosphatase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We screened human megakaryoblastic cell line (MEG-01) an umbilical vein endothelial cell cDNA libraries to obtain a 3.7-kilobase cDNA designated PTPase MEG.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis of MEG-01 RNA detected a 3.7-kilobase transcript, suggesting that a full-length cDNA has been identified.</Gene>
<Gene>PTPase MEG cDNA contains an open reading frame of 926 amino acids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA has a G+C-rich 5' untranslated region of 771 nucleotides that has the potential to form stable stem-loop structures and has two upstream ATG codons.</Gene>

<Gene>The predicted protein (Mr = 105,910) has no apparent membrane-spanning region and contains a single protein-tyrosine-phosphatase domain (amino acids 659-909) that is 35-40% identical to previously described tyrosine-phosphatase domains.</Gene>
<Gene>The recombinant phosphatase domain possesses protein-tyrosine-phosphatase activity when expressed in Escherichia coli.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The amino-terminal region (amino acids 31-367) is 45% identical to the amino terminus of human erythrocyte protein 4.1, a cytoskeletal protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The identification of a protein-tyrosine-phosphatase that is related to cytoskeletal proteins implies that cell signaling activities reside not only in transmembrane receptors but in cytoskeletal elements as well.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The receptor for ciliary neurotrophic factor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although neurotrophic factors were originally isolated on the basis of their ability to support the survival of neurons, these molecules are now thought to influence many aspects of the development and maintenance of the nervous system.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identifying the receptors for these neurotrophic factors should aid in identifying the cells on which these factors act and in understanding their precise mechanisms of action.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A " tagged-ligand panning " procedure was used to clone a receptor for ciliary neurotrophic factor (CNTF).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This receptor is expressed exclusively within the nervous system and skeletal muscle.</Gene>

<Gene>The CNTF receptor has a structure unrelated to the receptors utilized by the nerve growth factor family of neurotrophic molecules, but instead is most homologous to the receptor for a cytokine, interleukin-6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This similarity suggestes that the CNTF receptor, like the interleukin-6 receptor, requires a second, signal-transducing component.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast to all known receptors, the CNTF receptor is anchored to cell membranes by a glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol linkage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A direct repeat in the cellular retinol-binding protein type II gene confers differential regulation by RXR and RAR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The vitamin A derivative retinoic acid exerts its effects on transcription through two distinct classes of nuclear receptors, the retinoic acid receptor (RAR) and the retinoid X receptor (RXR).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We provide evidence that expression of the gene for cellular retinol-binding protein type II (CRBPII), a key protein in the intestinal absorption of vitamin A, is dramatically up-regulated by retinoic acid in the presence of RXR but not RAR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This regulation is conferred through a specific cis element in the CRBPII promoter that contains five nearly perfect tandem repeats of the sequence AGGTCA spaced by a single nucleotide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The discovery of this new RX response element provides a means for distinguishing between the two retinoid receptor systems and suggests that an RXR-mediated pathway exists for modulating vitamin A metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning, expression and chromosomal localization of a new putative receptor-like protein tyrosine phosphatase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a mouse cDNA of 5.7 kb, encoding a new member of the family of receptor-like protein tyrosine phosphatases, termed mRPTP mu.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA predicts a protein of 1432 amino acids (not including signal peptide) with a calculated Mr of 161,636.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, we have cloned the human homologue, hRPTP mu, which shows 98.7% amino acid identity to mRPTP mu.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted mRPTP mu protein consists of a 722 amino acid extracellular region, containing 13 potential N-glycosylation sites, a single transmembrane domain and a 688 amino acid intracellular part containing 2 tandem repeats homologous to the catalytic domains of other tyrosine phosphatases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The N-terminal extracellular part contains a region of about 170 amino acids with no sequence similarities to known proteins, followed by one Ig-like domain and 4 fibronectin type III-like domains.</Gene>

<Gene>The intracellular part is unique in that the region between the transmembrane domain and the first catalytic domain is about twice as large as in other receptor-like protein tyrosine phosphatases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RNA blot analysis reveals a single transcript, that is most abundant in lung and present in much lower amounts in brain and heart.</Gene>
<Gene>Transfection of the mRPTP mu cDNA into COS cells results in the synthesis of a protein with an apparent Mr of 195,000, as detected in immunoblots using an antipeptide antibody.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human RPTP mu gene is localized on chromosome 18pter-q11, a region with frequent abnormalities implicated in human cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Coexpression of two distinct genes is required to generate secreted bioactive cytotoxic lymphocyte maturation factor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cytotoxic lymphocyte maturation factor (CLMF) is a disulfide-bonded heterodimeric lymphokine that (i) acts as a growth factor for activated T cells independent of interleukin 2 and (ii) synergizes with suboptimal concentrations of interleukin 2 to induce lymphokine-activated killer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We now report the cloning and expression of both human CLMF subunit cDNAs from a lymphoblastoid B-cell line, NC-37.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The two subunits represent two distinct and unrelated gene products whose mRNAs are coordinately induced upon activation of NC-37 cells.</Gene>

<Gene>Coexpression of the two subunit cDNAs in COS cells is necessary for the secretion of biologically active CLMF; COS cells transfected with either subunit cDNA alone do not secrete bioactive CLMF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recombinant CLMF expressed in mammalian cells displays biologic activities essentially identical to natural CLMF, and its activities can be neutralized by monoclonal antibodies prepared against natural CLMF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since this heterodimeric protein displays the properties of an interleukin, we propose that CLMF be given the designation interleukin 12.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Structure, expression, and genetic linkage of the mouse BCM1 (OX45 or Blast-1) antigen. Evidence for genetic duplication giving rise to the BCM1 region on mouse chromosome 1 and the CD2/LFA3 region on mouse chromosome 3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The mouse BCM1 (OX45, Blast-1) antigen has been cDNA cloned and sequenced to provide data supporting the view that BCM1, LFA3, and CD2 constitute a subgroup within the Ig superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mouse BCM1 is widely expressed on leukocytes and is likely to be anchored to the cell surface by a glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol anchor, as is the case for rat and human BCM1 antigen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic linkage studies by recombination and pulse field analysis showed the BCM1 locus (Bcm-1) to be on distal mouse chromosome 1 and to be linked within 1,600 kb to the locus for an ATPase alpha chain gene (Atpa-3).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A similar relationship was established between the human BCM1 locus (BCM1) and ATP1A2, and other markers on chromosome 1q.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conservation of genomic organization within a segment of human chromosome 1q and mouse chromosome 1 was demonstrated.</Gene>
<Gene>A similar situation is seen in the region of the CD2 and LFA3 genes between mouse chromosome 3 and human chromosome 1p.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the CD2/LFA3 genes are linked within 580 kb to Atpa-1/ATP1A1 genes to provide a parallel situation to the linkage between Bcm-1/BCM1 and Atpa-3/ATP1A2 on chromosomes 1 (mouse) and 1q (human).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, the data suggest duplication of a chromosome region including the precursors of the genes for BCM1, CD2, and LFA3, and the ATPase genes to give rise to the linkage groups now observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The duplicated regions may have stayed together on chromosome 1 in the human (with the insertion of a centromere), while in the mouse, the genetic regions are proposed to have become dispersed in the formation of chromosomes 1 and 3.</Gene>

<Gene>CD2 and LFA3 are more dissimilar in sequence than BCM1 and LFA3, and if the precursors of the CD2 and LFA3 loci formed before the proposed chromosome segment duplication, then a gene encoding a recognizer molecule for BCM1 may exist in linkage with Bcm-1/BCM1 on chromosome 1 (mouse) and 1q (human).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Soluble forms of tumor necrosis factor receptors (TNF-Rs). The cDNA for the type I TNF-R, cloned using amino acid sequence data of its soluble form, encodes both the cell surface and a soluble form of the receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two proteins which specifically bind tumor necrosis factor (TNF) have recently been isolated from human urine in our laboratory.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The two proteins cross-react immunologically with two species of cell surface TNF receptors (TNF-R).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Antibodies against one of the two TNF binding proteins (TBPI) were found to have effects characteristic of TNF, including stimulating phosphorylation of specific cellular proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oligonucleotide probes designed on the basis of the NH2-terminal amino acid sequence of TBPI were used to clone the cDNA for the structurally related cell surface type 1 TNF-R.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is notable that although this receptor can signal the phosphorylation of cellular proteins, it appears from its amino acid sequence to be devoid of intrinsic protein kinase activity.</Gene>

<Gene>The extracellular domain of the receptor is composed of four internal cysteine-rich repeats, homologous to structures repeated four times in the extracellular domains of the nerve growth factor receptor and the B lymphocytes surface antigen CDw40.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The amino acid composition and size of the extracellular domain of the type I TNF-R closely resemble those of TBPI.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The COOH-terminal amino acid sequence of the four cysteine rich repeats within the extracellular domain of the type I TNF-R matches the COOH-terminal sequence of TBPI.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Amino acid sequences in the extracellular domain also fully match other sequences found in TBPI.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>On the other hand, amino acid sequences in the soluble form of the type II TNF-R (TBPII), while indicating a marked homology of structure, did not suggest any identity between this protein and the extracellular domain of the type I TNF-R. CHO cells transfected with type I TNF-R cDNA produced both cell surface and soluble forms of the receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The receptor produced by CHO cells was recognized by several monoclonal antibodies against TBPI, reacting with several distinct epitopes in this molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that the soluble forms of the TNF-Rs are structurally identical to the extracellular cytokine binding domains of these receptors and are consistent with the notion that the soluble forms are, at least partly, derived from the same transcripts that encode the cell surface receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel secretory tumor necrosis factor-inducible protein (TSG-6) is a member of the family of hyaluronate binding proteins, closely related to the adhesion receptor CD44.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TSG-6 cDNA was isolated by differential screening of a lambda cDNA library prepared from tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-treated human diploid FS-4 fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that TSG-6 mRNA was not detectable in untreated cells, but became readily induced by TNF in normal human fibroblast lines and in peripheral blood mononuclear cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, TSG-6 mRNA was undetectable in either control or TNF-treated human vascular endothelial cells and a variety of tumor-derived or virus-transformed cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The sequence of full-length TSG-6 cDNA revealed one major open reading frame predicting a polypeptide of 277 amino acids, including a typical cleavable signal peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The NH2-terminal half of the predicted TSG-6 protein sequence shows a significant homology with a region implicated in hyaluronate binding, present in cartilage link protein, proteoglycan core proteins, and the adhesion receptor CD44.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The most extensive sequence homology exists between the predicted TSG-6 protein and CD44.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot analysis with an antiserum raised against a TSG-6 fusion protein detected a 39-kD glycoprotein in the supernatants of TNF-treated FS-4 cells and of cells transfected with TSG-6 cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Binding of the TSG-6 protein to hyaluronate was demonstrated by coprecipitation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data indicate that the inflammatory cytokine (TNF or IL-1)-inducible, secretory TSG-6 protein is a novel member of the family of hyaluronate binding proteins, possibly involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions during inflammation and tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and antisense oligodeoxynucleotide inhibition of a human homolog of cdc2 required in hematopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanisms triggering the commitment of pluripotent bone marrow stem cells to differentiated lineages such as mononuclear macrophages or multinucleated megakaryocytes are still unknown, although several lines of evidence suggested correlation between cholinergic signaling and hematopoietic differentiation.</Gene>

<Gene>We now present cloning of a cDNA coding for CHED (cholinesterase-related cell division controller), a human homolog of the Schizosaccharomyces pombe cell division cycle 2 (cdc2)-like kinases, universal controllers of the mitotic cell cycle.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Library screening, RNA blot hybridization, and direct PCR amplification of cDNA reverse-transcribed from cellular mRNA revealed that CHED mRNA is expressed in multiple tissues, including bone marrow.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CHED protein includes the consensus ATP binding and phosphorylation domains characteristic of kinases, displays 34-42% identically aligned amino acid residues with other cdc2-related kinases, and is considerably longer at its amino and carboxyl termini.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An antisense oligodeoxynucleotide designed to interrupt CHED's expression (AS-CHED) significantly reduced the ratio between CHED mRNA and actin mRNA within 1 hr of its addition to cultures, a reduction that persisted for 4 days.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AS-CHED treatment selectively inhibited megakaryocyte development in murine bone marrow cultures but did not prevent other hematopoietic pathways, as evidenced by increasing numbers of mononuclear cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An oligodeoxynucleotide blocking production of the acetylcholine-hydrolyzing enzyme, butyrylcholinesterase, displayed a similar inhibition of megakaryocytopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, an oligodeoxynucleotide blocking production of the human 2Hs cdc2 homolog interfered with production of the human 2Hs cdc2 homolog interfered with cellular proliferation without altering the cell-type composition of these cultures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, these findings strengthen the link between cholinergic signaling and cell division control in hematopoiesis and implicate both CHED and cholinesterases in this differentiation process.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Structural analysis and expression of human desmoglein: a cadherin-like component of the desmosome.</Gene>
<Gene>Desmosomes are adhesive cell junctions found in great abundance in tissues that experience mechanical stress.</Gene>
<Gene>The transmembrane desmosomal glycoproteins have been proposed to play a role in cell adhesion; desmoglein I (DGI) is a major member of this class of desmosomal molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, evidence supporting a role for DGI in cell adhesion or in the plaque is lacking.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In order to begin to understand DGI function we have identified human cDNA clones encoding the entire mature polypeptide of 1000 amino acids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that like the bovine DGI molecule human DGI is highly related to the calcium-dependent class of cell adhesion molecules known as cadherins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Four related extracellular domains located in the amino-terminal domain of the molecule contain putative calcium binding sites originally identified in the cadherins.</Gene>
<Gene>The highest degree of similarity between human N-cadherin and human DGI, and likewise between bovine DGI and human DGI, is greatest in the most amino-terminal extracellular domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This suggests a conserved functional role for the extracellular domains, perhaps in calcium-mediated cell adhesion.</Gene>

<Gene>The cytoplasmic portion of the molecule contains a cadherin-like region and, like bovine DGI, a carboxy-terminal tail that is not present in the cadherins, comprising three additional domains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One of these contains a novel repeating motif of 29 +/- 1 residues, first identified in bovine DGI.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Each of the highly homologous repeating units is likely to consist of two beta-strands and two turns with special characteristics.</Gene>

<Gene>Five amino acids that are identical in bovine and human DGI lie in the second of the two predicted beta-strands, and intriguingly contain putative target sites for protein kinase C. On the basis of structural analysis, a model predicting the disposition of human DGI domains in the desmosome is proposed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern analysis suggests that unlike bovine epidermis, which expresses a single mRNA of reported size approximately 7.6 kb, human foreskin and cultured keratinocytes display a complex pattern with bands of approximately 7.2, 4.0 and 3.0 kb.</Gene>
<Gene>Each of these cross-hybridizing mRNAs is coordinately expressed in normal human keratinocytes in response to long-term culture and increased calcium.</Gene>
<Gene>Characterization of human loricrin. Structure and function of a new class of epidermal cell envelope proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated and characterized a full-length cDNA clone encoding human loricrin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Curiously, this protein displays major differences from the recently described mouse loricrin (Mehrel, T., Hohl, D., Nakazawa, H., Rothnagel, J.A., Longley, M.A., Bundman, D., Cheng, C.K., Lichti, U., Bisher, M.E., Steven, A. C., Steinert, P.M., Yuspa, S.H., and Roop, D.R. (1990) Cell 61, 1103-1112).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although both proteins are glycine-serine-cysteine-rich, the sequences have not been conserved.</Gene>

<Gene>However, analysis of the sequences reveals a common motif of quasi-peptide repeats of an aliphatic or aromatic amino acid residue followed by several glycine and/or serine and cysteine residues.</Gene>
<Gene>These sequences are interspersed and flanked by short glutamine- or glutamine/lysine-rich peptides.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus loricrins consist of a family of cell envelope proteins of highly variable sequences that nevertheless retain common structural elements.</Gene>
<Gene>We show that unlike all other putative protein components of the cell envelope, loricrins are highly insoluble, due at least in part to cross-linking by disulfide bonds.</Gene>

<Gene>Furthermore, we have isolated four peptides from purified human cell envelopes that contain recognizable loricrin sequences and which are cross-linked by the N epsilon-(gamma-glutamyl)lysine isodipeptide bond.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The presence of such bonds thus affords an explanation for the extraordinary insolubility of loricrin by cross-linking to the cell envelope and can also explain the low steady-state levels of monomeric loricrin in cytoskeletal extracts of epidermis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study represents the first report of this isodipeptide cross-link in a protein component of the cornified cell envelope.</Gene>

<Gene>We propose a model for the structure of loricrin in which (i) the unusual glycine-serine-rich sequences adopt a flexible loop conformation, indexed on the recurrent aliphatic residues; (ii) inter- or intramolecular isodipeptide and disulfide cross-links induce or stabilize folding of loricrin so as to form a more compact rosette-like structure; and (iii) the presence of the flexible glycine-rich loops necessarily will impact a flexible character to the cell envelope and entire epithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression cloning of a cocaine- and antidepressant-sensitive human noradrenaline transporter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>At most synapses, chemical signalling is terminated by a rapid reaccumulation of neurotransmitter into presynaptic terminals.</Gene>
<Gene>Uptake systems for the biogenic amines are the initial site of action for therapeutic antidepressants and drugs such as cocaine and the amphetamines.</Gene>
<Gene>We have isolated a complementary DNA clone encoding a human noradrenaline transporter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA sequence predicts a protein of 617 amino acids, with 12-13 highly hydrophobic regions compatible with membrane-spanning domains.</Gene>
<Gene>Expression of the cDNA clone in transfected HeLa cells indicates that noradrenaline transport activity is sodium-dependent and sensitive to selective noradrenaline transport inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transporter RNA is localized to the brainstem and the adrenal gland.</Gene>

<Gene>The predicted protein sequence demonstrates significant amino-acid identity with the Na+/gamma-aminobutyric acid transporter, thus identifying a new gene family for neurotransmitter transporter proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of its structure and function may lead to structure-based drug design for the treatment of human depression and could help determine whether transporter abnormalities underlie affective disorders.</Gene>
<Gene>Localization of low molecular weight GTP binding proteins to exocytic and endocytic compartments.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A set of 11 clones encoding putative GTP binding proteins highly homologous to the yeast YPT1/SEC4 gene products have been isolated from an MDCK cell cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We localized three of the corresponding proteins in mammalian cells by using affinity-purified antibodies in immunofluorescence and immunoelectron microscopy studies.</Gene>
<Gene>One, the MDCK homolog of rab2, is associated with a structure having the characteristics of an intermediate compartment between the endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi apparatus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The second, rab5, is located at the cytoplasmic surface of the plasma membrane and on early endosomes, while the third, rab7, is found on late endosomes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide evidence that members of the YPT1/SEC4 subfamily of GTP binding proteins are localized to specific exocytic and endocytic subcompartments in mammalian cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A human homologue of the yeast HDEL receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Retention of resident proteins in the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum is achieved in both yeast and animal cells by their continual retrieval from the cis-Golgi, or a pre-Golgi compartment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sorting of these proteins is dependent on a C-terminal tetrapeptide signal, usually Lys-Asp-Glu-Leu (KDEL in the single letter code) in animal cells, His-Asp-Glu-Leu (HDEL) in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Gene>

<Gene>There is evidence that the ERD2 gene encodes the sorting receptor that recognizes HDEL in yeast; its product is an integral membrane protein of relative molecular mass 26,000 (26K) that is not glycosylated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, Vaux et al. suggest that the mammalian KDEL receptor is a 72K glycoprotein that they detected using an anti-idiotypic antibody approach.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>If this were so, it would indicate a surprising divergence of the retrieval machinery between yeast and animal cells.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Using probes based on the rat sequence, partial and full-length cDNA and genomic clones of human SCF have been isolated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Based on the primary structure of the 164 amino acid protein purified from BRL-3A cells, truncated forms of the rat and human proteins have been expressed in E. coli and mammalian cells and have been shown to possess biological activity.</Gene>
<Gene>SCF is able to augment the proliferation of both myeloid and lymphoid hematopoietic progenitors in bone marrow cultures.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Isolation and characterization of cDNA encoding a human nuclear antigen predominantly recognized by autoantibodies from patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.</Gene>

<Gene>Autoantibodies to a novel nuclear Ag, Sp100, have recently been described that recognize a nuclear protein with an apparent molecular mass of 95 to 100 kDa and a dot-like distribution within cell nuclei.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>By immunoscreening of a lambda gt11 cDNA expression library derived from HeLa cells with an anti-Sp100 autoimmune serum a 0.7-kb cDNA (Sp26) coding for a fragment of Sp100 was isolated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of this cDNA and use of the recombinant protein in ELISA revealed that the fragment carries major Sp100 autoepitopes and that anti-Sp100 autoantibodies predominantly occur in patients suffering from primary biliary cirrhosis (50/184).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Sp26 cDNA was used as hybridization probe for isolation of longer cDNA from human liver- and placenta-derived lambda gt10 cDNA libraries.</Gene>
<Gene>Overlapping fragments were assembled to generate a full length cDNA coding for a protein with a molecular mass of 53 kDa and an isoelectric point of 4.7.</Gene>

<Gene>The Sp100 autoantigen expressed in vitro from this cDNA and authenticated by a capture immunoblot assay, comigrated in SDS-PAGE with the authentic HeLa autoantigen of 95 to 100 kDa and thus showed an aberrant electrophoretic mobility.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Computer based protein sequence analysis of the Sp100 autoantigen revealed regions of striking sequence similarities to the alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains of various human and non-human MHC class I Ag and to several transacting transcriptional regulatory proteins.</Gene>

text: <Gene>IgA, the predominant isotype in secretions, mediates the neutralization and removal of environmental antigens from mucosal sites.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although cell surface receptors for the Fc region of IgA (Fc alpha R) have been implicated in a variety of immune effector mechanisms, the molecular features of Fc alpha R remain only marginally characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this report, we describe the isolation of a clone from a myeloid cell line cDNA library that directs the expression of a cell surface molecule with IgA binding specificity.</Gene>

text: <Gene>The cDNA encodes a peptide of Mr 30,000 including a putative transmembrane region with features atypical of conventional membrane-anchored proteins.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Databank searches indicate that the human myeloid cell Fc alpha R sequence is unique, is a member of the immunoglobulin gene superfamily, and is related to Fc receptors for IgG (Fc gamma RI, II, and III) and IgE (Fc epsilon RI).</Gene>

text: <Gene>The cDNA encoding human ferrochelatase [EC 4.99.1.1] was isolated from a human placenta cDNA library in bacteriophage lambda gt11 by screening with a radiolabeled fragment of mouse ferrochelatase cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA had an open reading frame of 1269 base pairs (bp) encoding a protein of 423 amino acid residues (Mr. 47,833) with alternative putative polyadenylation signals in the 3' non-coding regions and poly (A) tails.</Gene>
<Gene>Amino acid sequencing showed that the mature protein consists of 369 amino acid residues (Mr. 42,158) with a putative leader sequence of 54 amino acid residues.</Gene>

<Gene>Northern blot analysis showed two mRNAs of about 2500 and 1600 bp for ferrochelatase in K562 and HepG2 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>As full-length cDNA for human ferrochelatase is now available, molecular lesions related to erythropoietic protoporphyria can be characterized.</Gene>

text: <Gene>The human milk lipase cDNA is highly homologous to rat pancreatic cholesterol esterase, suggesting that the milk lipase may be identical to the cholesterol esterase in human pancreas.</Gene>

<Gene>Maple syrup urine disease. Complete primary structure of the E1 beta subunit of human branched chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deduced from the nucleotide sequence and a gene analysis of patients with this disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A defect in the E1 beta subunit of the branched chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH) complex is one cause of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In an attempt to elucidate the molecular basis of MSUD, we isolated and characterized a 1.35 kbp cDNA clone encoding the entire precursor of the E1 beta subunit of BCKDH complex from a human placental cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nucleotide sequence analysis revealed that the isolated cDNA clone (lambda hBE1 beta-1) contained a 5'-untranslated sequence of four nucleotides, the translated sequence of 1,176 nucleotides and the 3'-untranslated sequence of 169 nucleotides.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Comparison of the amino acid sequence predicted from the nucleotide sequence of the cDNA insert of the clone with the NH2-terminal amino acid sequence of the purified mature bovine BCKDH-E1 beta subunit showed that the cDNA insert encodes for a 342-amino acid subunit with a Mr = 37,585.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The subunit is synthesized as the precursor with a leader sequence of 50 amino acids and is processed at the NH2 terminus.</Gene>

<Gene>A search for protein homology revealed that the primary structure of human BCKDH-E1 beta was similar to the bovine BCKDH-E1 beta and to the E1 beta subunit of human pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, in all regions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The structures and functions of mammalian alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complexes are apparently highly conserved.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genomic DNA from lymphoblastoid cell lines derived from normal and five MSUD patients, in whom E1 beta was not detected by immunoblot analysis, gave the same restriction maps on Southern blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The gene has at least 80 kbp.</Gene>
<Gene>Sequence and expression of a human type II mesothelial keratin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using mRNA from cultured human mesothelial cells, we constructed bacterial plasmids and lambda phage vectors that contained cDNA sequences specific for the keratins expressed in these cells.</Gene>
<Gene>A cloned cDNA encoding keratin K7 (55 kD) was identified by positive hybrid selection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Southern Blot analysis indicated that this sequence is represented only once in the human genome, and Northern Blot analysis demonstrated that the gene encoding K7 is expressed in abundance in cultured bronchial and mesothelial cells, but only weakly in cultured epidermal cells and not at all in liver, colon, or exocervical tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted amino acid sequence of this keratin has revealed a striking difference between this keratin and the type II keratins expressed in epidermal cells: whereas all of the epidermal type II keratins thus far sequenced have long nonhelical termini rich in glycine and serine, this mesothelial type II keratin has amino and carboxy terminal regions that are unusually short and lack the inexact repeats of glycine and serine residues.</Gene>
label: Gene
