text: <Gene>Primary structure of the human melanoma-associated antigen p97 (melanotransferrin) deduced from the mRNA sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>p97 is a cell-surface glycoprotein that is present in most human melanomas but only in trace amounts in normal adult tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To determine the structure of this tumor-associated antigen and to identify its functional domains, we have purified and cloned p97 mRNA and determined its nucleotide sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mRNA encodes a 738-residue precursor, which contains the previously determined N-terminal amino acid sequence of p97.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>After removal of a 19-residue signal peptide, the mature p97 molecule comprises extracellular domains of 342 and 352 residues and a C-terminal 25-residue stretch of predominantly uncharged and hydrophobic amino acids, which we believe acts as a membrane anchor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Each extracellular domain contains 14 cysteine residues, which form seven intradomain disulfide bridges, and one or two potential N-glycosylation sites.</Gene>
<Gene>Protease digestion studies show that the three major antigenic determinants of p97 are present on the N-terminal domain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The domains are strikingly homologous to each other (46% amino acid sequence homology) and to the corresponding domains of human serum transferrin (39% homology).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Conservation of disulfide bridges and of amino acids thought to compose the iron binding pockets suggests that p97 is also related to transferrin in tertiary structure and function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We propose that p97 be renamed melanotransferrin to denote its original identification in melanoma cells and its evolutionary relationship to serotransferrin and lactotransferrin, the other members of the transferrin superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation and sequence of a cDNA clone for human calcineurin B, the Ca2+-binding subunit of the Ca2+/calmodulin-stimulated protein phosphatase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have identified and cloned human cDNA for the Ca2+-binding subunit of calcineurin, the brain isozyme of the Ca2+/calmodulin-stimulated protein phosphatase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 2.5-kb cDNA has an open reading frame of 510 bp, a leader sequence of at least 500 bp, and a 1,277-bp 3'-noncoding sequence.</Gene>
<Gene>The deduced sequence of the human protein differs from bovine brain calcineurin B by an additional valine at the carboxyl terminus and substitution of Met-11 and Ser-153 by cysteine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A partial clone of the mouse protein corresponding to amino acids 75-150 was also isolated.</Gene>
<Gene>This portion of the human and mouse protein sequence is identical, with the DNA sequences showing 94% identity.</Gene>
<Gene>The respective mRNAs in human and mouse are also of similar size.</Gene>

<Gene>As was observed with protein levels, mRNA abundance in brain is 20-60 times that found in other tissues with the exception of HeLa cells which, like brain, contain abundant calcineurin B mRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human liver serine dehydratase. cDNA cloning and sequence homology with hydroxyamino acid dehydratases from other sources.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rat liver serine dehydratase cDNA was used to screen a human liver cDNA library in lambda gt11.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One positive clone occurred in every 5,000 clones.</Gene>
<Gene>Fifteen positive clones were plaque purified.</Gene>
<Gene>The largest cDNA obtained contained an open reading frame of 987 base pairs, and 5' and 3' noncoding regions of 89 and 317 base pairs, respectively.</Gene>

<Gene>The deduced amino acid sequence, with a calculated Mr of 34,615, was similar to that of rat liver serine dehydratase except for the absence of a segment consisting of 36 amino acid residues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro transcription/translation with the cDNA resulted in the formation of a polypeptide with an Mr of approximately 35,000, which cross-reacted with the anti-rat serine dehydratase antibody.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that the human serine dehydratase is structurally cognate with the rat enzyme.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, portions of the sequence postulated to be essential for activity in microbial threonine dehydratases are found in the mammalian serine dehydratases, suggesting that hydroxyamino and dehydratases may have originated from a common ancestor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>rac, a novel ras-related family of proteins that are botulinum toxin substrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A new family of ras-related proteins, designated rac (ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate) has been identified.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>rac1 and rac2 cDNA clones were isolated from a differentiated HL-60 library and encode proteins that are 92% homologous and share 58% and 26-30% amino acid homology with human rhos and ras, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nucleotide sequence analysis predicts both rac1 and rac2 proteins to contain 192 amino acids with molecular masses of 21,450 and 21,429 daltons, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>rac1 and rac2 possess four of the five conserved functional domains in ras associated with binding and hydrolysis of guanine nucleotides.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>They also contain the COOH-terminal consensus sequence Cys-X-X-X-COOH which localizes ras to the inner plasma membrane and the residues Gly12 and Ala59, at which sites mutations elicit transforming potential to ras.</Gene>
<Gene>The rac transcripts, particularly rac2, display relative myeloid tissue selectivity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both rac1 transcripts (2.4 and 1.1 kilobases (kb] increase when HL-60 cells differentiate to neutrophil-like morphology.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, differentiation of U937 cells to monocyte-like morphology causes no change in the 2.4-kb mRNA and a decrease in the 1.1-kb mRNA species.</Gene>
<Gene>rac2 mRNA (1.45 kb) increases 7-9-fold and 3-fold upon differentiation of HL-60 and U937 cells, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Neither rac mRNAs are present in a Jurkat T cell line, and unlike rac1, rac2 mRNA is absent in human brain and liver tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transfection experiments permitted the demonstration that rac1 and rac2 are substrates for ADP-ribosylation by the C3 component of botulinum toxin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The data suggest that racs are plasma membrane-associated GTP-binding proteins which could regulate secretory processes, particularly in myeloid cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human gastric cathepsin E. Predicted sequence, localization to chromosome 1, and sequence homology with other aspartic proteinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted sequence of human gastric cathepsin E (CTSE) was determined by analysis of cDNA clones isolated from a library constructed with poly(A+) RNA from a gastric adenocarcinoma cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The CTSE cDNA clones were identified using a set of complementary 18-base oligonucleotide probes specific for a 6-residue sequence surrounding the first active site of all previously characterized human aspartic proteinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis of CTSE cDNA clones revealed a 1188-base pair open reading frame that exhibited 59% sequence identity with human pepsinogen A.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted CTSE amino acid sequence includes a 379-residue proenzyme (Mr = 40,883) and a 17-residue signal peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted CTSE amino acid composition was consistent with that of purified material from gastric mucosa and gastric adenocarcinoma cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Additional evidence for the identification of the CTSE cDNA clones was obtained by analysis of poly(A+) RNA isolated from CTSE-producing and -nonproducing gastric adenocarcinoma cell subclones.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Three RNA transcripts (3.6, 2.6, and 2.1 kilobases) were identified in poly(A+) RNA isolated from a gastric adenocarcinoma cell line that produced CTSE that were absent from nonproducing subclones.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CTSE contains 7 cysteine residues, of which 6 were localized by comparative maximal alignment analysis with pepsinogen A to conserved residues that form intrachain disulfide bonds.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The seventh cysteine residue of CTSE is located within the activation peptide region of the proenzyme.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We suspect that this residue forms an interchain disulfide bond and thereby determines the dimerization of CTSE proenzyme molecules that is observed under native conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CTSE gene was localized to human chromosome 1 by concurrent cytogenetic and cDNA probe analyses of a panel of human x mouse somatic cell hybrids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Homology between a region of the human retinoblastoma gene and L1 family repetitive sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Five clones that hybridized weakly with the human retinoblastoma (Rb) gene were obtained by screening a human genomic library in a non-stringent condition.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The DNAs of two of these clones were partially sequenced and found to contain a region with considerable homology to part of the Rb gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These two clones were found to contain L1 family repeating sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This finding is discussed in relation with possible functions of the L1 family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>As the L1 family is transposable, the Rb gene may be inactivated by recombination at this homologous region.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Another possibility related with the DNA binding properties of Rb and L1 family proteins is also discussed.</Gene>

text: <Gene>COUP transcription factor is a member of the steroid receptor superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The COUP (chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter) transcription factor (COUP-TF) exists in a number of different tissues and is essential for expression of the chicken ovalbumin gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It binds to the ovalbumin promoter and, in conjunction with a second protein (S300-II), stimulates initiation of transcription in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>COUP-TF also binds specifically to the rat insulin promoter element, although the two binding sites share little sequence similarity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report the isolation of a human complementary DNA clone encoding COUP-TF.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Comparison of the amino-acid sequence of COUP-TF with known sequences reveals that it is a member of the steroid/thyroid hormone/vitamin receptor superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consequently, it is the first member of this family that has been shown to function in a cell-free transcription system.</Gene>
<Gene>We conclude that this superfamily of gene regulators contains proteins which bind and activate distal promoter elements of eukaryotic genes.</Gene>
<Gene>Interleukin-2 receptor beta chain gene: generation of three receptor forms by cloned human alpha and beta chain cDNA's.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interleukin-2 (IL-2) binds to two distinct receptor molecules, the IL-2 receptor alpha (IL-2R alpha, p55) chain and the newly identified IL-2 receptor beta (IL-2R beta, p70-75) chain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA encoding the human IL-2R beta chain has now been isolated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The overall primary structure of the IL-2R beta chain shows no apparent homology to other known receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike the IL-2R alpha chain, the IL-2R beta chain has a large cytoplasmic region in which a functional domain (or domains) mediating an intracellular signal transduction pathway (or pathways) may be embodied.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA-encoded beta chain binds and internalizes IL-2 when expressed on T lymphoid cells but not fibroblast cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the cDNA gives rise to the generation of high-affinity IL-2 receptor when co-expressed with the IL-2R alpha chain cDNA.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Autoimmune target in Heymann nephritis is a glycoprotein with homology to the LDL receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The pathogenesis of Heymann nephritis, a rat model of human membranous glomerulonephritis, depends on the interaction of autoantibodies with a renal glycoprotein (GP330) on glomerular podocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Partial complementary DNAs coding for GP330 were isolated and sequenced.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced amino acid sequence from 4.3 kilobases of complementary DNA contains the sequences identical to two peptides derived from the isolated glycoprotein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced amino acid sequence of this protein contains regions with homology to the human low density lipoprotein (LDL) receptor, an indication that GP330 and the LDL receptor may be members of the same gene family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Autoantibodies from the kidneys of rats with Heymann nephritis reacted with a nonglycosylated segment of GP330 that contains cysteine-rich 40-amino acid repeats, which are also features of the LDL receptor.</Gene>

text: <Gene>GP330 is also similar in some regions to the mouse epidermal growth factor precursor.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Human mRNA polyadenylate binding protein: evolutionary conservation of a nucleic acid binding motif.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a full length cDNA (cDNA) coding for the human poly(A) binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA derived 73 kd basic translation product has the same Mr, isoelectric point and peptidic map as the poly(A) binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DNA sequence analysis reveals a 70,244 dalton protein.</Gene>
<Gene>The N terminal part, highly homologous to the yeast poly(A) binding protein, is sufficient for poly(A) binding activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This domain consists of a four-fold repeated unit of approximately 80 amino acids present in other nucleic acid binding proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the C terminal part there is, as in the yeast protein, a sequence of approximately 150 amino acids, rich in proline, alanine and glutamine which together account for 48% of the residues.</Gene>
<Gene>A 2,9 kb mRNA corresponding to this cDNA has been detected in several vertebrate cell types and in Drosophila melanogaster at every developmental stage including oogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>Two human homeobox genes, c1 and c8: structure analysis and expression in embryonic development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two human cDNA clones (HHO.c1.95 and HHO.c8.5111) containing a homeobox region have been characterized, and the respective genomic regions have been partially analyzed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of the corresponding genes, termed c1 and c8, was evaluated in different organs and body parts during human embryonic/fetal development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HHO.c1.95 apparently encodes a 217-amino acid protein containing a class I homeodomain that shares 60 out of 61 amino acid residues with the Antennapedia homeodomain of Drosophila melanogaster.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HHO.c8.5111 encodes a 153-amino acid protein containing a homeodomain identical to that of the frog AC1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Clones HHO.c1 and HHO.c8 detect by blot-hydridization one and two specific polyadenylylated transcripts, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These are differentially expressed in spinal cord, backbone rudiments, limb buds (or limbs), heart, and skin of human embryos and early fetuses in the 5- to 9-week postfertilization period, thus suggesting that the c1 and c8 genes play a key role in a variety of developmental processes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, the results of the embryonic/fetal expression of c1 and c8 and those of two previously analyzed genes (c10 and c13) indicate a coherent pattern of expression of these genes in early human ontogeny.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Studies of the human c-myb gene and its product in human acute leukemias.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The myb gene is the transforming oncogene of the avian myeloblastosis virus (AMV); its normal cellular homolog, c-myb, is conserved across a broad span of evolution.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In humans, c-myb is expressed in malignant hematopoietic cell lines and in primary hematopoietic tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Partial complementary DNA clones were generated from blast cells of patients with acute myelogenous leukemia.</Gene>
<Gene>The sequences of the clones were compared to the c-myb of other species, as well as the v-myb of AMV.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the carboxyl terminal region of human c-myb was placed in an expression vector to obtain protein for the generation of antiserum, which was used to identify the human c-myb gene product.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Like v-myb, this protein was found within the nucleus of leukemic cells where it was associated with the nuclear matrix.</Gene>

text: <Gene>These studies provide further evidence that c-myb might be involved in human leukemia.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Human creatine kinase: isolation and sequence analysis of cDNA clones for the B subunit, development of subunit specific probes and determination of gene copy number.</Gene>

text: <Gene>cDNA clones for human B creatine kinase were isolated from human brain and placenta libraries.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The entire coding and 3' untranslated regions, as well as 23 bp of the 5' untranslated region were sequenced.</Gene>
<Gene>Complete sequence identity was found among the clones, with the exception of an area of heterogeneity among the 3' untranslated region of the brain and placenta clones.</Gene>
<Gene>A 77.7% nucleotide sequence identity was found between the coding region of human B creatine kinase and our previously reported human M creatine kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, no homology was found in the 3' untranslated regions.</Gene>
<Gene>Probes were constructed from the nonconserved 3' untranslated regions of human M and B creatine kinase and were shown to be highly specific.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Southern transfers of total genomic DNA derived from human placenta and digested to completion with several restriction enzymes were probed with the MCK and BCK specific probes producing single hybridization bands.</Gene>

text: <Gene>These results suggest that creatine kinase M and B are single copy genes in the human genome.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Involvement of DNA polymerase delta in DNA repair synthesis in human fibroblasts at late times after ultraviolet irradiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DNA repair synthesis following UV irradiation of confluent human fibroblasts has a biphasic time course with an early phase of rapid nucleotide incorporation and a late phase of much slower nucleotide incorporation.</Gene>
<Gene>The biphasic nature of this curve suggests that two distinct DNA repair systems may be operative.</Gene>
<Gene>Previous studies have specifically implicated DNA polymerase delta as the enzyme involved in DNA repair synthesis occurring immediately after UV damage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this paper, we describe studies of DNA polymerase involvement in DNA repair synthesis in confluent human fibroblasts at late times after UV irradiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Late UV-induced DNA repair synthesis in both intact and permeable cells was found to be inhibited by aphidicolin, indicating the involvement of one of the aphidicolin-sensitive DNA polymerases, alpha or delta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In permeable cells, the process was further analyzed by using the nucleotide analogue (butylphenyl)-2'-deoxyguanosine 5'-triphosphate, which inhibits DNA polymerase alpha several hundred times more strongly than it inhibits DNA polymerase delta.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The (butylphenyl)-2'-deoxyguanosine 5'-triphosphate inhibition curve for late UV-induced repair synthesis was very similar to that for polymerase delta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It appears that repair synthesis at late times after UV irradiation, like repair synthesis at early times, is mediated by DNA polymerase delta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning and primary structure of human 15-lipoxygenase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A full-length cDNA encoding 15-lipoxygenase has been isolated from a human reticulocyte cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted primary structure of the enzyme exhibits a sequence similarity of 61% and 45% with human 5-lipoxygenase and the soybean lipoxygenase isoenzyme I, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When all three lipoxygenases are aligned, there are two distinct regions of significant sequence identity including a cluster of five histidine residues conserved in all three lipoxygenases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Because histidines can serve as ligands for the enzymatically active iron, this region may be critical to enzymatic function.</Gene>
<Gene>These results provide a basis for exploring functional domains of lipoxygenases.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Isolation and properties of cDNA clones encoding SRF, a transcription factor that binds to the c-fos serum response element.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The serum response element (SRE) is a sequence required for transient transcriptional activation of genes in response to growth factors.</Gene>

label: Gene

text: <Gene>The SRF gene is highly conserved through evolution, and in cultured cells its transcription is itself transiently increased following serum stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA clone of SRF expressed in vitro generates protein that forms complexes indistinguishable from those formed with HeLa cell SRF, as judged by DNA binding specificity and the ability to promote SRE-dependent in vitro transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SRF binds DNA as a dimer, and the DNA binding/dimerization domain of the protein exhibits striking homology to two yeast regulatory proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human pregnancy-specific beta 1-glycoprotein (PS beta G) and the carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)-related proteins are members of the same multigene family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pregnancy-specific beta 1-glycoprotein (PS beta G), a major product of the placenta with unknown function, consists of a set of glycoproteins synthesized by the syncytiotrophoblast.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report here the molecular cloning of 3 cDNA encoding different members of the PS beta G family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two clones (C, D) correspond to a single transcript undergoing differential splicing.</Gene>
<Gene>The third one (E) originates from a different gene.</Gene>
<Gene>All three clones have identical (C, D) or similar (E) coding sequences except for the last residues at their carboxyl end.</Gene>
<Gene>They contain 93 residue motifs related to the ancestral Ig-like domain which makes them new members of this gene superfamily.</Gene>
<Gene>A striking sequence similarity (50 to 60%) is observed between PS beta G and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)-related proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The evolutionary relationship between CEA and PS beta G points to a possible common function in the control of cell invasion and/or metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of cDNA clones coding for rat isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase and assignment of the gene to human chromosome 15.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rat liver mRNA encoding the cytoplasmic precursor of mitochondrial isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase was highly enriched by polysome immunopurification using a polyclonal monospecific antibody.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The purified mRNA was used to prepare a plasmid cDNA library which was screened with two oligonucleotide mixtures encoding two peptides in the amino-terminal portion of mature rat isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thirty-one overlapping cDNA clones, spanning a region of 2.1 kbp, were isolated and characterized.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNA sequence of a 5'-end clone, rIVD-13 (155 bp), predicts a mitochondrial leader peptide of 30 amino acid residues and the first 18 amino acids of the mature protein.</Gene>
<Gene>These consecutive 18 residues completely matched the amino-terminal peptide determined by automated Edman degradation of the rat enzyme.</Gene>
<Gene>The leader peptide contains six arginines, has no acidic residues, and is particularly rich in leucine, alanine, and proline residues.</Gene>

<Gene>Southern blot analysis of DNAs from human-rodent somatic cell hybrids with an isolated rat cDNA (2 kbp) assigned the isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase gene to the long arm of chromosome 15, region q14----qter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The chromosomal assignment was confirmed and further refined to bands q14----q15 by in situ hybridization of the probe to human metaphase cells.</Gene>
<Gene>This location differs from that of the gene for medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, a closely related enzyme, which has been previously assigned to chromosome 1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning of a cDNA for human delta-aminolevulinate dehydratase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA encoding human delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALA-D; EC 4.2.1.24), the second enzyme in the heme biosynthetic pathway, was isolated from a human liver cDNA expression library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of the original 17 clones selected with anti-ALA-D antibody, only four expressed anti-ALA-D epitopes as assessed by rescreening with antibody preabsorbed with purified antigen.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Subsequent screening of the antibody-positive clones with mixed oligodeoxynucleotide (oligo) probes, synthesized to correspond to human N-terminal and bovine active-site peptide sequences, identified three clones which hybridized only with the oligo probes for the bovine amino acid (aa) sequences.</Gene>
<Gene>Restriction endonucleases analysis revealed that these three clones contained the same 800-bp cDNA insert.</Gene>
<Gene>This insert was recloned into bacteriophage M13mp18 and mp19 and sequenced by primer extension.</Gene>

<Gene>The aa sequence predicted from the partial nucleotide sequence was found to be essentially colinear with the sequences of four bovine ALA-D peptides, totaling 35 non-overlapping aa residues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>6-Phosphogluconolactonase deficiency, a hereditary erythrocyte enzyme deficiency: possible interaction with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Partial deficiency of 6-phosphogluconolactonase (EC 3.1.1.31) of the erythrocytes was discovered as an autosomal dominant disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hemolytic anemia occurred in an individual who had inherited both the gene for 6-phosphogluconolactonase deficiency and that for deficiency of a nonhemolytic variant of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.49).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is proposed that the interaction of this hereditary erythrocyte abnormality with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency may explain hemolysis in some other patients who have inherited polymorphic variants of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human muscle phosphoglycerate mutase deficiency: newly discovered metabolic myopathy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Muscle phosphoglycerate mutase activity was decreased (5.7 percent of the lowest control value) in a 52-year-old man with intolerance for strenuous exercise and recurrent pigmenturia since adolescence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All of the other enzymes of glycolysis had normal activities, and glycogen concentration was normal.</Gene>

<Gene>Electrophoretic, heat lability, and mercury inhibition studies showed that the small residual activity in the patient's muscle was represented by the brain (BB) isoenzyme of phosphoglycerate mutase, suggesting a genetic defect of the M subunit which predominates in normal muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The prevalence of the BB isoenzyme in other tissues, including muscle culture, may explain why symptoms were confined to muscle.</Gene>
<Gene>Linkage of the LW blood group locus with the complement C3 and Lutheran blood group loci.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Segregation data on LW in families of informative males show that the LW (Landsteiner-Wiener) blood group locus is closely linked to the complement C3 locus and to the locus for the Lutheran blood group.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This finding also confirms the presence of a larger linkage group on chromosome 19, including now the loci for apoE, Le, C3, LW, Lu, Se, H, PEPD, myotonic dystrophy (DM), neurofibromatosis (NF) and familial hypercholesterolemia (FHC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Linkage of LW with the Lewis blood group locus could not be definitely established by the present family data, but small positive scores between LW and Le suggest that the Le locus is situated outside the C3-LW region.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human beta-nerve growth factor gene sequence highly homologous to that of mouse.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nerve growth factor (NGF) is thought to have a profound effect on the development and maintenance of sympathetic and embryonic sensory neurones (see refs 1-3 for review).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NGF activity isolated from the male mouse submaxillary gland (MSG) consists of three types of subunits, alpha, beta and gamma, which specifically interact to form a 7S, approximately 130,000-molecular weight (Mr) complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 7S complex contains two identical 118-amino acid beta-chains, which are solely responsible for the nerve growth-stimulating activity of NGF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While NGF is found in almost all vertebrates, most research has focused on murine NGF, as the mouse male submaxillary gland contains higher levels of this polypeptide than other tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Even so, beta-NGF comprises only approximately 0.1% of the protein in this small gland, which has made the study of this polypeptide difficult.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The amino acid sequence of the mouse NGF beta-chain has been determined and some information has been obtained regarding the size of a mouse precursor molecule, pro-beta-NGF, but little was known about the structure and relatedness of beta-NGF from other vertebrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we describe the isolation of mouse beta-NGF complementary DNA (cDNA) and present its nucleotide sequence, which predicts a prepro-beta-NGF molecule of Mr 27,000 (27K) and a pro-beta-NGF molecule of Mr 25K. We have used the mouse beta-NGF cDNA clone to isolate the human beta-NGF gene, the coding regions of which are highly homologous to the mouse prepro-beta-NGF nucleotide and amino acid sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the gene encoding the alpha subunit of the rod cGMP-gated channel in autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the genes encoding two proteins of the retinal rod phototransduction cascade, opsin and the beta subunit of rod cGMP phosphodiesterase, cause retinitis pigmentosa (RP) in some families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report defects in a third member of this biochemical pathway in still other patients with this disease.</Gene>

<Gene>We screened 94 unrelated patients with autosomal dominant RP and 173 unrelated patients with autosomal recessive RP for mutations in the gene encoding the alpha subunit of the rod cGMP-gated cation channel.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Five mutant sequences cosegregated with disease among four unrelated families with autosomal recessive RP.</Gene>

<Gene>Two of these were nonsense mutations early in the reading frame (Glu76End and Lys139End) and one was a deletion encompassing most if not all of the transcriptional unit; these three alleles would not be expected to encode a functional channel.</Gene>
<Gene>The remaining two mutations were</Gene>
<Gene>a missense mutation (Ser316Phe) and a frameshift [Arg654(1-bp del)] mutation truncating the last 32 aa in the C terminus.</Gene>
<Gene>The latter two mutations were expressed in vitro and found to encode proteins that were predominantly retained inside the cell instead of being targeted to the plasma membrane.</Gene>
<Gene>We conclude that the absence or paucity of functional cGMP-gated cation channels in the plasma membrane is deleterious to rod photoreceptors and is an uncommon cause of RP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of a cellular apoptosis susceptibility gene, the human homologue to the yeast chromosome segregation gene CSE1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We recently isolated human cDNA fragments that render MCF-7 breast cancer cells resistant to cell death caused by Pseudomonas exotoxin, Pseudomonas exotoxin-derived immunotoxins, diphtheria toxin, and tumor necrosis factor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report here that one of these fragments is an antisense fragment of a gene homologous to the essential yeast chromosome segregation gene</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CSE1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and analysis of the full-length cDNA of the human CSE1 homologue, which we name CAS for cellular apoptosis susceptibility gene, reveals a protein coding region with similar length (971 amino acids for CAS, 960 amino acids for CSE1) and 59% overall protein homology to the yeast</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CSE1 protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The conservation of this gene indicates it has an important function in human cells consistent with the essential role of CSE1 in yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CAS is highly expressed in human tumor cell lines and in human testis and fetal liver, tissues that contain actively dividing cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, CAS expression increases when resting human fibroblasts are induced to proliferate and decreases when they are growth-arrested.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, CAS appears to play an important role in both toxin and tumor necrosis factor-mediated cell death, as well as in cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of four novel human genes amplified and overexpressed in breast carcinoma and localized to the q11-q21.3 region of chromosome 17.</Gene>
<Gene>We have performed differential screening of a human metastatic lymph lymph node cDNA library to identify genes possibly involved during breast cancer progression.</Gene>
<Gene>We have identified four novel genes overexpressed in malignant tiddues.</Gene>

<Gene>They were all located on the long arm of chromosome 17, in loci located between q11 and q21.3, a region known to contain the c-erbB-2 oncogene and the BRCA1 breast carcinomas, and overexpression of three of them was dependent on gene amplification in breast cancer cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings further support the concept that human chromosome 17 specifically carries genes possibly involved in breast cancer progression.</Gene>
<Gene>Molecular cloning of the human homolog of a striatum-enriched phosphatase (STEP) gene and chromosomal mapping of the human and murine loci.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A gene for a protein tyrosine phosphatase (PTPase) was isolated from a human fetal brain cDNA library by PCR amplification.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis revealed that the PTPase has a single phosphatase catalytic domain located at the C-terminus that includes the highly conserved amino acid domain [I/V]HCXAGXXR[S/T]GX[F/Y] found in all tyrosine phosphatases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two proline-rich regions located at the N-terminus may contain putative Src homology domain 3 (SH3) binding motifs.</Gene>

<Gene>Comparison of the PTPase with a previously cloned striatum enriched phosphatase (STEP) from rat and from mouse exhibited a high degree of identity (approximately 85-90%) at both the nucleotide and the amino acid levels, indicating that the human PTPase is the homolog of the rat and murine STEP gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By using a combination of somatic cell hybrid analysis and fluorescence in situ hybridization, we have mapped the human STEP locus to chromosome 11p15.2-p15.1 and the murine STEP gene to chromosome 7B3-B5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These are two regions of known conserved synteny, providing further evidence that the human STEP is a true homolog of the murine STEP gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Candidate disease genes in the vicinity include Usher syndrome type 1C in human and a mouse mutant locus, twister (twt).</Gene>
<Gene>Cloning of the cDNA for the human ATP synthase OSCP subunit (ATP5O) by exon trapping and mapping to chromosome 21q22.1-q22.2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Exon trapping was used to clone portions of potential genes from human chromosome 21.</Gene>
<Gene>One trapped sequence showed striking homology with the bovine and rat ATP synthase OSCP (oligomycin sensitivity conferring protein) subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We subsequently cloned the full-length human ATP synthase OSCP cDNA (GDB/HGMW approved name ATP50) from infant brain and muscle libraries and determined its nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequence (EMBL/GenBank Accession No. X83218).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The encoded polypeptide contains 213 amino acids, with more than 80% identity to bovine and murine ATPase OSCP subunits and over 35% identity to Saccharomyces cerevisiae and sweet potato sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human ATP5O gene is located at 21q22.1-q22.2, just proximal to D21S17, in YACs 860G11 and 838C7 of the Chumakov et al.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>(Nature 359:380, 1992)</Gene>
<Gene>YAC contig.</Gene>
<Gene>The gene is expressed in all human tissues examined, most strongly in muscle and heart.</Gene>

<Gene>This ATP5O subunit is a key structural component of the stalk of the mitochondrial respiratory chain F1F0-ATP synthase and as such may contribute in a gene dosage-dependent manner to the phenotype of Down syndrome (trisomy 21).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genomic organization of the human gene (CA5) and pseudogene for mitochondrial carbonic anhydrase V and their localization to chromosomes 16q and 16p.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Carbonic anhydrase V (CA V) is expressed in mitochondrial matrix in liver and several other tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is of interest for its putative roles in providing bicarbonate to carbamoyl phosphate synthetase for ureagenesis and to pyruvate carboxylase for gluconeogenesis and its possible importance in explaining certain inherited metabolic disorders with hyperammonemia and hypoglycemia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following the recent characterization of the cDNA for human CA V, we report the isolation of the human gene from two lambda genomic libraries and its characterization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CA V gene (CA5) is approximately 50 kb long and contains 7 exons and 6 introns.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The exon-intron boundaries are found in positions identical to those determined for the previously described CA II, CA III, and CA VII genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Like the CA VII gene, CA5 does not contain typical TATA and CAAT promoter elements in the 5' flanking region but does contain a TTTAA sequence 147 nucleotides upstream of the initiation codon.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CA5 also contains a 12-bp GT-rich segment beginning 13 bp downstream of the polyadenylation signal in the 3' untranslated region of exon 7.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>FISH analysis allowed CA5 to be assigned to chromosome 16q24.3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An unprocessed pseudogene containing sequence homologous to exons 3-7 and introns 3-6 was also isolated and was assigned by FISH analysis to chromosome 16p11.2-p12.</Gene>
<Gene>Generation of a transcription map at the HSD17B locus centromeric to BRCA1 at 17q21.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A detailed transcription map of the 320-kb region containing the HSD17B locus on chromosome 17 was generated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thirty unique cDNA fragments, retrieved following the hybridization of immobilized YACs to primary pools of cDNAs prepared from RNA of mammary gland, ovary, placenta, and the Caco-2 cell line, were aligned into 10 transcription units by physical mapping and hybridization to RNAs of a series of tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNAs were then further characterized by sequencing and used to screen mammary gland cDNA libraries.</Gene>
<Gene>Fragments corresponding to the broadly expressed gamma-tubulin and Ki antigen genes were identified.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A full-length cDNA clone encoding a 117-amino-acid protein homologous to the rat ribosomal protein L34 was isolated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Portions of genes with restricted patterns of expression were also obtained, including the previously characterized HSD17B1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One new gene, for which a full-length cDNA was isolated, was found to have an interesting tissue-specific pattern of expression with abundant mRNA in both the colon and the testis and in the mammary carcinoma cell line BT-474.</Gene>
<Gene>This contrasted with the barely detectable level observed in several tissues including normal mammary gland.</Gene>

<Gene>Of the five additional transcription units identified, one showed no similarity, two showed identity to human expressed sequences, and two displayed similarity to genes of animal species by amino acid alignment.</Gene>

<Gene>These latter cDNA clones include potential homologues of a rat nuclear tyrosine phosphatase and of a factor of Drosophila that is known to be involved in the negative regulation of transcription of segment identity genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A novel K+ channel beta-subunit (hKv beta 1.3) is produced via alternative mRNA splicing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Voltage-gated K+ channels can form multimeric complexes with accessory beta-subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report here a novel K+ channel beta-subunit cloned from human heart, hKv beta 1.3, that has 74-83% overall identity with previously cloned beta-subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Comparison of hKv beta 1.3 with the previously cloned hKv beta 3 and rKv beta 1 proteins indicates that the carboxyl-terminal 328 amino acids are identical, while unique variable length amino termini exist.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of human beta-subunit cDNA and genomic nucleotide sequences confirm that these three beta-subunits are alternatively spliced from a common beta-subunit gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Co-expression of hKv beta 1.3 in Xenopus oocytes with the delayed rectifier hKv1.5 indicated that hKv beta 1.3 has unique functional effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This novel beta-subunit induced a time-dependent inactivation during membrane voltage steps to positive potentials, induced a 13-mV hyperpolarizing shift in the activation curve, and slowed deactivation (tau = 13 +/- 0.5 ms versus 35 +/- 1.7 ms at -40 mV).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Most notably, hKv beta 1.3 converted the Kv1.5 outwardly rectifying current voltage relationship to one showing strong inward rectification.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that Kv channel current diversity may arise from association with alternatively spliced Kv beta-subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A simplified nomenclature for the K+ channel beta-subunit subfamilies is suggested.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>De novo mutation of the myelin P0 gene in Dejerine-Sottas disease (hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy type III).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have investigated the myelin P0 gene on chromosome 1 as a candidate gene in two sporadic cases with Dejerine-Sottas disease or hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) type III.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found different mutations, a cysteine substitution for serine 63 in the extracellular domain and an arginine substitution for glycine 167 in the transmembrane domain.</Gene>
<Gene>The patients were genetically heterozygous for the normal allele and the mutant allele, which was absent in their parents and in one hundred unrelated, healthy controls.</Gene>
<Gene>The results strongly suggest that a de novo dominant mutation of the P0 gene is responsible for at least some sporadic cases of Dejerine-Sottas disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human serum biotinidase. cDNA cloning, sequence, and characterization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Biotinidase (EC 3.5.1.12) catalyzes the hydrolysis of biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylase degradation, to biotin and lysine.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Biotinidase deficiency is an inherited metabolic disorder of biotin recycling that is characterized by neurological and cutaneous abnormalities, and can be successfully treated with biotin supplementation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequences of tryptic peptides of the purified human serum enzyme were used to design oligonucleotide primers for polymerase chain reaction amplification from human hepatic total RNA to generate putative biotinidase cDNA fragments.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis of a cDNA isolated from a human liver library by plaque hybridization with the largest cDNA probe revealed an open reading frame of 1629 bases encoding a protein of 543 amino acid residues, including 41 amino acids of a potential signal peptide.</Gene>

<Gene>Comparison of the open reading frame with the known biotinidase tryptic peptides and recognition of the expressed protein encoded by this cDNA by monoclonal antibodies prepared against purified biotinidase demonstrated the identity of this cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Southern analyses suggested that biotinidase is a single copy gene and revealed that human cDNA probes hybridized to genomic DNA from mammals, but not from chicken or yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern analysis indicated the presence of biotinidase mRNA in human heart, brain, placenta, liver, lung, skeletal muscle, kidney, and pancreas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>C3G, a guanine nucleotide-releasing protein expressed ubiquitously, binds to the Src homology 3 domains of CRK and GRB2/ASH proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CRK protein, together with GRB2/ASH and Nck proteins, belongs to the adaptor-type Src homology (SH)2-containing molecules, which transduce signals from tyrosine kinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here another guanine nucleotide-releasing protein (GNRP), C3G, has been identified as a CRK SH3-binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The nucleotide sequence of a 4.1-kb C3G cDNA contains a 3.2-kb open reading frame encoding a 121-kDa protein, and antibodies against C3G have been shown to detect a protein of 130-140 kDa.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The carboxyl terminus of C3G has a peptide sequence homologous to GNRPs for Ras, and the expression of this carboxyl terminus region suppresses the loss of CDC25 function in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The C3G protein expressed in Escherichia coli binds to CRK and GRB2/ASH proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutational analysis of C3G assigns the SH3 binding region to a 50-amino acid region containing a proline-rich sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mRNAs of both the C3G and CRK proteins are expressed ubiquitously in human adult and fetal tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results of these studies suggest that the complex of CRK and C3G, or GRB2/ASH and C3G, may transduce the signals from tyrosine kinases to Ras in a number of different tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel mammalian protein, p55CDC, present in dividing cells is associated with protein kinase activity and has homology to the Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell division cycle proteins Cdc20 and Cdc4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel protein, p55CDC, has been identified in cycling mammalian cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This transcript is readily detectable in all exponentially growing cell lines but disappears when cells are chemically induced to fall out of the cell cycle and differentiate.</Gene>

<Gene>The p55CDC protein appears to be essential for cell division, since transfection of antisense p55CDC cDNA into CHO cells resulted in isolation of only those cells which exhibited a compensatory increase in p55CDC transcripts in the sense orientation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunoprecipitation of p55CDC yielded protein complexes with kinase activity which fluctuated during the cell cycle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Since p55CDC does not have the conserved protein kinase domains, this activity must be due to one or more of the associated proteins in the immune complex.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The highest levels of protein kinase activity were seen with alpha-casein and myelin basic protein as substrates and demonstrated a pattern of activity distinct from that described for the known cyclin-dependent cell division kinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The p55CDC protein was also phosphorylated in dividing cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The amino acid sequence of p55CDC contains seven repeats homologous to the beta subunit of G proteins, and the highest degree of homology in these repeats was found with the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Cdc20 and Cdc4 proteins, which have been proposed to be involved in the formation of a functional bipolar mitotic spindle in yeast cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The G beta repeat has been postulated to mediate protein-protein interactions and, in p55CDC, may modulate its association with a unique cell cycle protein kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that p55CDC is a component of the mammalian cell cycle mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The immunoreactive region in a novel autoantigen contains a nuclear localization sequence.</Gene>
<Gene>Antibodies in the serum of patients with autoimmune diseases have been used to identify human autoantigens.</Gene>
<Gene>Because autoantibodies often recognize active sites within corresponding protein antigens, autoantibodies have facilitated the functional characterization of these polypeptides.</Gene>
<Gene>In the present study, serum from a patient with Sjögren's syndrome was used to identify a novel autoantigen which was designated Ge-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using the patient's serum, a 4.8-kb cDNA encoding Ge-1 was identified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Fragments of the cDNA were ligated into prokaryotic expression vectors, expressed in Escherichia coli, and used to produce recombinant Ge-1 fusion proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Fusion proteins containing different portions of Ge-1 were used to identify a 58 amino acid immunoreactive region within the protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This immunoreactive region contained the protein's putative nuclear localization sequence (NLS).</Gene>

<Gene>To demonstrate that the immunoreactive region was capable of functioning as a NLS, a eukaryotic expression plasmid was constructed to encode the immunoreactive region fused to the cytoplasmic protein, chicken muscle pyruvate kinase.</Gene>
<Gene>After transfection of this plasmid into COS-1 cells, the fusion protein was detected in the nucleus.</Gene>
<Gene>The presence of the NLS motif within the immunoreactive region of Ge-1 and other nuclear autoantigens suggests that the NLS may be a target of human autoantibodies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular characterization of an aquaporin cDNA from brain: candidate osmoreceptor and regulator of water balance.</Gene>

<Gene>The aquaporins transport water through membranes of numerous tissues, but the molecular mechanisms for sensing changes in extracellular osmolality and regulating water balance in brain are unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>We have isolated a brain aquaporin by homology cloning.</Gene>

<Gene>Like aquaporin 1 (AQP1, also known as CHIP, channel-forming integral membrane protein of 28 kDa), the deduced polypeptide has six putative transmembrane domains but lacks cysteines at the known mercury-sensitive sites.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two initiation sites were identified encoding polypeptides of 301 and 323 amino acids; expression of each in Xenopus oocytes conferred a 20-fold increase in osmotic water permeability not blocked by 1 mM HgCl2, even after substitution of cysteine at the predicted mercury-sensitive site.</Gene>
<Gene>Northern analysis and RNase protection demonstrated the mRNA to be abundant in mature rat brain but only weakly detectable in eye, kidney, intestine, and lung.</Gene>

<Gene>In situ hybridization of brain localized the mRNA to ependymal cells lining the aqueduct, glial cells forming the edge of the cerebral cortex and brainstem, vasopressin-secretory neurons in supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of hypothalamus, and Purkinje cells of cerebellum.</Gene>

<Gene>Its distinctive expression pattern implicates this fourth mammalian member of the aquaporin water channel family (designated gene symbol, AQP4) as the osmoreceptor which regulates body water balance and mediates water flow within the central nervous system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vasopressin increases water permeability of kidney collecting duct by inducing translocation of aquaporin-CD water channels to plasma membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Water excretion by the kidney is regulated by the peptide hormone vasopressin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Vasopressin increases the water permeability of the renal collecting duct cells, allowing more water to be reabsorbed from collecting duct urine to blood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Despite long-standing interest in this process, the mechanism of the water permeability increase has remained undetermined.</Gene>
<Gene>Recently, a molecular water channel (AQP-CD) has been cloned whose expression appears to be limited to the collecting duct.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Previously, we immunolocalized this water channel to the apical plasma membrane (APM) and to intracellular vesicles (IVs) of collecting duct cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we test the hypothesis that vasopressin increases cellular water permeability by inducing exocytosis of AQP-CD-laden vesicles, transferring water channels from IVs to APM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rat collecting ducts were perfused in vitro to determine water permeability and subcellular distribution of AQP-CD in the same tubules.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The collecting ducts were fixed for immunoelectron microscopy before, during, and after exposure to vasopressin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Vasopressin exposure induced increases in water permeability and the absolute labeling density of AQP-CD in the APM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In parallel, the APM:IV labeling ratio increased.</Gene>

<Gene>Furthermore, in response to vasopressin withdrawal, AQP-CD labeling density in the APM and the APM:IV labeling ratio decreased in parallel to a measured decrease in osmotic water permeability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that vasopressin increases the water permeability of collecting duct cells by inducing a reversible translocation of AQP-CD water channels from IVs to the APM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functional expression and pharmacological characterization of the human EAA4 (GluR6) glutamate receptor: a kainate selective channel subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA encoding an ionotropic glutamate receptor subunit protein humEAA4 (GluR6), has been cloned from a human fetal brain library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This cDNA when expressed in COS or HEK-293 cells is associated with high-affinity kainate receptor binding and ion channel formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have successfully established cell lines stably expressing humEAA4 in HEK-293 cells</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first report of the establishment of stable cell lines expressing a glutamate receptor channel.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The relative potency of compounds for displacing [3H]-kainate binding to humEAA4 receptors expressed in COS or HEK-293 cells is domoate > kainate > quisqualate > 6-cyano-7-nitroquinoxaline-2,3-dione > L-glutamate = 6,7- dinitroquinoxaline-2,3-dione > dihydrokainate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Applications of kainate, glutamate, and domoate but not AMPA evoked rapidly desensitizing currents in cells expressing homo-oligomeric humEAA4 in a concentration dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The order of potency was: domoate > kainate > L-glutamate.</Gene>
<Gene>Although AMPA did not itself activate humEAA4 receptors it did reduce, to a limited extent, kainate-evoked responses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AMPA may therefore be a weak partial agonist for this receptor.</Gene>
<Gene>To date this effect has not been demonstrated with rat GluR6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It is possible that subtle species differences may exist in the nature of agonist receptor interaction.</Gene>
<Gene>Kainate evoked currents were attenuated by the quinoxalinediones CNQX and DNQX but not by DAP5.</Gene>

<Gene>The receptor desensitization was attenuated on application of concanavalin A. Ion-permeability studies indicated that the receptor-linked ion channel is permeable to both Na+ and Ca2+ ions.</Gene>
<Gene>Characterization of a novel Src-like adapter protein that associates with the Eck receptor tyrosine kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Eph family of receptor protein tyrosine kinases (RPTKs) is the largest family of RPTKs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The signal transduction pathways initiated by this family have only recently begun to be explored.</Gene>

<Gene>Using a yeast two-hybrid screen to identify molecules that interact with the cytoplasmic domain of Eck, it was previously shown that activated Eck RPTK bound to and stimulated phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (Pandey, A., Lazar, D.F., Saltiel, A. R., and Dixit, V.M. (1994) J. Biol.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Also isolated from this same screen was a novel protein containing SH3 and SH2 adapter modules that had striking homology to those found in the Src family of non-receptor tyrosine kinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, unlike other Src family members, it lacked a catalytic tyrosine kinase domain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hence, this protein was designated SLAP for Src-like adapter protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using glutathione S-transferase fusion Proteins, it was demonstrated that SLAP bound to activated Eck receptor tyrosine kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, SLAP is a novel candidate downstream signaling intermediate and the first member of the Src family that resembles an adapter molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of central and peripheral cannabinoid receptors in human immune tissues and leukocyte subpopulations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two proteins with seven transmembrane-spanning domains typical of guanosine-nucleotide-binding-protein-coupled receptors have been identified as cannabinoid receptors; the central cannabinoid receptor, CB1, and the peripheral cannabinoid receptor, CB2, initially described in rat brain and spleen, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we report the distribution patterns for both CB1 and CB2 transcripts in human immune cells and in several human tissues, as analysed using a highly sensitive and quantitative PCR-based method.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CB1 was mainly expressed in the central nervous system and, to a lower extent, in several peripheral tissues such as adrenal gland, heart, lung, prostate, uterus, ovary, testis, bone marrow, thymus and tonsils.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the CB2 gene, which is not expressed in the brain, was particularly abundant in immune tissues, with an expression level 10-100-fold higher than that of CB1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although CB2 mRNA was also detected in some other peripheral tissues, its level remained very low.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In spleen and tonsils, the CB2 mRNA content was equivalent to that of CB1 mRNA in the central nervous system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among the main human blood cell subpopulations, the distribution pattern of the CB2 mRNA displayed important variations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The rank order of CB2 mRNA levels in these cells was B-cells > natural killer cells >> monocytes > polymorphonuclear neutrophil cells > T8 cells > T4 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The same rank order was also established in human cell lines belonging to the myeloid, monocytic and lymphoid lineages.</Gene>
<Gene>The prevailing expression of the CB2 gene in immune tissues was confirmed by Northern-blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the expression of the CB2 protein was demonstrated by an immunohistological analysis performed on tonsil sections using specific anti-(human CB2)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IgG; this experiment showed that CB2 expression was restricted to B-lymphocyte-enriched areas of the mantle of secondary lymphoid follicles.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that (a) CB1 and CB2 can be considered as tissue-selective antigens of the central nervous system and immune system, respectively, and (b) cannabinoids may exert specific receptor-mediated actions on the immune system through the CB2 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning and functional expression of the gene encoding the human proteinase-activated receptor 2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We previously reported the molecular cloning of a mouse guanosine-nucleotide-binding-protein-coupled receptor similar to the thrombin receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since the physiological agonist was unknown, the receptor was named proteinase-activated receptor 2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We describe here the cloning and functional expression of the gene encoding the corresponding human receptor.</Gene>
<Gene>The gene is divided into two exons separated by about 14 kb intronic DNA.</Gene>
<Gene>The deduced protein sequence is 397 amino acids long and 83% identical to the mouse receptor sequence.</Gene>
<Gene>Within the extracellular amino terminus, the residues predicted to form the tethered agonist ligand differ between the two receptors; of the first six residues only four are conserved.</Gene>
<Gene>At positions five and six, a lysine residue and a valine residue, respectively, have replaced arginine and leucine residues found in the mouse sequence.</Gene>

<Gene>When the human receptor is expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells, it can be activated by low nanomolar concentrations of the serine proteinase trypsin and by peptides made from the receptor sequence.</Gene>

<Gene>Northern-blot analysis of receptor expression showed that the receptor transcript is widely expressed in human tissues with especially high levels in pancreas, liver, kidney, small intestine and colon.</Gene>
<Gene>Moderate expression was detected in many organs but none in brain or skeletal muscle.</Gene>

<Gene>By fluorescence in situ hybridization, the human proteinase-activated receptor 2 gene was mapped to chromosomal region 5q13, where, previously, the related thrombin receptor gene has been located.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A nuclear protein, synthesized in growth-arrested human hepatoblastoma cells, is a novel member of the short-chain alcohol dehydrogenase family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have described a protein (Hep27) [Donadel, G., Garzelli, C., Frank, R. & Gabrielli, F. (1991)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Eur. J. Biochem.</Gene>
<Gene>195, 723-729] which is synthesized and accumulated in the nucleus of human hepatoblastoma (HepG2) cells, following growth arrest induced by butyrate treatment.</Gene>
<Gene>The synthesis of Hep27 is inhibited in cells that, released from the butyrate block, have resumed DNA synthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This report describes the cloning and the characterization of the cDNA coding for the Hep27 protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The translation of the Hep27 cDNA predicts an amino acid sequence that can be aligned with those of the known short-chain alcohol dehydrogenase enzymes (SCAD) family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both the recognition of enzymic functional domains and the similarity with the SCAD family of proteins of several amino acid blocks throughout the molecule, strongly suggest that this protein is a new member of the SCAD family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In agreement with its nuclear localization Hep27 has a region similar to the bipartite nuclear-targeting sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The study of Hep27 mRNA expression and protein synthesis suggests the existence of a regulation at the post-transcriptional level.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The possible nuclear role of the Hep27 protein is discussed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interaction of papillomavirus E6 oncoproteins with a putative calcium-binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are associated with the majority of cervical cancers and encode a transforming protein, E6, that interacts with the tumor suppressor protein p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because E6 has p53-independent transforming activity, the yeast two-hybrid system was used to search for other E6-binding proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>One such protein, E6BP, interacted with cancer-associated HPV E6 and with bovine papillomavirus type 1 (BPV-1) E6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transforming activity of BPV-1 E6 mutants correlated with their E6BP-binding ability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>E6BP is identical to a putative calcium-binding protein, ERC-55, that appears to be localized in the endoplasmic reticulum.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of a G protein-activated human phosphoinositide-3 kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phosphoinositide-3 kinase activity is implicated in diverse cellular responses triggered by mammalian cell surface receptors and in the regulation of protein sorting in yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Receptors with intrinsic and associated tyrosine kinase activity recruit heterodimeric phosphoinositide-3 kinases that consist of p110 catalytic subunits and p85 adaptor molecules containing Src homology 2 (SH2) domains.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A phosphoinositide-3 kinase isotype, p110 gamma, was cloned and characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The p110 gamma enzyme was activated in vitro by both the alpha and beta gamma subunits of heterotrimeric guanosine triphosphate (GTP)-binding proteins (G proteins) and did not interact with p85.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A potential pleckstrin homology domain is located near its amino terminus.</Gene>
<Gene>The p110 gamma isotype may link signaling through G protein-coupled receptors to the generation of phosphoinositide second messengers phosphorylated in the D-3 position.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Repression of transcriptional activity by heterologous KRAB domains present in zinc finger proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report the characterization of three novel members of the KRAB-domain containing C2-H2 zinc finger family (ZNF133, 136 and 140).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>KRAB (Krüppel-associated box) is an evolutionarily conserved protein domain found N-terminally with respect to the zinc finger repeats that encodes the DNA binding domain.</Gene>
<Gene>ZNF133 and ZNF140 have both the KRAB A- and KRAB B-boxes present at their N-terminus, whereas ZNF136 contains only the KRAB A-box.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously demonstrated that the KRAB domains derived from ZNF133 and ZNF140 are potent transcriptional repression domains</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[Margolin et al. (1994)</Gene>
<Gene>Proc. Natl.</Gene>
<Gene>Acad.</Gene>
<Gene>Sci.</Gene>

<Gene>The KRAB domain from ZNF136, containing only subdomain A, is a considerable weaker suppression domain; however, when fused to the heterologous KRAB B subdomain of ZNF10 (KOX1) the two subdomains from a KRAB domain which induces repression as potently as previously reported KRAB domains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular mechanism for an inherited cardiac arrhythmia.</Gene>

<Gene>In the congenital long-QT syndrome, prolongation of the cardiac action potential occurs by an unknown mechanism and predisposes individuals to syncope and sudden death as a result of ventricular arrhythmias.</Gene>

<Gene>Genetic heterogeneity has been demonstrated for autosomal dominant long-QT syndrome by the identification of multiple distinct loci, and associated mutations in two candidate genes have recently been reported.</Gene>
<Gene>One form of hereditary long QT (LQT3) has been linked to a mutation in the gene encoding the human heart voltage-gated sodium-channel alpha-subunit (SCN5A on chromosome 3p21).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we characterize this mutation using heterologous expression of recombinant human heart sodium channels.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutant channels show a sustained inward current during membrane depolarization.</Gene>
<Gene>Single-channel recordings indicate that mutant channels fluctuate between normal and non-inactivating gating modes.</Gene>
<Gene>Persistent inward sodium current explains prolongation of cardiac action potentials, and provides a molecular mechanism for this form of congenital long-QT syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>A cap-binding protein complex mediating U snRNA export.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cap structures are added cotranscriptionally to all RNA polymerase II transcripts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>They affect several processes including RNA stability, pre-messenger RNA splicing, RNA export from the nucleus and translation initiation.</Gene>

<Gene>The effect of the cap on translation is mediated by the initiation factor eIF-4F, whereas the effect on pre-mRNA splicing involves a nuclear complex (CBC) composed of two cap binding proteins, CBP80 and CBP20.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A role for CBC in the nuclear export of capped RNAs has also been proposed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report here the characterization of human and Xenopus CBP20s.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Antibodies against recombinant CBP20 prevent interaction of CBC with capped RNAs in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following microinjection into Xenopus oocytes, the antibodies inhibit both pre-mRNA splicing and export of U small nuclear RNAs to the cytoplasm.</Gene>

<Gene>These results demonstrate that CBC mediates the effect of the cap structure in U snRNA export, and provide direct evidence for the involvement of a cellular RNA-binding factor in the transport of RNA to the cytoplasm.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hyperproinsulinaemia in obese fat/fat mice associated with a carboxypeptidase E mutation which reduces enzyme activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mice homozygous for the fat mutation develop obesity and hyperglycaemia that can be suppressed by treatment with exogenous insulin.</Gene>

<Gene>The fat mutation maps to mouse chromosome 8, very close to the gene for carboxypeptidase E (Cpe), which encodes an enzyme (CPE) that processes prohormone intermediates such as proinsulin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We now demonstrate a defect in proinsulin processing associated with the virtual absence of CPE activity in extracts of fat/fat pancreatic islets and pituitaries.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A single Ser202Pro mutation distinguishes the mutant Cpe allele, and abolishes enzymatic activity in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, the fat mutation represents the first demonstration of an obesity-diabetes syndrome elicited by a genetic defect in a prohormone processing pathway.</Gene>
<Gene>A novel gene, Translin, encodes a recombination hotspot binding protein associated with chromosomal translocations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have identified a novel gene, Translin, encoding a protein which specifically binds to consensus sequences at breakpoint junctions of chromosomal translocations in many cases of lymphoid malignancies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The encoded protein, Translin, is a previously undescribed type with no significant similarity to known proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the native form, Translin polypeptides form a multimeric structure which is responsible for its DNA binding activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nuclear localization of Translin is limited to lymphoid cell lines, raising the intriguing possibility that nuclear transport of Translin is regulated in a physiologically significant way such that active nuclear transport is associated with the lymphoid specific process known as Ig/TCR gene rearrangement.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Primary adhalinopathy: a common cause of autosomal recessive muscular dystrophy of variable severity.</Gene>
<Gene>Marked deficiency of muscle adhalin, a 50 kDa sarcolemmal dystrophin-associated glycoprotein, has been reported in severe childhood autosomal recessive muscular dystrophy (SCARMD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is a Duchenne-like disease affecting both males and females first described in Tunisian families.</Gene>
<Gene>Adhalin deficiency has been found in SCARMD patients from North Africa Europe, Brazil, Japan and North America (SLR & KPC, unpublished data).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The disease was initially linked to an unidentified gene on chromosome 13 in families from North Africa, and to the adhalin gene itself on chromosome 17q in one French family in which missense mutations were identified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus there are two kinds of myopathies with adhalin deficiency: one with a primary defect of adhalin (primary adhalinopathies), and one in which absence of adhalin is secondary to a separate gene defect on chromosome 13.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have examined the importance of primary adhalinopathies among myopathies with adhalin deficiency, and describe several additional mutations (null and missense) in the adhalin gene in 10 new families from Europe and North Africa.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Disease severity varies in age of onset and rate of progression, and patients with null mutations are the most severely affected.</Gene>
<Gene>Structure and functional expression of the human macrophage inflammatory protein 1 alpha/RANTES receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The chemokine beta family is comprised of at least six distinct cytokines that regulate trafficking of phagocytes and lymphocytes in mammalian species; at least one of these, macrophage inflammatory protein 1 alpha (MIP-1 alpha), also regulates the growth of hematopoietic stem cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We now show that MIP-1 alpha and the related beta chemokine, RANTES, induce transient alterations in intracellular Ca2+ concentration in polymorphonuclear leukocytes that can be reciprocally and specifically desensitized, suggesting a common receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, we have now cloned both the cDNA and the gene for this receptor, functionally expressed the receptor in Xenopus oocytes, and mapped the gene to human chromosome 3p21.</Gene>
<Gene>Transcripts for the receptor were found in mature and immature myeloid cells as well as B cells.</Gene>
<Gene>The receptor is a member of the G protein-coupled receptor superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It has approximately 33% amino acid identity with receptors for the alpha chemokine, interleukin 8, and may be the human homologue of the product of US28, an open reading frame of human cytomegalovirus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
