text: <Gene>p57KIP2, a structurally distinct member of the p21CIP1 Cdk inhibitor family, is a candidate tumor suppressor gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks) are positive regulators of cell proliferation, whereas Cdk inhibitors (CKIs) inhibit proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We describe a new CKI, p57KIP2, which is related to p21CIP1 and p27KIP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>p57KIP2 is a potent, tight-binding inhibitor of several G1 cyclin/Cdk complexes, and its binding is cyclin dependent.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike CIP1, KIP2 is not regulated by p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of p57KIP2 arrests cells in G1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>p57KIP2 proteins have a complex structure.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mouse p57KIP2 consists of four structurally distinct domains: an amino-terminal Cdk inhibitory domain, a proline-rich domain, an acidic-repeat region, and a carboxy-terminal domain conserved with p27KIP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human p57KIP2 appears to have conserved the amino- and carboxy-terminal domains but has replaced the internal regions with sequences containing proline-alanine repeats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In situ hybridization during mouse embryogenesis revealed that KIP2 mRNA displays a striking pattern of expression during development, showing high level expression in skeletal muscle, brain, heart, lungs, and eye.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Most of the KIP2-expressing cells are terminally differentiated, suggesting that p57KIP2 is involved in decisions to exit the cell cycle during development and differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human KIP2 is located at 11p15.5, a region implicated in both sporadic cancers and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a familial cancer syndrome, marking it as a candidate tumor suppressor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The discovery of a new member of the p21CIP1 inhibitor family with novel structural features and expression patterns suggests a complex role for these proteins in cell cycle control and development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A novel human protease similar to the interleukin-1 beta converting enzyme induces apoptosis in transfected cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have identified a novel cDNA encoding a protein (named TX) with > 50% overall sequence identity with the interleukin-1 beta converting enzyme (ICE) and approximately 30% sequence identity with the ICE homologs NEDD-2/ICH-1L and CED-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A computer homology model of TX was constructed based on the X-ray coordinates of the ICE crystal recently published.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This model suggests that TX is a cysteine protease, with the P1 aspartic acid substrate specificity retained.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transfection experiments demonstrate that TX is a protease which is able to cleave itself and the p30 ICE precursor, but not to generate mature IL-1 beta from pro-IL-1 beta.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, this protein induces apoptosis in transfected COS cells.</Gene>
<Gene>TX therefore delineates a new member of the growing Ice/ced-3 gene family coding for proteases with cytokine processing activity or involved in programmed cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human E48 antigen, highly homologous to the murine Ly-6 antigen ThB, is a GPI-anchored molecule apparently involved in keratinocyte cell-cell adhesion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The E48 antigen, a putative human homologue of the 20-kD protein present in desmosomal preparations of bovine muzzle, and formerly called desmoglein III (dg4), is a promising target antigen for antibody-based therapy of squamous cell carcinoma in man.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To anticipate the effect of high antibody dose treatment, and to evaluate the possible biological involvement of the antigen in carcinogenesis, we set out to molecularly characterize the antigen.</Gene>
<Gene>A cDNA clone encoding the E48 antigen was isolated by expression cloning in COS cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis revealed that the clone contained an open reading frame of 128 amino acids, encoding a core protein of 13,286 kD. Database searching showed that the E48 antigen has a high level of sequence similarity with the mouse ThB antigen, a member of the Ly-6 antigen family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phosphatidylinositol-specific (PI-specific) phospholipase-C treatment indicated that the E48 antigen is glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored (GPI-anchored) to the plasma membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene encoding the E48 antigen is a single copy gene, located on human chromosome 8 in the 8q24-qter region.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of the gene is confined to keratinocytes and squamous tumor cells.</Gene>
<Gene>The putative mouse homologue, the ThB antigen, originally identified as an antigen on cells of the lymphocyte lineage, was shown to be highly expressed in squamous mouse epithelia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the ThB expression level is in keratinocytes, in contrast to that in lymphocytes, not mouse strain related.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transfection of mouse SV40-polyoma transformed mouse NIH/3T3 cells with the E48 cDNA confirmed that the antigen is likely to be involved in cell-cell adhesion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human peroxisomal targeting signal-1 receptor restores peroxisomal protein import in cells from patients with fatal peroxisomal disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two peroxisomal targeting signals, PTS1 and PTS2, are involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisome matrix.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human patients with fatal generalized peroxisomal deficiency disorders fall into at least nine genetic complementation groups.</Gene>
<Gene>Cells from many of these patients are deficient in the import of PTS1-containing proteins, but the causes of the protein-import defect in these patients are unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have cloned and sequenced the human cDNA homologue (PTS1R) of the Pichia pastoris PAS8 gene, the PTS1 receptor (McCollum, D., E. Monosov, and S. Subramani. 1993.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>J. Cell Biol.</Gene>
<Gene>The PTS1R mRNA is expressed in all human tissues examined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Antibodies to the human PTS1R recognize this protein in human, monkey, rat, and hamster cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The protein is localized mainly in the cytosol but is also found to be associated with peroxisomes.</Gene>
<Gene>Part of the peroxisomal PTS1R protein is tightly bound to the peroxisomal membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Antibodies to PTS1R inhibit peroxisomal protein-import of PTS1-containing proteins in a permeabilized CHO cell system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro-translated PTS1R protein specifically binds a serine-lysine-leucine-peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A PAS8-PTS1R fusion protein complements the P. pastoris pas8 mutant.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

label: Gene

text: <Gene>Purification, cloning, and characterization of a human coactivator, PC4, that mediates transcriptional activation of class II genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activator-dependent transcription in mammalian cells requires upstream stimulatory activity (USA)-derived cofactors in addition to those present in TFIID.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel positive cofactor (PC4) purified from the human USA fraction effected a marked enhancement (up to 85-fold) of GAL4-AH-dependent transcription in conjunction with TFIID and other general factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of a corresponding cDNA identified PC4 as a 127 residue single-stranded DNA-binding protein with serine-rich regions near the N-terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recombinant PC4 was functionally equivalent to native PC4, and both proteins markedly enhanced activation by diverse activation domains fused to the DNA-binding domain of GAL4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recombinant PC4 interacted independently both with free or DNA-bound VP16 activation domains and with free or DNA-bound TFIIA-TBP complexes (but not with TBP alone).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that PC4 is a general coactivator that functions cooperatively with TAFs and mediates functional interactions between upstream activators and the general transcriptional machinery.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning, sequencing, and functional expression of a cDNA encoding human coproporphyrinogen oxidase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Coproporphyrinogen oxidase (EC 1.3.3.3) catalyzes the sixth step in the heme biosynthetic pathway, the oxidation of coproporphyrinogen III to protoporphyrinogen IX.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The activity of this enzyme is deficient in the disease hereditary coproporphyria.</Gene>
<Gene>The sequence of the cDNA and predicted amino acid sequence of the human coproporphyrinogen oxidase are presented.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human protein sequence contains a region completely homologous to that we obtained by sequencing an 11-amino acid peptide fragment from purified murine liver coproporphyrinogen oxidase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Results of Southern blotting were consistent with the presence of a single human coproporphyrinogen oxidase gene, and Northern blotting demonstrated one transcript of similar size in erythroid and nonerythroid cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of the cDNA coding for the putative mature human coproporphyrinogen oxidase in Escherichia coli resulted in a 17-fold increase in coproporphyrinogen activity over endogenous activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning and characterization of a novel human sperm antigen (HE2) specifically expressed in the proximal epididymis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel human cDNA encoding a small secretory glycopeptide specifically expressed within the caput and proximal corpus regions of the human epididymis, HE2, has been cloned and sequenced.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Southern hybridization analysis showed it to be derived from a single-copy gene.</Gene>

<Gene>A subclone containing the coding region of the mature peptide was used to generate the putatively encoded peptide as a 10,000 M(r) recombinant fusion protein in a bacterial expression system.</Gene>
<Gene>This recombinant HE2 protein, as well as an oligopeptide deduced from the open-reading frame, was used to raise polyclonal antisera.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence showed that the predicted HE2 peptide is present in the epididymal epithelium and on the sperm surface, where it adopts a typical antigenic pattern with a subacrosomal equatorial distribution on the sperm head.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human liver nicotinamide N-methyltransferase. cDNA cloning, expression, and biochemical characterization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nicotinamide N-methyltransferase (NNMT) catalyzes the N-methylation of nicotinamide and other pyridines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human liver NNMT activity has a bimodal frequency distribution, an observation which raises the possibility that this enzyme activity might be regulated by a genetic polymorphism, a polymorphism that could have functional implications for individual differences in drug and xenobiotic toxicity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>As a first step toward testing that hypothesis, we set out to clone and express a cDNA for human liver NNMT.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human liver NNMT was partially purified, photoaffinity-labeled, subjected to limited proteolysis, and partial amino acid sequence information was obtained.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The polymerase chain reaction was then used to amplify a 550-nucleotide sequence with human liver cDNA as template and primers designed on the basis of the NNMT amino acid sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The 5'- and 3'-ends of a human liver NNMT cDNA were obtained by use of the rapid amplification of cDNA ends.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The combined use of these approaches resulted in the isolation of a human liver NNMT cDNA that was 969 nucleotides in length, with a 792-nucleotide open reading frame that encoded a 264-amino acid protein with a calculated molecular mass of 29.6 kDa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human liver NNMT cDNA was transcribed in vitro and translated with a reticulocyte lysate system to yield a protein with a molecular mass of approximately 29 kDa that comigrated during SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with photoaffinity-labeled human liver NNMT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The NNMT cDNA was also subcloned into the eukaryotic expression vector p91023(B).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>COS-1 cells transfected with this construct expressed a high level of NNMT enzymatic activity, and the biochemical properties of this activity were similar to those of human liver NNMT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human liver NNMT and transfected COS-1 cell NNMT had apparent Km values for the two cosubstrates for the reaction, nicotinamide and S-adenosyl-L-methionine, of 0.43 and 0.38 mM and of 1.8 and 2.2 microM, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IC50 values for the inhibition of NNMT by N1-methylnicotinamide were 60 and 30 microns for human liver and COS-1 cell-expressed NNMT, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning of a cDNA for human liver NNMT will help make it possible to test the hypothesis that inheritance may play a role in the regulation of individual differences in human liver NNMT activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Purification and characterization of the recombinant human calcium-binding S100 proteins CAPL and CACY.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The S100 proteins CAPL and CACY are expressed in a tissue- and cell-specific manner and have been reported to be associated with the metastatic phenotype of tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In order to study the biochemical, cation-binding, and conformational properties, we produced and purified large amounts of the recombinant human proteins in Escherichia coli.</Gene>
<Gene>Several characteristics of native proteins are shown to correspond to those of the bacterially expressed proteins.</Gene>
<Gene>Both are able to form homodimers in vitro, probably the biologically active species, but not heterodimers.</Gene>
<Gene>The Ca(2+)-binding parameters were studied by flow offlysis at physiological ionic strength.</Gene>
<Gene>Both isotherms show a maximum of two Ca2+ per protein and are insensitive to Mg2+, indicating that the sites are of the Ca(2+)-specific type.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The isotherms show slight (CAPL, nH = 1.15) or pronounced (CACY, nH = 1.33) positive cooperativity with K0.5 values of 0.32 mM (CACY) and 0.15 mM (CAPL), indicating that the sites are of the low-affinity type.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conformational changes in the Tyr microenvironment of CACY indicate that Ca2+ binding induces a shift of Tyr to a less polar environment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mg2+ does not affect the fluorescence properties nor does it induce a difference spectrum, thus suggesting that at physiological ionic conditions it does not interact with the protein.</Gene>

<Gene>The Ca(2+)-induced difference spectra of CAPL are about 3 times smaller than those of CACY, suggesting that the additional Tyr84 in CACY is much more sensitive to Ca2+ than the two Tyr residues conserved in both proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>X-arrestin: a new retinal arrestin mapping to the X chromosome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have been using a differential cDNA cloning approach to isolate human retina-specific and retina-enriched genes [1].</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A 1,314 bp cDNA was isolated by this approach, representing a highly retina-specific message encoding a 388 amino acid protein showing 58%, 50%, and 49% homology to bovine beta-arrestin, and bovine and human retinal arrestin (S-antigen), respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chromosomal mapping localized this new arrestin gene to the proximal long arm of the X chromosome, hence it was named X-arrestin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In situ hybridization demonstrated its expression in the inner and outer segments and the inner plexiform regions of the retina.</Gene>
<Gene>Human G(olf) alpha: complementary deoxyribonucleic acid structure and expression in pancreatic islets and other tissues outside the olfactory neuroepithelium and central nervous system.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>G(olf) alpha is a G-protein originally believed to mediate signal transduction exclusively within the olfactory neuroepithelium and subsequently found to be a major stimulatory G-protein in the basal ganglia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we present evidence that G(olf) alpha is expressed in several other tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human isoform of G(olf) alpha was isolated from two human insulinoma cDNA libraries.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Comparison of the human sequence with rat G(olf) alpha shows 91% nucleotide identity (within the coding region) and 99% identity at the amino acid level.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern and reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction analyses indicated that G(olf) alpha is expressed in all human insulinomas examined thus far as well as in normal pancreatic islets.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>G(olf) alpha mRNA was also detected in testis, retina, brain, and liver.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot analysis of various mouse tissues demonstrated that the level of G(olf) alpha protein in islets is lower than that in the olfactory neuroepithelium and other parts of the brain; its expression in retina, lung, and spleen was moderately higher than that in islets, and its expression in testis approached that in olfactory neuroepithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>G(olf) alpha was also detected by immunohistochemistry in mouse islets, human insulinomas, the epithelial lining of mouse epididymis, photoreceptor cells of mouse retina, and mouse lung alveoli.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest a role for G(olf) alpha in a diverse population of cells located outside the olfactory neuroepithelium and central nervous system.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cDNAs encoding the large subunit of human replication factor C.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Replication factor C (RFC) is a multisubunit, DNA polymerase accessory protein required for the coordinated synthesis of both DNA strands during simian virus 40 DNA replication in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previous studies have shown that RFC is a DNA-dependent ATPase that binds in a structure-specific manner to the 3' end of a primer hybridized to a template DNA, an activity thought intrinsic to the 140-kDa component of this multisubunit complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, the isolation and analysis of cDNAs encoding this subunit is described.</Gene>
<Gene>Analysis of the full-length coding sequence revealed an open reading frame of 3.4 kb, encoding an 1148-amino acid protein with a predicted molecular mass of 130 kDa.</Gene>

<Gene>A putative ATP-binding motif was observed that is similar to a motif in several of the smaller subunits of RFC and in functionally homologous replication factors of bacterial and viral origin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A " DEAD " box is also conserved among these proteins.</Gene>
<Gene>The predicted protein shows significant identity with a DNA-binding protein of murine origin (B. Luckow, P. Lichter, and G. Schütz, personal communication).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Regions of similarity were also seen between the amino acid sequences of the 140-kDa subunit of RFC, poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase, and bacterial DNA ligases--possibly representing a conserved structural feature of these proteins that bind similar DNA substrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning and centrosomal localization of human caltractin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Caltractin, a 20-kDa calcium-binding protein, was previously purified and cloned at the DNA level from the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is a structural component of the basal body complex, the major microtubule-organizing center in Chlamydomonas and the functional homolog of the centrosome in the animal cell.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we report the characterization of a cDNA encoding a human caltractin that shares a high degree of amino acid identity (70%) with its algal counterpart.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Caltractin was identified in both HeLa and BHK cells as a 21-kDa polypeptide specifically localized to the centrosome of interphase and mitotic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The high level of conservation in the amino acid sequence of caltractin from algae to humans and its association with the major microtubule-organizing center in the cell suggest that caltractin plays a fundamental role in microtubule-organizing center structure and function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genomic binding-site cloning reveals an estrogen-responsive gene that encodes a RING finger protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Estrogen receptor (ER)-binding fragments were isolated from human genomic DNA by using a recombinant ER protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using one of these fragments as a probe, we have identified an estrogen-responsive gene that encodes a putative zinc finger protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It has a RING finger motif present in a family of apparent DNA-binding proteins and is designated estrogen-responsive finger protein (efp).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>efp cDNA contains a consensus estrogen-responsive element at the 3' untranslated region that can act as a downstream estrogen-dependent enhancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, efp is regulated by estrogen as demonstrated at both the mRNA and the protein level in ER-positive cells derived from mammary gland.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that efp may represent an estrogen-responsive transcription factor that mediates phenotypic expression of the diverse estrogen action.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, the genomic binding-site cloning may be applicable for isolation of the target genes of other transcription factors.</Gene>
<Gene>A human mitochondrial ATP-dependent protease that is highly homologous to bacterial Lon protease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have cloned a human ATP-dependent protease that is highly homologous to members of the bacterial Lon protease family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cloned gene encodes a protein of 963 amino acids with a calculated molecular mass of 106 kDa, slightly higher than that observed by Western blotting the protein from human tissues and cell lines (100 kDa).</Gene>
<Gene>A single species of mRNA was found for this Lon protease in all human tissues examined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The protease is encoded in the nucleus, and the amino-terminal portion of the protein sequence contains a potential mitochondrial targeting presequence.</Gene>
<Gene>Immunofluorescence microscopy suggested a predominantly mitochondrial localization for the Lon protease in cultured human cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A truncated LON gene, in which translation was initiated at Met118 of the coding sequence, was expressed in Escherichia coli and produced a protease that degraded alpha-casein in vitro in an ATP-dependent manner and had other properties similar to E. coli Lon protease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning of cDNA encoding an unrecognized component of amyloid in Alzheimer disease.</Gene>
<Gene>A neuropathological hallmark of Alzheimer disease (AD) is a widespread amyloid deposition.</Gene>
<Gene>We analyzed the entire amino acid sequences in an amyloid preparation and found, in addition to the major beta/A4-protein (A beta) fragment, two unknown peptides.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We raised antibodies against synthetic peptides using subsequences of these peptides.</Gene>
<Gene>These antibodies immunostained amyloid in neuritic and diffuse plaques as well as vascular amyloid.</Gene>
<Gene>Electron microscopic analysis demonstrated that the immunostaining was localized on amyloid fibrils.</Gene>

<Gene>We have isolated an apparently full-length cDNA encoding a 140-amino-acid protein within which two previously unreported amyloid sequences are encoded in tandem in the most hydrophobic domain.</Gene>
<Gene>We tentatively named this 35-amino acid peptide NAC (non-A beta component of AD amyloid) and its precursor NACP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NAC is the second component, after A beta, identified chemically in the purified AD amyloid preparation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Secondary structure predictions indicate that the NAC peptide sequence has a strong tendency to form beta-structures consistent with its association with amyloid.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NACP is detected as a M(r) 19,000 protein in the cytosolic fraction of brain homogenates and comigrates on immunoblots with NACP synthesized in Escherichia coli from NACP cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NACP mRNA is expressed principally in brain but is also expressed in low concentrations in all tissues examined except in liver, suggesting its ubiquitous and brain-specific functions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The availability of the cDNA encoding full-length NACP should help to elucidate the mechanisms of amyloidosis in AD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning of Nrf1, an NF-E2-related transcription factor, by genetic selection in yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have devised a complementation assay in yeast to clone mammalian transcriptional activators and have used it to identify a human basic leucine-zipper transcription factor that we have designated Nrf1 for NF-E2-related factor 1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nrf1 potentially encodes a 742-aa protein and displays marked homology to the mouse and human NF-E2 transcription factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nrf1 activates transcription via NF-E2 binding sites in yeast cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ubiquitous expression pattern of Nrf1 and the range of promoters containing the NF-E2 binding motif suggest that this gene may play a role in the regulation of heme synthesis and ferritin genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recessive mutations in the gene encoding the beta-subunit of rod phosphodiesterase in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have found four mutations in the human gene encoding the beta-subunit of rod cGMP phosphodiesterase (PDE beta) that cosegregate with autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa, a degenerative disease of photoreceptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In one family two affected siblings both carry allelic nonsense mutations at codons 298 and 531.</Gene>
<Gene>Affected individuals have abnormal rod and cone electroretinograms.</Gene>

<Gene>PDE beta is the second member of the phototransduction cascade besides rhodopsin that is absent or altered as a cause of retinitis pigmentosa, suggesting that other members of this pathway may be defective in other forms of this disease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chromosomal localization of genes encoding the transcription factors, c-rel, NF-kappa Bp50, NF-kappa Bp65, and lyt-10 by fluorescence in situ hybridization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have used fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to perform precise chromosomal mapping of the genes encoding the transcription factors c-rel, NF-kappa Bp50, NF-kappa Bp65, and lyt-10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The previously published assignments of c-rel and NF-kappa Bp50 have been refined to specific bands.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The map position of lyt-10, inferred from its isolation from a t(10;14)(q24;q32) translocation, has been confirmed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NF-kappa Bp65 has now been mapped to 11q13, a site of frequent involvement in aberration in multiple tumor types.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning, sequencing and expression of a cDNA encoding mammalian valyl-tRNA synthetase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A fragment of the cDNA encoding a rat valyl-tRNA synthetase (TrsVal)-like protein was cloned from a rat cDNA library in lambda gt11 using an oligodeoxyribonucleotide (oligo) probe.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Three independent plaque clones containing the human TrsVal cDNA were then isolated from a lambda gt10 human erythroleukemia cDNA library using the rat cDNA fragment as the hybridization probe.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analyses of the cDNA fragments provided a 3.2-kb sequence with an open reading frame that contained the 'HIGH' synthetase signature sequence and the tRNA 3'-end-binding motif, KMSKS, and putative Val-binding motif, EWCISRQ.</Gene>
<Gene>The sequence was extended to the 3' end of the cDNA by the polymerase chain reaction using an internal primer and an oligo(dT) adapter.</Gene>

<Gene>The deduced 1051-amino-acid sequence shares 65% identity with yeast TrsVal, and contains a highly basic N-terminal region, a newly evolved protease-sensitive region in sequence close to the C terminus, and several sites for protein kinase C phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A 3-kb cDNA fragment was sub-cloned into plasmid pSVL and expressed in COS-7 cells; up to a sevenfold increase in TrsVal activity was obtained.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results confirm the cloning and sequencing of a human TrsVal-encoding cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Localization of the intronless gene coding for calmodulin-like protein CLP to human chromosome 10p13-ter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The functional intronless gene coding for a calmodulin-like protein (CLP) has been localized to human chromosome 10p13-ter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chromosomal assignment was performed by Southern blot analysis of DNA from human-rodent somatic cell hybrids and amplification of a CLP gene-specific 1090-bp DNA fragment by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) on DNA from human-hamster cell hybrids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Chromosomal sublocalization was carried out by in situ hybridization of human chromosome metaphase spreads.</Gene>
<Gene>The CLP gene is the first member of the human calmodulin/calmodulin-like gene family to be chromosomally sublocalized.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Its presence near the telomeric end of the short arm of chromosome 10 may be of significance with respect to its highly (epithelial) cell-type restricted expression in vivo and strong downregulation upon malignant transformation.</Gene>
<Gene>The generation of a human CLP gene-specific sequence tag site specified by the two primers used for PCR should prove useful for future linkage studies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A novel form of cytochrome P-450 family 4 in human polymorphonuclear leukocytes. cDNA cloning and expression of leukotriene B4 omega-hydroxylase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of cDNA clones for human leukotriene B4 (LTB4) omega-hydroxylase clearly demonstrates that the hydroxylase is a member of the cytochrome P-450 (CYP) superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cDNA</Gene>
<Gene>clones isolated from a human leukocyte cDNA library with CYP4A4 cDNA as a probe encode a protein of 520 amino acids with a molecular weight of 59,805.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced amino acid sequence contains an invariant cysteine in the conserved heme-binding domain near the C terminus, characteristic of the P-450 superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The microsomes from yeast cells transfected with an expression vector pAAH5 carrying isolated cDNA catalyzed the omega-hydroxylation of LTB4 with a Km value of 0.71 microM, and its activity was significantly inhibited by carbon monoxide and by antisera against CYP4A4, consistent with the properties previously reported with LTB4 omega-hydroxylase in human polymorphonuclear leukocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The amino acid sequence of LTB4 omega-hydroxylase (P-450LTB omega) shows 31-44% similarity to those of CYP4A, CYP4B, and CYP4C, whereas less than 25% similarity was observed with any of the other P-450 families.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>According to the systematic classification of the P-450 superfamily, P-450LTB omega is classified into the CYP4 family but does not belong to any of the known CYP4 subfamilies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This P-450 composes a new subfamily of CYP4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RNA blot analysis indicated that mRNA hybridized to the cDNA was expressed in the polymorphonuclear leukocytes as well as leukocytes from four individuals.</Gene>
<Gene>Isolation of the cDNA opens the way to investigate the physiological role and to regulation of the omega-hydroxylase in the inflammation process.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning of the cDNA for the catalytic subunit of human DNA polymerase epsilon.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA encoding the catalytic polypeptide of human DNA polymerase epsilon was cloned.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced amino acid sequence reveals that the catalytic polypeptide is 2257 amino acids in length and its calculated molecular mass is 258 kDa.</Gene>
<Gene>A single RNA message of 7.5 kilobases was recognized by isolated cDNA clones.</Gene>
<Gene>The identity of the cDNA was verified by direct amino acid sequencing of tryptic fragments derived from the catalytic polypeptide of the HeLa DNA polymerase epsilon.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The primary structure comparison with multiple DNA polymerases indicates that human DNA polymerase epsilon catalytic polypeptide is a homolog of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae DNA polymerase II catalytic polypeptide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The proteins are 39% identical.</Gene>
<Gene>In the region containing known DNA polymerase consensus motifs, the identity is 63%.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of the mRNA encoding DNA polymerase epsilon is strongly dependent on cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cDNA cloning and mitochondrial import of the beta-subunit of the human electron-transfer flavoprotein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a cDNA clone which encodes the entire beta-subunit of human electron-transferring flavoprotein (ETF) by screening an expression library from human liver using polyclonal antibodies against porcine ETF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This cDNA encodes a protein of 255 amino-acid residues with a predicted molecular mass of 27,877 Da which shows a high degree of similarity with partial amino-acid sequences obtained from both rat liver and Paracoccus denitrificans beta-ETF.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern-blot analysis shows that the human beta-ETF mRNA is approximately 1 kb in size and is abundant in liver, heart and skeletal muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Incubation with intact mitochondria indicates that the cDNA-encoded beta-ETF polypeptide contains the information necessary to reach the mitochondrial matrix.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These data are in agreement with previous experiments suggesting that beta-ETF, unlike the majority of nuclear-encoded mitochondrial matrix proteins, does not have a cleavable leader peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, when valinomycin is added to the incubation mixture, the import is abolished, thus demonstrating that it is an energy-dependent process.</Gene>
<Gene>Interestingly, the sequence analysis of beta-ETF protein identifies a 26.3% identity with the Fix A gene product of the nitrogen-fixing bacterium Azorhizobium caulinodans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning of human cDNAs encoding mitochondrial and cytosolic serine hydroxymethyltransferases and chromosomal localization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human cDNAs for cytosolic and mitochondrial serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) were cloned by functional complementation of an Escherichia coli glyA mutant with a human cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA for the cytosolic enzyme encodes a 483-residue protein of M(r) 53,020.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNA for the mitochondrial enzyme encodes a mature protein of 474 residues of M(r) 52,400.</Gene>

<Gene>The deduced protein sequences share a high degree of sequence identity to each other (63%), and the individual isozymes are highly homologous to the analogous rabbit liver cytosolic (92% identity) and mitochondrial (97% identity) SHMT isozymes (Martini, F., Angelaccio, S., Pascarella, S., Barra, D., Bossa, F., and Schirch, V. (1987)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>J. Biol.</Gene>
<Gene>Chem.</Gene>
<Gene>262, 5499-5509; Martini, F., Maras, B., Tanci, P., Angelaccio, S., Pascarella, S., Barra, D., Bossa, F., and Schirch, V. (1989) J. Biol.</Gene>
<Gene>Chem.</Gene>
<Gene>SHMT is a highly conserved protein with the human isozymes retaining about 43% sequence identity with the E. coli protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human cytosolic and mitochondrial SHMT genes were localized to chromosome regions 17p11.2 and 12q13, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The high degree of nucleotide sequence identity between the two isozymes, and the presence of keratin genes in both chromosomal regions, is consistent with these regions of chromosome 12 and 17 arising by a duplication event.</Gene>
<Gene>Crystal structures of human calcineurin and the human FKBP12-FK506-calcineurin complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Calcineurin (CaN) is a calcium- and calmodulin-dependent protein serine/threonine phosphate which is critical for several important cellular processes, including T-cell activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CaN is the target of the immunosuppressive drugs</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cyclosporin A and FK506, which inhibit CaN after forming complexes with cytoplasmic binding proteins (cyclophilin and FKBP12, respectively).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report here the crystal structures of full-length human CaN at 2.1 A resolution and of the complex of human CaN with FKBP12-FK506 at 3.5 A resolution.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the native CaN structure, an auto-inhibitory element binds at the Zn/Fe-containing active site.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The metal-site geometry and active-site water structure suggest a catalytic mechanism involving nucleophilic attack on the substrate phosphate by a metal-activated water molecule.</Gene>
<Gene>In the FKBP12-FK506-CaN complex, the auto-inhibitory element is displaced from the active site.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The site of binding of FKBP12-FK506 appears to be shared by other non-competitive inhibitors of calcineurin, including a natural anchoring protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HCC-1, a novel chemokine from human plasma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A novel CC chemokine, HCC-1, was isolated from the hemofiltrate of patients with chronic renal failure.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HCC-1 has a relative molecular mass of 8,673 and consists of 74 amino acids including four cysteines linked to disulfide bonds.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HCC-1 cDNA was cloned from human bone marrow and shown to code for the mature protein plus a putative 19-residue leader sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mature HCC-1 has sequence identity of 46% with macrophage inflammatory protein (MIP)-1 alpha and MIP-1 beta, and 29-37% with the other human CC chemokines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike MIP-1 alpha and the other CC chemokines, HCC-1 is expressed constitutively in several normal tissues (spleen, liver, skeletal and heart muscle, gut, and bone marrow), and is present at high concentrations (1-80 nM) in plasma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HCC-1 has weak activities on human monocytes and acts via receptors that also recognize MIP-1 alpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It induced intracellular Ca2+ changes and enzyme release, but no chemotaxis, at concentrations of 100-1,000 nM, and was inactive on T lymphocytes, neutrophils, and eosinophil leukocytes.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, HCC-1 enhanced the proliferation of CD34+ myeloid progenitor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It was as effective as MIP-1 alpha, but about 100-fold less potent.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>LAF-4 encodes a lymphoid nuclear protein with transactivation potential that is homologous to AF-4, the gene fused to MLL in t(4;11) leukemias.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel human gene, LAF-4, was isolated from a subtracted cDNA library that showed strong sequence similarity to AF-4, a gene that is translocated in t(4;11)(q21;q23) acute lymphoblastic leukemias (ALLs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In t(4;11) ALL, the AF-4 gene at 4q21 is translocated into the MLL locus at 11q23, resulting in the expression of an MLL/AF-4 fusion protein that is the presumptive oncoprotein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AF-4 and LAF-4 are homologous throughout their coding regions, yet neither protein is related to previously cloned genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human LAF-4 readily hybridized with genes in mouse and chicken, thus showing that this gene family has been highly conserved during vertebrate evolution.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In mouse tissues, LAF-4 mRNA was found to be present at highest levels in lymphoid tissues, present at lower levels in brain and lung, and absent from other tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In human and mouse lymphoid cell lines, LAF-4 expression was highest in pre-B cells, intermediate in mature B cells, and absent in plasma cells, thus pointing to a potential regulatory role for LAF-4 in lymphoid development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Antibodies to LAF-4 showed it to be a nuclear protein that showed an uneven, granular immunofluorescence pattern.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro-translated LAF-4 was able to bind strongly to double-stranded DNA cellulose.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, both LAF-4 and AF-4 had domains that activated transcription strongly when fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, the AF-4 transactivation domain is retained in the MLL/AF-4 fusion protein; thus, it may contribute to the transforming potential of the oncoprotein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, the cloning of LAF-4 has defined a new family of potential regulatory proteins that may function in lymphoid development and oncogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A human ubiquitin conjugating enzyme, L-UBC, maps in the Alzheimer's disease locus on chromosome 14q24.3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have identified a novel ubiquitin conjugating enzyme gene, L-UBC, which maps to human Chromosome (Chr) 14q24.3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is also the location of the major early onset familial Alzheimer's disease gene (FAD3).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>L-UBC encodes a protein that demonstrates homology to the yeast ubiquitin conjugating enzyme, UBC-4, and human UbcH5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Their functions are to ubiquitinate specific proteins targeted for degradation.</Gene>
<Gene>The protein also exhibits very strong homology to a rabbit protein, E2-F1, which mediates p53 degradation driven by papilloma virus E6 protein in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The accumulation of specific proteins that have undergone aberrant processing in neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques is the classic pathological feature in brains of Alzheimer's disease patients.</Gene>
<Gene>Abnormal ubiquitination has previously been suggested to play a role in the etiology of Alzheimer's disease.</Gene>
<Gene>This gene therefore represents a plausible candidate gene for FAD3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning, chromosomal localization, and tissue expression of autotaxin from human teratocarcinoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Autotaxin, a potent human tumor cell motility-stimulating exophosphodiesterase, was isolated and cloned from the human teratocarcinoma cell line NTera2D1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced amino acid sequence for the teratocarcinoma autotaxin has 94% identity to the melanoma-derived protein, 90% identity to rat brain phosphodiesterase I/nucleotide pyrophosphatase (PD-I alpha), and 44% identity to the plasma cell membrane marker PC-I. Utilizing polymerase chain reaction screening of the CEPH YAC library, we localized the autotaxin gene to human chromosome 8q23-24.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis of relative mRNA from multiple human tissues revealed that autotaxin mRNA steady state expression is most abundant in brain, placenta, ovary, and small intestine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning and characterization of a putative novel human osteoclast-specific 116-kDa vacuolar proton pump subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA encoding a possible novel human 116-kDa polypeptide subunit of the osteoclastic proton pump (OC-116KDa) has been identified by differential screening of a human osteoclastoma cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted sequence of OC-116kDa consists of 822 amino acids and is 46.9% and 47.2% identical at the amino acid level to the 116-KDa polypeptide of the vacuolar proton pump of rat and bovine brain respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>OC-116KDa mRNA was found at high levels in osteoclastomas by Northern analysis but was not detected in tumor stromal cells or in other tissues including kidney, liver, skeletal muscle and brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>OC-116KDa mRNA was localized to multinucleated giant cells within the osteoclastoma tumor by in situ hybridization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ubiquitously expressed pICln protein forms homomeric complexes in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Endothelial cells contain a cell-volume sensitive chloride conductance with biophysical properties similar to those of a ubiquitously expressed chloride current that is activated by cell swelling.</Gene>
<Gene>The latter current has been associated with the ICln protein (pICln) which may be the chloride channel itself or, alternatively, a channel regulator.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We were therefore interested in whether pICln is involved in the endothelial volume-sensitive chloride current.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>As a first step, we have cloned human pICln and studied its expression at the protein level.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using a polyclonal antiserum raised against human pICln we found a widespread expression of pICln, both in endothelial cells and in other cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A characteristic feature of pICln is its anomalous migration during denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also demonstrate that bacterially expressed pICln forms homomeric complexes in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning, sequencing and expression of a novel cDNA encoding human vacuolar ATPase (14-kDa subunit).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA encoding the 14-kDa subunit of vacuolar ATPase was cloned from human fetal brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The sequence was composed of 680 nucleotides containing an open reading frame of 357 nucleotides.</Gene>
<Gene>The deduced peptide sequence consisted of 119 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular weight of 13,369 Da and a pI of 5.19.</Gene>

<Gene>Overall, this amino-acid sequence was respectively 69% and 70% identical to those of Manduca sexta and Drosophila melanogaster 14-kDa subunits, although the two representatives of Class Insecta were remarkably similar to one another (91% identity).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Three regions in particular (the N-terminal, amino acids 5-36; the middle, residues 58-68; and the C-terminal, residues 88-118) were highly conserved.</Gene>
<Gene>Hence, we think that the 14-kDa subunits have evolved from the same ancestral gene, and that the three conserved regions are important for the structure and function of vacuolar ATPase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A single 0.8-kb band was detected in various human tissues by Northern blot analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>Since the human 14-kDa subunit is expressed ubiquitously, it might be a housekeeping protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A separate transcript found in the cDNA library lacked a 6-bp segment in the 5' non-coding region (nucleotides -40 to -35) and also carried a 23C to T (8Thr to Ile) point mutation in the coding region; these minor differences likely reflected normal polymorphism.</Gene>
<Gene>Molecular cloning and functional analysis of a human cDNA encoding an Escherichia coli AlkB homolog, a protein involved in DNA alkylation damage repair.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Escherichia coli AlkB protein is involved in protecting cells against mutation and cell death induced specifically by SN2-type alkylating agents such as methyl methanesulfonate (MMS).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A human cDNA encoding a polypeptide homologous to E.coli AlkB was discovered by searching a database of expressed sequence tags (ESTs) derived from high throughput cDNA sequencing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The full-length human AlkB homolog (hABH) cDNA clone contains a 924 bp open reading frame encoding a 34 kDa protein which is 52% similar and 23% identical to E.coli AlkB.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The hABH gene, which maps to chromosome 14q24, was ubiquitously expressed in 16 human tissues examined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>When hABH was expressed in E.coli alkB mutant cells partial rescue of the cells from MMS-induced cell death occurred.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Under the conditions used expression of hABH in skin fibroblasts was not regulated by treatment with MMS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings show that the AlkB protein is structurally and functionally conserved from bacteria to human, but its regulation may have diverged during evolution.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of human urocortin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Urocortin, a new member of the CRF peptide family which also includes urotensin I and sauvagine, was recently cloned from the rat midbrain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The synthetic replicate of urocortin was found to bind with high affinity to type 1 and type 2 CRF receptors and, based upon its anatomic localization within the brain, was proposed to be a natural ligand for the type 2 CRF receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a genomic library, we have cloned the human counterpart of rat urocortin and localized it to human chromosome 2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human and rat urocortin share 95% identity within the mature peptide region.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Synthetic human urocortin binds with high affinity to CRF receptor types 1, 2 alpha, and 2 beta, stimulates cAMP accumulation from cells stably transfected with these receptors, and acts in vitro to release ACTH from dispersed rat anterior pituitary cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the CRF-binding protein binds human urocortin with high affinity and can prevent urocortin-stimulated ACTH secretion in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The inhibitory effect of the CRF-binding protein on human urocortin can be blocked by biologically inactive CRF fragments, such as CRF(9-33).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning, expression, and chromosomal localization of a human brain-specific Na(+)-dependent inorganic phosphate cotransporter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We describe the molecular cloning of a cDNA encoding a human brain Na(+)-dependent inorganic phosphate (P(i)) cotransporter (hBNPI).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of hBNPI reveal a protein of 560 amino acids with six to eight putative transmembrane segments.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>hBNPI shares a high degree of homology with other Na(+)-dependent inorganic P(i) cotransporters, including those found in rat brain and human and rabbit kidney.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of hBNPI in COS-1 cells results in Na(+)-dependent P(i) uptake.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis demonstrates that hBNPI mRNA is expressed predominantly in brain and most abundantly in neuron-enriched regions such as the amygdala and hippocampus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moderate levels of expression are also observed in glia-enriched areas such as the corpus callosum, and low levels are observed in the substantia nigra, subthalamic nuclei, and thalamus.</Gene>
<Gene>In situ hybridization histochemistry reveals relatively high levels of hBNPI mRNA in pyramidal neurons of the cerebral cortex and hippocampus and in granule neurons of dentate gyrus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The level of hBNPI mRNA is quite low in fetal compared with adult human brain, suggesting developmental regulation of hBNPI gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Southern analyses of nine eukaryotic genomic DNAs probed under stringent conditions with hBNPI cDNA revealed that the hBNPI gene is highly conserved during vertebrate evolution and that each gene is most likely present as a single copy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using fluorescent in situ hybridization, we localized hBNPI to the long arm of chromosome 19 (19q13) in close proximity to the late-onset familial Alzheimer's disease locus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In its active form, the GTP-binding protein rab8 interacts with a stress-activated protein kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rab8 is a small GTP-binding protein that plays a role in vesicular transport from the trans-Golgi network to the basolateral plasma membrane in polarized epithelial cells (MDCK), and to the dendritic surface in hippocampal neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As is the case for most other rab proteins, the precise molecular interactions by which rab8 carries out its function remain to be elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report the identification and the complete cDNA-derived amino acid sequence of a murine rab8-interacting protein (rab8ip) that specifically interacts with rab8 in a GTP-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rab8ip displays 93% identity with the GC kinase, a serine/threonine protein kinase recently identified in human lymphoid tissue that is activated in the stress response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Like the GC kinase, rab8ip has protein kinase activity manifested by autophosphorylation and phosphorylation of the classical serine/threonine protein kinase substrates, myelin basic protein and casein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When coexpressed in transfected 293T cells, rab8 and the rab8ip/GC kinase formed a complex that could be recovered by immunoprecipitation with antibodies to rab8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cell fractionation and immunofluorescence analyses indicate that in MDCK cells endogenous rab8ip is present both in the cytosol and as a peripheral membrane protein concentrated in the Golgi region and basolateral plasma membrane domains, sites where rab8 itself is also located.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In light of recent evidence that rab proteins may act by promoting the stabilization of SNARE complexes, the specific GTP-dependent association of rab8 with the rab8ip/GC kinase raises the possibility that rab-regulated protein phosphorylation is important for vesicle targeting or fusion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the rab8ip/GC kinase may serve to modulate secretion in response to stress stimuli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Distinct pharmacological properties and distribution in neurons and endocrine cells of two isoforms of the human vesicular monoamine transporter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A second isoform of the human vesicular monoamine transporter (hVMAT) has been cloned from a pheochromocytoma cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The contribution of the two transporter isoforms to monoamine storage in human neuroendocrine tissues was examined with isoform-specific polyclonal antibodies against hVMAT1 and hVMAT2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Central, peripheral, and enteric neurons express only VMAT2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>VMAT1 is expressed exclusively in neuroendocrine, including chromaffin and enterochromaffin, cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>VMAT1 and VMAT2 are coexpressed in all chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VMAT2 alone is expressed in histamine-storing enterochromaffin-like cells of the oxyntic mucosa of the stomach.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The transport characteristics and pharmacology of each VMAT isoform have been directly compared after expression in digitonin-permeabilized fibroblastic (CV-1) cells, providing information about substrate feature recognition by each transporter and the role of vesicular monoamine storage in the mechanism of action of psychopharmacologic and neurotoxic agents in human.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Serotonin has a similar affinity for both transporters.</Gene>
<Gene>Catecholamines exhibit a 3-fold higher affinity, and histamine exhibits a 30-fold higher affinity, for VMAT2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Reserpine and ketanserin are slightly more potent inhibitors of VMAT2-mediated transport than of VMAT1-mediated transport, whereas tetrabenazine binds to and inhibits only VMAT2. N-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium, phenylethylamine, amphetamine, and methylenedioxymethamphetamine are all more potent inhibitors of VMAT2 than of VMAT1, whereas fenfluramine is a more potent inhibitor of VMAT1-mediated monamine transport than of VMAT2-mediated monoamine transport.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The unique distributions of hVMAT1 and hVMAT2 provide new markers for multiple neuroendocrine lineages, and examination of their transport properties provides mechanistic insights into the pharmacology and physiology of amine storage in cardiovascular, endocrine, and central nervous system function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The adipocyte specific transcription factor C/EBPalpha modulates human ob gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The ob gene product, leptin, apparently exclusively expressed in adipose tissue, is a signaling factor regulating body weight homeostasis and energy balance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ob gene expression is increased in obese rodents and regulated by feeding, insulin, and glucocorticoids, which supports the concept that ob gene expression is under hormonal control, which is expected for a key factor controlling body weight homeostasis and energy balance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In humans, ob mRNA expression is increased in gross obesity; however, the effects of the above factors on human ob expression are unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We describe the structure of the human ob gene and initial functional analysis of its promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human ob gene's three exons cover approximately 15 kb of genomic DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The entire coding region is contained in exons 2 and 3, which are separated by a 2-kb intron.</Gene>
<Gene>The first small 30-bp untranslated exon is located >10.5 kb upstream of the initiator ATG codon.</Gene>
<Gene>Three kilobases of DNA upstream of the transcription start site has been cloned and characterized.</Gene>
<Gene>Only 217 bp of 5' sequence are required for basal adipose tissue-specific expression of the ob gene as well as enhanced expression by C/EBPalpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutation of the single C/EBPalpha site in this region abolished inducibility of the promoter by C/EBPalpha in cotransfection assays.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene structure will facilitate our analysis of ob mutations in human obesity, whereas knowledge of sequence elements and factors regulating ob gene expression should be of major importance in the prevention and treatment of obesity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of a specific coactivator, ARA70, for the androgen receptor in human prostate cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The androgen receptor (AR) is a member of the steroid receptor superfamily that plays an important role in male sexual differentiation and prostate cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations or abnormal expression of AR in prostate cancer can play a key role in the process that changes prostate cancer from androgen-dependent to an androgen-independent stage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using a yeast two-hybrid system, we were able to isolate a ligand-dependent AR-associated protein (ARA70), which functions as an activator to enhance AR transcriptional activity 10-fold in the presence of 10(-10)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>M dihydrotestosterone or 10(-9)</Gene>
<Gene>M testosterone, but not 10(-6)</Gene>
<Gene>M hydroxyflutamide in human prostate cancer DU145 cells.</Gene>

<Gene>Our data further indicated that ARA70 Will only slightly induce the transcriptional activity of other steroid receptors such as estrogen receptor, glucocorticoid receptor, and progesterone receptor in DU145 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these data suggest that AR may need a specific coactivator(s) such as ARA70 for optimal androgen activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intergenic splicing of MDS1 and EVI1 occurs in normal tissues as well as in myeloid leukemia and produces a new member of the PR domain family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The EVI1 gene, located at chromosome band 3q26, is overexpressed in some myeloid leukemia patients with breakpoints either 5' of the gene in the t(3;3)(q21;q26) or 3' of the gene in the inv(3)(q21q26).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>EVI1 is also expressed as part of a fusion transcript with the transcription factor AML1 in the t(3;21)(q26;q22), associated with myeloid leukemia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In cells with t(3;21), additional fusion transcripts are AML1-MDS1 and AML1-MDS1-EVI1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MDS1 is located at 3q26 170-400 kb upstream (telomeric) of EVI1 in the chromosomal region in which some of the breakpoints 5' of EVI1 have been mapped.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MDS1 has been identified as a single gene as well as a previously unreported exon(s) of EVI1 We have analyzed the relationship between MDS1 and EVI1 to determine whether they are two separate genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this report, we present evidence indicating that MDS1 exists in normal tissues both as a unique transcript and as a normal fusion transcript with EVI1, with an additional 188 codons at the 5' end of the previously reported EVI1 open reading frame.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This additional region has about 40% homology at the amino acid level with the PR domain of the retinoblastoma-interacting zinc-finger protein RIZ.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results are important in view of the fact that EVI1 and MDS1 are involved in leukemia associated with chromosomal translocation breakpoints in the region between these genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MDC9, a widely expressed cellular disintegrin containing cytoplasmic SH3 ligand domains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cellular disintegrins are a family of proteins that are related to snake venom integrin ligands and metalloproteases.</Gene>

<Gene>We have cloned and sequenced the mouse and human homologue of a widely expressed cellular disintegrin, which we have termed MDC9 (for metalloprotease/disintegrin/cysteine-rich protein 9).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced mouse and human protein sequences are 82% identical.</Gene>

<Gene>MDC9 contains several distinct protein domains: a signal sequence is followed by a prodomain and a domain with sequence similarity to snake venom metalloproteases, a disintegrin domain, a cysteine-rich region, an EGF repeat, a membrane anchor, and a cytoplasmic tail.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cytoplasmic tail of MDC9 has two proline-rich sequences which can bind the SH3 domain of Src, and may therefore function as SH3 ligand domains.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot analysis shows that MDC9 is an approximately 84-kD glycoprotein in all mouse tissues examined, and in NIH 3T3 fibroblast and C2C12 myoblast mouse cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MDC9 can be both cell surface biotinylated and 125I-labeled in NIH 3T3 mouse fibroblasts, indicating that the protein is present on the plasma membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of MDC9 in COS-7 cells yields an 84-kD protein, and immunofluorescence analysis of COS-7 cells expressing MDC9 shows a staining pattern that is consistent with a plasma membrane localization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The apparent molecular mass of 84 kD suggests that MDC9 contains a membrane-anchored metalloprotease and disintegrin domain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We propose that MDC9 might function as a membrane-anchored integrin ligand or metalloprotease, or that MDC9 may combine both activities in one protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A GLRA1 null mutation in recessive hyperekplexia challenges the functional role of glycine receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dominant missense mutations in the human glycine receptor (GlyR) alpha 1 subunit gene (GLRA1) give rise to hereditary hyperekplexia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These mutations impair agonist affinities and change conductance states of expressed mutant channels, resulting in a partial loss of function.</Gene>
<Gene>In a recessive case of hyperekplexia, we found a deletion of exons 1-6 of the GLRA1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Born to consanguineous parents, the affected child is homozygous for this GLRA1(null) allele consistent with a complete loss of gene function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The child displayed exaggerated startle responses and pronounced head-retraction jerks reflecting a disinhibition of vestigial brain-stem reflexes.</Gene>
<Gene>In contrast, proprio- and exteroceptive inhibition of muscle activity previously correlated to glycinergic mechanisms were not affected.</Gene>

<Gene>This case demonstrates that, in contrast to the lethal effect of a null allele in the recessive mouse mutant oscillator (Glra1 spd-ot), the loss of the GlyR alpha 1 subunit is effectively compensated in man.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Induction of apoptosis by Apo-2 ligand, a new member of the tumor necrosis factor cytokine family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cytokines in the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) family regulate development and function of the immune system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a new member of this family, designated Apo-2 ligand (Apo-2L), via an expressed sequence tag.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Apo-2L is a 281-amino acid protein, related most closely to Fas/Apo-1 ligand.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transfected Apo-2L is expressed at the cell surface with its C terminus exposed, indicating a type II transmembrane protein topology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Like Fas/Apo-1 ligand and TNF, the C-terminal extracellular region of Apo-2L (amino acids 114-281) exhibits a homotrimeric subunit structure.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Soluble Apo-2L induces extensive apoptosis in lymphoid as well as non-lymphoid tumor cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The effect of Apo-2L is not inhibited by soluble Fas/Apo-1 and TNF receptors; moreover, expression of human Fas/Apo-1 in mouse fibroblasts, which confers sensitivity to induction of apoptosis by agonistic anti-Fas/Apo-1 antibody, does not confer sensitivity to Apo-2L. Hence, Apo-2L acts via a receptor which is distinct from Fas/Apo-1 and TNF receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that, along with other family members such as Fas/Apo-1 ligand and TNF, Apo-2L may serve as an extracellular signal that triggers programmed cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cDNA cloning and expression of a novel human UDP-N-acetyl-alpha-D-galactosamine. Polypeptide N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferase, GalNAc-t3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The glycosylation of serine and threonine residues during mucin-type O-linked protein glycosylation is carried out by a family of UDP-GalNAc:polypeptide N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferases (GalNAc-transferase).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously two members, GalNAc-T1 and -T2, have been isolated and the genes cloned and characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report the cDNA cloning and expression of a novel GalNAc-transferase termed GalNAc-T3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene was isolated and cloned based on the identification of a GalNAc-transferase motif (61 amino acids) that is shared between GalNAc-T1 and -T2 as well as a homologous Caenorhabditis elegans gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA sequence has a 633-amino acid coding region indicating a protein of 72.5 kDa with a type II domain structure.</Gene>
<Gene>The overall amino acid sequence similarity with GalNAc-T1 and -T2 is approximately 45%; 12 cysteine residues that are shared between GalNAc-T1 and -T2 are also found in GalNAc-T3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GalNAc-T3 was expressed as a soluble protein without the hydrophobic transmembrane domain in insect cells using a Baculo-virus vector, and the expressed GalNAc-transferase activity showed substrate specificity different from that previously reported for GalNAc-T1 and -T2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern analysis of human organs revealed a very restricted expression pattern of GalNAc-T3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Characterization of multiple mRNAs that encode mammalian translation initiation factor 5 (eIF-5).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Eukaryotic translation initiation factor 5 (eIF-5) interacts with the 40 S initiation complex (40S.mRNA.MettRNAf.eIF-2.GTP) to promote the hydrolysis of bound GTP with the concomitant joining of the 60 S ribosomal subunit to the 40 S initiation complex to form a functional 80 S initiation complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this paper, the multiple mRNAs that encode mammalian eIF-5 have been characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In rat tissues, three major eIF-5 mRNAs of 3.5, 2.8, and 2.2 kilobases in length are detected.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All major eIF-5 mRNAs are initiated from a single transcription initiation site, contain identical 5'-untranslated and coding regions, but differ from one another only in the length of their 3'-untranslated regions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The different lengths of the 3'-untranslated region of eIF-5 mRNAs are generated by the use of alternative polyadenylation signals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, we demonstrate tissue-specific variations in eIF-5 mRNA expression as well as preference for polyadenylation sites.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results should lead to increased understanding of the regulation of eIF-5 gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ICE-LAP6, a novel member of the ICE/Ced-3 gene family, is activated by the cytotoxic T cell protease granzyme B.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Members of the ICE/Ced-3 gene family are likely effector components of the cell death machinery.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we characterize a novel member of this family designated ICE-LAP6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>By phylogenetic analysis, ICE-LAP6 is classified into the Ced-3 subfamily which includes Ced-3, Yama/CPP32/apopain, Mch2, and ICE-LAP3/Mch3/CMH-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, ICE-LAP6 contains an active site QACGG pentapeptide, rather than the QACRG pentapeptide shared by other family members.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of ICE-LAP6 induces apoptosis in MCF7 breast carcinoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>More importantly, ICE-LAP6 is proteolytically processed into an active cysteine protease by granzyme B, an important component of cytotoxic T cell-mediated apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Once activated, ICE-LAP6 is able to cleave the death substrate poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase into signature apoptotic fragments.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning, expression and function of the murine CB2 peripheral cannabinoid receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have cloned the peripheral cannabinoid receptor, mCB2, from a mouse splenocyte cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 3.7 kb sequence contains an open reading frame encoding a protein of 347 residues sharing 82% overall identity with the only other known peripheral receptor, human CB2 (hCB2) and shorter than hCB2 by 13 amino acids at the carboxyl terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Binding experiments with membranes from COS-3 cells transiently expressing mCB2 showed that the synthetic cannabinoid WIN 55212-2 had a 6-fold lower affinity for mCB2 than for hCB2, whereas both receptors showed similar affinities for the agonists CP 55,940, delta(9)-THC and anandamide and almost no affinity for the central receptor- (CB1) specific antagonist SR 141716A. Both hCB2 and mCB2 mediate agonist-stimulated inhibition of forskolin-induced cAMP production in CHO cell lines permanently expressing the receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SR 141716A failed to antagonize this activity in either cell line, confirming its specificity for CB1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human glycine receptor beta subunit: primary structure, functional characterisation and chromosomal localisation of the human and murine genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The inhibitory glycine receptor (GlyR) is a pentameric receptor comprised of alpha and beta subunits, of which the beta subunit has not been characterised in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A 2106 bp cDNA, isolated from a human hippocampal cDNA library, contained an open reading frame of 497 amino acids which encodes the beta subunit of the human GlyR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mature human GlyR beta polypeptide displays 99% amino acid identity with the rat GlyR beta subunit and 48% identity with the human GlyR alpha 1 subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Neither [3H]strychnine binding nor glycine-gated currents were detected when the human GlyR beta subunit cDNA was expressed in the human embryonic kidney 293 cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, co-expression of the beta subunit cDNA with the alpha 1 subunit cDNA resulted in expression of functional GlyRs which showed a 4-fold reduction in the EC50 values when compared to alpha 1 homomeric GlyRs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Glycine-gated currents of alpha 1/beta GlyRs were 17-fold less sensitive than homomeric alpha 1 GlyRs to the antagonists picrotoxin, picrotoxinin and picrotin, providing clear evidence that heteromeric alpha 1/beta GlyRs were expressed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The beta subunit appears to play a structural rather than ligand binding role in GlyR function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Fluorescence in situ hybridisation was used to localise the gene encoding the human GlyR beta subunit (GLRB) to chromosome 4q32, a position syntenic with mouse chromosome 3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In situ hybridisation using the human GlyR beta subunit cDNA showed that the murine GlyR beta subunit gene (Glrb) maps to the spastic (spa) locus on mouse chromosome 3 at bands E3-F1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is consistent with the recent finding that a mutation in the murine GlyR beta subunit causes the spa phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It also raises the possibility that mutations in the human beta subunit gene may cause inherited disorders of the startle response.</Gene>
<Gene>Coding sequence and chromosome mapping of the human gene (CDC46) for replication protein hCdc46/Mcm5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated the complete cDNA sequence encoding the human homolog of the yeast replication protein Cdc46/Mcm5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA was used as a probe for chromosomal fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), which localized the human Cdc46 gene (CDC46) to chromosome region 22q13.1-->q13.2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is the fourth human Mcm gene whose chromosome region has been determined, and it is now apparent that human Mcm genes are widely distributed in the genome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As deduced from the cDNA sequence, human protein hCdc46 is composed of 734 amino acids and contains a central region that is almost 80% identical with the yeast protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunoprecipitation experiments with hCdc46-specific antibodies confirm that essentially all nuclear hCdc46 proteins form a stable dimeric complex with protein P1Mcm3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>kappa opioid receptors in human microglia downregulate human immunodeficiency virus 1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Microglial cells, the resident macrophages of the brain, play an important role in the neuropathogenesis of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1), and recent studies suggest that opioid peptides regulate the function of macrophages from somatic tissues.</Gene>
