<Gene>We report herein the presence of kappa opioid receptors (KORs) in human fetal microglia and inhibition of HIV-1 expression in acutely infected microglial cell cultures treated with KOR ligands.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and sequencing analyses, we found that mRNA for the KOR was constitutively expressed in microglia and determined that the nucleotide sequence of the open reading frame was identical to that of the human brain KOR gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of KOR in microglial cells was confirmed by membrane binding of [3H]U69,593, a kappa-selective ligand, and by indirect immunofluorescence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of microglial cell cultures with U50,488 or U69,593 resulted in a dose-dependent inhibition of expression of the monocytotropic HIV-1 SF162 strain.</Gene>
<Gene>This antiviral effect of the kappa ligands was blocked by the specific KOR antagonist, nor-binaltrophimine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that kappa opioid agonists have immunomodulatory activity in the brain, and that these compounds could have potential in the treatment of HIV-1-associated encephalopathy.</Gene>
<Gene>cDNA cloning and functional analysis of the p97 subunit of the 26S proteasome, a polypeptide identical to the type-1 tumor-necrosis-factor-receptor-associated protein-2/55.11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning of cDNA for a new regulatory subunit, designated p97, of the human 26S proteasome showed that the polypeptide consists of 908 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 100184 Da and an isoelectric point of 4.94.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Computer analysis showed that p97 is very similar to type-1 tumor-necrosis-factor (TNF)-receptor-associated protein (TRAP)-2 and 55.11, both of which were identified recently as binding proteins of the cytoplasmic domain of type-1 TNF receptor by yeast two-hybrid screening.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This finding suggests that the 26S proteasome might serve as a mediator molecule in the TNF signaling pathway in cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Computer-assisted similarity analysis also revealed the high sequence similarity of p97 with a yeast protein whose function is yet unknown, the gene for which is here termed NAS1 (non-ATPase subunit 1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Disruption of NAS1 resulted in several phenotypes, including lethality and temperature-sensitive growth, depending on the genetic background of the cells used.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human p97 cDNA suppressed the growth defect of nas1 disruptant cells, when expressed from single-copy or multi-copy vectors, indicating that p97 is functionally equivalent to yeast Nas1p.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Culturing of the temperature-sensitive nas1 cells at the restrictive temperature promoted the accumulation polyubiquitinated cellular proteins, implying that the 26S proteasome requires a functional Nas1p subunit for ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that p97/Nas1p plays an important regulatory role in the function of the 26S proteasome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Receptor-associated Mad homologues synergize as effectors of the TGF-beta response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transforming growth factor-beta TGF-beta is the prototype for a family of extracellular proteins that affect cell proliferation and tissue differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TGF-beta-related factors, including BMP-2/4, Dpp and activin, act through two types of serine/threonine kinase receptors which can form a heteromeric complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the mechanism of signal transduction by these receptors is largely unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>In Drosophila, Mad is required for signalling by Dpp.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated complementary DNAs for four human Mad homologues, one of which, hMAD-4, is identical to DPC-4, a candidate tumour suppressor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>hMAD-3 and -4 synergized to induce strong ligand-independent TGF-beta-like responses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When truncated at their carboxy termini, hMAD-3 and -4 act as dominant-negative inhibitors of the normal TGF-beta response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The activity of hMAD-3 and -4 was regulated by the TGF-beta receptors, and hMAD-3 but not hMAD-4 was phosphorylated and associated with the ligand-bound receptor complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results define hMAD-3 and -4 as effectors of the TGF-beta response and demonstrate a function for DPCA-4/hMAD-4 as a tumour suppressor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The C5a chemoattractant receptor mediates mucosal defence to infection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A family of G-protein-coupled chemoattractant receptors is known to mediate the transport and activation of neutrophils and macrophages This family includes receptors for chemokines, such as interleukin-8, bacterial formylated peptides, platelet-activating factor, leukotriene B4, and the complement anaphylatoxins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The apparent redundancy of these receptors suggests that they have an important underlying role in host defence.</Gene>
<Gene>To isolate the contribution of particular molecules, we disrupted a gene that encodes a single chemoattractant receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that mice deficient in the chemoattractant C5a receptor, in comparison to their wild-type littermates, were unable to clear intrapulmonary-instilled Pseudomonas aeruginosa, despite a marked increase in neutrophil influx, and succumbed to pneumonia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These C5a-receptor-deficient mice challenged with sublethal inocula of Pseudomonas become superinfected with secondary bacterial strains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that the C5a receptor has a non-redundant function, and is required for mucosal host defence in the lung.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cell-cell adhesion mediated by binding of membrane-anchored ligand LERK-2 to the EPH-related receptor human embryonal kinase 2 promotes tyrosine kinase activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human embryonal kinase 2 (HEK2) is a protein-tyrosine kinase that is a member of the EPH family of receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transcripts for HEK2 have a wide tissue distribution.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, a still growing family of ligands, which we have named LERKs, for ligands of the eph-related kinases, has been isolated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In order to analyze functional effects between the LERKs and the HEK2 receptor, we expressed HEK2 cDNA in an interleukin-3-dependent progenitor cell line 32D that grows as single cells in culture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Within the group of LERKs, LERK-2 and -5 were shown to bind to HEK2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Membrane-bound and soluble forms of LERK-2 were demonstrated to signal through HEK2 as judged by receptor phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Coincubation of HEK2 and LERK-2 expressing cells induced cell-cell adhesion and formation of cell aggregates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This interaction could be inhibited by preincubation of HEK2 expressing cells with soluble LERK-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Coexpression of HEK2 and LERK-2 in 32D cells showed reduced kinase activity and autophosphorylation of HEK2 compared with the juxtacrine stimulation, which seems to be due to a reduced sensitivity of the receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of the receptor protein tyrosine kinase myk-1/htk in normal and malignant mammary epithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have recently reported the molecular characterization of a novel murine receptor PTK (myk-1), belonging to the eph-related family, whose expression was differentially regulated during mammary gland development and elevated in invasive mouse mammary tumours.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this communication we have investigated the cellular origin of myk-1 expression by in situ hybridisation and RNase protection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Murine antisense myk-1 probe specifically recognised ductal and alveolar epithelium in the resting mouse mammary gland.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In normal human breast, the expression of htk, the human homologue, was also confined to the secretory luminal epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RNase protection analysis of enriched luminal and myoepithelial cells prepared from human reduction mammoplasty tissue confirmed the luminal specificity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Elevated expression of htk was found in several human breast carcinoma cell lines as well as in primary, high grade, infiltrating, ductal carcinomas of the breast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The specific epithelial expression of the myk-1/htk receptor PTK suggest a specialised role of this eph-related PTK in the differentiation and/or maintenance of secretory epithelium in the adult.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of a novel human clathrin heavy chain gene (CLTCL).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An exon representing a novel clathrin heavy chain gene (CLTCL) was isolated during gene identification studies and transcription mapping of human chromosome 22.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation and sequencing of cDNA clones corresponding to this exon revealed extensive similarity of the predicted amino acid sequence of this gene product to those of clathrin heavy chain genes of other species.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis has revealed an apparent developmental expression pattern of an approximately 6-kb mRNA.</Gene>

<Gene>The gene appears to be expressed ubiquitously in the limited number of fetal tissues that were tested, but is selectively expressed in certain adult tissues, particularly in skeletal muscle.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, alternative splicing of an exon was observed near the carboxyl terminus of the predicted gene product.</Gene>

<Gene>Its location overlaps the domain putatively involved in clathrin light chain binding and is adjacent to the heavy chain self-assembly (or trimerization) region, suggesting that alternative splicing may be involved in regulating one or both of these interactions.</Gene>

<Gene>The expression pattern of this gene, in addition to its potential role in receptor-mediated endocytosis and signal transduction, suggests that it may be important in some developmental processes.</Gene>

<Gene>The location of CLTCL on human chromosome 22 near the region commonly deleted in DiGeorge and other apparent haploinsufficiency syndromes warrants further investigation into its relationship with these developmental disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning of two rat Na+/Pi cotransporters: evidence for differential tissue expression of transcripts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, Na+/Pi cotransport activity has been demonstrated in rat liver hepatocytes.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we report the isolation of two Na+/Pi cotransporter cDNAs (RNaPi-1a and RNaPi-1b) from a rat liver cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The two cDNAs have the same coding but different 5'-untranslated regions.</Gene>
<Gene>The rat cDNAs encode a polypeptide of 465 amino acids, having 62% and 66% identity with the rabbit NaPi-1 and human kidney Na+/Pi cotransporter, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis showed that a RNaPi-1a--specific probe detected two major transcripts (2.3 and 1.8 kb), whereas a RNaPi-1b--specific probe hybridized with one transcript (1.8 kb) in rat kidney, liver, and hepatocytes in primary culture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rat liver expressed much higher levels of RNaPi-1a than RNaPi-1b, whereas the converse was true for rat kidney.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Low levels of RNaPi-1 mRNAs were also detected in rat heart, brain, and skeletal muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings indicate that there are at least two isoforms of RNaPi-1 transcripts expressed in liver and kidney and that the levels of expression of the RNaPi-1a and RNaPi-1b may be controlled by tissue-specific factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Association of inhibitory tyrosine protein kinase p50csk with protein tyrosine phosphatase PEP in T cells and other hemopoietic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>p50csk is a tyrosine protein kinase (TPK) that represses the activity of Src family TPKs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We previously showed that Csk is a potent negative regulator of antigen receptor signaling in T lymphocytes and that its Src homology (SH) 3 and SH2 domains are required to inhibit these signals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To test the idea that the Csk SH3 and SH2 domains mediate interactions with other cellular proteins, we attempted to identify Csk-associated polypeptides using the yeast two-hybrid system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results of our experiments demonstrated that Csk physically associates with PEP, a protein tyrosine phosphatase (PTP) expressed in hemopoietic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further analyses revealed that this interaction was mediated by the Csk SH3 domain and by a proline-rich region (PPPLPERTP) in the non-catalytic C-terminal portion of PEP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The association between Csk and PEP was documented in transiently transfected Cos-1 cells and in a variety of cells of hemopoietic lineages, including T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additional analyses demonstrated that the association between Csk and PEP is highly specific.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these data indicated that PEP may be an effector and/or a regulator of p50csk in T cells and other hemopoietic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, they allowed the identification of PEP as the first known ligand for the Csk SH3 domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cDNA cloning of human allograft inflammatory factor-1: tissue distribution, cytokine induction, and mRNA expression in injured rat carotid arteries.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously identified a partial cDNA fragment obtained from rat carotid arteries subject to balloon angioplasty which is increased in response to vascular injury.</Gene>
<Gene>We now report the isolation and characterization of a full length human clone which is 98% homologous at the amino acid level to the rat.</Gene>
<Gene>Allograft Inflammatory Factor-1 (AIF-1), a gene previously reported to be expressed in rat IFN gamma-activated macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This transcript is expressed in low levels in undamaged, and increases 1 day and 3 days, and declines 7 days post balloon angioplasty.</Gene>
<Gene>This human AIF-1 homologue is inducible in serum and cytokine-stimulated human smooth muscle cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, human tissue distribution indicates a constitutive expression in lymphoid tissue which can be augmented by mitogens.</Gene>
<Gene>In summary, human AIF represents a cytokine inducible, tissue-specific, and highly conserved transcript transiently expressed in response to vascular trauma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Functional expression of a novel human neurokinin-3 receptor homolog that binds [3H]senktide and [125I-MePhe7]neurokinin B, and is responsive to tachykinin peptide agonists.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In 1992, Xie et al. identified a cDNA sequence in the expression cloning search for the kappa opioid receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>When the cDNA was expressed in Cos-7 cells, binding of opioid compounds was observed to be of low affinity and without kappa, mu, or delta selectivity [Xie, G.-X., Miyajima, A. and Goldstein, A. (1992) Proc.</Gene>
<Gene>Natl.</Gene>
<Gene>Acad.</Gene>
<Gene>Sci.</Gene>
<Gene>This cDNA was highly homologous to the human neurokinin-3 (NK-3) receptor sequence, and displayed lower homology to NK-1 and NK-2 sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This sequence was stably expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells, which do not express neurokinin receptors naturally, and ligand binding and second messenger characteristics were compared with a human NK-3 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The NK-3 receptor homolog bound [3H] senktide with a Kd of 39 nM, similar to that of the NK-3 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The rank order of tachykinin peptides competing for [3H]senktide binding at the NK-3 receptor homolog was [MePhe7]neurokinin B > senktide > substance P =</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>neurokinin A ></Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>neurokinin B.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This cell line also bound [125I-MePhe7]neurokinin B; however, neurokinin B was an effective competitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tachykinin peptides stimulated both inositol phospholipid hydrolysis and arachidonic acid release at NK-3 and NK-3 receptor homolog cell lines, with similar rank orders of potency of [MePhe7] neurokinin B = neurokinin B = senktide > NKA = substance P. These results indicate that expression of the NK-3 receptor homolog cDNA in the Chinese hamster ovary cell system induces the expression of a receptor site with many similarities but certain key differences from that of the human NK-3 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results are discussed with reference to the existence of a novel human tachykinin receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular cloning and characterization of a transcription factor for the C-type natriuretic peptide gene promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our previous studies on the promoter function of the human C-type natriuretic peptide (CNP) gene revealed the existence of two GC-rich cis elements essential for gene transcription in rat pituitary-derived GH3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To isolate transcription factors that bind to those GC-rich elements, we screened a lambda ZAP cDNA library derived from GH3 cells by Southwestern screening.</Gene>

<Gene>Several positive clones with specific binding abilities were obtained, and one was identical as TSC-22, a speculated transcriptional modulator stimulated by transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta) of unknown function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TSC-22 significantly enhanced CNP promoter activity in GH3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We further cloned a 1.8-kb full-length human TSC-22 cDNA from a fetal kidney cDNA library by a combination of polymerase chain reaction and the rapid amplification of the cDNA ends technique.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In adults, human TSC-22 mRNA was highly expressed in brain, lung and heart.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TSC-22 gene expression in GH3 and human aortic endothelial cells was stimulated by cytokines including TGF-beta, in correlation with the CNP mRNA increase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that TSC-22 is a transcriptional regulator of the CNP gene and transmits signals from cytokines, such as TGF-beta, to CNP gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of Rep-8 (D8S2298E) in the human chromosome 8p11.2-p12.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel human gene referred to as the Rep-8 gene (D8S2298E) was cloned by a combination of exon trapping, thermal asymmetric interlaced-PCR, and screening of a cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is located in human chromosome 8p11.2-p12.</Gene>
<Gene>The gene consists of eight exons and spans about 20 kb between the glutathione S-reductase and the protein phosphatase 2A beta subunit genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The full-length Rep-8 gene contains 1483 nucleotides and codes for a protein of 270 amino acids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Southern blot experiments showed that the Rep-8 gene exists as a single copy per haploid.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>With a zoo blot analysis, human Rep-8 DNA hybridized strongly with the monkey DNA, but only weakly with the DNAs of species other than Homo sapiens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis showed that it is expressed abundantly in the testis and ovary, suggesting that the Rep-8 gene product may play a role in reproduction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence analysis of two genomic regions containing the KIT and the FMS receptor tyrosine kinase genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The KIT and FMS tyrosine kinase receptors, which are implicated in the control of cell growth and differentiation, stem through duplications from a common ancestor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have conducted a detailed structural analysis of the two loci containing the KIT and FMS genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The sequence of the approximately 90-kb KIT locus reveals the position and size of the 21 introns and of the 5' regulatory region of the KIT gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The introns and the 3'-untranslated parts of KIT and FMS have been analyzed in parallel.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Comparison of the two sequences shows that, while introns of both genes have extensively diverged in size and sequence, this divergence is, at least in part, due to intron expansion through internal duplications, as suggested by the discrete extant analogies.</Gene>
<Gene>Repetitive elements as well as exon predictions obtained using the GRAIL and GENEFINDER programs are described in detail.</Gene>
<Gene>These programs led us to identify a novel gene, designated SMF, immediately downstream of FMS, in the opposite orientation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This finding emphasizes the gene-rich characteristic of this genomic region.</Gene>
<Gene>Isolation, characterization, and chromosomal mapping of a novel cDNA clone encoding human selenium binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated the full-length human 56 kDa selenium binding protein (hSP56) cDNA clone, which is the human homolog of mouse 56 kDa selenium binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA is 1,668 bp long and has an open reading frame encoding 472 amino acids.</Gene>
<Gene>The calculated molecular weight is 52.25 kDa and the estimated isoelectric point is 6.13.</Gene>

<Gene>Using Northern blot hybridization, we found that this 56 kDa selenium binding protein is expressed in mouse heart with an intermediate level between those found in liver/lung/kidney and intestine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have also successfully expressed hSP56 in Escherichia coli using the expression vector-pAED4.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The hSP56 gene is located at human chromosome 1q21-22).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and chromosomal location of a novel member of the myotonic dystrophy family of protein kinases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have cloned a novel serine/threonine protein kinase (PK428) which is highly related (65%) within the kinase domain to the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DM-PK), as well as the cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase (33%).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blots demonstrate that PK428 mRNA is distributed widely among tissues and is expressed at the highest levels in pancreas, heart, and skeletal muscle, with lower levels in liver and lung.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two PK428 mRNAs 10 and 3.8 kilobase pairs in size are seen in a number of cell lines, including hematopoietic and breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An antibody generated to a glutathione S-transferase-PK428 fusion protein detects a 65-kDa protein in these cell lines, and a similarly sized protein when the cloned cDNA is transiently expressed in Cos 7 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunoprecipitation of the transiently expressed PK428 protein and incubation with [gamma-32P]ATP demonstrate that it is capable of autophosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, immunoprecipitates of the PK428 protein kinase also phosphorylated histone H1 and a peptide encoding a cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase substrate.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene corresponding to the 3.8-kb PK428 mRNA, and its corresponding 65-kDa protein, was isolated by polymerase chain reaction screening of a P1 phage human genomic library.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using this P1 phage clone as a probe, the PK428 gene was located on 1q41-42, a possible location for a human senescence gene, a gene associated with Rippling muscle disease, as well as a region associated with genetically acquired mental retardation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation and characterization of a structural homologue of human PRK2 from rat liver. Distinguishing substrate and lipid activator specificities.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A homologue of human protein kinase C (PKC)-related kinase-2, PRK2, which had previously escaped identification in normal mammalian tissues, was isolated from rat liver as the protease-activated kinase (PAK) originally named PAK-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 130-kDa cytosolic enzyme was purified to homogeneity and shown by tryptic peptide and reverse transcriptase- polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)-amplified rat cDNA sequence analyses to be structurally related to the 116-kDa rat hepatic PAK-1/protein kinase N (PKN) and, even more closely (95% sequence identity) to the 130-kDa human PKC-related kinase, PRK2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rat myeloma RNA was used as the RT-PCR template because of its relative abundance in PAK-2/PRK2 mRNA compared with liver and other rat tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The catalytic properties of PAK-2/PRK2 in many respects resembled those of hepatic PAK-1/PKN, but were distinguished by more favorable kinetics with several peptide substrates, and greater sensitivity to PKC pseudosubstrate and polybasic amino acid inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PAK-2/PRK2 was also activated by lipids, particularly cardiolipin and to a lesser extent by other acidic phospholipids and unsaturated fatty acids.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cardiolipin activation was most evident with autophosphorylation and histone H2B phosphorylation, but only marginally evident with the favored ribosomal S6-(229-239) peptide substrate for the protease-activated kinase activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It was concluded that PAK-2 is the rat homologue of human PRK2, with biochemical properties distinct from although overlapping those of the PAK-1/PKN/PRK1 isoform.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human dipeptidyl-peptidase I. Gene characterization, localization, and expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Dipeptidyl-peptidase I, a lysosomal cysteine proteinase, is important in intracellular degradation of proteins and appears to be a central coordinator for activation of many serine proteinases in immune/inflammatory cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Little is known about the molecular genetics of the enzyme.</Gene>
<Gene>In the present investigation the gene for dipeptidyl-peptidase I was cloned and characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The gene spans approximately 3.5 kilobases and consists of two exons and one intron.</Gene>
<Gene>The genomic organization is distinct from the complex structures of the other members of the papain-type cysteine proteinase family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>By fluorescence in situ hybridization, the gene was mapped to chromosomal region 11q14.1-q14.3.</Gene>
<Gene>Analysis of the sequenced 5'-flanking region revealed no classical TATA or CCAAT box in the GC-rich region upstream of cap site.</Gene>
<Gene>A number of possible regulatory elements that could account for tissue-specific expression were identified.</Gene>

<Gene>Northern analyses demonstrated that the dipeptidyl-peptidase I message is expressed at high levels in lung, kidney, and placenta, at moderate to low levels in many organs, and at barely detectable levels in the brain, suggesting tissue-specific regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Among immune/inflammatory cells, the message is expressed at high levels in polymorphonuclear leukocytes and alveolar macrophages and their precursor cells.</Gene>

<Gene>Treatment of lymphocytes with interleukin-2 resulted in a significant increase in dipeptidyl-peptidase I mRNA levels, suggesting that this gene is subjected to transcriptional regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results provide initial insights into the molecular basis for the regulation of human dipeptidyl-peptidase I.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Osteoprotegerin: a novel secreted protein involved in the regulation of bone density.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A novel secreted glycoprotein that regulates bone resorption has been identified.</Gene>
<Gene>The protein, termed Osteoprotegerin (OPG), is a novel member of the TNF receptor superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo, hepatic expression of OPG in transgenic mice results in a profound yet nonlethal osteopetrosis, coincident with a decrease in later stages of osteoclast differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These same effects are observed upon administration of recombinant OPG into normal mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro, osteoclast differentiation from precursor cells is blocked in a dose-dependent manner by recombinant OPG.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, OPG blocks ovariectomy-associated bone loss in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These data show that OPG can act as a soluble factor in the regulation of bone mass and imply a utility for OPG in the treatment of osteoporosis associated with increased osteoclast activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of a novel human cDNA (rhoHP1) homologous to rho genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel full-length cDNA showing homology with rho genes was isolated from a human placenta cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sequencing of a total of 1086 nucleotides of this clone revealed an open reading frame of 630 nucleotides (210 amino acids).</Gene>

<Gene>In view of its degree of homology to members of the Rho family of molecules (50-54% identical amino acids, 60-63% identical nucleotides within the coding region), the predicted product was designated RhoHP1(Rho-related protein HP1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern analysis indicated that a message about 1.2-kb long is expressed in human heart, placenta, liver, skeletal muscle, and pancreas and, with weaker intensity, in several other tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>I kappa B epsilon, a novel member of the I kappa B family, controls RelA and cRel NF-kappa B activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have isolated a human cDNA which encodes a novel I kappa B family member using a yeast two-hybrid screen for proteins able to interact with the p52 subunit of the transcription factor NF-kappa B. The protein is found in many cell types and its expression is up-regulated following NF-kappa B activation and during myelopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with its proposed role as an I kappa B molecule, I kappa B-epsilon is able to inhibit NF-kappa B-directed transactivation via cytoplasmic retention of rel proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>I kappa B-epsilon translation initiates from an internal ATG codon to give rise to a protein of 45 kDa, which exists as multiple phosphorylated isoforms in resting cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike the other inhibitors, it is found almost exclusively in complexes containing RelA and/or cRel.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upon activation, I kappa B-epsilon protein is degraded with slow kinetics by a proteasome-dependent mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Similarly to I kappa B-alpha and I kappa B, I kappa B-epsilon contains multiple ankyrin repeats and two conserved serines which are necessary for signal-induced degradation of the molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A unique lysine residue located N-terminal of the serines appears to be not strictly required for degradation.</Gene>
<Gene>Unlike I kappa B- alpha and I kappa B-beta, I kappa B-epsilon does not contain a C-terminal PEST-like sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>I kappa B-epsilon would, therefore, appear to regulate a late, transient activation of a subset of genes, regulated by RelA/cRel NF-kappa B complexes, distinct from those regulated by other I kappa B proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Characterization of VPS41, a gene required for vacuolar trafficking and high-affinity iron transport in yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the yeast gene VPS41 give rise to poor growth on low iron medium, severe alterations in vacuolar morphology, and cause the missorting of membranous and soluble vacuolar proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our studies predict that VPS41 encodes a hydrophilic protein of 992 amino acids that contains no obvious signal sequence or hydrophobic domains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The deduced Vps41p sequence contains a domain rich in glutamic and aspartic residues, as well as a domain with resemblance to a region of clathrin heavy chain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have also identified and sequenced putative VPS41 homologues from Caenorhabditis elegans, plants, and humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The VPS41 homologues (but not the yeast VPS41 itself) contain a conserved cysteine-rich RING-H2 zinc finger at their COOH termini.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Biochemical experiments suggest that VPS41 functions in post-Golgi protein processing: the deletion mutant exhibits defective high affinity transport due to impaired Fet3p activity and also exhibits defects in the processing and sorting of multiple vacuolar hydrolases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of a full-length human WNT7A gene implicated in limb development and cell transformation, and mapping to chromosome 3p25.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Wnt gene family has a role in development as well as tumourigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One mouse member, Wnt7a, is vital for limb development in vivo and also possesses transforming ability in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study reports the isolation of a full length of human homologue of mouse Wnt7a gene by library screening.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Yeast artificial chromosome-fluorescence in situ hybridisation (YAC-FISH) mapped the WNT7A gene to chromosome 3p25.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human WNT7A had an ORF encoding a deduced protein of 349 aa that exhibited 97% and 92% identity to mouse Wnt7a at the aa and nucleic acid levels, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It possessed the 22 conserved cysteine residues and 3 more at the amino terminus, and a putative poly A tail.</Gene>
<Gene>This is the fifth human WNT gene in which a complete cDNA sequence had been determined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Coassembly of TRP and TRPL produces a distinct store-operated conductance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Drosophila retinal-specific protein, TRP (transient receptor potential), is the founding member of a family of store-operated channels (SOCs) conserved from C. elegans to humans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro studies indicate that TRP is a SOC, but that the related retinal protein, TRPL, is constitutively active.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the current work, we report that coexpression of TRP and TRPL leads to a store-operated, outwardly rectifying current distinct from that owing to either TRP or TRPL alone.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TRP and TRPL interact directly, indicating that the TRP-TRPL-dependent current is mediated by heteromultimeric association between the two subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We propose that the light-activated current in photoreceptor cells is produced by a combination of TRP homo- and TRP-TRPL heteromultimers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The MAD-related protein Smad7 associates with the TGFbeta receptor and functions as an antagonist of TGFbeta signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TGFbeta signaling is initiated when the type I receptor phosphorylates the MAD-related protein, Smad2, on C-terminal serine residues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This leads to Smad2 association with Smad4, translocation to the nucleus, and regulation of transcriptional responses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we demonstrate that Smad7 is an inhibitor of TGFbeta signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Smad7 prevents TGFbeta-dependent formation of Smad2/Smad4 complexes and inhibits the nuclear accumulation of Smad2. Smad7 interacts stably with the activated TGFbeta type I receptor, thereby blocking the association, phosphorylation, and activation of Smad2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, mutations in Smad7 that interfere with receptor binding disrupt its inhibitory activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These studies thus define a novel function for MAD-related proteins as intracellular antagonists of the type I kinase domain of TGFbeta family receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOX22 is a new member of the SOX gene family, mainly expressed in human nervous tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOX (SRY box-containing) genes share a particular DNA-binding domain, called HMG, with the mammalian testis-determining gene SRY Several SOX genes have already been shown to be transcription factors involved in the decision of important cell fates during development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report the cloning of a new human member of the SOX gene family, SOX22.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The corresponding protein contains several domains that are also present in other paralogous SOX proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The SOX22 gene maps to chromosome 20 on band p13 and does not appear to be clustered with any other SOX gene mapped to date.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOX22</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mRNA is expressed in various fetal and adult organs and tissues, suggesting that this gene plays roles in both differentiation and maintenance of several cell types.</Gene>
<Gene>A novel human serine-threonine phosphatase related to the Drosophila retinal degeneration C (rdgC) gene is selectively expressed in sensory neurons of neural crest origin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Through our transcriptional mapping effort in the Xp22 region, we have isolated by exon trapping a new transcript highly homologous to the Drosophila retinal degeneration C (rdgC) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>rdgC encodes a serine/threonine phosphatase protein and is required in Drosophila to prevent light-induced retinal degeneration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This human gene is the first mammalian member of the serine-threonine phosphatase with EF hand motif gene family, and was thus named PPEF (Protein Phosphatase with EF calcium-binding domain).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression pattern of the mouse Ppef gene was studied by RNA in situ hybridization on embryonic tissue sections.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>While rdgC is expressed in the visual system of the fly, as well as in the mushroom bodies of the central brain, we found that Ppef is highly expressed in sensory neurons of the dorsal root ganglia (DRG) and neural crest-derived cranial ganglia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The selective pattern of expression makes PPEF an important marker for sensory neuron differentiation and suggests a role for serine-threonine phosphatases in mammalian development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and characterization of hOGG1, a human homolog of the OGG1 gene of Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The OGG1 gene of Saccharomyces cerevisiae encodes a DNA glycosylase activity that is a functional analog of the Fpg protein from Escherichia coli and excises 7,8-dihydro-8-oxoguanine (8-oxoG) from damaged DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The repair of this ubiquitous kind of oxidative damage is essential to prevent mutations both in bacteria and in yeast.</Gene>
<Gene>A human cDNA clone carrying an ORF displaying homology to the yeast protein was identified.</Gene>
<Gene>The predicted protein has 345 amino acids and a molecular mass of 39 kDa.</Gene>

<Gene>This protein shares a 38% sequence identity with the yeast Ogg1 protein, adding this novel human gene product to the growing family of enzymes that the repair of oxidatively damaged bases and are related to the E. coli endonuclease III.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Northern blot analysis indicates that this gene, localized to chromosome 3p25, is ubiquitously expressed in human tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>The cloned coding sequence was expressed in an E. coli strain that carried a disrupted fpg gene, the bacterial functional analog of OGG1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cell-free extracts from these cultures displayed a specific lyase activity on duplex DNA that carried an 8-oxoG/C base pair.</Gene>
<Gene>The products of the reaction are consistent with an enzymatic activity like the one displayed by the yeast Ogg1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of the substrate specificity reveals a very strong preference for DNA fragments harboring 8-oxoG/C base pairs.</Gene>
<Gene>The pattern of specificity correlates well with the one found for the yeast enzyme.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, when the human coding sequence was expressed in a yeast strain mutant in OGG1 it was able to complement the spontaneous mutator phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results make this novel gene (hOGG1) a strong candidate for the human homolog of the yeast OGG1 and suggest an important role of its product in the protection of the genome from the mutagenic effects of the oxidatively damaged purines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A minK-HERG complex regulates the cardiac potassium current I(Kr).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MinK is a widely expressed protein of relative molecular mass approximately 15K that forms potassium channels by aggregation with other membrane proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MinK governs ion channel activation, regulation by second messengers, and the function and structure of the ion conduction pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Association of minK with a channel protein known as KvLQT1 produces a voltage-gated outward K+ current (I[sK]) resembling the slow cardiac repolarization current (I[Ks]).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HERG, a human homologue of the ether-a-go-go gene of the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster, encodes a protein that produces the rapidly activating cardiac delayed rectifier (I[Kr]).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These two potassium currents, I(Ks) and I(Kr), provide the principal repolarizing currents in cardiac myocytes for the termination of action potentials.</Gene>

<Gene>Although heterologously expressed HERG channels are largely indistinguishable from native cardiac I(Kr), a role for minK in this current is suggested by the diminished I(Kr) in an atrial tumour line subjected to minK antisense suppression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that HERG and minK form a stable complex, and that this heteromultimerization regulates I(Kr) activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MinK, through the formation of heteromeric channel complexes, is thus central to the control of the heart rate and rhythm.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>X-linked IAP is a direct inhibitor of cell-death proteases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The inhibitor-of-apoptosis (IAP) family of genes has an evolutionarily conserved role in regulating programmed cell death in animals ranging from insects to humans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ectopic expression of human IAP proteins can suppress cell death induced by a variety of stimuli, but the mechanism of this inhibition was previously unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that human X-chromosome-linked IAP directly inhibits at least two members of the caspase family of cell-death proteases, caspase-3 and caspase-7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As the caspases are highly conserved throughout the animal kingdom and are the principal effectors of apoptosis, our findings suggest how IAPs might inhibit cell death, providing evidence for a mechanism of action for these mammalian cell-death suppressors.</Gene>
<Gene>Differential expression of FMR1, FXR1 and FXR2 proteins in human brain and testis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lack of expression of the fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) results in mental retardation and macroorchidism, seen as the major pathological symptoms in fragile X patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FMRP is a cytoplasmic RNA-binding protein which cosediments with the 60S ribosomal subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, two proteins homologous to FMRP were discovered: FXR1 and FXR2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These novel proteins interact with FMRP and with each other and they are also associated with the 60S ribosomal subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we studied the expression pattern of the three proteins in brain and testis by immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
<Gene>In adult brain, FMR1, FXR1 and FXR2 proteins are coexpressed in the cytoplasm of specific differentiated neurons only.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, we observed a different expression pattern in fetal brain as well as in adult and fetal testis, suggesting independent functions for the three proteins in those tissues during embryonic development and adult life.</Gene>
<Gene>PHOG, a candidate gene for involvement in the short stature of Turner syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The abnormalities seen in Turner syndrome (monosomy X) presumably result from haploinsufficiency of certain genes on the X chromosome.</Gene>
<Gene>Gene dosage considerations lead to the prediction that the culpable genes escape X inactivation and have functional homologs on the Y chromosome.</Gene>
<Gene>Among the genes with these characteristics are those residing in the pseudoautosomal regions (PAR) of the sex chromosomes.</Gene>

<Gene>A pseudoautosomal location for a dosage-sensitive locus involved in stature has been suggested based on the analyses of patients with deletions of a specific segment of the short arm PAR; hemizygosity for this putative locus probably also contributes to the short stature in Turner individuals.</Gene>
<Gene>We have isolated a gene from the critical deleted region that encodes a novel homeodomain-containing transcription factor and is expressed at highest levels in osteogenic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have named the gene PHOG, for pseudoautosomal homeobox-containing osteogenic gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Its deletion in patients with short stature, the predicted altered dosage in 45,X individuals, along with the nature of the encoded protein and its expression pattern, make PHOG an attractive candidate for involvement in the short stature of Turner syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have also found that the mouse homolog of PHOG is autosomal, which may help to explain the lack of a growth abnormality in mice with monosomy X.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cDNA cloning, expression and chromosome mapping of the human STAT4 gene: both STAT4 and STAT1 genes are mapped to 2q32.2-->q32.3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Studies of transcriptional activation by interferons and a variety of cytokines have led to the identification of a family of proteins that serve as signal transducers and activators of transcription (STAT).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>STAT4 is phosphorylated following interleukin (IL)-12 stimulation and is essential for IL-12 signal transduction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The human STAT4 cDNA was cloned, and both STAT4 and STAT1 genes were mapped to human chromosome bands 2q32.2-->q32.3 by fluorescence in situ hybridization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that STAT4 and STAT1 may have arisen via a tandem gene duplication.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, human STAT1 is expressed ubiquitously, whereas human STAT4 is expressed in several tissues including spleen, heart, brain, peripheral blood cells, and testis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning and chromosome assignment to 1q32 of a human cDNA (RAB7L1) encoding a small GTP-binding protein, a member of the RAS superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A full-length cDNA homologous to RAB7, a member of the RAB-related GTP-binding protein subfamily, was isolated from a human placenta cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This cDNA, designated RAB7L1, has an open reading frame of 609 nucleotides encoding 203 amino acids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Northern analysis showed that the mRNA is ubiquitously expressed in human tissues, although signal intensities were different among the various organs examined.</Gene>
<Gene>This gene was located on chromosome band 1q32 by fluorescence in situ hybridization.</Gene>
<Gene>A beta-arrestin/green fluorescent protein biosensor for detecting G protein-coupled receptor activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>G protein-coupled receptors (GPCR) represent the single most important drug targets for medical therapy, and information from genome sequencing and genomic data bases has substantially accelerated their discovery.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The lack of a systematic approach either to identify the function of a new GPCR or to associate it with a cognate ligand has added to the growing number of orphan receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this work we provide a novel approach to this problem using a beta-arrestin2/green fluorescent protein conjugate (betaarr2-GFP).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It provides a real-time and single cell based assay to monitor GPCR activation and GPCR-G protein-coupled receptor kinase or GPCR-arrestin interactions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Confocal microscopy demonstrates the translocation of betaarr2-GFP to more than 15 different ligand-activated GPCRs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data clearly support the common hypothesis that the beta-arrestin binding of an activated receptor is a convergent step of GPCR signaling, increase by 5-fold the number of GPCRs known to interact with beta-arrestins, demonstrate that the cytosol is the predominant reservoir of biologically active beta-arrestins, and provide the first direct demonstration of the critical importance of G protein-coupled receptor kinase phosphorylation to the biological regulation of beta-arrestin activity and GPCR signal transduction in living cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The use of betaarr2-GFP as a biosensor to recognize the activation of pharmacologically distinct GPCRs should accelerate the identification of orphan receptors and permit the optical study of their signal transduction biology intractable to ordinary biochemical methods.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Purification and cloning of hepatocyte growth factor activator inhibitor type 2, a Kunitz-type serine protease inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) activator is a serine protease responsible for proteolytic activation of HGF in response to tissue injury and thus plays an important role in the regulation of biological functions of HGF in regenerating tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We previously purified an inhibitor of HGF activator (HGF activator inhibitor type 1, HAI-1) from the conditioned medium of a human stomach carcinoma cell line MKN45 and cloned its cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HAI-1 is a novel member of the Kunitz family of serine protease inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we purified a second type of HGF activator inhibitor (HAI-2) from the conditioned medium of MKN45 cells and molecularly cloned its cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA sequence revealed that HAI-2 is derived from a precursor protein of 252 amino acids and contains two Kunitz domains, indicating that HAI-2 is also a member of the Kunitz family of serine protease inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The primary translation product of HAI-2 has a hydrophobic sequence in the COOH-terminal region, suggesting that, like HAI-1, HAI-2 is produced in a membrane-associated form and secreted in a proteolytically truncated form.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because HAI-2 and HAI-1 are potent inhibitors specific for HGF activator, they may be involved in regulation of proteolytic activation of HGF in injured tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Glycogenin-2, a novel self-glucosylating protein involved in liver glycogen biosynthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Glycogenin is a self-glucosylating protein involved in the initiation phase of glycogen biosynthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A single mammalian gene had been reported to account for glycogen biogenesis in liver and muscle, the two major repositories of glycogen.</Gene>

<Gene>We describe the characterization of novel forms of glycogenin, designated glycogenin-2 (GN-2), encoded by a second gene that is expressed preferentially in certain tissues, including liver, heart, and pancreas.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cloning of cDNAs encoding glycogenin-2 indicated the existence of multiple species, including three liver forms (GN-2alpha, GN-2beta, and GN-2gamma) generated in part by alternative splicing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overall, GN-2 has 40-45% identity to muscle glycogenin but is 72% identical over a 200-residue segment thought to contain the catalytic domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GN-2 expressed in Escherichia coli or COS cells is active in self-glucosylation assays, and self-glucosylated GN-2 can be elongated by skeletal muscle glycogen synthase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Antibodies raised against GN-2 produced in E. coli recognized proteins of Mr approximately 66,000 present in extracts of rat liver and in cultured H4IIEC3 hepatoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In H4IIEC3 cells, most of the GN-2 was present as a free protein but some was covalently associated with glycogen fractions and was only released by treatment with alpha-amylase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>H4IIEC3 cells also expressed the muscle form of glycogenin (glycogenin-1), which was attached to a chromatographically separable glycogen fraction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>hSK4, a member of a novel subfamily of calcium-activated potassium channels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene for hSK4, a novel human small conductance calcium-activated potassium channel, or SK channel, has been identified and expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In physiological saline hSK4 generates a conductance of approximately 12 pS, a value in close agreement with that of other cloned SK channels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Like other members of this family, the polypeptide encoded by hSK4 contains a previously unnoted leucine zipper-like domain in its C terminus of unknown function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>hSK4 appears unique, however, in its very high affinity for Ca2+</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>(EC50 of 95 nM) and its predominant expression in nonexcitable tissues of adult animals.</Gene>

<Gene>Together with the relatively low homology of hSK4 to other SK channel polypeptides (approximately 40% identical), these data suggest that hSK4 belongs to a novel subfamily of SK channels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human pulmonary alveolar proteinosis associated with a defect in GM-CSF/IL-3/IL-5 receptor common beta chain expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is a heterogeneous disorder of genetic or acquired etiologies.</Gene>
<Gene>In some cases congenital PAP is associated with hereditary surfactant protein (SP)-B deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To date, the molecular defect in the majority of patients with PAP has not been identified.</Gene>
<Gene>In mice, PAP has been generated by targeted deletion of the genes for either the GM-CSF/IL-3/IL-5 receptor common beta chain (beta c) or GM-CSF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we describe an expression defect of beta c in three of seven pediatric patients with PAP and in one patient with severe lung disease suspected to be PAP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The patients failed to express normal levels of beta c as shown by flow cytometry.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Strikingly reduced or absent function of beta c was demonstrated by ligand binding studies and progenitor clonogenic assays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of beta c DNA revealed a point mutation from proline to threonine at codon 602 in one patient.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings provide evidence that a defect in the expression of a hematopoietic cytokine receptor is associated with human PAP.</Gene>
<Gene>Characterization and functional expression of the cDNA encoding human brain quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mammalian quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase (QPRTase) (EC 2.4.2.19) is a key enzyme in catabolism of quinolinate, an intermediate in the tryptophan-nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Quinolinate acts as a most potent endogenous exitotoxin to neurons.</Gene>
<Gene>Elevation of quinolinate levels in the brain has been linked to the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative disorders.</Gene>
<Gene>As the first step to elucidate molecular basis underlying the quinolinate metabolism, the cDNA encoding human brain QPRTase was cloned and characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Utilizing partial amino acid sequences obtained from highly purified porcine kidney QPRTase, a human isolog was obtained from a human brain cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA encodes a open reading frame of 297 amino acids, and shares 30 to 40% identity with those of bacterial QPRTases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To confirm that the cDNA clone encodes human QPRTase, its functional expression was studied in a bacterial host.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Introduction of the human cDNA into a QPRTase defective (nadC)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>E. coli strain brought about an abrupt increase in QPRTase activity and allowed the cells to grow in the absence of nicotinic acid.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It is concluded that the cloned cDNA encodes human QPRTase which is functional beyond the phylogenic boundary.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a new tumour-associated antigen TM4SF5 and its expression in human cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In a previous large-scale screening for differentially expressed genes in pancreatic cancer, a gene was identified that was highly overexpressed in pancreatic cancer encoding a novel putative tetraspan transmembrane protein highly homologous to the tumour-associated antigen L6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a radiation hybrid panel the identified human gene named TM4SF5 (transmembrane 4 superfamily member 5) was localized to chromosome 17 in the region 17p13.3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cloned TM4SF5 cDNA has a 32bp 5'-untranslated region (UTR), a 591bp open reading frame (ORF) and a 85bp 3'UTR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted TM4SF5 protein with 197 amino acids contains three NH2-terminal hydrophobic transmembrane regions, followed by an extracellular hydrophilic domain containing two potential N-linked glycosylation sites and a COOH-terminal hydrophobic transmembrane region.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These structural features are shared by the L6 antigen and a number of related cell surface proteins associated with cell growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TM4SF5 was overexpressed in pancreatic cancer tissues as compared to both normal pancreas and chronic pancreatitis tissues, and was detected at high levels in other tumour tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although the precise function of TM4SF5 remains to be elucidated it may be useful in a clinical setting for tumour diagnosis and/or therapy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This hypothesis is supported by the strong homology to the L6 antigen, which has proved promising in immunological, therapeutic and diagnostic approaches.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Triplet repeat-containing ribosomal protein L14 gene in immortalized human endothelial cell line (t-HUE4).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cDNA encoding human 60S ribosomal subunit protein L14 (hRL14) was isolated from a human immortal endothelial cell line, t-HUE4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This cell line was established via a series of cell lines cultured in a serum-free and a protein-free medium, and a directional cDNA library has been constructed and screened in search for the genes modulating protein synthesis machinery in cell proliferation.</Gene>
<Gene>A putative full-length clone with an open reading frame of 220 amino acids; predicted molecular weight of 23.6 kDa.</Gene>

<Gene>A significant identity for hRL14 was observed with rat RL14 (85% identity), with exception of COOH-terminal region, but not with any eukaryote amino acid sequences so far deposited to database.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The typical features of ribosomal proteins were observed in hRL14, as seen in nuclear targeting sequences necessary for the transport from cytoplasm to nucleolus, a bZIP like (basic region-leucine zipper) element for the binding to rRNA, and the internal repeat sequences; the pentapeptide QKA(A/S)X.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The COOH-terminal region of the transcripts contained fifteen triplet repeats (GCT; alanine) at nucleotide 465 to 509, which is significantly expanded compared to the rat RL14.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the repeat number was all the same among the normal human endothelial cell line and the cell lines established in the course of t-HUE4 establishment.</Gene>
<Gene>A single band with about 800 bases was identified by Northern blot analysis without tissue specificity.</Gene>
<Gene>This GCT repeat was found to be one of the longest uninterrupted repeats in a coding sequence, which were associated with the highest degree of polymorphism.</Gene>
<Gene>Molecular cloning of human D-dopachrome tautomerase cDNA: N-terminal proline is essential for enzyme activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>D-Dopachrome tautomerase converts 2-carboxy-2,3-dihydroindole-5,6-quinone (D-dopachrome) into 5,6-dihydroxyindole.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This protein has an amino acid sequence that is highly homologous with that of macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), which has the potential to catalyze D-dopachrome to 5,6-dihydroxyindole-2-carboxylic acid and is an important cytokine for T-lymphocyte activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We isolated and sequenced a 566 bp-long cDNA encoding human D-dopachrome tautomerase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA contains an open reading frame encoding 118 amino acids, including the initiator methionine.</Gene>
<Gene>The amino acid sequence of the protein shares 80% homology with that of the rat enzyme.</Gene>

<Gene>Northern blot analysis demonstrated that mRNA of D-dopachrome tautomerase is expressed in a large amount in the liver, and to lesser extent in other organs, including the heart, lung and pancreas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>After purification of D-dopachrome tautomerase expressed in E. coli, we confirmed that the recombinant protein catalyzes the conversion of D-dopachrome to 5,6-dihydroxyindole.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Its catalytic mechanism is not well understood.</Gene>
<Gene>We found that the protein completely lost the enzyme activity when the N-terminal proline residue was replaced with alanine by site-directed mutagenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>This fact suggests that the N-terminal proline is essential for the catalytic mechanism.</Gene>

<Gene>Although the precise pathophysiological function of D-dopachrome tautomerase remains to be elucidated, the present results could contribute to further understanding of isomerase activity in relation to the immune response.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of full-length cDNA of mouse PAX4 gene and identification of its human homologue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent genetic studies have suggested that PAX4, a member of the paired box (PAX) gene family, is involved in the mechanism regulating the fate of pancreatic islet endocrine progenitor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Murine PAX4 was originally identified by genomic screening and, to date, only a partial sequence of PAX4 has been reported.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we cloned the full-length cDNA of mouse PAX4 by RACE (rapid amplification of cDNA ends) using RNA from MIN6 cells, a mouse insulinoma cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The full length of cDNA was 1.38 kb, consistent with the estimated size of the transcript by Northern blot.</Gene>
<Gene>The deduced mouse PAX4 protein was 349 amino acids and had the predicted molecular weight of 38 kDa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two DNA binding motifs, a 128-amino acid paired domain and a 61-amino acid paired-type homeodomain exhibit the highest amino acid homology with PAX6 (71.2%, 65.0%, respectively), another member of the PAX gene family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the sequence of the C-terminal segment of PAX4 diverged and showed no significant homology with any other known PAX genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As to the genomic DNA, the coding region of the mouse PAX4 gene spanned approximately 5.5 kb and was composed of 10 exons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the public DNA database, a human cosmid (g1572c264), which was localized on human chromosome 7q31.3, was found to contain a gene homologous to PAX4.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The nucleotide and protein sequence homologies between mouse PAX4 and its human homologue were 83.1% and 80.0%, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, the ARP5 (ADP-ribosylation factor 5) gene was also found in the same cosmid g1572c264, suggesting the ARP5 gene to be adjacent to the human PAX4 homologue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The human cosmid g1572c264 contains at least four SSRPs (simple sequence repeat polymorphism), which could be used for genetic linkage studies of the locus.</Gene>

<Gene>The results of this study, i.e. isolation of the full-length cDNA sequence of PAX4 and identification of the homologous human gene, will facilitate further functional and genetic studies of the PAX4 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of cDNAs encoding two human alpha class glutathione transferases (GSTA3 and GSTA4) and the heterologous expression of GSTA4-4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Expressed Sequence Tag database has been searched for examples of previously undescribed human Alpha class glutathione transferases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An incomplete transcript of the previously described GSTA3 gene was identified in a cDNA library derived from 8-9 week placenta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This indicates that the GSTA3 gene is functional and is possibly under specific developmental regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A second cDNA, termed GSTA4, was identified in a brain cDNA library.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The encoded GSTA4-4 enzyme was expressed in Escherichia coli and was found to be immunologically distinct from GSTA1-1 and to have high activity with alk-2-enals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although GSTA4-4 appears to be functionally similar to the mouse GST5.7 and rat GST8-8 Alpha class enzymes, sequence comparisons and phylogenetic analysis suggest that GSTA4-4 may be a member of a distinct Alpha class subgroup.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Actinin-4, a novel actin-bundling protein associated with cell motility and cancer invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Regulation of the actin cytoskeleton may play a crucial role in cell motility and cancer invasion.</Gene>
<Gene>We have produced a monoclonal antibody (NCC- Lu-632, IgM, k) reactive with an antigenic protein that is upregulated upon enhanced cell movement.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNA for the antigen molecule was found to encode a novel isoform of nonmuscle alpha-actinin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This isoform (designated actinin-4) was concentrated in the cytoplasm where cells were sharply extended and in cells migrating and located at the edge of cell clusters, but was absent from focal adhesion plaques or adherens junctions, where the classic isoform (actinin-1) was concentrated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Actinin-4 shifted steadily from the cytoplasm to the nucleus upon inhibition of phosphatidylinositol 3 kinase or actin depolymerization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cytoplasmic localization of actinin-4 was closely associated with an infiltrative histological phenotype and correlated significantly with a poorer prognosis in 61 cases of breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that cytoplasmic actinin-4 regulates the actin cytoskeleton and increases cellular motility and that its inactivation by transfer to the nucleus abolishes the metastatic potential of human cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HLA-G expression in melanoma: a way for tumor cells to escape from immunosurveillance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Considering the well established role of nonclassical HLA-G class I molecules in inhibiting natural killer (NK) cell function, the consequence of abnormal HLA-G expression in malignant cells should be the escape of tumors from immunosurveillance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To examine this hypothesis, we analyzed HLA-G expression and NK sensitivity in human malignant melanoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our analysis of three melanoma cell lines and ex vivo biopsy demonstrated that (i) IGR and M74 human melanoma cell lines exhibit a high level of HLA-G transcription with differential HLA-G isoform transcription and protein expression patterns, (ii) a higher level of HLA-G transcription ex vivo is detected in a skin melanoma metastasis biopsy compared with a healthy skin fragment from the same individual, and (iii) HLA-G protein isoforms other than membrane-bound HLA-G1 protect IGR from NK lysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It thus appears of critical importance to consider the specific role of HLA-G expression in tumors in the design of future cancer immunotherapies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A third member of the synapsin gene family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Synapsins are a family of neuron-specific synaptic vesicle-associated phosphoproteins that have been implicated in synaptogenesis and in the modulation of neurotransmitter release.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In mammals, distinct genes for synapsins I and II have been identified, each of which gives rise to two alternatively spliced isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have now cloned and characterized a third member of the synapsin gene family, synapsin III, from human DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Synapsin III gives rise to at least one protein isoform, designated synapsin IIIa, in several mammalian species.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Synapsin IIIa is associated with synaptic vesicles, and its expression appears to be neuron-specific.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The primary structure of synapsin IIIa conforms to the domain model previously described for the synapsin family, with domains A, C, and E exhibiting the highest degree of conservation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Synapsin IIIa contains a novel domain, termed domain J, located between domains C and E. The similarities among synapsins I, II, and III in domain organization, neuron-specific expression, and subcellular localization suggest a possible role for synapsin III in the regulation of neurotransmitter release and synaptogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The human synapsin III gene is located on chromosome 22q12-13, which has been identified as a possible schizophrenia susceptibility locus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>On the basis of this localization and the well established neurobiological roles of the synapsins, synapsin III represents a candidate gene for schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The relationship between agonist intrinsic activity and the rate of endocytosis of muscarinic receptors in a human neuroblastoma cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The molecular mechanisms underlying the internalization of G protein-coupled receptors are still poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Normally agonists but not antagonists cause internalization (defined here as a reduction in the number of receptors at the cell surface), suggesting a functional relationship between agonist activity and internalization.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study we investigated the effects of eight muscarinic ligands on the rate constants for endocytosis and recycling of m3 muscarinic acetylcholine receptors in human SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found that there was a linear correlation between the intrinsic activity of the ligand and its ability to increase the rate constant for endocytosis, suggesting that the same active conformation of the receptor is responsible for stimulating both second messenger generation and receptor endocytosis.</Gene>
<Gene>In contrast, the rate constant for recycling did not depend on which agonist had triggered receptor endocytosis, suggesting that recycling is a purely constitutive process.</Gene>
<Gene>Because receptor internalization depends on the rate constants for both endocytosis and recycling, the relationship between internalization and intrinsic activity is nonlinear.</Gene>

<Gene>In particular, mathematical modeling of receptor trafficking revealed that under certain conditions very small (3% or less) increases in the rate constant for endocytosis are sufficient to cause substantial receptor internalization.</Gene>

<Gene>An important implication of this analysis is that extremely weak partial agonists (which may in practice be indistinguishable from antagonists) may produce significant receptor internalization.</Gene>
<Gene>Non-histone chromosomal proteins HMG1 and 2 enhance ligation reaction of DNA double-strand breaks.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNA ligase IV in a complex with XRCC4 is responsible for DNA end-joining in repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSB) and V(D)J recombination.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that non-histone chromosomal high mobility group (HMG) proteins 1 and 2 enhanced the ligation of linearized pUC119 DNA with DNA ligase IV from rat liver nuclear extract.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intra-molecular and inter-molecular ligations of cohesive-ended and blunt-ended DNA were markedly stimulated by HMG1 and 2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recombinant HMG2-domain A, B, and (A + B) polypeptides were similarly, but non-identically, effective for the stimulation of DSB ligation reaction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ligation of single-strand breaks (nicks) was only slightly activated by the HMG proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The DNA end-binding Ku protein singly or in combination with the catalytic component of DNA-dependent protein kinase (DNA-PK) as the DNA-PK holoenzyme was ineffective for the ligation of linearized pUC119 DNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although the stimulatory effect of HMG1 and 2 on ligation of DSB in vitro was not specific to DNA ligase IV, these results suggest that HMG1 and 2 are involved in the final ligation step in DNA end-joining processes of DSB repair and V(D)J recombination.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The eukaryotic UDP-N-acetylglucosamine pyrophosphorylases. Gene cloning, protein expression, and catalytic mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A search of the yeast data base for a protein homologous to Escherichia coli UDP-N-acetylglucosamine pyrophosphorylase yielded UAP1 (UDP-N-acetylglucosamine pyrophosphorylase), the Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene for UDP-N-acetylglucosamine pyrophosphorylase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Candida albicans and human homologs were also cloned by screening a C. albicans genomic library and a human testis cDNA library, respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>Sequence analysis revealed that the human UAP1 cDNA was identical to previously reported AGX1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A null mutation of the S. cerevisiae UAP1 (ScUAP1) gene was lethal, and when expressed under the control of ScUAP1 promoter, both C. albicans and Homo sapiens UAP1 (CaUAP1 and HsUAP1) rescued the ScUAP1-deficient S. cerevisiae cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>All the recombinant ScUap1p, CaUap1p, and HsUap1p possessed UDP-N-acetylglucosamine pyrophosphorylase activities in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The yeast Uap1p utilized N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate as the substrate, and together with Agm1p, it produced UDP-N-acetylglucosamine from N-acetylglucosamine-6-phosphate.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results demonstrate that the UAP1 genes indeed specify eukaryotic UDP-GlcNAc pyrophosphorylase and that phosphomutase reaction precedes uridyltransfer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
