text: <Gene>Sequence comparison with other UDP-sugar pyrophosphorylases revealed that amino acid residues, Gly112, Gly114, Thr115, Arg116, Pro122, and Lys123 of ScUap1p are highly conserved in UDP-sugar pyrophosphorylases reported to date.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Among these amino acids, alanine substitution for Gly112, Arg116, or Lys123 severely diminished the activity, suggesting that Gly112, Arg116, or Lys123 are possible catalytic residues of the enzyme.</Gene>
<Gene>Role of Mxi1 in ageing organ systems and the regulation of normal and neoplastic growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mxi1 belongs to the Mad (Mxi1) family of proteins, which function as potent antagonists of Myc oncoproteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This antagonism relates partly to their ability to compete with Myc for the protein Max and for consensus DNA binding sites and to recruit transcriptional co-repressors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mad(Mxi1) proteins have been suggested to be essential in cellular growth control and/or in the induction and maintenance of the differentiated state.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with these roles, mxi1 may be the tumour-suppressor gene that resides at region 24-26 of the long arm of chromosome 10.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This region is a cancer hotspot, and mutations here may be involved in several cancers, including prostate adenocarcinoma.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we show that mice lacking Mxi1 exhibit progressive, multisystem abnormalities.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These mice also show increased susceptibility to tumorigenesis either following carcinogen treatment or when also deficient in Ink4a.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This cancer-prone phenotype may correlate with the enhanced ability of several mxi1-deficient cell types, including prostatic epithelium, to proliferate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results show that Mxi1 is involved in the homeostasis of differentiated organ systems, acts as a tumour suppressor in vivo, and engages the Myc network in a functionally relevant manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNA sequence and muscle-specific expression of human sarcosin transcripts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have characterized two abundant human cDNAs which, through Northern hybridization analysis, are selectively expressed in human sarcomeric muscle.</Gene>
<Gene>DNA sequencing was performed and the two cDNAs were found to share sequence identity, with the exception of a 3' UTR extension present on the longer transcript.</Gene>
<Gene>Our data suggest that the two transcripts are generated through alternative use of two poly(A) addition signals.</Gene>
<Gene>The cDNAs encode a large open reading frame encompassing at least 435 codons.</Gene>
<Gene>Through sequence comparisons, both at the DNA and predicted amino acid sequence level, we have been unable to find significant sequence similarity to any other characterized sequence.</Gene>
<Gene>Consequently, we have termed this novel human sequence sarcosin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although novel, Southern hybridization analysis demonstrated that the sarcosin sequence has been conserved in several mammalian species.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of the gene responsible for Best macular dystrophy.</Gene>

<Gene>Best macular dystrophy (BMD), also known as vitelliform macular dystrophy (VMD2; OMIM 153700), is an autosomal dominant form of macular degeneration characterized by an abnormal accumulation of lipofuscin within and beneath the retinal pigment epithelium cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In pursuit of the disease gene, we limited the minimum genetic region by recombination breakpoint analysis and mapped to this region a novel retina-specific gene (VMD2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic mapping data, identification of five independent disease-specific mutations and expression studies provide evidence that mutations within the candidate gene are a cause of BMD.</Gene>

<Gene>The 3' UTR of the candidate gene contains a region of antisense complementarity to the 3' UTR of the ferritin heavy-chain gene (FTH1), indicating the possibility of antisense interaction between VMD2 and FTH1 transcripts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BRCA1 protein is linked to the RNA polymerase II holoenzyme complex via RNA helicase A.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The breast cancer specific tumour suppressor protein, BRCA1 (refs 1,2), activates transcription when linked with a DNA-binding domain and is a component of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) holoenzyme.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show here that RNA helicase A (RHA) protein links BRCA1 to the holoenzyme complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The region of BRCA1 which interacts with RHA and, thus, the holoenzyme complex, corresponds to subregions of the BRCT domain of BRCA1 (ref. 9).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This interaction was shown to occur in yeast nuclei, and expression in human cells of a truncated RHA molecule which retains binding to BRCA1 inhibited transcriptional activation mediated by the BRCA1 carboxy terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data are the first to identify a specific protein interaction with the BRCA1 C-terminal domain and are consistent with the model that BRCA1 functions as a transcriptional coactivator.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Total colourblindness is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the alpha-subunit of the cone photoreceptor cGMP-gated cation channel.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Total colourblindness (OMIM 216900), also referred to as rod monochromacy (RM) or complete achromatopsia, is a rare, autosomal recessive inherited and congenital disorder characterized by photophobia, reduced visual acuity, nystagmus and the complete inability to discriminate between colours.</Gene>
<Gene>Electroretinographic recordings show that in RM, rod photoreceptor function is normal, whereas cone photoreceptor responses are absent.</Gene>
<Gene>The locus for RM has been mapped to chromosome 2q11 (ref. 2), however the gene underlying RM has not yet been identified.</Gene>

<Gene>Recently, a suitable candidate gene, CNGA3, encoding the alpha-subunit of the cone photoreceptor cGMP-gated cation channel, a key component of the phototransduction pathway, has been cloned and assigned to human chromosome 2q11 (refs 3,4).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report the identification of missense mutations in CNGA3 in five families with RM.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Homozygous mutations are present in two families, whereas the remaining families show compound heterozygous mutations.</Gene>

<Gene>In all cases, the segregation pattern of the mutations is consistent with the autosomal recessive inheritance of the disease and all mutations affect amino acids that are highly conserved among cyclic nucleotide gated channels (CNG) in various species.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first report of a colour vision disorder caused by defects other than mutations in the cone pigment genes, and implies at least in this instance a common genetic basis for phototransduction in the three different cone photoreceptors of the human retina.</Gene>
<Gene>An L-type calcium-channel gene mutated in incomplete X-linked congenital stationary night blindness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The locus for the incomplete form of X-linked congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB2) maps to a 1.1-Mb region in Xp11.23 between markers DXS722 and DXS255.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We identified a retina-specific calcium channel alpha1-subunit gene (CACNA1F) in this region, consisting of 48 exons encoding 1966 amino acids and showing high homology to L-type calcium channel alpha1-subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutation analysis in 13 families with CSNB2 revealed nine different mutations in 10 families, including three nonsense and one frameshift mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These data indicate that aberrations in a voltage-gated calcium channel, presumably causing a decrease in neurotransmitter release from photoreceptor presynaptic terminals, are a frequent cause of CSNB2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ZW10 helps recruit dynactin and dynein to the kinetochore.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the Drosophila melanogaster zw10 gene, which encodes a conserved, essential kinetochore component, abolish the ability of dynein to localize to kinetochores.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Several similarities between the behavior of ZW10 protein and dynein further support a role for ZW10 in the recruitment of dynein to the kinetochore: (a) in response to bipolar tension across the chromosomes, both proteins mostly leave the kinetochore at metaphase, when their association with the spindle becomes apparent; (b) ZW10 and dynein both bind to functional neocentromeres of structurally acentric minichromosomes; and (c) the localization of both ZW10 and dynein to the kinetochore is abolished in cells mutant for the gene rough deal.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ZW10's role in the recruitment of dynein to the kinetochore is likely to be reasonably direct, because dynamitin, the p50 subunit of the dynactin complex, interacts with ZW10 in a yeast two-hybrid screen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since in zw10 mutants no defects in chromosome behavior are observed before anaphase onset, our results suggest that dynein at the kinetochore is essential for neither microtubule capture nor congression to the metaphase plate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, dynein's role at the kinetochore is more likely to be involved in the coordination of chromosome separation and/or poleward movement at anaphase onset.</Gene>
<Gene>The IFN-inducible nucleoprotein IFI 16 is expressed in cells of the monocyte lineage, but is rapidly and markedly down-regulated in other myeloid precursor populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IFI 16 is an interferon-inducible nucleoprotein expressed by human monocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IFI 16 and a related mouse protein, p202, control cellular proliferation by binding and modulating the functions of cell cycle regulatory factors including p53 and the retinoblastoma gene product, pRb.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we examined IFI 16 expression in myeloid precursor cells cultured in vitro in colony-forming assays using granulocyte (G-) and granulocyte-macrophage (GM-) colony-stimulating factor (CSF).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IFI 16 was expressed in 100% of CD34+ cells isolated from human bone marrow.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When the CD34+ cells were induced to differentiate, two sub-populations of cells were identified by two-color cytofluorography: the CD14+ (monocytoid) cells all expressed IFI 16, whereas the CD14- (polymorphonuclear precursor) cells did not.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The strongest expression of IFI 16 was in the cells staining brightest for CD14, whereas depletion of CD14+ monocytoid cells from mixed monocytic/granulocytic cultures largely abolished IFI 16-stained cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, in eight independent colony-forming assays, the number of IFI 16+ cells correlated closely with the numbers of monocyte precursors identified morphologically (R2 = 0.99), but was unrelated to the numbers of myelocytes, promyelocytes, and metamyelocytes; nor was IFI 16 expressed by erythroid or eosinophil precursors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that IFI 16 is expressed in CD34+ and monocytoid daughter cells, but is rapidly and markedly down-regulated at the corresponding stages of polymorphonuclear and erythroid development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This differential expression of IFI 16 in myeloid precursor subpopulations and its perceived molecular properties are consistent with a possible role in regulating myelopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A novel candidate oncogene, MCT-1, is involved in cell cycle progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using the arbitrarily primed-PCR (AP-PCR) assay to detect genetic abnormalities that occur in a panel of lymphoid cell lines, we identified an amplified stretch of genomic DNA that contained a putative open reading frame.</Gene>
<Gene>Northern blot analysis with this genomic clone revealed widespread low level expression in normal human tissue.</Gene>
<Gene>The full cDNA sequence was obtained with no significant homology to any known genes in the genome database.</Gene>
<Gene>We termed this novel gene with multiple copies in a T-cell malignancy as MCT-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MCT-1 was localized to the long arm of chromosome Xq22-24 by flourescence in situ hybridization analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although there was no significant homology at the primary sequence level, there was a limited degree of amino acid homology with a domain of cyclin H that appears to specify protein-protein complexes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This relationship between MCT-1 and cyclin H implied a potential role for MCT-1 in cell cycle regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of MCT-1 increased the proliferative rate of cells by decreasing the length of the G1 phase without a reciprocal increase in the S and G2-M phases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent work has established the role of cell cycle regulatory molecules in the development of certain human malignancies.</Gene>

<Gene>Therefore, we investigated the transforming ability of MCT-1 overexpression using soft agar growth assays and demonstrated that only MCT-1-overexpressing cells were able to establish colonies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, MCT-1 is a novel candidate oncogene with homology to a protein-protein binding domain of cyclin H.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a principal mRNA species for human 3alpha-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase isoform (AKR1C3) that exhibits high prostaglandin D2 11-ketoreductase activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human 3alpha-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase exists in four isoforms, which belong to the aldo-keto reductase (AKR) superfamily and are named AKR1C1-AKR1C4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The properties of AKR1C3 have not been fully characterized compared to the other isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, a cDNA that shows more than 99% homology with AKR1C3 cDNA has been cloned from human myeloblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have here expressed and purified a recombinant enzyme (designated as DBDH) from this cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DBDH oxidized xenobiotic alicyclic alcohols and 3alpha- or 17beta-hydroxy-5beta-androstanes, and catalyzed the reversible conversion between prostaglandin D2 and 9alpha,11beta-prostaglandin F2 more efficiently than that of 3alpha- or 17beta-hydroxysteroids:the respective Km values were 0.6 and 6.8 microM, and kcat/Km values were about 1,000 min-1.mM-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Anti-inflammatory drugs highly inhibited the enzyme.</Gene>
<Gene>The recombinant AKR1C3 prepared by site-directed mutagenesis of DBDH also showed the same properties as the wild-type DBDH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analyses of expression of mRNAs for DBDH and AKR1C3 by reverse transcription-PCR indicated that only one mRNA species for DBDH is expressed in 33 human specimens of liver, kidney, lung, brain, heart, spleen, adrenal gland, small intestine, placenta, prostate, and testis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that AKR1C3 acts as prostaglandin D2 11-ketoreductase, and that its principal gene in the human has a coding region represented by DBDH cDNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a retinoic acid responsive aldoketoreductase expressed in HL60 leukaemic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Neutrophil and monocyte differentiation can be induced in HL60 leukaemia cells by all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) and 1alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (D3), respectively, whose differentiating effects can be enhanced by exposure to 'anti-inflammatory agents' and steroids.</Gene>

<Gene>We have provided evidence that this potentiation is via inhibition of the activity of an enzyme of the aldoketoreductase (AKR) family, but had failed to identify expression of known AKRs in HL60 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we have identified a previously unclassified aldoketoreductase family member (termed HAKR e) that is expressed in HL60 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HAKR e is dramatically and transiently up-regulated in HL60 cells within 24 h of exposure to ATRA, further supporting the proposition that a member(s) of this family of enzymes play(s) a role in controlling cell growth and/or differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression and functional characterization of kinin receptors reveal subtype-specific phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>G protein-coupled receptors such as the receptors for bradykinin are present in low copy numbers in most natural cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To overcome the problems associated with the analysis of these receptors at the protein level, we used highly efficient expression systems such as the baculovirus/insect cell system.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the structural and functional statuses of recombinant receptors have often remained elusive.</Gene>
<Gene>We have expressed the two types of human kinin receptors, B1 and B2, in Sf9 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Both receptors are found on the surface of infected cells where they display the same pharmacological profiles as their cognate receptors of native cells.</Gene>

<Gene>The functional analysis of kinin receptors coupled to the intracellular signaling pathways of Sf9 cells revealed differential patterns of ligand-induced phosphorylation for the two kinin receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The B1 receptor failed to undergo ligand-induced phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However the B2 receptor showed selective phosphorylation of a minor 38 kDa band and lack of phosphorylation of a dominant 33 kDa band, indicating that only a fraction of the receptor protein is functionally linked to the kinase pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A striking discrepancy between the number of binding sites and the amount of receptor protein per cell (molar ratio of 1:20 to 1:1000) indicated that a significant portion of kinin receptors is associated with the intracellular compartments of Sf9 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pulse-chase and immunoprecipitation experiments demonstrated that the heterogeneity of recombinant receptors is not due to proteolytic processing but likely reflects incomplete or lacking N-glycosylation.</Gene>
<Gene>We conclude that the baculovirus/Sf9 system is suitable for the recombinant expression and functional analysis of kinin receptors though limitations of the system have to be considered.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Isolation of hMRE11B: failure to complement yeast mre11 defects due to species-specific protein interactions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Saccharomyces cerevisiae MRE11 gene plays an important role in meiotic recombination, mitotic DNA repair and telomere maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We present the isolation of hMRE11B cDNA from a human HeLa cell cDNA library as an MRE11 homolog.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared to the previously identified hMRE11, hMRE11B contains an additional 84bp sequence that results in a 28 amino-acid insertion close to the C-terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression pattern of hMRE11B in different tissues shows the presence of two mRNA species of approx.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>2.6 and 7.5kb.</Gene>
<Gene>Overexpression of hMRE11B does not complement the alkylation sensitivity of the mre11 null and temperature-sensitive mutant strains.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we examine factors that may explain this lack of complementation.</Gene>
<Gene>First, both Northern and Western analyses rule out the lack of hMRE11B transcription and/or translation in yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Second, we demonstrate that hMre11B, like the yeast Mre11 protein, dimerizes in vivo in a yeast two-hybrid system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This dimerization requires the C-terminal one-third of hMre11B protein, which includes the 28 amino acids absent in hMre11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, hMre11B does not interact with Mre11, Rad50 and Xrs2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hence, the lack of protein-protein interaction between hMre11B and the yeast Mre11, Rad50, and Xrs2 may explain the inability of hMRE11B to complement the yeast mre11 mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We rule out the hypothesis that the lack of interaction and, in turn of complementation, is due to the absence of sequence homology at the C-terminal domain of hMre11B compared to the yeast Mre11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, we propose that the C-terminus of hMre11B participates in protein-protein interaction and functions in a species-specific manner.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>XCE, a new member of the endothelin-converting enzyme and neutral endopeptidase family, is preferentially expressed in the CNS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we have isolated a cDNA encoding a novel member of the family of zinc metallopeptidases that includes neutral endopeptidase and endothelin-converting enzyme.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The predicted amino-acid sequence of this enzyme, termed XCE, consists of 775 amino-acids with a single putative membrane-spanning region, an N-terminal cytoplasmic domain of 59 residues, and a large luminal domain that contains a characteristic zinc-binding motif.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot analysis of cells stably expressing this new metallopeptidase revealed a glycosylated protein of approximately 95 kDa.</Gene>
<Gene>XCE mRNA was found to be predominantly expressed in the central nervous system, sympathetic ganglia and in uterine subepithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the rat and human CNS, a very specific pattern of neuronal labelling (in presumptive cholinergic interneurons of basal ganglia, basal forebrain neurons, as well as brainstem and spinal cord motoneurons) was detected by in situ hybridization histochemistry.</Gene>
<Gene>The enzyme substrate, as yet unidentified, might be found among the numerous neuropeptide transmitters which are colocalized with acetylcholine in these neurons.</Gene>
<Gene>Cytotoxicity of Fas ligand against lymphoma cells with radiation-induced Fas antigen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Fas antigen, also termed APO-1 or CD95, is a transmembrane protein and a member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor/nerve growth factor receptor superfamily which mediates apoptosis upon oligomerization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Fas/Fas ligand system is considered to be a key regulator of apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, we have demonstrated that Fas antigen expression is induced by low-dose irradiation of some types of lymphomas, and we also demonstrated that irradiation-induced Fas antigen expression increased with the passage of time until peaking at 48 h after irradiation in CML-C1, CML-C2, DL-40, and DL-95 cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we also examined the potential cytotoxicity of Fas ligand peptide against several types of lymphoma/leukemia cell lines that showed induction of Fas antigen expression under irradiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Flow cytometry analysis was performed at 6, 24 and 48 h after irradiation.</Gene>

<Gene>Samples (1 x10(6) cells/ml) from irradiated and non-irradiated cells of each cell line were incubated with or without 5 microg/ml of Fas ligand peptide for 2 h at 37 degrees C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% carbon dioxide (CO2) in air.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The killing effect of Fas ligand against cell lines of CML-C1, DL-40, and DL-95 were clearly identified as the percentage of cells with Fas antigen expression induced by irradiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Concerning HD-70 cell line, for which soluble Fas antigen has been identified, the killing effects were clearly observed in samples pre-treated with PBS washings.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To our knowledge, this is the first report describing a possible application of the Fas/Fas ligand system in treatment of certain types of malignancies in which Fas antigen is inducible by irradiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Haplotype analysis in Icelandic and Finnish BRCA2 999del5 breast cancer families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The 999del5 mutation is the single, strong BRCA2 founder mutation in Iceland and the most common BRCA1/2 founder mutation in Finland.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To evaluate the origin and time since spreading of the 999del5 mutation in Iceland and in Finland, we constructed haplotypes with polymorphic markers within and flanking the BRCA2 gene in a set of 18 Icelandic and 10 Finnish 999del5 breast cancer families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All Icelandic families analysed shared a common core haplotype of about 1.7 cM. The common ancestors for the Icelandic families studied were estimated to trace back to 340-1000 years, not excluding the possibility that the mutation was brought to Iceland during the settlement of the country.</Gene>
<Gene>Analysis of the Finnish families revealed two distinct haplotypes.</Gene>
<Gene>A rare one, found in three families in the old settlement region in southwestern Finland, shared a four-marker (0.5 cM) core haplotype with the Icelandic 999del5 haplotype.</Gene>
<Gene>A distinct approximately 6 cM haplotype was shared by seven 999del5 Finnish families estimated to have a common ancestry 140-300 years ago.</Gene>
<Gene>These families cluster in two geographical regions in Finland, in the very same area as those with the rare haplotype and also in the most eastern, late settlement region of Finland.</Gene>
<Gene>The results may indicate a common ancient origin for the 999del5 mutation in Iceland and in Finland, but distinct mutational events cannot be ruled out.</Gene>
<Gene>The surprising finding of the same mutation in two completely different haplotypes in a sparsely populated area in Finland may suggest gene conversion.</Gene>
<Gene>KRIT1 association with the integrin-binding protein ICAP-1: a new direction in the elucidation of cerebral cavernous malformations (CCM1) pathogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in KRIT1, a protein initially identified based on a yeast two-hybrid interaction with the RAS-family GTPase RAP1A, are responsible for the development of the inherited vascular disorder cerebral cavernous malformations (CCM1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As the function of the KRIT1 protein and its role in CCM pathogenesis remain unknown, we performed yeast two-hybrid screens to identify additional protein binding partners.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A fragment containing the N-terminal 272 amino acid residues of KRIT1, a region lacking similarity to any known protein upon database searches, was used as bait.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>From parallel screens of human fetal brain and HeLa cDNA libraries, we obtained multiple independent isolates of human integrin cytoplasmic domain-associated protein-1 (ICAP-1) as interacting clones.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The interaction of KRIT1 and ICAP-1 was confirmed by GST-KRIT1 trapping of endogenous ICAP-1 from 293T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The alpha isoform of ICAP-1 is a 200 amino acid serine/threonine-rich phosphoprotein which binds the cytoplasmic tail of beta1 integrins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that mutagenesis of the N-terminal KRIT1 NPXY amino acid sequence, a motif critical for ICAP-1 binding to beta1 integrin molecules, completely abrogates the KRIT1/ICAP-1 interaction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The interaction between ICAP-1 and KRIT1, and the presence of a FERM domain in the latter, suggest that KRIT1 might be involved in the bidirectional signaling between integrin molecules and the cytoskeleton.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, these data suggest that KRIT1 might affect cell adhesion processes via integrin signaling in CCM1 pathogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase 1 gene (IMPDH1) cause the RP10 form of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa (adRP) is a heterogeneous set of progressive retinopathies caused by several distinct genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>One locus, the RP10 form of adRP, maps to human chromosome 7q31.1 and may account for 5-10% of adRP cases among Americans and Europeans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified two American families with the RP10 form of adRP by linkage mapping and used these families to reduce the linkage interval to 3.45 Mb between the flanking markers D7S686 and RP-STR8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sequence and transcript analysis identified 54 independent genes within this region, at least 10 of which are retinal-expressed and thus candidates for the RP10 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A screen of retinal transcripts comparing retinas from normal mice to retinas from crx-/crx- knockout mice (with poorly differentiated photoreceptors) demonstrated a 6-fold reduction in one candidate, inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase 1 (IMPDH1; EC 1.1.1.205).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since many of the genes known to cause retinitis pigmentosa are under CRX control in photoreceptors, IMPDH1 became a high-priority candidate for mutation screening.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNA sequencing of affected individuals from the two American RP10 families revealed a GAC-->AAC transition in codon 226 substituting an asparagine for an aspartic acid in both families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The identical mutation was also found in a British RP10 family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Asp226Asn missense mutation is present in all affected individuals tested and absent from unaffected controls.</Gene>
<Gene>The aspartic acid at codon 226 is conserved in all IMPDH genes, in all species examined, including bacteria, suggesting that this mutation is highly deleterious.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Subsequent screening of probands from 60 other adRP families revealed an additional family with this mutation, confirming its association with retinitis pigmentosa and the relatively high frequency of this mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Another IMPDH1 substitution, Val268Ile, was also observed in this cohort of patients but not in controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IMPDH1 is a ubiquitously expressed enzyme, functioning as a homotetramer, which catalyzed the rate-limiting step in de novo synthesis of guanine nucleotides.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>As such, it plays an important role in cyclic nucleoside metabolism within photoreceptors.</Gene>
<Gene>Several classes of drugs are known to affect IMPDH isoenzymes, including nucleotide and NAD analogs, suggesting that small-molecule therapy may be available, one day, for RP10 patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lead induced DNA strand breaks in lymphocytes of exposed workers: role of reactive oxygen species and protein kinase C.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Lead and lead compounds play a significant role in modern industry; a wide variety of population is at risk of occupational exposure and lead is suspected to be a human carcinogen.</Gene>

<Gene>The biochemical and molecular mechanisms of lead toxicity are poorly understood, but emerging data suggest that some of the effects of lead may be due to its interference with calcium in the activation of protein kinase C (PKC) and/or through production of reactive oxygen species (ROS).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Many of these results are conducted in vitro on cell lines or ex vivo on human lymphocytes treated in vitro.</Gene>
<Gene>We, therefore, performed a study on the induction of DNA damage, using the alkaline comet assay, in lymphocytes of battery plant workers.</Gene>

<Gene>To elucidate in vivo the mechanism(s) responsible for this effect, we determined ROS production, and glutathione (GSH) levels in living cells using the fluorescent probe (2',7'-dichlorofluorescein and monochlorobimane, respectively).</Gene>

<Gene>Subcellular fractions were obtained from sonicated lymphocytes; cytosolic and membrane expression of PKC isoforms (alpha, and zeta) was evaluated after electrophoresis by immunoblot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The results indicate that lead-exposed workers have significantly elevated levels of DNA breaks compared to the unexposed group.</Gene>

<Gene>A multivariate analysis of variance (ANOVA) shows that the most common confounding factors (smoking, drinking and age) have no synergistic effects with lead-exposure on the comet parameters or on GSH levels and ROS production.</Gene>
<Gene>The logistic regression analysis distinguishing the exposed and non-exposed indicates that only GSH with tail moment are selected as significant risk factors.</Gene>
<Gene>There is a significant positive correlation with ROS production and negative correlation with GSH levels.</Gene>
<Gene>The content of PKC alpha in cytosol and membranes is decreased 40% (indicating a down-regulation of protein), whereas PKC zeta isoform is not modified in an evident manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results suggest that lead-exposure induces an increase of DNA breakage with an alternate cellular redox state and a significant down-regulation of PKC alpha, suggesting that this metal may act as a tumor promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The pharmacogenetics of NAT: structural aspects.</Gene>
<Gene>Inherited and de novo mutations in sporadic cases of DYT1-dystonia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A study of Danish probands with primary torsion dystonia is presented.</Gene>
<Gene>The probands were examined clinically and biochemically to exclude secondary dystonia.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutation analyses for the GAG-deletion in the DYT1 gene were performed on 107 probands; and the mutation was detected in three.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All three probands had the classical phenotype of DYT1-dystonia, but only one had a family history of dystonia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The other two probands had, obviously, sporadic DYT1-dystonia, one of which was caused by a de novo mutation, while the other one had a parent being an asymptomatic carrier.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>De novo mutations in the DYT1 gene are seldom reported although independent founder mutations are known to have occurred.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The frequency of DYT1-dystonia was low in our study even though several probands had early onset generalised dystonia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>None of the probands in our study with other types of dystonia had the GAG-deletion as reported in other studies.</Gene>
<Gene>The difficulties in genetic counselling concerning the heterogeneity of dystonia exemplified by DYT1-dystonia are outlined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The IARC TP53 database: new online mutation analysis and recommendations to users.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the tumor suppressor gene TP53 are frequent in most human cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Comparison of the mutation patterns in different cancers may reveal clues on the natural history of the disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Over the past 10 years, several databases of TP53 mutations have been developed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The most extensive of these databases is maintained and developed at the International Agency for Research on Cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>The database compiles all mutations (somatic and inherited), as well as polymorphisms, that have been reported in the published literature since 1989.</Gene>
<Gene>The IARC TP53 mutation dataset is the largest dataset available on the variations of any human gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The database is available at www.iarc.fr/P53/. In this paper, we describe recent developments of the database.</Gene>

<Gene>These developments include restructuring of the database, which is now patient-centered, with more detailed annotations on the patient (carcinogen exposure, virus infection, genetic background).</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, a new on-line application to retrieve somatic mutation data and analyze mutation patterns is now available.</Gene>
<Gene>We also discuss limitations on the use of the database and provide recommendations to users.</Gene>
<Gene>Human flavin-containing monooxygenase (form 3): polymorphisms and variations in chemical metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The human flavin-containing monooxygenases catalyze the oxygenation of nucleophilic heteroatom-containing drugs, xenobiotics and endogenous materials.</Gene>

<Gene>Evidence for six forms of the FMO gene exist but it is FMO form 3 (FMO3) that is the prominent form in adult human liver that is likely to be associated with the bulk of FMO-mediated metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An understanding of the substrate specificity of human FMO3 is beginning to emerge and several examples of drugs and chemicals extensively metabolized by FMO3 have been reported.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of FMO3 is species- and tissue-specific, but unlike human cytochrome P450 (CYP450), mammalian FMO3 does not appear to be inducible.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interindividual variation in FMO3-dependent metabolism of drugs, chemicals and endogenous materials is therefore more likely to be due to genetic and not environmental effects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Certain mutations of the human FMO3 gene have been associated with abnormal N-oxygenation of trimethylamine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Deficient N-oxygenation of trimethylamine results in a condition called trimethylaminuria.</Gene>
<Gene>Some treatment strategies for this inborn error of metabolism are discussed.</Gene>
<Gene>Other common variants of the FMO3 gene including E158K, V257M and E308G have been observed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It is possible that allelic variation of human FMO3 causes abnormal metabolism of chemicals and has clinical implications for human drug metabolism, but this is an understudied area.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human FMO3 allelic variation may eventually be shown to contribute to interindividual and interethnic variability in FMO3-mediated metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human FMO3 may be another example of an environmental gene that participates in a protective mechanism to help shield humans from potentially toxic exposure to chemicals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Heterogeneity in the relative frequencies of single and multiple site alleles, haplotypes and genotypes of the human FMO3 amongst various ethnic groups suggests population differences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Twenty single-nucleotide polymorphisms in four genes encoding cardiac ion channels.</Gene>

<Gene>We here report 20 novel single-nucleotide polymorphisms in four genes that are potentially involved in the excitement of cardiomyocytes: 1 in KCNA5 (encoding Kv1.5), 5 in KCNAB1 (encoding Kvbeta1.3), 5 in KCNIP2 (encoding KChIP2), and 9 in CACNA1C (encoding a cardiac L-type voltage-dependent calcium ion channel, dihydropyridine receptor).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also examined their allelic frequencies in Japanese individuals.</Gene>
<Gene>These data will be useful for genetic association studies designed to investigate secondary long QT syndrome or other circulatory disorders.</Gene>
<Gene>Vitreoretinopathy with phalangeal epiphyseal dysplasia, a type II collagenopathy resulting from a novel mutation in the C-propeptide region of the molecule.</Gene>

<Gene>A large family with dominantly inherited rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, premature arthropathy, and development of phalangeal epiphyseal dysplasia, resulting in brachydactyly was linked to COL2A1, the gene encoding proalpha1(II) collagen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutational analysis of the gene by exon sequencing identified a novel mutation in the C-propeptide region of the molecule.</Gene>
<Gene>The glycine to aspartic acid change occurred in a region that is highly conserved in all fibrillar collagen molecules.</Gene>

<Gene>The resulting phenotype does not fit easily into pre-existing subgroups of the type II collagenopathies, which includes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia, and the Kniest, Strudwick, and Stickler dysplasias.</Gene>
<Gene>Haplotype study of West European and North African Unverricht-Lundborg chromosomes: evidence for a few founder mutations.</Gene>
<Gene>Unverricht-Lundborg disease (ULD) is a progressive myoclonus epilepsy common in Finland and North Africa, and less common in Western Europe.</Gene>
<Gene>ULD is mostly caused by expansion of a dodecamer repeat in the cystatin B gene ( CSTB) promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We performed a haplotype study of ULD chromosomes (ULDc) with the repeat expansion.</Gene>
<Gene>We included 48 West European Caucasian (WEC) and 47 North African (NA) ULDc.</Gene>
<Gene>We analysed eight markers flanking CSTB(GT10-D21S1890-D21S1885-D21S2040-D21S1259- CSTB-D21S1912-PFKL-D21S171) and one intragenic variant in the CSTB 3' UTR (A2575G).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We observed a founder effect in most of the NA ULD patients, as 61.7% of the NA ULDc (29/47) shared the same haplotype, A1 (1-1-A-1-6-7), for markers D21S1885-D21S2040-A2575G-D21S1259-D21S1912-PFKL.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, if we considered only the markers D21S1885, D21S2040, A2575G and D21S1259, 43 of the 47 NA ULDc shared the same alleles 1-1-A-1, haplotype A. As previously shown, the WEC ULDc were heterogeneous.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the Baltic haplotype, A3 (5-1-1-A-1-1), was observed in ten WEC ULDc (20.8%) and the CSTB 3'UTR variant, which we called the Alps variant, was observed in 17 ULDc (35.4%).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, as almost all NA patients, like Scandinavian patients, were of the haplotype A, we assumed that there was an ancient common founder effect in NA and Baltic ULD patients.</Gene>
<Gene>We estimated that the putative most recent common ancestral ULD carrier with this haplotype A must have existed about 2,500 years ago (100-150 generations).</Gene>
<Gene>Finally, this work provides evidence for the existence of only a small number of founder mutations in ULD.</Gene>
<Gene>Three novel mutations of the PKD1 gene in Korean patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations at the PKD1 locus account for 85% of cases of the common genetic disorder called autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Screening for mutations of the PKD1 gene is complicated by the genomic structure of the 5'-duplicated region encoding 75% of the gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To date, more than 90 mutations of the PKD1 gene have been reported in the European and American populations, and relatively little information is available concerning the pattern of mutations present in the Asian populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We looked for mutations of the PKD1 gene in 51 unrelated Korean ADPKD patients, using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) with primer pairs located in the 3' single-copy region of the PKD1 gene and by single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found three novel mutations, a G to A substitution at nucleotide 11012 (G3601S), a C to A substitution at nucleotide 11312 (Q3701X), and a C to T substitution at nucleotide 12971 (P4254S), and a single polymorphism involving a G to C substitution at nucleotide 11470 (L3753L).</Gene>
<Gene>These mutations were not found in control individuals, and no other mutations in the 3' single-copy region of the PKD1 gene of patients with these mutations were observed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In particular, P4254S segregated with the disease phenotype.</Gene>

<Gene>The clinical data of affected individuals from this study, and of previously reported Korean PKD1 mutations, showed that patients with frameshift or nonsense mutations were more prone to develop end-stage renal failure than those with missense mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings indicate that many different PKD1 mutations are likely to be responsible for ADPKD in the Korean population, as in the Western population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Evidence for a founder effect for pseudoxanthoma elasticum in the Afrikaner population of South Africa.</Gene>
<Gene>Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) is a heritable elastic tissue disorder recently shown to be attributable to mutations in the ABCC6 ( MRP6) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Whereas PXE has been identified in all ethnic groups studied to date, the prevalence of this disease in various populations is uncertain, although often assumed to be similar.</Gene>
<Gene>A notable exception however is the prevalence of PXE among South African Afrikaners.</Gene>

<Gene>A previous report has suggested that a founder effect may explain the higher prevalence of PXE in Afrikaners, a European-derived population that first settled in South Africa in the 17th century.</Gene>
<Gene>To investigate this hypothesis, we performed haplotype and mutational analysis of DNA from 24 South African families of Afrikaner, British and Indian descent.</Gene>
<Gene>Among the 17 Afrikaner families studied, three common haplotypes and six different disease-causing variants were identified.</Gene>
<Gene>Three of these mutant alleles were missense variants, two were nonsense mutations and one was a single base-pair insertion.</Gene>
<Gene>The most common variant accounted for 53% of the PXE alleles, whereas other mutant alleles appeared at lower frequencies ranging from 3% to 12%.</Gene>
<Gene>Haplotype analysis of the Afrikaner families showed that the three most frequent mutations were identical-by-descent, indicating a founder origin of PXE in this population.</Gene>
<Gene>D90A-SOD1 mediated amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: a single founder for all cases with evidence for a Cis-acting disease modifier in the recessive haplotype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>More than 100 different heterozygous mutations in copper/zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD1) have been found in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a fatal neurodegenerative disease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Uniquely, D90A-SOD1 has been identified in recessive, dominant and apparently sporadic pedigrees.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The phenotype of homozygotes is stereotyped with an extended survival, whereas that of affected heterozygotes varies.</Gene>
<Gene>The frequency of D90A-SOD1 is 50 times higher in Scandinavia (2.5%) than elsewhere, though ALS prevalence is not raised there.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our earlier study indicated separate founders for recessive and dominant/sporadic ALS and we proposed a disease-modifying factor linked to the recessive mutation.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we have doubled our sample set and employed novel markers to characterise the mutation's origin and localise any modifying factor.</Gene>
<Gene>Linkage disequilibrium analysis indicates that D90A homozygotes and heterozygotes share a rare haplotype and are all descended from a single ancient founder (alpha 0.974)</Gene>
<Gene>c.895 generations ago.</Gene>
<Gene>Homozygotes arose subsequently only c.63 generations ago (alpha 0.878).</Gene>
<Gene>Recombination has reduced the region shared by recessive kindreds to 97-265 kb around SOD1, excluding all neighbouring genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We propose that a cis-acting regulatory polymorphism has arisen close to D90A-SOD1 in the recessive founder, which decreases ALS susceptibility in heterozygotes and slows disease progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>SNP S1103Y in the cardiac sodium channel gene SCN5A is associated with cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death in a white family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cardiac arrhythmias cause 400 000 sudden deaths annually in the United States alone.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations in the cardiac sodium channel gene SCN5A on chromosome 3p21 cause cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we define an SCN5A mutation, S1103Y, in a white family associated with syncope, ventricular fibrillation, and sudden death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A very recent study reported the same mutation in 13.2% of African Americans, but not in the white population.</Gene>

<Gene>Our study shows that mutation S1103Y does exist in the white population, and it is associated with a considerable risk of syncope, ventricular arrhythmia, ventricular fibrillation, and sudden death in this population.</Gene>
<Gene>Common sequence variants of the macrophage scavenger receptor 1 gene are associated with prostate cancer risk.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rare germline mutations of macrophage scavenger receptor 1 (MSR1) gene were reported to be associated with prostate cancer risk in families with hereditary prostate cancer (HPC) and in patients with non-HPC (Xu et al. 2002).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To further evaluate the role of MSR1 in prostate cancer susceptibility, at Johns Hopkins Hospital, we studied five common variants of MSR1 in 301 patients with non-HPC who underwent prostate cancer treatment and in 250 control subjects who participated in prostate cancer-screening programs and had normal digital rectal examination and PSA levels (<4 ng/ml).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Significantly different allele frequencies between case subjects and control subjects were observed for each of the five variants (P value range.01-.04).</Gene>
<Gene>Haplotype analyses provided consistent findings, with a significant difference in the haplotype frequencies from a global score test (P=.01).</Gene>

<Gene>Because the haplotype that is associated with the increased risk for prostate cancer did not harbor any of the known rare mutations, it appears that the observed association of common variants and prostate cancer risk are independent of the effect of the known rare mutations.</Gene>
<Gene>These results consistently suggest that MSR1 may play an important role in prostate carcinogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Subcortical band heterotopia with simplified gyral pattern and syndactyly.</Gene>
<Gene>We describe a girl with an unusual form of subcortical band heterotopia (SBH) and a complex malformation syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>SBH had an irregular inner margin, organized in contiguous fascicles of migrating neurons, sometimes giving the appearance of many small contiguous gyri.</Gene>
<Gene>The true cortex had decreased thickness and showed a simplified gyral pattern with decreased number of gyri, which were usually of increased width, and shallow sulci.</Gene>
<Gene>The cerebellum was hypoplastic.</Gene>

<Gene>Additional features included epicanthal folds, hypertelorism, small nose with hypoplastic nares, bilateral syndactyly of the toes, pulmonary valve stenosis, atrial and ventricular septal defects.</Gene>
<Gene>At the age of 1 year the patient had severe developmental delay and epilepsy.</Gene>
<Gene>Chromosome studies and mutation analysis of the DCX and LIS1 genes gave negative results.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This observation delineates a new multiple congenital abnormalities mental retardation syndrome and confirms genetic heterogeneity of SBH.</Gene>
<Gene>Lack of association between the G protein beta3 subunit gene and essential hypertension in Chinese: a case-control and a family-based study.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A C825T polymorphism of the gene encoding the G protein beta3 subunit (GNB3) is associated with enhanced G protein activity and increased intracellular signal transduction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 825T allele has been implicated in the development of hypertension in some ethnic groups, especially in whites.</Gene>
<Gene>Studies in Asians and blacks are more controversial, and little information is available on this polymorphism in the susceptibility to hypertension in the Chinese population.</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, the inconsistency between studies may be due to genetic heterogeneity of the population selected and/or the lack of statistical power.</Gene>
<Gene>We investigated the relationship of this polymorphism with hypertension in two independent northern Chinese populations using both a case-control and a family-based study design.</Gene>
<Gene>The GNB3 C825T polymorphism was determined by polymerase chain reaction and restriction enzyme digestion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the case-control study which included 585 hypertensive case subjects and 580 normotensive control subjects there was no significant association between the polymorphism and hypertension status or blood pressure levels.</Gene>
<Gene>The lack of association was confirmed by the results obtained in 181 hypertensive families using both transmission disequilibrium test and sib transmission disequilibrium test.</Gene>
<Gene>No preferential transmission was observed for the GNB3 825T allele to the affected subjects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, there was no significant association between the polymorphism and body mass index in the case-control study.</Gene>

<Gene>Therefore our work does not provide evidence in favor of GNB3 C825T being a candidate gene for conferring genetic susceptibility to hypertension or obesity in northern Chinese population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gene-gene interaction between the monoamine oxidase A gene and solute carrier family 6 (neurotransmitter transporter, noradrenalin) member 2 gene in anorexia nervosa (restrictive subtype).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We earlier found an association between anorexia nervosa (AN) restrictive subtype (AN-R) and an inserted sequence within the NETpPR, a polymorphic region located in the promoter of the solute carrier family 6 (neurotransmitter transporter, noradrenalin) member 2 (SLC6A2) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To further examine the noradrenergic system in AN-R we performed an association study with a functional polymorphism (MAOA-uVNTR) in the promoter of the monoamine oxidase A (MAOA) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since monoamine oxidase A metabolises noradrenalin, a positive association with the MAOA gene would be biologically plausible.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transmission disequilibrium test and 95 trios/duos (AN-R females+biological parents) showed the main effect of the longer, more transcriptionally active form of the MAOA-uVNTR (MAOA-L) to be statistically non-significant (McNemar's chi(2)=1.4, df=1, P=0.238, odds ratio: 1.4, 95% CI 0.8-2.7).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A case-control approach supported this finding.</Gene>
<Gene>We then stratified the MAOA-uVNTR TDT data according to the (a) NETpPR genotype of the AN-R females, and (b) NETpPR allele transmitted from NETpPR-S4/L4 heterozygous mothers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In both cases, contingency table analysis revealed previously unreported gene-gene interaction between the MAOA and SLC6A2 genes (P=0.019 and 0.019, respectively).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Receiving an MAOA-L allele more than doubles the risk for developing AN-R, conditional on an individual also being a NETpPR-L4 homozygote (stratum-specific odds ratio: 2.4, 95% CI 1.1-6.0).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest important involvement of the noradrenergic system in the biological underpinnings of AN-R.</Gene>
<Gene>Evidence for a QTL on chromosome 19 influencing LDL cholesterol levels in the general population.</Gene>
<Gene>The genetic basis of cardiovascular disease (CVD) with its complex etiology is still largely elusive.</Gene>

<Gene>Plasma levels of lipids and apolipoproteins are among the major quantitative risk factors for CVD and are well-established intermediate traits that may be more accessible to genetic dissection than clinical CVD end points.</Gene>

<Gene>Chromosome 19 harbors multiple genes that have been suggested to play a role in lipid metabolism and previous studies indicated the presence of a quantitative trait locus (QTL) for cholesterol levels in genetic isolates.</Gene>

<Gene>To establish the relevance of genetic variation at chromosome 19 for plasma levels of lipids and apolipoproteins in the general, out-bred Caucasian population, we performed a linkage study in four independent samples, including adolescent Dutch twins and adult Dutch, Swedish and Australian twins totaling 493 dizygotic twin pairs.</Gene>

<Gene>The average spacing of short-tandem-repeat markers was 6-8 cM. In the three adult twin samples, we found consistent evidence for linkage of chromosome 19 with LDL cholesterol levels (maximum LOD scores of 4.5, 1.7 and 2.1 in the Dutch, Swedish and Australian sample, respectively); no indication for linkage was observed in the adolescent Dutch twin sample.</Gene>
<Gene>The QTL effects in the three adult samples were not significantly different and a simultaneous analysis of the samples increased the maximum LOD score to 5.7 at 60 cM pter.</Gene>
<Gene>Bivariate analyses indicated that the putative LDL-C QTL also contributed to the variance in ApoB levels, consistent with the high genetic correlation between these phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our study provides strong evidence for the presence of a QTL on chromosome 19 with a major effect on LDL-C plasma levels in outbred Caucasian populations.</Gene>
<Gene>A 3.4-kbp transcript of ZNF331 is solely expressed in follicular thyroid adenomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Translocations involving chromosomal region 19q13 are a frequent finding in follicular adenomas of the thyroid and might represent the most frequent type of structural aberration in human epithelial tumors.</Gene>
<Gene>By positional cloning, a putative candidate gene, ZNF331 (formerly RITA) located close to the breakpoint was identified.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, aberrant expression of ZNF331 has been described in two cell lines of follicular thyroid adenomas with aberrations in 19q13 indicating an involvement of ZNF331 in tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nevertheless, knowledge about structure and expression of ZNF331 is limited.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We performed RACE-PCR and genomic sequence analyses to gain a deeper insight into its molecular structure.</Gene>
<Gene>To elucidate ZNF331 expression patterns we performed Northern blot analyses on various normal tissues as well as on thyroid carcinoma and adenoma cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Herein, unique expression of a 3.4-kbp transcript is described in thyroid adenoma cell lines with 19q13 aberrations, which was not detected either in normal tissues or in thyroid carcinoma cell lines.</Gene>
<Gene>Developmentally-programmed FMRP expression in oligodendrocytes: a potential role of FMRP in regulating translation in oligodendroglia progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) is a selective RNA-binding protein whose function is implicated in regulating protein synthesis of its mRNA targets.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The lack of FMRP leads to abnormal synapse development in the brain and impaired learning/memory.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although FMRP is predominantly expressed in neurons of the adult brain, whether FMRP also functions in glia during early development remains elusive, since expression of FMRP in glia has not been rigorously examined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is an important question because recent studies revealed important roles of glia in synaptic development.</Gene>

<Gene>Here we report that in addition to the observed neuronal expression, FMRP expression is detected in oligodendroglia progenitor cells (OPCs), immature oligodendrocytes and oligodendroglia cell lines, where it interacts with a subgroup of oligodendrocyte-specific mRNAs, including the myelin basic protein (MBP) mRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FMRP expression gradually declines as oligodendrocytes differentiate in vitro and in the developing brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The decline of FMRP expression during oligodendrocyte differentiation is associated with a vigorous up-regulation of the MBP protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we show that the MBP 3'untranslated region (3'UTR) is necessary and sufficient for binding FMRP, and mediates translation inhibition of a reporter gene by FMRP specifically in oligodendrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results support the hypothesis that FMRP may participate in regulating translation of its bound mRNAs in oligodendroglia during early brain development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Propofol anesthesia in children does not induce sister chromatid exchanges in lymphocytes.</Gene>
<Gene>Y-chromosomal microsatellite mutation rates: differences in mutation rate between and within loci.</Gene>
<Gene>Low frequency of deafness-associated GJB2 variants in Kenya and Sudan and novel GJB2 variants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A large proportion of non-syndromic autosomal recessive deafness (NSARD) in many populations is caused by variants of the GJB2 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, the frequency of GJB2 variants was studied in 406 and 183 apparently unrelated children from Kenya and Sudan, respectively, with mostly severe to profound non-syndromic deafness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nine (2.2 %) Kenyan and 12 (6.6 %) of the Sudanese children only were carriers of variants within the coding sequence of the GJB2 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Variants in the 5'-adjacent region were detected in further 115 individuals.</Gene>

<Gene>A total of 10 novel variants was recognized, among them four variants in the adjacent 5'-region of the GJB2 coding exon 2 (g.3318-6T>A, g.3318-15C>T, g.3318-34C>T, g.3318-35T>G), a 6 base-pair deletion (g.3455_3460del</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>[p.Asp46_Gln48delinsGlu]), a variant leading to a stop codon (g.3512C></Gene>
<Gene>A</Gene>
<Gene>[p.Tyr65X]), synonymous variants (g.3395C>T [p.Thr26], g.3503C>T</Gene>
<Gene>[p.Asn62], g.3627A>C</Gene>
<Gene>[p.Arg104]), and one non-synonymous variant (g.3816C>A</Gene>
<Gene>[p.Val167Met]).</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, the previously described variants g.3352delG (commonly designated 30delG or 35 delG), g.3426G>A</Gene>
<Gene>[p.Val37Ile], g.3697G>A [p.Arg127His], g.3774G></Gene>
<Gene>A [p.Val153Ile], and g.3795G>A</Gene>
<Gene>[p.Gly160Ser] were identified.</Gene>
<Gene>With the exception of g.3318-34C>T and g.3352delG, all variants occurred heterozygously.</Gene>
<Gene>For most of the variants identified in the Kenyan and Sudanese study population, a causative association with NSARD appears to be unlikely.</Gene>

<Gene>Compared to many other ethnic groups, deafness-associated variants of the coding region of GJB2 are rare in Sudan and Kenya, suggesting a role of other genetic, or epigenetic factors as a cause for deafness in these countries.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Clinical features of psychotic disorders and polymorphisms in HT2A, DRD2, DRD4, SLC6A3 (DAT1), and BDNF: a family based association study.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Schizophrenia is clinically heterogeneous and multidimensional, but it is not known whether this is due to etiological heterogeneity.</Gene>
<Gene>Previous studies have not consistently reported association between any specific polymorphisms and clinical features of schizophrenia, and have primarily used case-control designs.</Gene>

<Gene>We tested for the presence of association between clinical features and polymorphisms in the genes for the serotonin 2A receptor (HT2A), dopamine receptor types 2 and 4, dopamine transporter (SLC6A3), and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two hundred seventy pedigrees were ascertained on the basis of having two or more members with schizophrenia or poor outcome schizoaffective disorder.</Gene>
<Gene>Diagnoses were made using a structured interview based on the SCID.</Gene>
<Gene>All patients were rated on the major symptoms of schizophrenia scale (MSSS), integrating clinical and course features throughout the course of illness.</Gene>
<Gene>Factor analysis revealed positive, negative, and affective symptom factors.</Gene>
<Gene>The program QTDT was used to implement a family-based test of association for quantitative traits, controlling for age and sex.</Gene>

<Gene>We found suggestive evidence of association between the His452Tyr polymorphism in HT2A and affective symptoms (P = 0.02), the 172-bp allele of BDNF and negative symptoms (P = 0.04), and the 480-bp allele in SLC6A3 (= DAT1) and negative symptoms (P = 0.04).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As total of 19 alleles were tested, we cannot rule out false positives.</Gene>

<Gene>However, given prior evidence of involvement of the proteins encoded by these genes in psychopathology, our results suggest that more attention should be focused on the impact of these alleles on clinical features of schizophrenia.</Gene>
<Gene>Genomic evidence for recent positive selection at the human MDR1 gene locus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The MDR1 multidrug transporter regulates the traffic of drugs, peptides and xenobiotics into the body as well as sensitive tissues like the brain, germ cells and the developing fetus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hence, it may influence an individual's response to drugs as well as his/her susceptibility to complex diseases in which environmental factors, especially xenobiotics, play a role.</Gene>

<Gene>Polymorphisms within this gene, especially single-nucleotide polymorphism e26/3435(C/T), have been variously associated with differences in MDR1 expression, function, drug response and disease susceptibility.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we report the detailed characterization of the haplotype and linkage disequilibrium architecture of the entire 200 kb of the MDR1 gene in five world populations, namely, Chinese, Malays, Indians, Caucasians and African-Americans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed varied haplotype diversity across the entire gene in the different populations.</Gene>

<Gene>The major haplotype mh5, which contains the subhaplotype e12/1236T-e21/2677T-e26/3435T, is highly represented among the four non-African populations, while mh7, which contains the subhaplotype e12/1236C-e21/2677G-e26/3435C, accounts for over a third of African-American chromosomes.</Gene>

<Gene>These observations are inconsistent with a simple population evolution model, but instead are suggestive of recent historical events that have maintained such long range linkage disequilibrium.</Gene>

<Gene>Using a modified long-range haplotype test, we found statistically significant evidence of recent positive selection for the e21/2677T and e26/3435T alleles in the Chinese population, and for the e26/3435T allele in the Malay population.</Gene>
<Gene>Interestingly, we also detected evidence for positive selection of the alternative allele e26/3435C in the African-American population.</Gene>

<Gene>These data suggest that independent mutational events may have occurred on the mh5 and mh7 haplotypes of the MDR1 gene to confer positive selection in the non-African and African-American populations, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the PCSK9 gene in Norwegian subjects with autosomal dominant hypercholesterolemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) is at a locus for autosomal dominant hypercholesterolemia, and recent data indicate that the PCSK9 gene is involved in cholesterol biosynthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations within this gene have previously been found to segregate with hypercholesterolemia.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, DNA sequencing of the 12 exons of the PCSK9 gene has been performed in 51 Norwegian subjects with a clinical diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia where mutations in the low-density lipoprotein receptor gene and mutation R3500Q in the apolipoprotein B-100 gene had been excluded.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two novel missense mutations were detected in the catalytic subdomain of the PCSK9 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two patients were heterozygotes for D374Y, and one patient was a double heterozygote for D374Y and N157K. D374Y segregated with hypercholesterolemia in the two former families where family members were available for study.</Gene>
<Gene>Our findings support the notion that mutations in the PCSK9 gene cause autosomal dominant hypercholesterolemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Disruption of contactin 4 (CNTN4) results in developmental delay and other features of 3p deletion syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>3p deletion syndrome is a rare contiguous-gene disorder involving the loss of the telomeric portion of the short arm of chromosome 3 and characterized by developmental delay, growth retardation, and dysmorphic features.</Gene>
<Gene>All reported cases have involved, at a minimum, the deletion of chromosome 3 telomeric to the band 3p25.3.</Gene>

<Gene>Despite the presence of several genes in this region that are involved in neural development, a causative relationship between a particular transcript and the observed clinical manifestations has remained elusive.</Gene>

<Gene>We have identified a child with characteristic physical features of 3p deletion syndrome and both verbal and nonverbal developmental delay who carries a de novo balanced translocation involving chromosomes 3 and 10.</Gene>

<Gene>Fine mapping of this rearrangement demonstrates that the translocation breakpoint on chromosome 3 falls within the recently identified minimal candidate region for 3p deletion syndrome and disrupts the Contactin 4 (CNTN4) mRNA transcript at 3p26.2-3p26.3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This transcript (also known as BIG-2) is a member of the immunoglobulin super family of neuronal cell adhesion molecules involved in axon growth, guidance, and fasciculation in the central nervous system (CNS).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results demonstrate the association of CNTN4 disruption with the 3p deletion syndrome phenotype and strongly suggest a causal relationship.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings point to an important role for CNTN4 in normal and abnormal CNS development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Offspring gender ratio and the rate of recurrent spontaneous miscarriages in jewish women at high risk for breast/ovarian cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>BRCA1/BRCA2 germline mutations are associated with an increased breast/ovarian cancer risk.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Offspring gender ratios may be skewed against male births in BRCA1 mutation carriers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the lack of viable homozygous BRCA1/BRCA2-mutation carriers implies that recurrent miscarriages may be associated with homozygous fetuses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Jewish Israeli high-risk women who were tested for being carriers of the predominant BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations in Jewish high-risk families were analyzed for the sex of offspring and the rate of spontaneous miscarriages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overall, 817 women participated: 393 BRCA1/BRCA2-mutation carriers (229 with breast/ovarian cancer) and 424 high-risk noncarriers (208 with breast/ovarian cancer).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>No differences between the male-to-female offspring ratios of all study groups were noted.</Gene>
<Gene>Among mutation carriers, the offspring male-to-female ratio was 0.97 (444 : 460), and among mutation carriers with cancer it was 0.92 (262 : 284).</Gene>
<Gene>Similarly, no offspring gender skewing was noted among high-risk noncarriers, regardless of health status.</Gene>

<Gene>The rates of three or more spontaneous miscarriages among participants with at least one live birth were 4.37% (15/343) among mutation carriers and 3% (12/401) among high-risk women (P = not significant).</Gene>
<Gene>In conclusion, the offspring gender ratio is similar in high-risk Jewish families and in the general population.</Gene>
<Gene>The issue of the rate of recurrent miscarriages in high-risk Jewish women is unresolved.</Gene>
<Gene>Corticosteroid pharmacogenetics: association of sequence variants in CRHR1 with improved lung function in asthmatics treated with inhaled corticosteroids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Corticosteroids mediate a variety of immunological actions and are commonly utilized in the treatment of a wide range of diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>Unfortunately, therapy with this class of medications is associated with a large proportion of non-responders and significant side effects.</Gene>
<Gene>Inhaled corticosteroids are the most commonly used asthma controller therapy.</Gene>
<Gene>However, asthmatic response to corticosteroids also varies widely between individuals.</Gene>
<Gene>We investigated the genetic contribution to the variation in response to inhaled corticosteroid therapy in asthma.</Gene>

<Gene>The association of longitudinal change in lung function and single nucleotide polymorphisms from candidate genes crucial to the biologic actions of corticosteroids were evaluated in three independent asthmatic clinical trial populations utilizing inhaled corticosteroids as the primary therapy in at least one treatment arm.</Gene>
<Gene>Variation in one gene, corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor 1 (CRHR1) was consistently associated with enhanced response to therapy in each of our three populations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Individuals homozygous for the variants of interest manifested a doubling to quadrupling of the lung function response to corticosteroids compared with lack of the variants (P-values ranging from 0.006 to 0.025 for our three asthmatic populations).</Gene>
<Gene>As the primary receptor mediating the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone, which regulates endogenous cortisol levels, CRHR1 plays a pivotal, pleiotropic role in steroid biology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data indicate that genetic variants in CRHR1 have pharmacogenetic effects influencing asthmatic response to corticosteroids, provide a rationale for predicting therapeutic response in asthma and other corticosteroid-treated diseases, and suggests this gene pathway as a potential novel therapeutic target.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A double cryptic chromosome imbalance is an important factor to explain phenotypic variability in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>Paraoxonase 1 polymorphisms and survival.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The antioxidant enzyme paraoxonase 1 (PON1) has previously been suggested to confer protection against coronary heart disease (CHD), one of the main causes of death in the Western world.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two coding polymorphisms, 55M/L and 192Q/R, and a promoter variant, -107C/T, has been extensively studied with respect to susceptibility to CHD.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we have investigated the impact of these three polymorphisms on mortality using a sample of 1932 Danish individuals aged 47-93 years, previously used in gene-longevity studies.</Gene>

<Gene>A cross-sectional study comparing the genotype distribution of the three polymorphisms separately as well as the haplotype distribution in different age groups did not reveal any difference.</Gene>
<Gene>However, a longitudinal follow-up study on survival in the same sample indicated that 192RR homozygotes have a poorer survival compared to QQ homozygotes (hazard rate: 1.38, P = 0.04).</Gene>
<Gene>We hereafter used an independent sample of 541 Danish individuals from the oldest cohort and confirmed the initial findings (hazard rate: 1.38, P = 0.09).</Gene>
<Gene>In both samples, the effect was most pronounced in women.</Gene>

<Gene>Using self-reported data on ischemic heart disease to evaluate the impact of the PON 192Q/R polymorphism on susceptibility to CHD, we found only a nonsignificant trend of 192RR homozygosity in women being a risk factor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results thus indicates that PON1 192RR homozygosity is associated with increased mortality in women in the second half of life and that this increased mortality is possibly related to CHD severity and survival after CHD rather than susceptibility to development of CHD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Trisomy 1 in a case of a missed abortion.</Gene>
<Gene>CFTR mutation distribution among U.S. Hispanic and African American individuals: evaluation in cystic fibrosis patient and carrier screening populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>

<Gene>We reviewed CFTR mutation distribution among Hispanic and African American individuals referred for CF carrier screening and compared mutation frequencies to those derived from CF patient samples.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Results from CFTR mutation analyses received from January 2001 through September 2003, were analyzed for four populations: Hispanic individuals with a CF diagnosis (n = 159) or carrier screening indication (n = 15,333) and African American individuals with a CF diagnosis (n = 108) or carrier screening indication (n = 8,973).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All samples were tested for the same 87 mutation panel.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>In the Hispanic population, 42 mutations were identified: 30 in the patient population (77.5% detection rate) and 33 among carrier screening referrals.</Gene>
<Gene>Five mutations not included in the ACMG/ACOG carrier screening panel (3876delA, W1089X, R1066C, S549N, 1949del84) accounted for 7.55% detection in patients and 5.58% among carriers.</Gene>
<Gene>Among African American referrals, 33 different mutations were identified: 21 in the patient population (74.4% detection) and 23 in the carrier screening population.</Gene>
<Gene>Together, A559T and 711+5G></Gene>
<Gene>A were observed at a detection rate of 3.71% in CF patients and 6.38% in carriers.</Gene>
