<Gene>The mutation distribution seen in both the carrier screening populations reflected an increased frequency of mutations with variable expression such as D1152H, R117H, and L206W. CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>A detailed analysis of CFTR mutation distribution in the Hispanic and African American patient and carrier screening populations demonstrates that a diverse group of mutations is most appropriate for diagnostic and carrier screening in these populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To best serve the increasingly diverse U.S. population, ethnic-specific mutations should be included in mutation panels.</Gene>
<Gene>Fine mapping and identification of a candidate gene SSH1 in disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis (DSAP) is an uncommon autosomal dominant chronic keratinization disorder, characterized by multiple superficial keratotic lesions surrounded by a slightly raised keratotic border.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus far, although two loci for DSAP have been identified, the genetic basis and pathogenesis of this disorder have not been elucidated yet.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we performed a genome-wide linkage analysis in three Chinese affected families and localized the gene in an 8.0 cM interval defined by D12S330 and D12S354 on chromosome 12.</Gene>

<Gene>Upon screening 30 candidate genes, we identified a missense mutation, p.Ser63Asn in SSH1 in one family, a frameshift mutation, p.Ser19CysfsX24 in an alternative variant (isoform f) of SSH1 in another family, and a frameshift mutation, p.Pro27ProfsX54 in the same alternative variant in one non-familial case with DSAP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SSH1 encodes a phosphatase that plays a pivotal role in actin dynamics.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggested that cytoskeleton disorganization in epidermal cells is likely associated with the pathogenesis of DSAP.</Gene>
<Gene>Alternative splicing in the N-terminus of Alzheimer's presenilin 1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Presenilin 1 (PS1) is mutated in the majority of familial cases of Alzheimer disease (AD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although it is clear that PS1 is involved in the processing of the amyloid precursor protein (APP), the exact function of PS1 is still elusive.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human presenilin 1 (PS1) is alternatively spliced, resulting in the presence or absence of a four-amino acid motif, VRSQ, in the PS1 N-terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In human tissues, both isoforms are expressed.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we report that mouse and rat only express the longer PS1 isoform.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The presence of this motif introduces a potential phosphorylation site for protein kinase C. Because the splice occurs in the region of PS1 that we have previously shown to bind to rabGDI, this might provide a regulatory mechanism for this interaction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data show that the -VRSQ isoform binds rabGDI, but the +VRSQ does not.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, mutation of the putatively phosphorylated threonine in PS1 disrupts the binding to rabGDI, showing its importance for the interaction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To our knowledge this is the first study showing a functional difference between PS1 splice variants.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The possible consequences for APP processing and the pathogenesis of AD are discussed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Haplotype structure of the beta adrenergic receptor genes in US Caucasians and African Americans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The beta-adrenergic receptors (beta-AR) are G protein-coupled receptors activated by epinephrine and norepinephrine and are involved in a variety of their physiological functions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously, three beta-AR genes (ADRB1, ADRB2 and ADRB3) were resequenced, identifying polymorphisms that were used in genetic association studies of cardiovascular and metabolic disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These studies have produced intriguing but inconsistent results, potentially because the known functional variants: ADRB1 Arg389Gly and Gly49Ser, ADRB2 Arg16Gly and Gln27Glu, and ADRB3 Arg64Trp provided an incomplete picture of the total functional diversity at these genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we created marker panels for each beta-AR gene that included the known functional markers and also other markers evenly spaced and with sufficient density to identify haplotype block structure and to maximize haplotype diversity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A total of 27 markers were genotyped in 96 US Caucasians and 96 African Americans.</Gene>
<Gene>In both populations and for each gene, a single block with little evidence of historical recombination was observed.</Gene>

<Gene>For each gene, haplotype captured most of the information content of each functional locus, even if that locus was not genotyped, and presumably haplotype would capture the signal from unknown functional loci whose alleles are of moderate abundance.</Gene>
<Gene>This study demonstrates the utility of using beta-AR gene haplotype maps and marker panels as tools for linkage studies on beta-AR function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cis-acting transmission of genomic instability.</Gene>
<Gene>Genomic instability is a highly pleiotropic phenotype, which may reflect a variety of underlying mechanisms.</Gene>
<Gene>Destabilization has been shown in some cases to involve mutational alteration or inactivation of trans-acting cellular factors, for example, p53 or mismatch repair functions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, aspects of instability are not well explained by mutational inactivation of trans-acting factors, and other epigenetic and cis-acting mechanisms have recently been proposed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The trans and cis models result in divergent predictions for the distribution of instability-associated genetic alterations within the genome, and for the inheritance of genomic instability among sibling sub-clones of unstable parents.</Gene>

<Gene>These predictions have been tested in this study primarily by tracking the karyotypic distribution of chromosomal rearrangements in clones and sub-clones exhibiting radiation-induced genomic instability; inheritance of mutator phenotypes was also analyzed.</Gene>

<Gene>The results indicate that genomic instability is unevenly transmitted to sibling sub-clones, that chromosomal rearrangements within unstable clones are non-randomly distributed throughout the karyotype, and that the majority of chromosomal rearrangements associated with instability affect trisomic chromosomal segments.</Gene>

<Gene>Observations of instability in trisomic regions suggests that in addition to promoting further alterations in chromosomal number, aneuploidy can affect the recovery of structural rearrangements.</Gene>

<Gene>In summary, these findings cannot be fully explained by invoking a homogeneously distributed factor acting in trans, but do provide support for previous suggestions that genomic instability may in part be driven by a cis-acting mechanism.</Gene>
<Gene>Tumor associated antigen recognition by autologous serum in patients with breast cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Breast cancer accounts for 30-40% of all deaths from cancers in females.</Gene>

<Gene>In an effort to identify tumor associated antigens that may be useful for immunotherapy, we utilized serological analysis of recombinant cDNA expression libraries (SEREX) technique to identify breast cancer-associated antigens.</Gene>
<Gene>SEREX screening of cDNA expression libraries derived from 3 breast cancer patients identified a total of 88 positive clones (bcg-1 to bcg-88), including 27 hitherto unknown sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cDNA sequences and mRNA expression patterns were characterized.</Gene>
<Gene>Seroreactivity of the SEREX clones were determined in sera from 75 breast cancer patients, 75 colon cancer patients, and 25 healthy donors.</Gene>
<Gene>Expression analysis on a cDNA panel from 17 different normal tissues by reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) revealed tissue restricted mRNA expression of 2 of the 27 unknown antigens.</Gene>
<Gene>Bcg-72 is expressed only in breast, prostate and thymus, while bcg-84 is expressed at moderate levels in testis, spleen and breast.</Gene>
<Gene>The other 25 unknown antigens were expressed in most other tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>Serologic assay revealed that 7 out of the 88 clones showed reactivity to at least one serum from either 75 breast or 75 colon cancer patients.</Gene>
<Gene>These clones did not react with sera from a panel of 25 healthy adult individuals.</Gene>
<Gene>Our results demonstrate the utility of the SEREX approach for the identification of potential tumor associated antigens in human breast cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Automated genomic sequence analysis of the three collagen VI genes: applications to Ullrich congenital muscular dystrophy and Bethlem myopathy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>INTRODUCTION: Mutations in the genes encoding collagen VI (COL6A1, COL6A2, and COL6A3) cause Bethlem myopathy (BM) and Ullrich congenital muscular dystrophy (UCMD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BM is a relatively mild dominantly inherited disorder with proximal weakness and distal joint contractures.</Gene>
<Gene>UCMD is an autosomal recessive condition causing severe muscle weakness with proximal joint contractures and distal hyperlaxity.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We developed a method for rapid direct sequence analysis of all 107 coding exons of the COL6 genes using single condition amplification/internal primer (SCAIP) sequencing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have sequenced all three COL6 genes from genomic DNA in 79 patients with UCMD or BM. RESULTS:</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found putative mutations in one of the COL6 genes in 62% of patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This more than doubles the number of identified COL6 mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Most of these changes are consistent with straightforward autosomal dominant or recessive inheritance.</Gene>

<Gene>However, some patients showed changes in more than one of the COL6 genes, and our results suggest that some UCMD patients may have dominantly acting mutations rather than recessive disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DISCUSSION:</Gene>
<Gene>Our findings may explain some or all of the cases of UCMD that are unlinked to the COL6 loci under a recessive model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The large number of single nucleotide polymorphisms which we generated in the course of this work may be of importance in determining the major phenotypic variability seen in this group of disorders.</Gene>
<Gene>Photochemoprevention of ultraviolet B signaling and photocarcinogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>Exposure to solar radiation, particularly its ultraviolet (UV) B component, has a variety of harmful effects on human health.</Gene>
<Gene>Some of these effects include sunburn cell formation, basal and squamous cell cancers, melanoma, cataracts, photoaging of the skin, and immune suppression.</Gene>
<Gene>Amongst these various adverse effects of UV radiation, skin cancer is of the greatest concern.</Gene>

<Gene>Over the years, changes in lifestyle has led to a significant increase in the amount of UV radiation that people receive, and this consequently has led to a surge in the incidence of skin cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>The development of skin cancer is a complex multistage phenomenon involving three distinct stages exemplified by initiation, promotion and progression stages.</Gene>
<Gene>Each of these stages is mediated via alterations in various cellular, biochemical, and molecular changes.</Gene>

<Gene>Initiation, the first step in the carcinogenesis process is essentially an irreversible step in which genetic alterations occur in genes that ultimately leads to DNA modification and fixation of mutation.</Gene>
<Gene>Tumor promotion is the essential process in cancer development involving clonal expansion of initiated cells giving rise to pre-malignant</Gene>
<Gene>and then to malignant lesions, essentially by alterations in signal transduction pathways.</Gene>
<Gene>Tumor progression involves the conversion of pre-malignant and malignant lesions into an invasive and potentially metastatic malignant tumor.</Gene>

<Gene>All these processes for skin cancer development involve stimulation of DNA synthesis, DNA damage and proliferation, inflammation, immunosuppression, epidermal hyperplasia, cell cycle dysregulation, depletion of antioxidant defenses, impairment of signal transduction pathways, induction of cyclooxygenase, increase in prostaglandin synthesis, and induction of ornithine decarboxylase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Photochemoprevention has been appreciated as a viable approach to reduce the occurrence of skin cancer and in recent years, the use of agents, especially botanical antioxidants, present in the common diet and beverages consumed by human population have gained considerable attention as photochemopreventive agents for human use.</Gene>
<Gene>Many such agents have also found a place in skin care products.</Gene>
<Gene>Although this is more common in oriental countries, its popularity is significantly growing in western countries.</Gene>
<Gene>In this article, we have summarized the available information of laboratory studies on UVB-mediated signaling that can be exploited as targets for photochemoprevention.</Gene>

<Gene>We suggest that the use of skin care products supplemented with proven chemopreventive agents in conjunction with the use of sunscreens along with educational efforts may be an effective strategy for reducing UV-induced photodamage and skin cancer in humans.</Gene>
<Gene>The mechanistic basis for the use of such products is discussed.</Gene>
<Gene>Molecular genetic and ocular findings in patients with holt-oram syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>
<Gene>The autosomal dominant Holt-Oram syndrome (HOS) is characterized by upper limb and cardiac septal defects.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations of the TBX5 gene have been identified as the underlying gene defect in HOS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Embryonic expression of TBX5 has been found in the human retina.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first report of ocular findings in two unrelated families with mutations in the TBX5 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS: Six living persons affected with HOS and 10 unaffected family members were subjected to mutation analysis and complete ophthalmological examination, including electrophysiological examinations (EOG and flash ERG).</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>A heterozygous single base-pain substitution in exon 5 (408C --> A) was detected in all affected patients.</Gene>
<Gene>All examined affected patents were ophthalmological asymptomatic with normal EOG.</Gene>
<Gene>A scotopic elongated b-wave latency was found in affected family members who were older than 35 years.</Gene>
<Gene>The ERG was normal in the young patients.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS: Haploinsufficiency of TBX5 alters the dorsal-ventral polarity in developing eye vesicles without amy detected functional loss in human.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Slight ERG abnormalities later in life may be a result of changes induced by the inner ganglion cell layer in the inner nuclear layer.</Gene>
<Gene>Low RET mutation frequency and polymorphism analysis of the RET and EDNRB genes in patients with Hirschsprung disease in Taiwan.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hirschsprung disease (HSCR), or congenital intestinal aganglionosis, is a relatively common disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the nerve plexuses of the lower digestive tract, resulting in intestinal obstruction in neonates.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations in genes of the RET receptor tyrosine kinase and endothelin receptor B (EDNRB)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>signaling pathways have been shown to be associated in HSCR patients.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we collected genomic DNA samples from 55 HSCR patients in central Taiwan and analyzed the coding regions of the RET and EDNRB genes by PCR amplification and DNA sequencing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the 55 patients, an A to G transition was detected in two (identical twin brothers).</Gene>
<Gene>The mutation was at the end of RET exon 19 at codon 1062 (Y1062C), a reported critical site for the signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) in exons 2, 7, 11, 13, and 15 of RET and exon 4 of EDNRB in the HSCR patients or controls were detected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The differences between patients and controls in allele distribution of the five RET polymorphic sites were statistically significant.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The most frequent genotype encompassing exons 2 and 13 SNPs (the polymorphic sites with the highest percentage of heterozygotes) was AA/GG in patients, which was different from the AG/GT in the normal controls.</Gene>
<Gene>Transmission disequilibrium was observed in exons 2, 7, and 13, indicating nonrandom association of the susceptibility alleles with the disease in the patients.</Gene>
<Gene>This study represents the first comprehensive genetic analysis of HSCR disease in Taiwan.</Gene>
<Gene>Superimposing polymorphism: the case of a point mutation within a polymorphic Alu insertion.</Gene>
<Gene>The COL3A1 Alu insertion is a member of the AluY subfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It has been found to be absent in non-human primates and polymorphic in worldwide human populations.</Gene>
<Gene>The integration of the element into the human genome seems to have preceded the initial migration(s) of anatomically modern humans out of the African continent.</Gene>
<Gene>Although the insertion has been detected in populations from all the continents, its highest frequency values are located within sub-Saharan Africa.</Gene>

<Gene>The sequence alignment of the COL3A1 insertion from several African individuals revealed a bi-allelic single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) at the downstream terminus of the element's poly-A tract.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Once discovered, a selective PCR procedure was designed to determine the frequency of both alleles in 19 worldwide populations.</Gene>
<Gene>The A-allele in this binary SNP experiences a clinal increase in the eastward direction from Africa to Southeast Asia and Mongolia, reaching fixation in the two latter regions.</Gene>
<Gene>The T variant, on the other hand, exhibits a westward clinal increase outside of Africa, with its lowest frequency in Asia and achieving fixation in northern Europe.</Gene>
<Gene>The presence of this internal SNP extends the usefulness provided by the polymorphic Alu insertion (PAI).</Gene>

<Gene>It is possible that superimposing polymorphisms like this one found in the COL3A1 locus may accentuate signals from genetic drift events allowing for visualization of recent dispersal patterns.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Burkitt-type acute leukemia in a patient with B-prolymphocytic leukemia: evidence for a common origin.</Gene>
<Gene>Burkitt-type acute leukemia cells were present in the bone marrow of a patient with B-prolymphocytic leukemia diagnosed from peripheral blood cell morphology.</Gene>
<Gene>Immunophenotype analysis confirmed morphological patterns.</Gene>

<Gene>Cytogenetic and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis showed an identical t(8;22)(q24;q21) with MYC locus rearrangement in blood and bone marrow cells, with additional chromosome abnormalities in the bone marrow.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the loss of one copy of the TP53 gene and identical IGH DNA clonal rearrangements were shown with FISH and polymerase chain reaction analysis respectively in the two types of leukemic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data indicated the common origin of the two coexisting leukemias and are the first example of such occurrence in a leukemic patient.</Gene>
<Gene>Haplotypes of variants in the UDP-glucuronosyltransferase1A9 and 1A1 genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVES:</Gene>
<Gene>Nine different functional UGT1A enzymes are generated from a single UGT1A gene by alternative splicing, with each enzyme having a unique exon 1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SN-38, the active metabolite of the anticancer agent irinotecan, is metabolized by both UGT1A1 and UGT1A9.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We aim to characterize the UGT1A9-UGT1A1 haplotypes in Asians and Caucasians and gain insights on their functional consequences.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS: Asian and Caucasian individuals were genotyped for UGT1A1 and UGT1A9 variants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: A higher frequency of the UGT1A9 -118T10 allele was observed in Asians compared to Caucasians, while the -275T>A and -2152C>T variants were relatively uncommon in Caucasians and not found in Asians.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The strongest linkage disequilibrium (LD) was observed between the UGT1A1 -53 and -3156 and between the UGT1A9 -275 and -2152 loci.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lower LD was observed between the -118 UGT1A9 variant and the UGT1A1 variants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Fourteen UGT1A9-UGT1A1 haplotypes were found in Asians, seven of them found to be shared by both populations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Common UGT1A9-UGT1A1 diplotypes were defined, and a difference was observed across the SN-38 glucuronidation rates in Caucasian livers stratified by diplotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>This study for the first time described common UGT1A9-UGT1A1 haplotypes, highlighting important ethnic differences between Asians and Caucasians.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>If the functional effect of these haplotypes can be confirmed, this haplotypic information would be applicable to the correct design of prospective clinical studies of irinotecan, as well as of other drugs primarily metabolized by both UGT1A1 and UGT1A9.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a transcriptionally active hVH-5 pseudogene on 10q22.2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) are important regulators of a vast number of biological functions that affect life and death of eukaryotic cells and are tightly regulated by the concerted action of several phosphatases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among these is the human homologue of vaccinia virus H1 phosphatase gene clone 5 (hVH-5) product, which dephosphorylates and thus inhibits members of the MAPK family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we analyzed hVH-5 transcripts in mammary carcinoma cell lines and discovered a sequence with 88% similarity to hVH-5 transcripts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because this variant of hVH-5 lacked intronic sequences in its genomic structure, we suggest it might be a processed pseudogene of hVH-5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>psihVH-5 transcripts were detected in human peripheral tissues as well as in 11 of 14 breast cancer cell lines.</Gene>

<Gene>In respect to the normal hVH-5 gene, the pseudogene contains several point mutations and a frame shift due to the deletion of 2 bases that would lead to the truncation of the putative psihVH-5 product.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Functional characterization of SLCO1B1 (OATP-C) variants, SLCO1B1*5, SLCO1B1*15 and SLCO1B1*15+C1007G, by using transient expression systems of HeLa and HEK293 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVES:</Gene>
<Gene>SLCO1B1*5 and SLCO1B1*15 have been reported to reduce the clearance of pravastatin in healthy volunteers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, there remains controversy in the effects of SLCO1B1*5 on the activity of OATP1B1 in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the effect of SLCO1B1*15 on the function of OATP1B1 has not been studied using cDNA-expression systems.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Object of the present study was to study the influence of SLCO1B1*5, *15 and *15+C1007G, a novel haplotype found in a patient with pravastatin-induced myopathy, on the functional properties of OATP1B1 by transient expression systems of HEK293 and HeLa cells using endogenous conjugates and statins as substrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Transporting assays for endogenous substrates were performed using tritium labeled estradiol-17beta-D-glucuronide and estrone-3-sulfate.</Gene>
<Gene>Quantitation of pravastatin, atorvastatin, cerivastatin and simvastatin were carried out using HPLC tandem mass spectrometry.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The transporting activities of cells expressing SLCO1B1*5, *15 and *15+C1007G decreased significantly but those of SLCO1B1*1b, *1a+C1007G and *1b+C1007G were not altered for all of the substrates tested except for simvastatin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Kinetic analysis of pravastatin and atorvastatin showed that Km values were not altered but Vmax values decreased significantly in cells expressing SLCO1B1*5, *15 and *15+C1007G. Immunocytochemical study showed that SLCO1B1*5, *15 and *15+C1007G proteins are localized not only at the plasma membrane but also in the intracellular space.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>These findings suggest that 521T>C, existing commonly in SLCO1B1*5, *15 and *15+C1007G, is the key single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) that determines the functional properties of SLCO1B1*5, *15 and *15+C1007G allelic proteins and that decreased activities of these variant proteins are mainly caused by a sorting error produced by this SNP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The effect of exogenous estradiol treatment on the mRNA expression of vascular endothelial growth factor and its receptors in cultured human oviduct mucosal cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>

<Gene>To evaluate the responses of cultured oviduct mucosal cells to exogenous estradiol treatment in regulating the mRNA expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and its receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>The mucosal layer of the ampullary regions of the human oviduct was isolated and cultured with (study groups) or without (control group) the addition of exogenous estradiol in five different concentrations.</Gene>
<Gene>Semiquantitative reverse-transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction was performed on the oviduct mucosal cells before and after the 6-day culture.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>There were no significant differences in the mRNA expression of VEGF and its receptors, both KDR and flt-1, between the five study groups and the control group.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>The mRNA expression of VEGF and its receptors is not altered by exogenous estradiol treatment in cultured oviduct.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This helps to explain the mechanism of temporal regulation of VEGF in human oviduct, which reaches the peak level in the peri-ovulatory stage when both the serum estradiol and gonadotropins concentrations are high.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Luteal phase serum cell-free DNA as a marker of failed pregnancy after assisted reproductive technology.</Gene>
<Gene>Acro-dermato-ungual-lacrimal-tooth (ADULT) syndrome: report of a child with phenotypic overlap with ulnar-mammary syndrome and a new mutation in TP63.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report on a new patient with clinical findings consistent with acro-dermato-ungual-lacrimal-tooth (ADULT) syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>The child had sparse hair, extensive freckling, lacrimal duct stenosis, oligodontia, dystrophic nails, reduced sweating, and bilateral athelia.</Gene>
<Gene>Examination of his hands showed ulnar ray hypoplasia with bilateral fifth finger brachydactyly and camptodactyly.</Gene>
<Gene>He also had surgical repair of an imperforate anus.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutation analysis of TP63 showed a single nucleotide substitution, c.G518A, predicting a novel missense mutation, p.V114M in exon 4.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This is the third mutation to be reported in TP63 in ADULT syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Delineation of the clinical phenotype associated with OPHN1 mutations based on the clinical and neuropsychological evaluation of three families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent reports have demonstrated that mutations in the OPHN1 gene were responsible for a syndromic rather than non-specific mental retardation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Abnormalities of the posterior fossa with cerebellar hypoplasia have been demonstrated in all male patients reported to date.</Gene>

<Gene>We report here a new family with X-linked mental retardation due to mutation in OPHN1 and present unpublished data about two families previously reported, concerning the facial and psychological phenotype of affected males and carrier females.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our study confirms that cerebellar hypoplasia is a hallmark of this syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, affected males display facial similarities that can help the diagnosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Most carrier females have mild mental retardation and subtle facial changes.</Gene>
<Gene>Application of a comprehensive subtelomere array in clinical diagnosis of mental retardation.</Gene>
<Gene>NSD1 analysis for Sotos syndrome: insights and perspectives from the clinical laboratory.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>
<Gene>Sotos syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized primarily by overgrowth, developmental delay, and a characteristic facial gestalt.</Gene>
<Gene>Defects in the NSD1 gene are present in approximately 80% of patients with Sotos syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The goal of this study was to determine the incidence of NSD1 abnormalities in patients referred to a clinical laboratory for testing and to identify clinical criteria that distinguish between patients with and without NSD1 abnormalities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Deletion or mutation analysis of the NSD1 gene was performed on 435 patients referred to our clinical genetics laboratory.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Detailed clinical information was obtained on 86 patients with and without NSD1 abnormalities, and a clinical checklist was developed to help distinguish between these two groups of patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Abnormalities of the NSD1 gene were identified in 55 patients, including 9 deletions and 46 mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, in the clinical laboratory setting, deletions were found in 2% and mutations in 21% of samples analyzed, because not all patients had both tests.</Gene>
<Gene>Thirty-three previously unreported mutations in the NSD1 gene were identified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Clinical features typically associated with Sotos syndrome were not found to be significantly different between individuals with and without NSD1 abnormalities.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The clinical checklist developed included poor feeding, increased body mass index, and enlarged cerebral ventricles, in addition to the typical clinical features of Sotos syndrome, and was able to distinguish between the two groups with 80% sensitivity and 70% specificity.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>The dramatic decrease in the frequency of finding NSD1 abnormalities in the clinical laboratory is likely because of the heterogeneity of the patient population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our experience from a diagnostic laboratory can help guide clinicians in deciding for whom NSD1 genetic analysis is indicated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rarity of IgH translocations in Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Comparatively little is known of the cytogenetics of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (WM).</Gene>
<Gene>This is primarily due to the low proliferation of the clonal B cells, which precludes conventional karyotyping in many cases.</Gene>
<Gene>Translocations involving the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) gene at 14q32 are characteristic of many B-cell lymphomas and myelomas.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Initial reports suggested that the t(9;14) was characteristic of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (the underlying pathological diagnosis in WM), but subsequent studies have failed to confirm the uniqueness of the translocation.</Gene>
<Gene>To clarify this, we examined 69 cases of WM with interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization and failed to demonstrate an IgH translocation in 67 (97%).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that IGH translocations are not a feature of WM, and the implications of this finding are discussed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IL-1 receptor antagonist attenuates MAP kinase/AP-1 activation and MMP1 expression in UVA-irradiated human fibroblasts induced by culture medium from UVB-irradiated human skin keratinocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Solar UV light comprises UVB wavelengths (290-320 nm) and UVA wavelengths (320-400 nm).</Gene>
<Gene>UVB radiation reaches the epidermis and, to a lesser extent, the upper part of the dermis, while UVA radiation penetrates more deeply into human skin.</Gene>
<Gene>Existing studies have demonstrated that UV-irradiated epidermal keratinocytes release cytokines that indirectly promote MMP-1 production in dermal fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we first investigated the effect of IL-1 on MAPK activity, c-Jun and c-Fos mRNA expression, and MMP-1 and MMP-2 production in UVA-irradiated human dermal fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results showed that UVA irradiation dose-dependently increased MMP-1 but not MMP-2 production in human skin fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-1alpha and IL-1beta promoted MMP-1 but not MMP-2 production in UVA-irradiated fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both IL-1alpha and IL-1beta activated MAP kinase, significantly elevating c-Jun and c-Fos mRNA expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We then investigated the indirect effect of UVB-irradiated keratinocyte culture medium on MMP-1 production in UVA-irradiated primary cultured human dermal fibroblasts and the effect of IL-1Ra.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results showed that cell culture medium from UVB-irradiated keratinocytes increased MMP-1 production in UVA-irradiated fibroblasts, and IL-1Ra dose-dependently inhibited MMP-1 production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-1Ra dose-dependently inhibited c-Jun mRNA expression of fibroblasts with no significant effect on c-Fos mRNA expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results demonstrate that UVB-irradiated keratinocytes promoted MMP-1 production in UVA-irradiated fibroblasts in a paracrine manner while IL-1Ra reduced MMP-1 production through inhibiting c-Jun mRNA expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, our data suggest that IL-1 plays an important role in the dermal collagen degradation associated with UV-induced premature aging of the skin and IL-1Ra may be applied for the prevention and treatment of photoaging.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Temporal and parental-specific expression of imprinted genes in a newly derived Chinese human embryonic stem cell line and embryoid bodies.</Gene>

<Gene>Although the study of imprinted genes in human development is very important, little is known about their expression and regulation in the early differentiation of human tissues due to lack of an appropriate model.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, a Chinese human embryonic stem (hES) cell line, SHhES1, was derived and fully characterized.</Gene>

<Gene>Expression profiles of human imprinted genes were determined by Affymetrix Oligo micro-array in undifferentiated SHhES1 cells and SHhES1-derived embryoid bodies (EBs) at day 3, 8, 13 and 18.</Gene>
<Gene>Thirty-two known human imprinted genes were detected in undifferentiated ES cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Significantly, differential expression was found in nine genes at different stages of EB formation.</Gene>

<Gene>Expression profile changes were confirmed by quantitative real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction in SHhES1 cells as well as in another independently derived hES cell line, HUES-7.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, the monoallelic expressions of four imprinted genes were examined in three different passages of undifferentiated ES cells and EBs of both hES cell lines.</Gene>
<Gene>The monoallelic expressions of imprinted genes, H19, PEG10, NDNL1 and KCNQ1 were maintained in both undifferentiated hES cells and derived EBs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>More importantly, with the availability of maternal peripheral blood lymphocyte sample, we demonstrated that the maternal expression of KCNQ1 and the paternal expression of NDNL1 and PEG10 were maintained in SHhES1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data provide the first demonstration that the parental-specific expression of imprinted genes is stable in EBs after extensive differentiation, also indicating that in vitro fertilization protocol does not disrupt the parental monoallelic expression of the imprinted genes examined.</Gene>
<Gene>A comparison of folic acid deficiency-induced genomic instability in lymphocytes of breast cancer patients and normal non-cancer controls from a Chinese population in Yunnan.</Gene>
<Gene>We hypothesized that the genomic response to folate deficiency might be different between breast cancer cases and healthy subjects.</Gene>

<Gene>To test this hypothesis, we performed a comprehensive study on the genotoxic and cytotoxic effects of in vitro folic acid (FA) deficiency on primary human lymphocytes from 19 breast cancer patients and 20 age-matched healthy females from Yunnan, China using the cytokinesis-block micronucleus assay.</Gene>
<Gene>Lymphocytes from the volunteers were cultured in RPMI1640 medium containing 30, 120 or 240 nM FA for 9 days.</Gene>

<Gene>The results showed that 30 nM FA was associated with increased frequencies of micronucleated binucleated cell (MNed BNC), nucleoplasmic bridges (NPB), nuclear buds (BUD), apoptosis (APO) and necrosis (NEC) relative to 120 and 240 nM FA (P<0.001) in lymphocytes of case and control groups in vitro, however there were no significant differences between the 120 and 240 nM FA within each sampling group.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The case group showed significantly higher frequencies of MNed BNC than control at 120 and 240 nM FA (P<0.05-0.001) but not at 30 nM FA (P=0.052).</Gene>
<Gene>NEC was significantly higher in breast cancer group than control at all concentrations of FA (P<0.005).</Gene>

<Gene>FA concentration explained 60, 39, 39, 52 and 71% of the variance of MNed BNC, NPB, BUD, APO and NEC, respectively compared with breast cancer status which only explained 6 and 7% of the variance of MNed BNC and NEC(Two way ANOVA, P<0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Difference of difference analysis showed that breast cancer cases were not abnormally sensitive to the genome-damaging effect of folate deficiency.</Gene>

<Gene>We concluded that (i) increased concentrations of FA abolished the genome-damaging effect of FA deficiency in lymphocytes of both breast cancer patients and controls to a similar extent and (ii) FA concentration is much more important than breast cancer status in determining genomic instability and cell death.</Gene>
<Gene>Evaluating the role of the 620W allele of protein tyrosine phosphatase PTPN22 in Crohn's disease and multiple sclerosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The 620W allele of PTPN22 has been associated with susceptibility to several different forms of chronic inflammatory disease, including Type 1 diabetes (T1D), rheumatoid arthritis (RA), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and autoimmune thyroiditis (AIT).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We set out to explore its possible role in two other inflammatory diseases: multiple sclerosis (MS) and Crohn's disease (CD).</Gene>
<Gene>In our cohort of 496 MS trios from the United Kingdom, we observed reduced transmission of the PTPN22 620W allele.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CD sample consisted of 169 trios as well as 249 cases of CD with their 207 matched control subjects collected in the province of Quebec, Canada; there was also no evidence of association between the PTPN22 620W allele and susceptibility for CD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pooled analyses combining our data with published data assessed a total of 1496 cases of MS and 1019 cases of CD but demonstrated no evidence of association with either disease.</Gene>

<Gene>Given the modest odds ratios of known risk alleles for inflammatory diseases, these analyses do not exclude a role for the PTPN22 allele in susceptibility to CD or MS, but they do suggest that such a putative role would probably be more modest than that reported so far in T1D, RA, SLE, and AIT.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Peroxisomal proliferator activated receptor-gamma deficiency in a Canadian kindred with familial partial lipodystrophy type 3 (FPLD3).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Familial partial lipodystrophy (Dunnigan) type 3 (FPLD3, Mendelian Inheritance in Man [MIM] 604367) results from heterozygous mutations in PPARG encoding peroxisomal proliferator-activated receptor-gamma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both dominant-negative and haploinsufficiency mechanisms have been suggested for this condition.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We present a Canadian FPLD3 kindred with an affected mother who had loss of fat on arms and legs, but no increase in facial, neck, suprascapular or abdominal fat.</Gene>

<Gene>She had profound insulin resistance, diabetes, severe hypertriglyceridemia and relapsing pancreatitis, while her pre-pubescent daughter had normal fat distribution but elevated plasma triglycerides and C-peptide and depressed high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The mother and daughter were each heterozygous for PPARG nonsense mutation Y355X, whose protein product in vitro was transcriptionally inactive with no dominant-negative activity against the wild-type receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition the mutant protein appeared to be markedly unstable.</Gene>

<Gene>CONCLUSION: Taken together with previous studies of human PPARG mutations, these findings suggest that PPAR-gamma deficiency due either to haploinsufficiency or to substantial activity loss due to dominant negative interference of the normal allele product's function can each contribute to the FPLD3 phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The TNFalpha receptor TNFRSF1A and genes encoding the amiloride-sensitive sodium channel ENaC as modulators in cystic fibrosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The CFTR mutations in cystic fibrosis (CF) lead to ion transport anomalities which predispose to chronic infection and inflammation of CF airways as the major determinants for morbidity and mortality in CF.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Discordant clinical phenotypes of siblings with identical CFTR mutations and the large variability of clinical manifestations of patients who are homozygous for the most common mutation F508del suggest that both environment and genes other than CFTR contribute substantially to CF disease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The prime candidates for genetic modifiers in CF are elements of host defence such as the TNFalpha receptor and of ion transport such as the amiloride-sensitive epithelial sodium channel ENaC, both of which are encoded side by side on 12p13 (TNFRSF1A, SCNN1A) and 16p12 (SCNN1B, SCNN1G).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thirty-seven families with F508del-CFTR homozygous siblings exhibiting extreme clinical phenotypes that had been selected from the 467 pairs of the European CF Twin and Sibling Study were genotyped at 12p13 and 16p12 markers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ENaC was identified as a modulator of CF by transmission disequilibrium at SCNN1G and association with CF phenotype intrapair discordance at SCNN1B. Family-based and case-control analyses and sequencing of SCNN1A and TNFRSF1A uncovered an association of the TNFRSF1A intron 1 haplotype with disease severity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Carriers of risk haplotypes were underrepresented suggesting a strong impact of both loci on survival.</Gene>

<Gene>The finding that TNFRSF1A, SCNN1B and SCNN1G are clinically relevant modulators of CF disease supports current concepts that the depletion of airway surface liquid and inadequate host inflammatory responses trigger pulmonary disease in CF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chiari type I malformation in four unrelated patients affected with Fabry disease.</Gene>

<Gene>Fabry disease (FD) is an X-linked inborn error of metabolism resulting from the deficient activity of alpha-galactosidase A which leads to the widespread deposition of glycosphingolipids in lysosomes, and to ischemic complications involving kidneys, heart and brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Among neurological symptoms, strokes and transient ischemic attacks (TIA) have been reported.</Gene>
<Gene>A 30-year-old male patient, with FD, was referred to us for evaluation of a sudden episode of dizziness, with disequilibrium, and diplopia, in agreement with the diagnosis of a TIA.</Gene>
<Gene>Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed no cerebrovascular involvement but revealed the presence of Chiari type I malformation (CMI).</Gene>

<Gene>We subsequently performed head MRI in a cohort of 44 consecutive hemizygous male patients and seven heterozygous females affected with FD, and identified three additional cases (two males and one female) of CMI.</Gene>
<Gene>Whether the association is coincidental or not will need further studies but our data suggest that CMI should be ruled out in all Fabry patients.</Gene>
<Gene>Fibrin sealant promotes migration and proliferation of human articular chondrocytes: possible involvement of thrombin and protease-activated receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Fibrin sealant (FS), a biological adhesive material, has been recently recommended as an adjunct in autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI).</Gene>
<Gene>While FS has been shown to possess osteoinductive potential, little is known about its effects on chondrogenic cells.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we assessed the bioactivity of FS (Tisseel) on the migration and proliferation of human articular chondrocytes in vitro.</Gene>

<Gene>Using a co-culture assay to mimic matrix-induced ACI (MACI), chondrocytes were found to migrate from collagen membranes towards FS within 12 h of culture, with significant migratory activity evident by 24 h.</Gene>

<Gene>In addition, 5-bromo-2'-deoxyuridine (BrdU) incorporation experiments revealed that thrombin, the active component of the tissue glue, stimulated chondrocyte proliferation, with maximal efficacy observed at 48 h post-stimulation (1-10 U/ml).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In an effort to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying these thrombin-induced effects, we examined the expression and activation of protease-activated receptors (PARs), established thrombin receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a combination of RT-PCR and immunohistochemistry, all four PARs were detected in human chondrocytes, with PAR-1 being the major isoform expressed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, thrombin and a PAR-1, but not other PAR-isotype-specific peptide agonists, were found to induce rapid intracellular Ca2+ responses in human chondrocytes in calcium mobilization assays.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these data demonstrate that FS supports both the migration and proliferation of human chondrocytes.</Gene>
<Gene>We propose that these effects are mediated, at least in part, via thrombin-induced PAR-1 signalling in human chondrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>WISP-2 expression in human salivary gland tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study was designed to disclose detailed genetic mechanisms in salivary gland tumors (SGTs) for development of novel independent marker.</Gene>
<Gene>We constructed an in-house cDNA microarray carrying 2,201 cDNA clones derived from SGT and oral squamous cell carcinoma cDNA libraries.</Gene>
<Gene>Four cell lines that originated from the SGT-derived cell lines were analyzed using this microarray system.</Gene>

<Gene>The genes identified by our microarray system were further analyzed at the mRNA or protein expression level in other types of human cancer cell lines and clinical samples (ten normal salivary glands [NSGs], eleven pleomorphic adenomas, ten adenoid cystic carcinomas and three adenocarcinomas).</Gene>
<Gene>Two up-regulated genes and six down-regulated genes were identified in common when compared with the control RNA.</Gene>
<Gene>Of the up-regulated genes, WISP-2, which plays an important role in breast carcinogenesis, was selected for further analyses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found a higher expression of the WISP-2 gene in the SGT-derived cell lines compared with other types of human cancer cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, WISP-2 mRNA and protein expression levels in NSGs were significantly higher than those in SGTs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that WISP-2 could be a reliable independent marker and that down-regulation or loss of the WISP-2 gene may be associated with the development of SGTs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Evaluation of RGS4 as a candidate gene for schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Several studies have suggested that the regulator of G-protein signaling 4 (RGS4) may be a positional and functional candidate gene for schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Three single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) located at the promoter region (SNP4 and SNP7) and the intron 1 (SNP18) of RGS4 have been verified in different ethnic groups.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Positive results have been reported in these SNPs with different numbers of SNP combinatory haplotypes.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, these three SNP markers were genotyped in 218 schizophrenia pedigrees of Taiwan (864 individuals) for association analysis.</Gene>

<Gene>Among these three SNPs, neither SNP4, SNP7, SNP18 has shown significant association with schizophrenia in single locus association analysis, nor any compositions of the three SNP haplotypes has shown significantly associations with the DSM-IV diagnosed schizophrenia.</Gene>
<Gene>Our results fail to support the RGS4 as a candidate gene for schizophrenia when evaluated from these three SNP markers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Distinct patterns of germ-line deletions in MLH1 and MSH2: the implication of Alu repetitive element in the genetic etiology of Lynch syndrome (HNPCC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A relatively high frequency of germ-line genomic rearrangements in MLH1 and MSH2 has been reported among Lynch Syndrome (HNPCC) patients from different ethnic populations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate the underlying molecular mechanisms, we characterized the DNA breakpoints of 11 germ-line deletions, six for MLH1 and five for MSH2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Distinct deletion patterns were found for the two genes.</Gene>
<Gene>The five cases of MSH2 deletions result exclusively from intragenic unequal recombination mediated by repetitive Alu sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, five out of the six MLH1 deletions are due to recombinations involving sequences of no significant homology (P=0.015).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A detailed analysis of the DNA breakpoints in the two genes, previously characterized by other groups, validated the observation that Alu-mediated unequal recombination is the main type of deletion in MSH2 (n=34), but not in MLH1 (n=21) (P<0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Plotting the distribution of known DNA breakpoints among the introns of the two genes showed that, the highest breakpoint density is co-localized with the highest Alu density.</Gene>
<Gene>Our study suggests that Alu is a promoting factor for the genomic recombinations in both MLH1 and MSH2, and the local Alu density may be involved in shaping the deletion pattern.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gene therapy for cystic fibrosis airway disease- is clinical success imminent?</Gene>

<Gene>Cystic fibrosis (CF) was one of the first inherited disorders for which gene therapy was seriously considered as a realistic option for treatment, and as such, it has long provided a paradigm for gene therapy of inherited diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>However, despite the cloning of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene in 1989, over 15 years later a practical gene therapy for CF has not eventuated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There are a number of reasons for this, and analysis of the specific issues that have delayed the successful development of gene therapy for CF also provides general insights into the practical complexities involved in the development of gene therapy for inherited disorders.</Gene>

<Gene>The issues which have prevented the application of gene therapy for CF to date include the lack of suitable gene delivery technologies, the complexities of the interactions between the host and vector, the biology of the lung airways, and the nature of the pathology found in individuals with CF.</Gene>

<Gene>We will discuss the history of CF gene therapy with specific reference to these and other issues that pre-occupy the field at present: namely, the question of what vectors appear to be suitable for airway gene delivery in CF, what cells must be targeted, how airway epithelium defences can be overcome or eluded to allow efficient gene delivery, how to ensure safe and long-term transgene expression and the need to identify relevant surrogate success measures that can be used to assess the outcome of gene therapy in CF patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations responsible for Larsen syndrome cluster in the FLNB protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: A gene for Larsen syndrome was recently described, and mutations were reported in five cases.</Gene>
<Gene>OBJECTIVE:</Gene>

<Gene>To test whether mutations in this gene, FLNB, could explain the disease in our independent collection of sporadic and dominant Larsen syndrome cases; and to test whether mutations occurred in a non-random pattern.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Missense mutations were found in each of five cases.</Gene>
<Gene>Four of the five were new; one was reported in a sporadic case in the original Larsen syndrome study of five cases.</Gene>
<Gene>All mutations from the two studies were compiled.</Gene>
<Gene>Clustered mutations were observed within three filamin B protein domains: the calponin homology 2 domain, repeat 14, and repeat 15.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This suggested that as few as five (of the total of 46) coding exons of FLNB could be screened to detect Larsen syndrome mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Four of these exons were screened in a sixth (sporadic) case and a previously reported G1691S substitution mutation detected.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations in FLNB may be responsible for all cases of Larsen syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>They appear to occur in specific functional domains of the filamin B protein.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This should simplify diagnostic screening of the FLNB gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Analyses in larger patient series are warranted to quantify this.</Gene>
<Gene>The study confirmed the extreme variability in clinical presentation and the presence of unaffected carriers.</Gene>
<Gene>A molecular screen would be valuable for diagnosis and genetic counselling.</Gene>
<Gene>Array-based comparative genomic hybridization facilitates identification of breakpoints of a novel der(1)t(1;18)(p36.3;q23)dn in a child presenting with mental retardation.</Gene>
<Gene>Clinical and molecular characterization of individuals with 18p deletion: a genotype-phenotype correlation.</Gene>
<Gene>Split-hand/split-foot malformation 3 (SHFM3) at 10q24, development of rapid diagnostic methods and gene expression from the region.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Split-hand/split-foot malformation (SHFM, also called ectrodactyly) is a clinically variable and genetically heterogeneous group of limb malformations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Several SHFM loci have been mapped, including SHFM1 (7q21), SHFM2 (Xq26), SHFM3 (10q24), SHFM4 (3q27) and SHFM5 (2q31).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To date, mutations in a gene (TP63) have only been identified for SHFM4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SHFM3 has been shown by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis to be caused by an approximately 500 kb DNA rearrangement at 10q24.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This region contains a number of candidate genes for SHFM3, though which gene(s) is (are) involved in the pathogenesis of SHFM3 is not known.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our aim in this study was to improve the diagnosis of SHFM3, and to begin to understand which genes are involved in SHFM3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show, using two different techniques, FISH and quantitative PCR that SHFM3 is caused by a minimal 325 kb duplication containing only two genes (BTRC and POLL).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The data presented provide improved methods for diagnosis and begin to elucidate the pathogenic mechanism of SHFM3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression analysis of 13 candidate genes within and flanking the duplicated region shows that BTRC (present in three copies) and SUFU (present in two copies) are overexpressed in SHFM3 patients compared to controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that SHFM3 may be caused by overexpression of BTRC and SUFU, both of which are involved in beta-catenin signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of the nuclear localization motif in the ETV6 (TEL) protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ETV6, or Translocation-Ets-Leukemia (TEL), is an ETS family transcriptional repressor that is essential for establishing hematopoiesis in neonatal bone marrow, and is frequently a target of chromosomal translocations in human cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ETV6 is predominantly a nuclear phosphoprotein that represses transcription by binding directly to the promoters of target genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The nuclear localization mechanism of ETV6, however, is not well understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this report, we provide evidence that a nuclear localization signal (NLS) exists in the C-terminal region of ETV6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ETV6 proteins with mutations outside of amino acids 332-452 localize to the nucleus, whereas proteins with mutations within amino acids 332-452 remain in the cytoplasm.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, when a fragment of ETV6 comprised of amino acids 332-452 was fused to cytoplasmic beta-galactosidase protein, the fusion protein was able to enter the nucleus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results strongly indicate that residues 332-452 mediate nuclear localization of ETV6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>McArdle disease: the mutation spectrum of PYGM in a large Italian cohort.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Deficiency of the muscle isozyme of glycogen phosphorylase is causative of McArdle disease or Glycogen storage disease type V (GSD-V), the most common autosomal recessive disorder of glycogen metabolism.</Gene>
<Gene>The typical clinical presentation is characterized by exercise intolerance with cramps, and recurrent myoglobinuria.</Gene>
<Gene>To date, 46 mutations in the PYGM gene have been detected in GSD-V patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report the mutational spectrum in 68 Italian patients.</Gene>
<Gene>We identified 30 different mutations in the PYGM gene, including 19 mutations that have not been reported previously.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The novel mutations include: eight missense mutations (c.475G>A, p.G159R; c.689C>G, p.P230R; c.1094C>T, p.A365E; c.1151C>A, p.A384D; c.1182C>T, p.R428C; c.1471C>T, p.R491C;</Gene>

<Gene>c.2444A>C, p.D815A; c.2477G>C, p.W826S), two nonsense mutations (c.1475G>A, p.W492X; c.1627A>T, p.K543X), five splice site mutations (c.855 +1G>C; c.1092 +1G>A; c. 1093-1G>T; c.1239 +1G>A; c.2380 +1G>A), and four deletions (c.715_717delGTC, p.V239del; c.304delA, p.N102DfsX4; c.1970_2177del, p.V657_G726; c.2113_2114delGG, p.G705RfsX16).</Gene>

<Gene>Whereas we confirmed lack of direct correlation between the clinical phenotype and the genotype, we also found that the so-called 'common mutation' (p.R50X) accounted for about 43% of alleles in our cohort and that no population-related mutations are clearly identified in Italian patients.</Gene>
<Gene>A polymorphism of C-to-T substitution at -31 IL1B is associated with the risk of advanced gastric adenocarcinoma in a Japanese population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Proinflammatory cytokine gene polymorphisms have been demonstrated to associate with gastric cancer risk, of which IL1B-31T/C and -511C/T changes have been well investigated due to the possibility that they may alter the IL1B transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The signal transduction target upon interleukin 1 beta (IL1beta) stimulation, the nuclear factor of kappa B (NFkappaB) activation, supports cancer development, signal transduction in which is mediated by FS-7 cell-associated cell surface antigen (FAS) signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Based on recent papers describing the prognostic roles of the polymorphisms and the NFkappaB functions on cancer development, we sought to determine if Japanese gastric cancer patients were affected by the IL1B -31/-511 and FAS-670 polymorphisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A case-control study was conducted on incident gastric adenocarcinoma patients (n=271) and age-gender frequency-matched control subjects (n=271).</Gene>

<Gene>We observed strong linkage disequilibrium between the T allele at -511 and the C allele at -31 and between the C allele at -511 and the T allele at -31 in IL1B in both the cases and controls (R (2)=0.94).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Neither IL1B-31, -511 nor FAS-670 polymorphisms showed significantly different risks of gastric adenocarcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Though FAS-670 polymorphisms did not show any significant difference, the proportion of subjects with IL1B-31TT (or IL1B-511CC) increased according to stage (trend P=0.019).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In particular, subjects with stage IV had a two times higher probability of having either IL1B-31TT (or IL1B-511CC) genotype compared with stage I subjects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These observations suggest that IL1B-31TT and IL1B-511CC are associated with disease progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A two base pair deletion in the PQBP1 gene is associated with microphthalmia, microcephaly, and mental retardation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>X-linked mental retardation has been traditionally divided into syndromic (S-XLMR) and non-syndromic forms (NS-XLMR), although the borderlines between these phenotypes begin to vanish and mutations in a single gene, for example PQBP1, can cause S-XLMR as well as NS-XLMR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we report two maternal cousins with an apparently X-linked phenotype of mental retardation (MR), microphthalmia, choroid coloboma, microcephaly, renal hypoplasia, and spastic paraplegia.</Gene>
<Gene>By multipoint linkage analysis with markers spanning the entire X-chromosome we mapped the disease locus to a 28-Mb interval between Xp11.4 and Xq12, including the BCOR gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A missense mutation in BCOR was described in a family with Lenz microphthalmia syndrome, a phenotype showing substantial overlapping features with that described in the two cousins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, no mutation in the BCOR gene was found in both patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Subsequent mutation analysis of PQBP1, located within the delineated linkage interval in Xp11.23, revealed a 2-bp deletion, c.461_462delAG, that cosegregated with the disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, the same mutation is associated with the Hamel cerebropalatocardiac syndrome, another form of S-XLMR.</Gene>
<Gene>Haplotype analysis suggests a germline mosaicism of the 2-bp deletion in the maternal grandmother of both affected individuals.</Gene>

<Gene>In summary, our findings demonstrate for the first time that mutations in PQBP1 are associated with an S-XLMR phenotype including microphthalmia, thereby further extending the clinical spectrum of phenotypes associated with PQBP1 mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A case surviving for over a year of renal tubular dysgenesis with compound heterozygous angiotensinogen gene mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Renal tubular dysgenesis (RTD) is a developmental abnormality of the renal proximal tubules found in patients with Potter syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>We report a female newborn with RTD who has survived for more than 18 months.</Gene>
<Gene>Infusions of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) in the early neonatal period were effective in raising and maintaining her blood pressure.</Gene>
<Gene>Peritoneal dialysis was required until the appearance of spontaneous urination at 29 days after birth.</Gene>
<Gene>Histopathological examinations of the kidney revealed dilated renal tubular lumina and foamy columnar epithelial cells in the renal tubules.</Gene>

<Gene>Endocrinological studies showed a discrepancy between low plasma renin activity (<0.1 ng/ml/hr) and high active renin concentration (135,000 pg/ml), suggesting an aberration in the renin substrate, angiotensinogen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Direct sequencing analysis revealed two novel mutations in the coding region of the angiotensinogen gene (AGT): a nonsense mutation in exon 2 (c.604C > T) and a frameshift deletion at nucleotide 1290 in exon 5 (c.1290delT).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The mutations were in the compound heterozygous state, because each parent had each mutation.</Gene>
<Gene>These findings suggest that angiotensinogen deficiency is one of the causes of RTD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A treatment of the condition with FFP may help to promote long survival.</Gene>
<Gene>Functional variants in the promoter region of Chitinase 3-like 1 (CHI3L1) and susceptibility to schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The chitinase 3-like 1 gene (CHI3L1) is abnormally expressed in the hippocampus of subjects with schizophrenia and may be involved in the cellular response to various environmental events that are reported to increase the risk of schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we provide evidence that the functional variants at the CHI3L1 locus influence the genetic risk of schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>First, using case-control and transmission/disequilibrium-test (TDT) methodologies, we detected a significant association between schizophrenia and haplotypes within the promoter region of CHI3L1 in two independent cohorts of Chinese individuals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Second, the at-risk CCC haplotype (P=.00058 and .0018 in case-control and TDT studies, respectively) revealed lower transcriptional activity (P=2.2 x 10(-7)) and was associated with lower expression (P=3.1 x 10(-5)) compared with neutral and protective haplotypes.</Gene>

<Gene>Third, we found that an allele of SNP4 (rs4950928), the tagging SNP of CCC, impaired the MYC/MAX-regulated transcriptional activation of CHI3L1 by altering the transcriptional-factor consensus sequences, and this may be responsible for the decreased expression of the CCC haplotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the protective TTG haplotype was associated with a high level of CHI3L1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings identify CHI3L1 as a potential schizophrenia-susceptibility gene and suggest that the genes involved in the biological response to adverse environmental conditions are likely to play roles in the predisposition to schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Orofacial cleft risk is increased with maternal smoking and specific detoxification-gene variants.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Maternal smoking is a recognized risk factor for orofacial clefts.</Gene>
<Gene>Maternal or fetal pharmacogenetic variants are plausible modulators of this risk.</Gene>
<Gene>In this work, we studied 5,427 DNA samples, including 1,244 from subjects in Denmark and Iowa with facial clefting and 4,183 from parents, siblings, or unrelated population controls.</Gene>
<Gene>We examined 25 single-nucleotide polymorphisms in 16 genes in pathways for detoxification of components of cigarette smoke, to look for evidence of gene-environment interactions.</Gene>
<Gene>For genes identified as related to oral clefting, we studied gene-expression profiles in fetal development in the relevant tissues and time intervals.</Gene>
<Gene>Maternal smoking was a significant risk factor for clefting and showed dosage effects, in both the Danish and Iowan data.</Gene>
<Gene>Suggestive effects of variants in the fetal NAT2 and CYP1A1 genes were observed in both the Iowan and the Danish participants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In an expanded case set, NAT2 continued to show significant overtransmission of an allele to the fetus, with a final P value of .00003.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There was an interaction between maternal smoking and fetal inheritance of a GSTT1-null deletion, seen in both the Danish (P=.03) and Iowan (P=.002) studies, with a Fisher's combined P value of <.001, which remained significant after correction for multiple comparisons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gene-expression analysis demonstrated expression of GSTT1 in human embryonic craniofacial tissues during the relevant developmental interval.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study benefited from two large samples, involving independent populations, that provided substantial power and a framework for future studies that could identify a susceptible population for preventive health care.</Gene>
<Gene>Families with the risk allele of DISC1 reveal a link between schizophrenia and another component of the same molecular pathway, NDE1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously reported a robust association between an allelic haplotype of 'Disrupted in Schizophrenia 1' (DISC1) and schizophrenia in a nationwide collection of Finnish schizophrenia families.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This specific DISC1 allele was later identified to associate with visual working memory, selectively in males.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DISC1 association to schizophrenia has since been replicated in multiple independent study samples from different populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we conditioned our sample of Finnish families for the presence of the Finnish tentative risk allele for DISC1 and re-analyzed our genome-wide scan data of 443 markers on the basis of this stratification.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two additional loci displayed an evidence of linkage (LOD > 3) and included a locus on 16p13, proximal to the gene encoding NDE1, which has been shown to biologically interact with DISC1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although none of the observed linkages remained significant after multiple test correction through simulation, further analysis of NDE1 revealed an association between a tag-haplotype and schizophrenia (P = 0.00046) specific to females, which proved to be significant (P = 0.011) after multiple test correction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our finding would support the concept that initial gene findings in multifactorial diseases will assist in the identification of other components of complex genetic etiology.</Gene>
<Gene>Notably, this and other converging lines of evidence underline the importance of DISC1-related functional pathways in the etiology of schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Townes-Brocks syndrome: twenty novel SALL1 mutations in sporadic and familial cases and refinement of the SALL1 hot spot region.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Townes-Brocks syndrome (TBS) is an autosomal dominant malformation syndrome characterized by renal, anal, ear, and thumb anomalies caused by SALL1 mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To date, 36 SALL1 mutations have been described in TBS patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All but three of those, namely p.R276X, p.S372X, and c.1404dupG, have been found only in single families thereby preventing phenotype-genotype correlations.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we present 20 novel mutations (12 short deletions, five short duplications, three nonsense mutations) in 20 unrelated families.</Gene>
<Gene>We delineate the phenotypes and report previously unknown ocular manifestations, i.e. congenital cataracts with unilateral microphthalmia.</Gene>

<Gene>We show that 46 out of the now 56 SALL1 mutations are located between the coding regions for the glutamine-rich domain mediating SALL protein interactions and 65 bp 3' of the coding region for the first double zinc finger domain, narrowing the SALL1 mutational hotspot region to a stretch of 802 bp within exon 2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of note, only two SALL1 mutations would result in truncated proteins without the glutamine-rich domain, one of which is reported here.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The latter is associated with anal, ear, hand, and renal manifestations, indicating that the glutamine-rich domain is not required for typical TBS.</Gene>
<Gene>A 6Mb deletion in band 2q22 due to a complex chromosome rearrangement associated with severe psychomotor retardation, microcephaly and distinctive dysmorphic facial features.</Gene>

<Gene>High-resolution analyses of complex chromosome rearrangements (CCR) have demonstrated in individuals with abnormal phenotypes that not all seemingly balanced CCRs based on G-banding are completely balanced at breakpoint level.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we report on an apparently balanced de novo CCR involving chromosomes 2, 3 and 5 present in a 6-month-old girl.</Gene>
<Gene>She was referred for genetic evaluation because of severe psychomotor retardation, distinctive dysmorphic features and microcephaly.</Gene>
<Gene>A 1Mb resolution array-CGH analysis of DNA from the patient revealed a deletion of about 6Mb for chromosome 2.</Gene>

<Gene>FISH analysis showed that the deletion interval found in band 2q22 mapped at the translocation breakpoint, and that the ZFHX1B gene, which is known to be involved in the Mowat-Wilson syndrome, is located within the deletion interval.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To our knowledge this is the first case of a complex chromosomal rearrangement associated with Mowat-Wilson syndrome.</Gene>

<Gene>Our data illustrate the important role for high-resolution investigation of apparently balanced chromosome rearrangements in patients with unexplained psychomotor retardation and/or other clinical features, and should contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms involved in chromosome rearrangement.</Gene>
<Gene>Overexpression of DNA polymerase beta results in an increased rate of frameshift mutations during base excision repair.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DNA polymerase beta (Pol beta) is important for the base excision repair (BER) pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of Pol beta is frequently found in cancer cells and is thought to be associated with tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we examined BER fidelity in extracts derived from a human lymphoblastoid cell line that over expresses Pol beta compared to normal control cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using an in vitro mutagenesis assay, we found an increased rate of frameshift mutations arising during DNA repair in whole-cell extracts derived from the Pol beta-overexpressing cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrate that the addition of excess Pol beta to a control cell extract enhances the mutagenic potential of the extract.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, using cell extracts and purified Pol beta, we demonstrate that the mechanism of frameshift formation involves slippage of Pol beta during the one-nucleotide gap-filling step of BER and that this slippage is fixed by strand-displacement synthesis stimulated by an excess of Pol beta.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Polymorphic Alu insertions and the genetic structure of Iberian Basques.</Gene>
<Gene>Eight Alu sequences (ACE, TPA25, PV92, APO, FXIIIB, D1, A25 and B65) were analyzed in two samples from Navarre and Guipuzcoa provinces (Basque Country, Spain).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Alu data for other European, Caucasus and North African populations were compiled from the literature for comparison purposes to assess the genetic relationships of the Basques in a broader geographic context.</Gene>
<Gene>Results of both MDS plot and AMOVA revealed spatial heterogeneity among these three population clusters clearly defined by geography.</Gene>
<Gene>On the contrary, no substantial genetic heterogeneity was found between the Basque samples, or between Basques and other Europeans (excluding Caucasus populations).</Gene>

<Gene>Moreover, the genetic information obtained from Alu data conflicts with hypotheses linking the origin of Basques with populations from North Africa (Berbers) or from the Caucasus region (Georgia).</Gene>

<Gene>In order to explain the reduced genetic heterogeneity detected by Alu insertions among Basque subpopulations, values of the Wright's F(ST )statistic were estimated for both Alu markers and a set of short tandem repeats (STRs) in terms of two geographical scales: (1) the Basque Country, (2) Europe (including Basques).</Gene>
<Gene>In the Basque area, estimates of Wahlund's effect for both genetic markers showed no statistical difference between Basque subpopulations.</Gene>
<Gene>However, when this analysis was performed on a European scale, F(ST) values were significantly higher for Alu insertions than for STR alleles.</Gene>
