<Gene>From these results, we suggest that the spatial heterogeneity of the Basque gene pool identified in previous polymorphism studies is relatively recent and probably caused by a differential process of genetic admixture with non-Basque neighboring populations modulated by the effect of a linguistic barrier to random mating.</Gene>
<Gene>Genotype/phenotype correlation in 325 individuals referred for a diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis complex in the United States.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tuberous sclerosis complex is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder marked by hamartoma growth in multiple organ systems.</Gene>
<Gene>We performed mutational analyses on 325 individuals with definite tuberous sclerosis complex diagnostic status.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We identified mutations in 72% (199/257) of de novo and 77% (53/68) of familial cases, with 17% of mutations in the TSC1 gene and 50% in the TSC2 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There were 4% unclassified variants and 29% with no mutation identified.</Gene>

<Gene>Genotype/phenotype analyses of all observed tuberous sclerosis complex findings in probands were performed, including several clinical features not analyzed in two previous large studies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We showed that patients with TSC2 mutations have significantly more hypomelanotic macules and learning disability in contrast to those with TSC1 mutations, findings not noted in previous studies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also observed results consistent with two similar studies suggesting that individuals with mutations in TSC2 have more severe symptoms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>On performing meta-analyses of our data and the other two largest studies in the literature, we found significant correlations for several features that individual studies did not have sufficient power to conclude.</Gene>
<Gene>Male patients showed more frequent neurologic and eye symptoms, renal cysts, and ungual fibromas.</Gene>
<Gene>Correlating genotypes with phenotypes should facilitate the disease management of tuberous sclerosis complex.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Disruption of a synaptotagmin (SYT14) associated with neurodevelopmental abnormalities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report cytogenetic and molecular studies of a de novo, apparently balanced t(1;3)(q32.1;q25.1) identified in a 12-year-old female (designated DGAP128) with cerebral atrophy, macrocephaly seizures, and developmental delay.</Gene>
<Gene>A combination of fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and Southern blot analysis demonstrated disruption of a synaptotagmin gene (SYT14) at the 1q32 breakpoint.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of SYT14 in human brain was confirmed using Northern analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Because members of the synaptotagmin family of proteins function as sensors that link changes in calcium levels with a variety of biological processes, including neurotransmission and hormone-responsiveness, SYT14 is an intriguing candidate gene for the abnormal development in this child.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first known constitutional rearrangement of SYT14, and further systematic genetic analysis and clinical studies of DGAP128 may offer unique insights into the role of SYT14 in neurodevelopment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interferon regulatory factor 6 (IRF6) and fibroblast growth factor receptor 1 (FGFR1) contribute to human tooth agenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phenotypic characteristics expressed in syndromes give clues to the factors involved in the cause of isolated forms of the same defects.</Gene>
<Gene>We investigated two genes responsible for craniofacial syndromes, FGFR1 and IRF6, in a collection of families with isolated tooth agenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cheek swab samples were obtained for DNA analysis from 116 case/parent trios.</Gene>
<Gene>Probands had at least one developmentally missing tooth, excluding third molars.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, we studied 89 cases and 50 controls from Ohio to replicate any positive findings.</Gene>
<Gene>Genotyping was performed by kinetic polymerase chain-reaction or TaqMan assays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Linkage disequilibrium analysis and transmission distortion of the marker alleles were performed.</Gene>

<Gene>The same variants in the IRF6 gene that are associated with isolated orofacial clefts are also associated with human tooth agenesis (rs861019, P = 0.058; rs17015215-V274I, P = 0.0006; rs7802, P = 0.004).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in IRF6 cause Van der Woude and popliteal pterygium syndromes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The craniofacial phenotypic characteristics of these syndromes include oral clefts and preferential tooth agenesis of incisors and premolars, besides pits on the lower lips.</Gene>
<Gene>Also it appears that preferential premolar agenesis is associated with FGFR1 (P = 0.014) and IRF6 (P = 0.002) markers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There were statistically significant data suggesting that IRF6 interacts not only with MSX1 (P = 0.001), but also with TGFA (P = 0.03).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Over-expression of BMP4 and BMP5 in a child with axial skeletal malformations and heterotopic ossification: a new syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are a highly conserved class of signaling molecules that induce ectopic cartilage and bone formation in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dysregulated expression of bone morphogenetic protein 4 (BMP4) is found in the cells of patients who have fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOP), a genetic disorder of axial and appendicular skeletal malformation and progressive heterotopic ossification.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of function mutations in the bone morphogenetic protein 5 (bmp5) gene leading to under-expression of BMP5 cause the murine short ear syndrome, characterized by small malformed ears and a broad range of axial skeletal malformations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found features reminiscent of both the short ear mouse and FOP in a child with malformed external ears, multiple malformations of the axial skeleton, and progressive heterotopic ossification in the neck and back.</Gene>
<Gene>We examined BMP mRNA expression in transformed lymphocytes by semi-quantitative RT-PCR and protein expression by ELISA assays and immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
<Gene>Elevated levels of BMP4 and BMP5 mRNA and protein were detected in the patient's cells while levels of BMP2 mRNA were unchanged.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that dysregulated expression of BMP4 and BMP5 genes is associated with an array of human axial skeletal abnormalities similar to the short ear mouse and FOP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cytogenetic and molecular characterization of A2BP1/FOX1 as a candidate gene for autism.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cytogenetic imbalances are increasingly being realized as causes of autism.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we report a de novo translocation between the short arms of chromosomes 15 and 16 in a female with autism, epilepsy, and global developmental delay.</Gene>

<Gene>FISH analysis identified a cryptic deletion of approximately 160 kb at the boundary of the first exon and first intron of the 1.7 Mb ataxin-2 binding protein-1 (A2BP1) gene, also called FOX1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Quantitative real time PCR (Q-PCR) analysis verified a deletion of exon 1 in the 5' promoter region of the A2BP1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR) showed reduced mRNA expression in the individual's lymphocytes, demonstrating the functional consequence of the deletion.</Gene>
<Gene>A2BP1 codes for a brain-expressed RNA binding or splicing factor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Because of emerging evidence in the role of RNA processing and gene regulation in pervasive developmental disorders, we performed further screening of A2BP1 in additional individuals with autism from the Autism Genetics Resource Exchange (AGRE) collection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Twenty-seven SNPs were genotyped across A2BP1 in 206 parent-child trios and two regions showed association at P < or = 0.008 level.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>No additional deletions or clear mutations were identified in 88 probands by re-sequencing of all exons and surrounding intronic regions or quantitative PCR (Q-PCR) of exon 1.</Gene>

<Gene>Although only nominal association was observed, and no obvious causal mutations were identified, these results suggest that A2BP1 may affect susceptibility or cause autism in a subset of patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further investigations in a larger sample may provide additional information regarding the involvement of this gene in the autistic phenotype.</Gene>
<Gene>The IRF5 polymorphism in type 1 diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The interferon regulatory factor 5 gene (IRF5) has been shown to play a crucial role in harmful immune responses by induction of proinflammatory cytokines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functional genetic variants associated with increased IRF5 expression of specific isoforms are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and it is possible that they may also predispose to other autoimmune disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We tested the association of two IRF5 SNPs, correlated with IRF5 expression and SLE risk, in 947 nuclear family trios type 1 diabetes (T1D) using the transmission disequilibrium test.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results suggest that the functional IRF5 variations do not confer an obvious risk for T1D.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Single nucleotide polymorphisms of cytokine genes in the healthy Slovak population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cytokines are molecules that control and modulate the activities of numerous target cells via binding to specific receptors.</Gene>
<Gene>The observed differences in the cytokine production among individuals can be, at least partially, explained by gene polymorphisms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Several cytokine gene polymorphisms have been identified to play a role in susceptibility to various diseases, including autoimmune, infectious, allergic or cardiovascular diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of the current study was to determine allele and genotype frequencies of 22 polymorphisms in 13 cytokine genes in the healthy Slovak population and to compare them with data available from six populations from Central and Southern Europe.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A polymerase chain reaction with sequence-specific primers was used to genotype polymorphisms within genes encoding IL-1alpha, IL-1beta, IL-1R, IL-1RA, IL-4Ralpha, IL-12, IFN-gamma, TGF-beta, TNF-alpha, IL-2, IL-4, IL-6 and IL-10 in a sample of 140 unrelated Slovak subjects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The allelic distribution of all polymorphisms in the Slovak population was very close to that in the geographically and historically closest populations in Central Europe--the Czech and the Polish.</Gene>
<Gene>However, several differences were found between the Slovak and four populations from Southern Europe.</Gene>
<Gene>The obtained data represent a basis for further studies on association of cytokine gene polymorphisms with some diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identifying haplotype block structure using an ancestor-derived model.</Gene>
<Gene>Recently, haplotype-based association studies have become popular for detecting disease-related or drug-response-associated genes.</Gene>
<Gene>In these studies, it has been gradually recognized that a haplotype block structure is important.</Gene>
<Gene>A rational and automatic method for identifying the haplotype block structure from SNP data has been desired.</Gene>
<Gene>We have developed a new method using an ancestor-derived model and the minimum description length principle.</Gene>
<Gene>The proposed method was applied to real data on the TAP2 gene in which a recombination hotspot was previously reported in human sperm data.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The proposed method could identify an appropriate haplotype block structure, while existing methods failed.</Gene>
<Gene>The performance of the proposed method was also investigated in a simulation study.</Gene>
<Gene>The proposed method presented a better performance in real data analysis and the simulation study than existing methods.</Gene>
<Gene>The proposed method was powerful from the viewpoint of hotspot sensitivity and was robust to mutation except at the edge of a sequence.</Gene>
<Gene>A microduplication of CBP in a patient with mental retardation and a congenital heart defect.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome is a well-characterized genetic syndrome caused by haploinsufficiency of CBP in a majority of individuals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In 10% of cases a microdeletion in 16p13.3 affecting CBP is detected.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report on a patient with a de novo 345-480 kb micro-duplication the region, encompassing only CBP and TRAP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This boy presented with various minor physical anomalies, moderate mental retardation, and an atrial septal defect, but none of the other typical characteristics of the Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, such as the broad thumbs and first toes or facial characteristics.</Gene>
<Gene>This finding implicates CBP as one of the causative genes for the trisomy 16p13 syndrome, and indicates this is a contiguous gene syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma showing t(2;6)(q31;p21.3) as a sole cytogenetic abnormality.</Gene>
<Gene>Identities, frequencies and origins of TMC1 mutations causing DFNB7/B11 deafness in Pakistan.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Non-syndromic deafness is genetically heterogeneous.</Gene>

<Gene>We previously reported that mutations of transmembrane channel-like gene 1 (TMC1) cause non-syndromic recessive deafness at the DFNB7/B11 locus on chromosome 9q13-q21 in nine Pakistani families.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The goal of this study was to define the identities, origins and frequencies of TMC1 mutations in an expanded cohort of 557 large Pakistani families segregating recessive deafness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We screened affected family members for homozygosity at short-tandem repeats flanking known autosomal recessive (DFNB) deafness loci, followed by TMC1 sequence analysis in families segregating deafness linked to DFNB7/B11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified 10 new families segregating DFNB7/B11 deafness and TMC1 mutations, including three novel alleles.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overall, 9 different TMC1 mutations account for deafness in 19 (3.4%) of the 557 Pakistani families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A single mutation, p.R34X, causes deafness in 10 (1.8%) of the families.</Gene>
<Gene>Genotype analysis of p.R34X-linked markers indicates that it arose from a common founder.</Gene>

<Gene>We also detected p.R34X among normal control samples of African-American and northern European origins, raising the possibility that p.R34X and other mutations of TMC1 are prevalent contributors to the genetic load of deafness across a variety of populations and continents.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic basis for partial protection against alcoholism in Asians, heterozygous for the variant ALDH2*2 gene allele.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVES:</Gene>

<Gene>It has been well documented that although homozygosity of the variant aldehyde dehydrogenase-2 (ALDH2) gene allele, ALDH2*2, in Asians almost fully protects against alcoholism, the heterozygosity only affords a partial protection to varying degrees.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The full protection against alcoholism has been ascribed to the low-amount of alcohol hypersensitivity accompanied by a prolonged and large accumulation of acetaldehyde in blood (Peng et al.</Gene>
<Gene>Pharmacogenetics 1999; 9:463-476).</Gene>
<Gene>The physiological basis for the partial protection, however, remains unclear.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS: To address this question, we recruited a total of 32 adult Han Chinese men, matched by age, body-mass index, and nutritional state from a population base of 404 men.</Gene>

<Gene>The subjects were divided into 3 combinatorial genotypic groups of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and ALDH, that is, ALDH2*1/*1-ADH1B*1/*1-ADH1C*1/*1 (n=8), ALDH2*1/*1-ADH1B*2/*2-ADH1C*1/*1 (n=8), and ALDH2*1/*2-ADH1B*2/*2-ADH1C*1/*1 (n=16).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following a moderate dose of ethanol (0.5 g/kg body weight), blood ethanol/acetaldehyde/acetate concentrations, cardiac and extracranial/intracranial arterial hemodynamic parameters, as well as self-rated subjective sensations, were measured for 130 min. RESULTS: Heterozygotic ALDH2*1/*2 subjects were found to be strikingly responsive to the moderate amount of alcohol, as evidenced by the prominent cardiovascular effects as well as subjective perceptions of general discomfort for as long as 2 h following ingestion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ADH1B polymorphisms did not appear to correlate with the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic effects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that acetaldehyde, rather than ethanol or acetate, is primarily responsible for the observed alcohol sensitivity reactions and suggest that substantially lower accumulation of blood acetaldehyde in the heterozygotes significantly reduces the aversion reaction to low amounts of alcohol that permits other biological as well as environmental factors to facilitate drinking and the according risk for the disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Identification of rare variants in the hLIMD1 gene in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The hLIMD1 gene is located at chromosome 3p21 and was identified as a putative tumor suppressor gene using an elimination test assay.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chromosome 3p21 loci are frequently deleted in a number of cancers, including breast.</Gene>
<Gene>The 3p21.3 locus harbors a number of tumor suppressor candidates, including LIMD1, a member of the ZYXIN family of genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LIMD1 directly interacts with RB and is thought to play a role in suppressing tumor growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate whether mutations in the LIMD1 gene could potentially be involved in breast cancer, we used single-stranded conformation polymorphism analysis on DNA from 235 breast cancers and 95 controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We identified four novel coding region alterations, including two amino acid substitutions at positions 255 and 302.</Gene>
<Gene>The two remaining novel variants were found at amino acid positions 246 and 647 and encoded silent alterations.</Gene>
<Gene>The rare Ser255Arg variant was identified in only sporadic breast tumors (2/165 tumors).</Gene>
<Gene>Some ZYXIN proteins are phosphorylated by serine/threonine kinases, and the Ser255Arg change is located in a region phosphorylated on serine residues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, the data suggest that this variant may warrant further characterization.</Gene>
<Gene>Kidney failure in Townes-Brocks syndrome: an under recognized phenomenon?</Gene>
<Gene>Though uncommon, kidney malformations are described in several cases of Townes-Brocks syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>By contrast, kidney failure has been reported as the presenting feature of Townes-Brocks syndrome on only one occasion.</Gene>

<Gene>While the SALL1 gene, mutations of which result in the Townes-Brocks phenotype, is expressed in the developing kidney, the absence of other corroborative reports of kidney failure presenting in affected individuals suggests that the solitary observation of kidney failure is as likely due to chance as to causal association.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In now reporting a further instance of this association, we review the literature, demonstrating that several other instances of kidney failure are in fact known, despite an incomplete dataset.</Gene>

<Gene>These findings suggest that kidney failure may be a constituent element of the natural history of Townes-Brocks syndrome and raise the possible benefits of longitudinal survey for progressive kidney impairment in patients with this syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>Clinical and molecular characterization of Italian patients affected by Cohen syndrome.</Gene>

<Gene>Cohen syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with variability in the clinical manifestations, characterized by developmental delay, visual disability, facial dysmorphisms and intermittent neutropenia.</Gene>
<Gene>We described a cohort of 10 patients affected by Cohen syndrome from nine Italian families ranging from 5 to 52 years at assessment.</Gene>
<Gene>Characteristic age related facial changes were well documented.</Gene>
<Gene>Visual anomalies, namely retinopathy and myopia, were present in 9/10 patients (retinopathy in 9/10 and myopia in 8/10).</Gene>
<Gene>Truncal obesity has been described in all patients older than 6 years (8/8).</Gene>
<Gene>DNA samples from all patients were analyzed for mutations in COH1 by DHPLC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We detected 15 COH1 alterations most of them were truncating mutations, only one being a missense change.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Partial gene deletions have been found in two families.</Gene>
<Gene>Most mutations were private.</Gene>
<Gene>Two were already reported in the literature just once.</Gene>

<Gene>A single base deletion leading to p.T3708fs3769, never reported before, was found in three apparently unrelated families deriving from a restricted area of the Veneto's lowland, between Padova town and Tagliamento river, in heterozygous state.</Gene>
<Gene>Given the geographical conformation of this region, which is neither geographically or culturally isolated, a recent origin of the mutation could be hypothesized.</Gene>
<Gene>Regional analysis on the occurrence of oral clefts in South America.</Gene>

<Gene>The aim of this work was to search for unequal birth prevalence rates (BPRs) of cleft lip +/- cleft palate (CL/P), and cleft palate only (CPO), among different geographic areas in South America, and to analyze phenotypic characteristics and associated risk factors in each identified cluster.</Gene>

<Gene>Included were 5,128 CL/P cases, 1,745 CPO cases, and 3,712 controls (like-sexed, non-malformed liveborn infant, born immediately after a malformed one, in the same hospital), over 4,199,630 consecutive births.</Gene>

<Gene>They were ascertained between 1967 and 2004, in 190 maternity hospitals of the ECLAMC (Estudio Colaborativo Latinoamericano de Malformaciones Congenitas) network, in 102 cities of all 10 South American countries.</Gene>

<Gene>Non-predefined geographical areas with significantly unusual cleft BPRs were identified with Kulldorf and Nagarwalla's spatial scan statistic, employing number of cases and births, and exact location of each hospital.</Gene>
<Gene>Expected values were cleft BPRs registered for the entire ECLAMC hospital network.</Gene>
<Gene>Syndromic and non-syndromic clefts were considered for cluster analysis, and phenotypic characterization, while only non-syndromic for risk factor analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>Seven clusters for CL/P, and four for CPO, with unusual BPRs were identified.</Gene>
<Gene>CL/P cases in high BPR areas were more severe than elsewhere in the sample, similar to a previous ECLAMC report on microtia.</Gene>

<Gene>For CL/P, high BPR clusters were associated with high altitude above sea level, Amerindian ancestry, and low socioeconomic strata; low BPR clusters showed association with African Black ancestry.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Advanced maternal age, a recognized risk factor for CPO, was also associated with the only identified geographic cluster for CPO.</Gene>
<Gene>Evidence that common variation in NEDD9 is associated with susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) and Parkinson's disease (PD) are the most common neurodegenerative disorders and in both diseases susceptibility is known to be influenced by genes.</Gene>
<Gene>We set out to identify novel susceptibility genes for LOAD by performing a large scale, multi-tiered association study testing 4692 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNPs).</Gene>

<Gene>We identified a SNP within a putative transcription factor binding site in the NEDD9 gene (neural precursor cell expressed, developmentally down-regulated), that shows good evidence of association with disease risk in four out of five LOAD samples [N = 3521, P = 5.38x10(-6), odds ratio (OR) = 1.38 (1.20-1.59)] and in addition, we observed a similar pattern of association in two PD sample sets [N = 1464, P = 0.0145, OR =1.31 (1.05-1.62)].</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In exploring a potential mechanism for the association, we observed that expression of NEDD9 and APOE show a strong inverse correlation in the hippocampus of Alzheimer's cases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data implicate NEDD9 as a novel susceptibility gene for LOAD and possibly PD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Association between caffeine intake and risk of Parkinson's disease among fast and slow metabolizers.</Gene>
<Gene>INTRODUCTION: Cytochrome P450 1A2 (CYP 1A2) is responsible for more than 90% of caffeine clearance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A polymorphic variant of CYP1A2 (-163C>A) (rs762551) is associated with high CYP1A2 inducibility.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both caffeine and its main metabolite, paraxanthine, may be neuroprotective.</Gene>
<Gene>The association between caffeine intake and risk of Parkinson's disease (PD) in fast and slow caffeine metabolizers has not been compared.</Gene>
<Gene>OBJECTIVE:</Gene>
<Gene>In a case-control study, we analyzed the relationship between caffeine intake and risk of PD in both fast and slow caffeine metabolizers.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>All the study participants were recruited prospectively, and interviewed for information on the amount and duration of caffeine intake.</Gene>
<Gene>Genotyping of the CYP1A2 variant was carried out using the allelic discrimination method.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Out of 1000 participants who were initially screened, 886 consisting of 418 PD and 468 race, sex and age matched controls were included.</Gene>
<Gene>No evidence existed to suggest any association between CYP1A2 and the onset of PD (P=0.08).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A significant association was seen between caffeine intake and the onset of PD (P=2.01x10(-5)), with the odds ratio for moderate and high drinkers at 0.71 [95% confidence interval (CI): 0.50-1.00] and 0.47 (95% CI: 0.34-0.65), respectively against the low drinkers.</Gene>
<Gene>Multivariate analysis revealed no evidence of any interaction effects of caffeine with CYP1A2 (P=0.956).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>The association between caffeine intake and risk of PD was similarly observed in both fast and slow caffeine metabolizers, supporting experimental evidence in animal models that both caffeine and its major metabolite, paraxanthine, are neuroprotective.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutation analysis of CHRNA1, CHRNB1, CHRND, and RAPSN genes in multiple pterygium syndrome/fetal akinesia patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Multiple pterygium syndromes (MPS) comprise a group of multiple congenital anomaly disorders characterized by webbing (pterygia) of the neck, elbows, and/or knees and joint contractures (arthrogryposis).</Gene>
<Gene>MPS are phenotypically and genetically heterogeneous but are traditionally divided into prenatally lethal and nonlethal (Escobar) types.</Gene>

<Gene>Previously, we and others reported that recessive mutations in the embryonal acetylcholine receptor g subunit (CHRNG) can cause both lethal and nonlethal MPS, thus demonstrating that pterygia resulted from fetal akinesia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesized that mutations in acetylcholine receptor-related genes might also result in a MPS/fetal akinesia phenotype</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>and so we analyzed 15 cases of lethal MPS/fetal akinesia without CHRNG mutations for mutations in the CHRNA1, CHRNB1, CHRND, and rapsyn (RAPSN) genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>No CHRNA1, CHRNB1, or CHRND mutations were detected, but a homozygous RAPSN frameshift mutation, c.1177-1178delAA, was identified in a family with three children affected with lethal fetal akinesia sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously, RAPSN mutations have been reported in congenital myasthenia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Functional studies were consistent with the hypothesis that whereas incomplete loss of rapsyn function may cause congenital myasthenia, more severe loss of function can result in a lethal fetal akinesia phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Paternal deletion 6q24.3: a new congenital anomaly syndrome associated with intrauterine growth failure, early developmental delay and characteristic facial appearance.</Gene>
<Gene>A family with two consecutive nonsense mutations in BMPR1A causing juvenile polyposis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We describe a novel germline mutation of BMPR1A in a family with juvenile polyposis and colon cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This mutation consists of two consecutive substitutions (735-6 TG>AT) that cause two nonsense mutations (Y245X, G246X), inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, on one parental chromosome.</Gene>
<Gene>This mutation caused protein truncation, and represents a novel case of consecutive nonsense mutations in human disease.</Gene>
<Gene>The FH mutation database: an online database of fumarate hydratase mutations involved in the MCUL (HLRCC) tumor syndrome and congenital fumarase deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Fumarate hydratase (HGNC approved gene symbol - FH), also known as fumarase, is an enzyme of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, involved in fundamental cellular energy production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>First described by Zinn et al in 1986, deficiency of FH results in early onset, severe encephalopathy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In 2002, the Multiple Leiomyoma Consortium identified heterozygous germline mutations of FH in patients with multiple cutaneous and uterine leiomyomas, (MCUL: OMIM 150800).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In some families renal cell cancer also forms a component of the complex and as such has been described as hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC: OMIM 605839).</Gene>

<Gene>The identification of FH as a tumor suppressor was an unexpected finding and following the identification of subunits of succinate dehydrogenase in 2000 and 2001, was only the second description of the involvement of an enzyme of intermediary metabolism in tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DESCRIPTION:</Gene>

<Gene>The FH mutation database is a part of the TCA cycle gene mutation database (formerly the succinate dehydrogenase gene mutation database) and is based on the Leiden Open (source) Variation Database (LOVD) system.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The variants included in the database were derived from the published literature and annotated to conform to current mutation nomenclature.</Gene>
<Gene>The FH database applies HGVS nomenclature guidelines, and will assist researchers in applying these guidelines when directly submitting new sequence variants online.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Since the first molecular characterization of an FH mutation by Bourgeron et al in 1994, a series of reports of both FH deficiency patients and patients with MCUL/HLRRC have described 107 variants, of which 93 are thought to be pathogenic.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The most common type of mutation is missense (57%), followed by frameshifts & nonsense (27%), and diverse deletions, insertions and duplications.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we introduce an online database detailing all reported FH sequence variants.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The FH mutation database strives to systematically unify all current genetic knowledge of FH variants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We believe that this knowledge will assist clinical geneticists and treating physicians when advising patients and their families, will provide a rapid and convenient resource for research scientists, and may eventually assist in gaining novel insights into FH and its related clinical syndromes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic heterogeneity by comparative genomic hybridization in BRCAx breast cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The chromosomal changes in eight familial BRCAx breast cancers (i.e., negative for BRCA1 or BRCA2) were analyzed by comparative genomic hybridization (CGH) to investigate intratumor heterogeneity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was the first step in a study of most frequent chromosomal aberrations in BRCAx familial breast cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Laser microdissection analysis of paraffin tissue samples was followed by whole-genome amplification.</Gene>

<Gene>CGH was performed on DNA isolated from two to three different cell groups per case to detect any cytogenetic aberrations in important clones that might have been missed when analyzing DNA extracted from large numbers of cells.</Gene>
<Gene>The results were compared, to evaluate the influence of tumor heterogeneity on CGH, and the heterogeneity was confirmed comparing CGH with fluorescence in situ hybridization results.</Gene>

<Gene>Different chromosomal aberrations were detected between adjacent clones within the same section, which highlights the utility of microdissection in addressing the problem of heterogeneity in whole-genome studies.</Gene>
<Gene>Some chromosomal regions were more frequently altered in the eight BRCAx tumors; loss of 2q, 3p, 3q, 8p, 9p, and 15q and gains of 1p, 4p, 4q, 5p, 6q, 12q, and 19p were the most common.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies focusing on specific genes and sequences with more sensitive approaches, such as array-CGH, are warranted to confirm these findings.</Gene>
<Gene>The infevers autoinflammatory mutation online registry: update with new genes and functions.</Gene>

<Gene>Infevers (Internet Fevers; http://fmf.igh.cnrs.fr/ISSAID/infevers), a website dedicated to mutations responsible for hereditary autoinflammatory diseases, was created in 2002 and has continued to evolve.</Gene>
<Gene>This new version includes eight genes; six were already present: MEFV, MVK, TNFRSF1A, NLRP3, NOD2, PSTPIP1, and two are new, LPIN2 and NLRP7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Currently, Infevers contains over 540 sequence variants.</Gene>
<Gene>Several new database functions were recently instituted.</Gene>
<Gene>The website now accepts confidential data and complex alleles.</Gene>

<Gene>For each gene, a newly created menu offers: 1) a tabular list of the variants that can be sorted by several parameters; 2) a gene graph providing a schematic representation of the variants along the gene; 3) statistical analysis of the data according to the phenotype, alteration type, and location of the mutation in the gene; 4) the cDNA and gDNA sequences of each gene, showing the nucleotide changes along the sequence, with a color-based code highlighting the gene domains, the first ATG, and the termination codon; and 5) a "download" menu making all tables and figures available for the users, which, except for the gene graphs, are all automatically generated and updated upon submission of the variants.</Gene>

<Gene>Finally, the entire database was curated to comply with the HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC) and HGVS nomenclature guidelines, and wherever necessary, an informative note was provided.</Gene>

<Gene>Infevers has already proven useful for the scientific community with a mean number of visits per month of 200 in 2002 and 800 in 2007, and its new design will lead to a more comprehensive comparative analysis and interpretation of auto-inflammatory sequence variants.</Gene>
<Gene>CYP2E1 polymorphisms and gene-environment interactions in the risk of upper aerodigestive tract cancers among Indians.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>INTRODUCTION:</Gene>
<Gene>The CYP2E1 enzyme is responsible for the metabolic activation of several procarcinogens into reactive metabolites that result in carcinogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The genetic polymorphisms that modify these enzymatic activities may be associated with upper aerodigestive tract cancer risk.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>This hospital-based study evaluated CYP2E1*1B, CYP2E1*5B and CYP2E1*6 polymorphisms in 408 histopathologically confirmed cases and 220 population-based controls using PCR-RFLP methods.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>The multivariate logistic regression analyses demonstrated no significant differences between groups for all three polymorphisms when analyzed separately.</Gene>

<Gene>However, the gene-environment interactions analyses revealed significant interactions among tobacco smokers (11-20 pack years), 20-40 pack years and > 40 pack years), regular tobacco chewers and alcoholics carrying CYP2E1*1B mutant genotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Similarly, CYP2E1*6 polymorphisms resulted in significant interactions among tobacco smokers (> 40 pack years) and regular tobacco chewers on the multiplicative scale.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The significant gene-environment interactions observed for CYP2E1*1B and CYP2E1*6 polymorphic genotypes may confer a substantial risk for upper aerodigestive tract cancers among Indians.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in fibroblast cultures from patients with POLG1 mutations is a consequence of catalytic mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated clinical and cellular phenotypes of 24 children with mutations in the catalytic (alpha) subunit of the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) gamma polymerase (POLG1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Twenty-one had Alpers syndrome, the commonest severe POLG1 autosomal recessive phenotype, comprising hepatoencephalopathy and often mtDNA depletion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cellular mtDNA content reflected the genotype more closely than did clinical features.</Gene>
<Gene>Patients with tissue depletion of mtDNA all had at least one allele with either a missense mutation in a catalytic domain or a nonsense mutation.</Gene>
<Gene>Four out of 12 patients exhibited a progressive, mosaic pattern of mtDNA depletion in cultured fibroblasts.</Gene>
<Gene>All these patients had mutations in a catalytic domain in both POLG1 alleles, in either the polymerase or exonuclease domain or both.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The tissue mtDNA content of patients who had two linker mutations was normal, and their phenotypes the mildest.</Gene>
<Gene>Epilepsy and/or movement disorder were major features in all 21.</Gene>
<Gene>Previous studies have implicated replication stalling as a mechanism for mtDNA depletion.</Gene>
<Gene>The mosaic cellular depletion that we have demonstrated in cell cultures may be a manifestation of severe replication stalling.</Gene>
<Gene>One patient with a severe cellular and clinical phenotype was a compound heterozygote with POLG1 mutations in the polymerase and exonuclease domain intrans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This suggests that POLG1 requires both polymerase and 3'-5' exonuclease activity in the same molecule.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This is consistent with current functional models for eukaryotic DNA polymerases, which alternate between polymerizing and editing modes, as determined by competition between these two active sites for the 3' end of the DNA.</Gene>
<Gene>Identification of novel dyslexia candidate genes through the analysis of a chromosomal deletion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Dyslexia is the most common childhood learning disorder and it is a significantly heritable trait.</Gene>
<Gene>At least nine chromosomal loci have been linked to dyslexia, and additional susceptibility loci on other chromosomes have been suggested.</Gene>

<Gene>Within two of these loci, DYX1C1 (15q21) and ROBO1 (3p12) have recently been proposed as dyslexia candidate genes through the molecular analysis of translocation breakpoints in dyslexic individuals carrying balanced chromosomal translocations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, genetic association studies have indicated a cluster of five dyslexia candidate genes in another linkage region on chromosome 6p22, although there is currently no consensus about which of these five genes contributes to the genetic susceptibility for dyslexia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this article, we report the identification of four new dyslexia candidate genes (PCNT, DIP2A, S100B, and PRMT2) on chromosome region 21q22.3 by FISH and SNP microarray analyses of a very small deletion in this region, which cosegregates with dyslexia in a father and his three sons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Granulin mutations associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration and related disorders: an update.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the gene encoding granulin (HUGO gene symbol GRN, also referred to as progranulin, PGRN), located at chromosome 17q21, were recently linked to tau-negative ubiquitin-positive frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLDU).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Since then, 63 heterozygous mutations were identified in 163 families worldwide, all leading to loss of functional GRN, implicating a haploinsufficiency mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these mutations explained 5 to 10% of FTLD.</Gene>

<Gene>The high mutation frequency, however, might still be an underestimation because not all patient samples were examined for all types of loss-of-function mutations and because several variants, including missense mutations, have a yet uncertain pathogenic significance.</Gene>

<Gene>Although the complete phenotypic spectrum associated with GRN mutations is not yet fully characterized, it was shown that it is highly heterogeneous, suggesting the influence of modifying factors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A role of GRN in neuronal survival was suggested but the exact mechanism by which neurodegeneration and deposition of pathologic brain inclusions occur still has to be clarified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>LDLR promoter variant and exon 14 mutation on the same chromosome are associated with an unusually severe FH phenotype and treatment resistance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is the most common form of autosomal-dominant hypercholesterolemia, and is caused by mutations in the low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Heterozygous FH is characterized by elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and early-onset cardiovascular disease, whereas homozygous FH results in more severe LDL cholesterol elevation with death by 20 years of age.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We present here the case of an African-American female FH patient presenting with a myocardial infarction at the age of 48, recurrent angina pectoris and numerous coronary artery stents.</Gene>

<Gene>Her pretreated LDL cholesterol levels were more typical of a homozygous FH pattern and she was resistant to conventional lipid-lowering treatment, yet her other clinical parameters were not necessarily consistent with homozygous FH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic testing revealed two LDLR variants on the same chromosome: one a novel missense mutation in exon 14 (Cys681Gly) and the other a promoter variant (IVS1-217C>T) previously shown to result in increased LDLR transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Disease-associated PCSK9 or APOB mutations were not identified in this individual.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overall, her genetic and clinical profile suggests that enhanced expression of the mutant LDLR allele resulted in a severe phenotype with characteristics of both heterozygous and homozygous FH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Novel suppressors of alpha-synuclein toxicity identified using yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mechanism by which the Parkinson's disease-related protein alpha-synuclein (alpha-syn) causes neurodegeneration has not been elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To determine the genes that protect cells from alpha-syn, we used a genetic screen to identify suppressors of the super sensitivity of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing alpha-syn to killing by hydrogen peroxide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Forty genes in ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolism, protein biosynthesis, vesicle trafficking and the response to stress were identified.</Gene>

<Gene>Five of the forty genes--ENT3, IDP3, JEM1, ARG2 and HSP82--ranked highest in their ability to block alpha-syn-induced reactive oxygen species accumulation, and these five genes were characterized in more detail.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The deletion of any of these five genes enhanced the toxicity of alpha-syn as judged by growth defects compared with wild-type cells expressing alpha-syn, which indicates that these genes protect cells from alpha-syn.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Strikingly, four of the five genes are specific for alpha-syn in that they fail to protect cells from the toxicity of the two inherited mutants A30P or</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A53T. This finding suggests that alpha-syn causes toxicity to cells through a different pathway than these two inherited mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Lastly, overexpression of Ent3p, which is a clathrin adapter protein involved in protein transport between the Golgi and the vacuole, causes alpha-syn to redistribute from the plasma membrane into cytoplasmic vesicular structures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our interpretation is that Ent3p mediates the transport of alpha-syn to the vacuole for proteolytic degradation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A similar clathrin adaptor protein, epsinR, exists in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Polymorphism of the hepatic influx transporter organic anion transporting polypeptide 1B1 is associated with increased cholesterol synthesis rate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the influence of SLCO1B1 polymorphism on cholesterol synthesis and absorption during baseline, and as affected by statins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In a crossover study, 32 healthy volunteers with different SLCO1B1 genotypes ingested a single dose of fluvastatin, pravastatin, simvastatin, rosuvastatin, and atorvastatin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Plasma total cholesterol, and cholesterol synthesis and absorption markers were measured before statin administration and up to 12 h thereafter.</Gene>

<Gene>The mean fasting baseline plasma desmosterol to cholesterol ratio was 40% higher in participants with the SLCO1B1 c.521CC variant genotype than in those with the c.521TT genotype (P=0.043).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The genotype had no significant effect on cholesterol absorption markers.</Gene>
<Gene>All statins decreased lathosterol and avenasterol to cholesterol ratios, but no significant differences in the response existed between SLCO1B1 genotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, the low activity SLCO1B1 c.521CC genotype is associated with an increased cholesterol synthesis rate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The short-term effects of statins on cholesterol homeostasis were not associated with the SLCO1B1 polymorphism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Association of a null allele of SPRN with variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>No susceptibility genes have been identified in human prion disase, apart from the prion protein gene (PRNP).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gene SPRN, encodes Shadoo (Sho, shadow of prion protein) which has protein homology and possible functional links with the prion protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>A genetic screen was carried out of the open reading frame of SPRN by direct sequencing in 522 patients with prion disease, including 107 with variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD), and 861 healthy controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>A common coding variant of SPRN, two further single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and three rare insertion or deletion variants were found.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A single base-pair insertion at codon 46, predicted to cause a frameshift and potentially a novel protein, was found in two patients with vCJD but not in controls (p = 0.01).</Gene>
<Gene>Two linked SNPs, one in intron 1 and the other a missense variant at codon 7, were associated with risk of sporadic CJD (p = 0.009).</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION: These data justify the functional genetic characterisation of SPRN and support the involvement of Shadoo in prion pathobiology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Locus-specific databases and recommendations to strengthen their contribution to the classification of variants in cancer susceptibility genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Locus-specific databases (LSDBs) are curated collections of sequence variants in genes associated with disease.</Gene>
<Gene>LSDBs of cancer-related genes often serve as a critical resource to researchers, diagnostic laboratories, clinicians, and others in the cancer genetics community.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>LSDBs are poised to play an important role in disseminating clinical classification of variants.</Gene>
<Gene>The IARC Working Group on Unclassified Genetic Variants has proposed a new system of five classes of variants in cancer susceptibility genes.</Gene>
<Gene>However, standards are lacking for reporting and analyzing the multiple data types that assist in classifying variants.</Gene>

<Gene>By adhering to standards of transparency and consistency in the curation and annotation of data, LSDBs can be critical for organizing our understanding of how genetic variation relates to disease.</Gene>

<Gene>In this article we discuss how LSDBs can accomplish these goals, using existing databases for BRCA1, BRCA2, MSH2, MLH1, TP53, and CDKN2A to illustrate the progress and remaining challenges in this field.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We recommend that: 1) LSDBs should only report a conclusion related to pathogenicity if a consensus has been reached by an expert panel.</Gene>
<Gene>2) The system used to classify variants should be standardized.</Gene>
<Gene>The Working Group encourages use of the five class system described in this issue by Plon and colleagues.</Gene>
<Gene>3) Evidence that supports a conclusion should be reported in the database, including sources and criteria used for assignment.</Gene>
<Gene>4) Variants should only be classified as pathogenic if more than one type of evidence has been considered.</Gene>
<Gene>5) All instances of all variants should be recorded.</Gene>
<Gene>Association between polymorphisms in SLC30A8, HHEX, CDKN2A/B, IGF2BP2, FTO, WFS1, CDKAL1, KCNQ1 and type 2 diabetes in the Korean population.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>According to recent genome-wide association studies, a number of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are reported to be associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).</Gene>

<Gene>The aim of the present study was to investigate the association among the polymorphisms of SLC30A8, HHEX, CDKN2A/B, IGF2BP2, FTO, WFS1, CDKAL1 and KCNQ1 and the risk of T2DM in the Korean population.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study was based on a multicenter case-control study, including 908 patients with T2DM and 502 non-diabetic controls.</Gene>

<Gene>We genotyped rs13266634, rs1111875, rs10811661, rs4402960, rs8050136, rs734312, rs7754840 and rs2237892 and measured the body weight, body mass index and fasting plasma glucose in all patients and controls.</Gene>
<Gene>The strongest association was found in a variant of CDKAL1 [rs7754840, odds ratio (OR) = 1.77, 95% CI = 1.50-2.10, p = 5.0 x 10(-11)].</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The G allele of rs1111875 (OR = 1.43, 95% CI = 1.18-1.72, p = 1.8 x 10(-4)) in HHEX), the T allele of rs10811661 (OR = 1.47, 95% CI = 1.23-1.75, p = 2.1 x 10(-5)) in CDKN2A/B) and the C allele of rs2237892 (OR = 1.31, 95% CI = 1.10-1.56, p = 0.003) in KCNQ1 showed significant associations with T2DM. Rs13266634 (OR = 1.19, 95% CI = 1.00-1.42, p = 0.045) in SLC30A8 showed a nominal association with the risk of T2DM, whereas SNPs in IGF2BP2, FTO and WFS1 were not associated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, we have shown that SNPs in HHEX, CDKN2A/B, CDKAL1, KCNQ1 and SLC30A8 confer a risk of T2DM in the Korean population.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Clinical practice and genetic counseling for cystic fibrosis and CFTR-related disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator-related disorders encompass a disease spectrum from focal male reproductive tract involvement in congenital absence of the vas deferens to multiorgan involvement in classic cystic fibrosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The reproductive, gastrointestinal, and exocrine manifestations of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator deficiency are correlated with CFTR genotype, whereas the respiratory manifestations that are the main cause of morbidity and mortality in cystic fibrosis are less predictable.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular genetic testing of CFTR has led to new diagnostic strategies and will enable targeting of molecular therapies now in development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Older diagnostic methods that measure sweat chloride and nasal potential difference nonetheless remain important because of their sensitivity and specificity.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, the measurement of immunoreactive trypsinogen and the genotyping of CFTR alleles are key to newborn screening programs because of low cost.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The multiorgan nature of cystic fibrosis leads to a heavy burden of care, thus therapeutic regimens are tailored to the specific manifestations present in each patient.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The variability of cystic fibrosis lung disease and the variable expressivity of mild CFTR alleles complicate genetic counseling for this autosomal recessive disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Widespread implementation of newborn screening programs among populations with significant cystic fibrosis mutation carrier frequencies is expected to result in increasing demands on genetic counseling resources.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Breakpoint mapping and haplotype analysis of three reciprocal translocations identify a novel recurrent translocation in two unrelated families: t(4;11)(p16.2;p15.4).</Gene>
<Gene>Alterations of ROBO1/DUTT1 and ROBO2 loci in early dysplastic lesions of head and neck: clinical and prognostic implications.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of chromosomal 3p12.3 was suggested to be associated with dysplastic lesions of head and neck.</Gene>
<Gene>This region harbors two candidate tumor suppressors ROBO1/DUTT1, ROBO2 and two non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) located at intron 2 of ROBO1/DUTT1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Aim of this study is to understand the role of these genes in development of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.</Gene>
<Gene>A collection of 72 dysplastic lesions and 116 HNSCC samples and two oral cancer cell lines were analyzed for ROBO1/DUTT1 and ROBO2 deletion and promoter methylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ROBO1/DUTT1, ROBO2 and two ncRNAs mRNA expression were analyzed by Q-PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemical analysis of ROBO1/DUTT1 and ROBO2 was performed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Alterations of these genes were correlated with different clinicopathological parameters.</Gene>
<Gene>High frequency of molecular alterations (deletion/methylation) was seen in ROBO1/DUTT1 than ROBO2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In mild dysplastic lesions both of these genes showed high molecular alterations and remained more or less constant in subsequent stages.</Gene>
<Gene>Q-PCR analysis showed reduced expression of these genes and the two ncRNAs.</Gene>
<Gene>In vitro demethylation experiment by 5-aza-dC showed upregulation of ROBO1/DUTT1 and ROBO2 while the expression of the ncRNAs remained unchanged.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemical analysis of ROBO1/DUTT1 and ROBO2 showed concordance with their mRNA expression and molecular alterations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Poor patients' outcome was predicted in the cases with alteration of ROBO1/DUTT1 along with tobacco addiction and nodal involvement.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggests (a) ROBO1/DUTT1 and the ncRNAs are transcribed from different promoters, and (b) inactivation of ROBO1/DUTT1 could be used as molecular signature for early detection and prognosis of the head and neck cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Familial occurrence of schwannomas and malignant rhabdoid tumour associated with a duplication in SMARCB1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The role of germline and somatic SMARCB1 gene mutations in malignant rhabdoid tumour (MRT) predisposition is well known.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Germline SMARCB1 mutations have also recently been identified in a subset of individuals with schwannomatosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Surprisingly, MRT predisposition and schwannomatosis have never been reported to co-occur in a family.</Gene>
<Gene>The correlation between genotype and phenotype for mutations in SMARCB1 has not been determined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We have identified a germline 2631 bp duplication that includes exon 6 of SMARCB1 in a unique family with a four generation history of MRT predisposition and schwannomatosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This duplication segregates with disease in individuals affected with both conditions, linking MRT predisposition and schwannomatosis as components of the same syndrome in this family.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>The unique combination of tumours that result from the duplication described in this report may provide important clues about the mechanisms that influence the phenotype associated with a given SMARCB1 mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>P2RX7: A bipolar and unipolar disorder candidate susceptibility gene?</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The chromosomal region 12q24 has been previously implicated by linkage studies of both bipolar disorder and unipolar mood disorder and we have reported two pedigrees segregating both bipolar disorder and Darier's disease that show linkage across this region.</Gene>
<Gene>The gene P2RX7 is located in this chromosomal region and has been recently reported as a susceptibility gene for bipolar disorder and unipolar depression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The non-synonymous SNP rs2230912 (resulting in amino-acid polymorphism Q460R) showed the strongest association and has been postulated to be pathogenically relevant.</Gene>
<Gene>We have investigated this gene in a large UK case-control sample (bipolar I disorder N = 687, unipolar recurrent major depression N = 1,036, controls N = 1,204).</Gene>
<Gene>Neither rs2230912 nor any of 8 other SNPs genotyped across P2RX7 was found to be associated with mood disorder in general, nor specifically with bipolar or unipolar disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further, sequencing of our two chromosome 12-linked bipolar-Darier families showed no evidence of rare variants at P2RX7 that could explain the linkage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data do not provide support for rs2230912 or the other polymorphisms studied within the P2RX7 locus, being involved in susceptibility to mood disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Growth hormone dose in growth hormone-deficient adults is not associated with IGF-1 gene polymorphisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AIMS:</Gene>
<Gene>Several SNPs and a microsatellite cytosine-adenine repeat promoter polymorphism of the IGF-1 gene have been reported to be associated with circulating IGF-1 serum concentrations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Variance in IGF-1 concentrations due to genetic variations may affect different response to growth hormone (GH) treatment, resulting in different individually required GH-doses in GH-deficient patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of this study was to test if the IGF-1 gene polymorphisms are associated with the GH-dose of GH-deficient adults.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MATERIALS & METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>A total of nine tagging SNPs, five additionally selected SNPs and a cytosine-adenine repeat polymorphism were determined in 133 German adult patients (66 men, 67 women; mean age 45.4 years +/- 13.1 standard deviation; majority Caucasian) with GH-deficiency (GHD) of different origin, derived from the prospective Pfizer International Metabolic Study (KIMS) Pharmacogenetics Study.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Patients received GH-treatment for 12 months with finished dose-titration of GH and centralized IGF-1 measurements.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GH-dose after 1 year of treatment, IGF-1 concentrations, IGF-1-standard deviation score (SDS), the IGF-1:GH ratio and anthropometric data were analyzed by genotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>Except for rs1019731, which showed a significant difference of IGF-1-SDS by genotypes (p = 0.02), all polymorphisms showed no associations with the GH-doses, IGF-1 concentrations, IGF-1-SDS and IGF-1:GH ratio after adjusting for the confounding variables gender, age and BMI.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: IGF-1 gene polymorphisms were not associated with the responsiveness to exogenous GH in GHD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, genetic variations of the IGF-1 gene seem not to be major influencing factors of the GH-IGF-axis causing variable response to exogenous GH-treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Osteogenesis imperfecta type III with intracranial hemorrhage and brachydactyly associated with mutations in exon 49 of COL1A2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a heritable bone disorder characterized by fractures with minimal trauma.</Gene>
<Gene>Intracranial hemorrhage has been reported in a small number of OI patients.</Gene>

<Gene>Here we describe three patients, a boy (aged 15 years) and two girls (aged 17 and 7 years) with OI type III who suffered intracranial hemorrhage and in addition had brachydactyly and nail hypoplasia.</Gene>

<Gene>In all of these patients, OI was caused by glycine mutations affecting exon 49 of the COL1A2 gene, which codes for the most carboxy-terminal part of the triple-helical domain of the collagen type I alpha 2 chain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These observations suggest that mutations in this region of the collagen type I alpha 2 chain carry a high risk of abnormal limb development and intracranial bleeding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Quantitative PCR high-resolution melting (qPCR-HRM) curve analysis, a new approach to simultaneously screen point mutations and large rearrangements: application to MLH1 germline mutations in Lynch syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Several techniques have been developed to screen mismatch repair (MMR) genes for deleterious mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Until now, two different techniques were required to screen for both point mutations and large rearrangements.</Gene>

<Gene>For the first time, we propose a new approach, called "quantitative PCR (qPCR) high-resolution melting (HRM) curve analysis (qPCR-HRM)," which combines qPCR and HRM to obtain a rapid and cost-effective method suitable for testing a large series of samples.</Gene>
<Gene>We designed PCR amplicons to scan the MLH1 gene using qPCR HRM.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Seventy-six patients were fully scanned in replicate, including 14 wild-type patients and 62 patients with known mutations (57 point mutations and five rearrangements).</Gene>
<Gene>To validate the detected mutations, we used sequencing and/or hybridization on a dedicated MLH1 array-comparative genomic hybridization (array-CGH).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>All point mutations and rearrangements detected by denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography (dHPLC)+multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) were successfully detected by qPCR HRM.</Gene>
<Gene>Three large rearrangements were characterized with the dedicated MLH1 array-CGH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One variant was detected with qPCR HRM in a wild-type patient and was located within the reverse primer.</Gene>
<Gene>One variant was not detected with qPCR HRM or with dHPLC due to its proximity to a T-stretch.</Gene>

<Gene>With qPCR HRM, prescreening for point mutations and large rearrangements are performed in one tube and in one step with a single machine, without the need for any automated sequencer in the prescreening process.</Gene>
<Gene>In replicate, its reagent cost, sensitivity, and specificity are comparable to those of dHPLC+MLPA techniques.</Gene>
<Gene>However, qPCR HRM outperformed the other techniques in terms of its rapidity and amount of data provided.</Gene>
<Gene>SCA-LSVD: a repeat-oriented locus-specific variation database for genotype to phenotype correlations in spinocerebellar ataxias.</Gene>
<Gene>Repeat expansion has been implicated in 10 out of 17 candidate genes identified for autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxias (ADCAs)-commonly referred as spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs).</Gene>
<Gene>Though genetically distinct, the SCAs share a large number of features that confound their clinical classification.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, there is a difference in the prevalence and phenotypic expression of ataxias between different ethnic groups.</Gene>

<Gene>We have created a new SCA-locus-specific variation database (LSVD) that aims to catalog and integrate information on SCAs associated with trinucleotide repeat expansion (SCA1, SCA 2, SCA 3, SCA 6, SCA 7, SCA 8, SCA 12, SCA 17, Friedreich's ataxia [FRDA], and dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy [DRPLA]) from all over the world.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The database has been developed using the Leiden Open (source) Variation Database (LOVD) software (Leiden University Medical Center, Leiden, the Netherlands).</Gene>

<Gene>The database houses detailed information on clinical features, such as age and symptom at onset, mode of inheritance, and genotype information, pertaining to the SCA patients from more than 400 families across India.</Gene>
<Gene>All the compiled genotype data conforms to the HGVS Nomenclature guidelines.</Gene>

<Gene>This would be a very useful starting point for understanding the molecular correlates of phenotypes in ataxia-a multilocus disease in which related molecular mechanisms converge to overlapping phenotypes.</Gene>
<Gene>Systematic screening for polymorphisms within the UGT1A6 gene in three Chinese populations and function prediction through structural modeling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AIMS:</Gene>
<Gene>To date, there have been relatively few studies on the UGT1A6 gene in the Chinese population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study was designed to determine the allele frequencies and haplotypes of this gene in the population and predict the candidate functional mutations.</Gene>
<Gene>MATERIALS & METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We carried out the first systematic screening of polymorphisms of the gene in an SNP analysis involving 1074 Chinese subjects from three ethnic groups, namely Han, Dong and She, using direct sequencing.</Gene>
<Gene>We identified the putative substrate binding pocket using a homology-modeled structure and produced a practical model for predicting the function of polymorphisms in UGT1A6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>A total of six SNPs and 10 mutations were detected including nine known and seven novel ones.</Gene>
<Gene>The novel mutations were 73G>A (V25I), 89T></Gene>
<Gene>In addition, we detected, for the first time in the Chinese population, SNPs 105C>T, 627G>T as well as mutations 308C>A (S103X), IVS2+15T>C and 1088C>T (P363L).</Gene>

<Gene>Strong linkage disequilibrium was observed among 19T>G, 315A>G, 541A>G and 552A>C. There were seven haplotypes whose frequencies were more than 0.01 in one or more of the three ethnic groups.</Gene>
<Gene>P363L in the C-terminal domain might weaken the binding of cofactor UDPGA to the domain and induce a poor metabolism genotype of UGT1A6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>Our study suggests that genetic polymorphisms in UGT1A6 may contribute to interindividual and intra-ethnic differences.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The results should prove helpful in the development of pharmacogenomics in China.</Gene>
<Gene>Vascular endothelial growth factor gene polymorphisms as prognostic markers for ocular manifestations in pseudoxanthoma elasticum.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) is a heritable disorder affecting the skin, eyes and cardiovascular system.</Gene>
<Gene>It is caused by mutations in the ABCC6 gene and its clinical picture is highly variable.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PXE often leads to severe visual impairment due to the development of choroidal neovascularisation (CNV).</Gene>
<Gene>CNV in PXE-associated retinopathy is believed to be mediated by the action of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The objective of the present study was to evaluate a possible impact of variations in the VEGFA gene on ocular manifestations of PXE.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>For this purpose, we evaluated the distribution of 10 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the promoter and coding region of the VEGFA gene in DNA samples from 163 German patients affected by PXE and in 163 healthy control subjects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Haplotype analysis of SNPs c.-1540A>C, c.-460C>T, c.-152G></Gene>
<Gene>A, c.405C>G, c.674C>T, c.1032C>T, c.4618C>T and c.5092C></Gene>
<Gene>A revealed that the haplotype CTGGCCCC was associated with PXE (OR 2.05, 95% CI 1.33-3.15, P(corrected) = 0.01).</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, five SNPs showed significant association with severe retinopathy.</Gene>
<Gene>The most significant single SNP association was c.-460C>T (OR 3.83, 95% CI 2.01-7.31, P(corrected) = 0.0003).</Gene>
<Gene>Logistic regression analysis identified the c.-460T and the c.674C alleles as independent risk factors for development of severe retinopathy.</Gene>
<Gene>Our findings suggest an involvement of VEGF in the pathogenesis of ocular PXE manifestations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF gene polymorphisms might prove useful as prognostic markers for the development of PXE-associated retinopathy and permit earlier therapeutic intervention in order to prevent loss of central vision, one of the most devastating consequences of this disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Hypomorphic mutations in meckelin (MKS3/TMEM67) cause nephronophthisis with liver fibrosis (NPHP11).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Nephronophthisis (NPHP), a rare recessive cystic kidney disease, is the most frequent genetic cause of chronic renal failure in children and young adults.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations in nine genes (NPHP1-9) have been identified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NPHP can be associated with retinal degeneration (Senior-Loken syndrome), brainstem and cerebellar anomalies (Joubert syndrome), or liver fibrosis.</Gene>

<Gene>METHODS: To identify a causative gene for the subset of patients with associated liver fibrosis, the authors performed a genome wide linkage search in a consanguineous family with three affected patients using 50K SNP microarrays and homozygosity mapping.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The authors obtained a significant maximum parametric LOD (logarithm of odds) score of Z(max) = 3.72 on chromosome 8q22 and identified a homozygous missense mutation in the gene MKS3/TMEM67.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When examining a worldwide cohort of 62 independent patients with NPHP and associated liver fibrosis we identified altogether four novel mutations (p.W290L, p.C615R, p.G821S, and p.G821R) in five of them.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations of MKS3/TMEM67, found recently in Meckel-Gruber syndrome (MKS) type 3 and Joubert syndrome (JBTS) type 6, are predominantly truncating mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the mutations detected here in patients with NPHP and associated liver fibrosis are exclusively missense mutations.</Gene>
<Gene>This suggests that they may represent hypomorphic alleles, leading to a milder phenotype compared with the more severe MKS or JBTS phenotype.</Gene>

<Gene>Additionally, mutation analysis for MKS3/TMEM67 in 120 patients with JBTS yielded seven different (four novel) mutations in five patients, four of whom also presented with congenital liver fibrosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: Hypomorphic MKS3/TMEM67 mutations cause NPHP with liver fibrosis (NPHP11).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first report of MKS3 mutations in patients with no vermian agenesis and without neurological signs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus NPHP, JBTS, and MKS represent allelic disorders.</Gene>
<Gene>The role of the COMT Val(158)Met polymorphism in the phenotypic expression of obsessive-compulsive disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is characterized by the presence of obsessions and compulsions, and shows considerable phenotypic variability.</Gene>
<Gene>Family and twin studies have indicated a genetic component in the etiology of OCD, and the catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) gene is an important candidate gene for OCD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study investigates the influence of the functional COMT Val158Met polymorphism on the phenotypic expression of OCD, using an item-level factor-analytic approach in a large sample.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The COMT Val158Met variant was genotyped in 373 patients and 462 controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It was tested whether there was an association between the COMT Val158Met polymorphism and OCD or dimensional phenotypes such as YBOCS severity score, age of onset of obsessive-compulsive symptoms and six symptom dimensions recently found in a large item-level factor-analytic study</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>[Katerberg et al., submitted].</Gene>
<Gene>We further investigated possible sex-specific associations between the COMT Val158Met polymorphism and OCD or dimensional phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There was a trend for an association of the COMT 158Met allele with OCD in males, and an interaction between the COMT Val158Met genotype and sex on the somatic and sensory phenomena symptom dimension, with females showing lower scores.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, a dimensional approach seems fruitful in detecting genes of importance for OCD.</Gene>
<Gene>UVB radiation induces human lens epithelial cell migration via NADPH oxidase-mediated generation of reactive oxygen species and up-regulation of matrix metalloproteinases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ultraviolet (UV) radiation is one of the important cataract risk factors.</Gene>
<Gene>The migration of human lens epithelial cells (HLECs) plays a crucial role in the remodeling of lens capsule and cataract formation.</Gene>
<Gene>The purpose of the present study was to investigate the molecular mechanisms of UV-induced lens cell migration.</Gene>
<Gene>We found that UVB radiation induces cell migration in cultured human lens epithelial cells.</Gene>

<Gene>Further, we observed that UVB radiation induces NADPH oxidase activity and ROS generation which are inhibited by NADPH oxidase inhibitor diphenylene iodonium or DPI and antioxidant epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, DPI and EGCG also block UVB irradiation-induced MMP-2, and -9 activity and expression and nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB. Collectively, our data suggest that NADPH oxidase may be a major source for the UVB-induced ROS generation, and it plays an essential role in the activation of NF-kappaB, which is involved in the activities of MMP-2 and MMP-9 and cell migration induced by UVB in HELCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Understanding the cell signaling pathways may constitute potential therapeutic targets in for UVB-induced cataract.</Gene>
<Gene>A genome-wide in vitro bacterial-infection screen reveals human variation in the host response associated with inflammatory disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Recent progress in cataloguing common genetic variation has made possible genome-wide studies that are beginning to elucidate the causes and consequences of our genetic differences.</Gene>

<Gene>Approaches that provide a mechanistic understanding of how genetic variants function to alter disease susceptibility and why they were substrates of natural selection would complement other approaches to human-genome analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we use a novel cell-based screen of bacterial infection to identify human variation in Salmonella-induced cell death.</Gene>
<Gene>A loss-of-function allele of CARD8, a reported inhibitor of the proinflammatory protease caspase-1, was associated with increased cell death in vitro (p = 0.013).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The validity of this association was demonstrated through overexpression of alternative alleles and RNA interference in cells of varying genotype.</Gene>
